DOC.HEAD: Man Gets Long Prison Sentence For ``Date Rape'' Incidents
DOC.TEXT: A man convicted in three ``date rapes'' involving three women he worked with at a restaurant was sentenced Tuesday to up to 53 years in prison by a state judge who labeled him a ``sexual predator.'' Albany County Judge W. Thomas Keegan sentenced Kenneth Smyers, 28, of Menands to 17 2-3 years to 53 years. Smyers was convicted Dec. 19 of one count each of rape and sexual abuse and two counts of sodomy. Before sentencing, Smyers proclaimed his innocence and asked why, if he had committed such crimes, it had taken the women involved so long to come forward and make complaints to authorities. Five women, all co-workers at the Albany-area restaurant, testified that Smyers attacked them, but some admitted they didn't tell authorities until several months later. The jury acquitted Smyers on one count each of rape and attempted sexual abuse in attacks on two of the women, and of attempted rape on the woman he was convicted of sexually abusing. Assistant District Attorney Veronica Dumas, who prosecuted Smyers, said the stiff sentence sends a signal that ``date rape'' is a crime that won't be tolerated in the county. ``He was convicted of four violent felonies and that sentence projects what those crimes are,'' she said. The incidents took place between October 1987 and July 1988, prosecutors said. According to testimony at Smyers' trial, the attacks occurred under differing circumstances. One woman said she voluntarily had sex with Smyers, but said a few days later he showed up at her apartment and forced himself on her over her objections. Another woman said she allowed Smyers to sleep on her couch during a snowstorm, but ended up having to fight him off. He was convicted of sexual abuse in that incident. Several of the women said they continued to work and socialize with Smyers after the incidents. Smyers' attorney, Stephen Coffey, said he would appeal the conviction. Coffey said that Smyers had a legitimate argument when he asked why it took so long for the women he's accused of attacking to come forward. ``Where were these women all this time? ... Why weren't they saying anything,'' he asked. ``They were educated women. Why was it they were working with him and associating with him, and with each other, and not coming forward?''

DOC.HEAD: Suspects in Computer Tampering Case Surrender
With AM-Computer Worm
DOC.TEXT: Two men accused of conspiring to break into an Army computer network and the phone system surrendered Tuesday in federal court, but the man the government says was the ringleader remained at large. Silicon Valley computer experts Mark K. Lottor, 25, and Robert E. Gilligan, 31, turned themselves over to authorities before U.S. District Court Magistrate Patricia Trumbull. Lottor and Gilligan entered innocent pleas and were released on $100,000 bond each. They are to return to court next week. Lottor faces five courts and Gilligan six in the government's 19-count indictment alleging a scheme to steal military secrets and phone numbers from the FBI investigation of former Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos. Authorities were still searching Tuesday for 24-year-old Kevin L. Poulsen, who is charged in 16 counts. Poulsen faces up to 37 years in prison if convicted. The other two suspects face 20 years each if found guilty of all charges. Lottor works for SRI International and Gilligan works for Sun Microsystems of Mountain View. Poulsen, a former SRI worker who is believed to have fled to Los Angeles after leaving a job with Sun, was an unindicted co-conspirator in the 1984 computer break-in case at the University of California at Los Angeles. Poulsen's friend, hacker Ron Austin, was convicted on charges related to the break-in. Authorities said Poulsen used the computer handle ``Dark Dante'' at the time. Federal officials contend the latest computer tampering began in 1985 and started to fall apart in February 1988 when police found telephone equipment belonging to Pacific Bell in a storage locker rented by Poulsen. ``As far as techniques, you can see this started out as a burglary,'' said FBI Agent William Smith. ``That's what we have: burglars who came upon equipment that allowed them to go beyond the common crime of burglary.''

DOC.HEAD: Oat Bran Craze May Have Peaked, Analysts Say
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Consumers weary of oat bran probably won't go back to bacon and eggs for breakfast, but they may be looking for alternatives now that a study has cast doubt on oat bran's cure-all image. ``Oat bran was a fad anyway, and I think the study will be the catalyst for the gradual reduction in sales,'' said Ron Saba, a food industry analyst with the Ohio Co., an investment firm. Saba said he thought some people would stick with oat bran. ``But for some people it's going to give them an excuse to trade in those oat bran muffins for Twinkies,'' he said. The New England Journal of Medicine on Thursday published results of a study that said eating oat bran had no more effect than other grains on a person's cholesterol level. It said any beneficial effect appeared to come from cereals displacing fatty foods in the diet. It contradicts previous studies that found oat bran was able to interfere with fat absorption and lower cholesterol, thereby lowering the chance for heart disease. Not everyone was certain the report would shake the confidence of health-conscious consumers. ``Maybe it takes some of fiery brilliance out of the oat bran craze ... but I don't know if we'll see any immediate change in consumer demand,'' said Bonnie Rivers, an analyst with Salomon Brothers Inc. ``I don't think consumers are going to go back to eating bacon and eggs for breakfast.'' For some consumers who've grown tired of oat bran in everything from pretzels and tortilla chips to doughnuts and beer, the study is just what they wanted to hear. ``I started eating oat bran for breakfast every day about a year ago after all the hoopla,'' said Pat Edwards, who was choosing among the cereals in a Grand Rapids supermarket Thursday night. ``Quite frankly, I was never too crazy about it. This is just the excuse I was looking for to try something else.'' ``That's just human nature,'' responded Quaker Oats Co. spokesman Ron Bottrell. ``People like variety. And we've never positioned oat bran as a magic bullet or the one food people had to eat to see a reduction in their cholesterol.'' However, Quaker, which saw sales of Oat Bran Original Hot Cereal go from 1 million pounds in all of 1987 to 2 million pounds per month in 1989, has criticized the study, saying that its sample was too small _ 20 volunteers _ and didn't reflect the general population. ``We don't feel like this one study can negate the 25 years of research that preceded it,'' said Quaker spokeswoman Theresa Herlevsen. ``This is not going to affect our marketing strategies at all.'' In 1986, Quaker spent a couple of million dollars a year advertising its oat bran cereal. By 1989, it was spending $50 million on its hot cereal products, much of which was spent on oat bran promotion, Herlevsen said. Analysts say oat bran products have been the fastest growing segment of the $6.5 billion cereal industry. In Battle Creek, a spokeswoman for Kellogg Co., which makes three ready-to-eat oat bran cereals _ two of which were introduced in the last two years _ also said the study will not affect marketing strategies. ``We don't make health claims on our cereal,'' said spokeswoman Nancy Roach. ``We've always promoted our products as being part of a balanced diet and we will continue to do so.'' Analysts say the study may prompt some companies to quit selling fringe oat-bran products, such as potato chips, and may stifle the introduction of such new products. Last year, 218 products containing oat bran were introduced, according to Gorman's New Product News, a Chicago newsletter. ``Things have gotten carried away with it being promoted almost like a drug,'' said Bob Bernstein, an analyst with Edward D. Jones & Co. ``It almost got to be that oat bran was the be-all and end-all cure-all. ... People will always looking for the easy way out.'' Other food companies called attention to the fact that the study didn't dispute any effects of soluble fiber found in other foods such as fruits, vegetables, beans and brown rice. But a recent study at the University of Texas was unable to duplicate three other studies which found rice bran could affect cholesterol levels. The Rice Council of America, which paid for the study, called the results inconclusive.

DOC.HEAD: Hawaiians Vote on What Constitutes a `Native'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
Eds: Kaulukukui is pronounced kah-OO-loo-koo-KOO-ee. OHA is pronounced OH-ha.
DOC.TEXT: When Thomas Kaulukukui tells his grandchildren of their ancestors who populated these islands and shares traditions passed through generations of his family, he can't help but think they are as Hawaiian as he. In a world that prizes definitions, however, some do not. Kaulukukui is one-half Hawaiian, his three children are one-quarter and his four grandchildren one-eighth. Under Hawaii law, only those with 50 percent or more Hawaiian blood are considered ``native'' Hawaiians. Others are termed Hawaiians. ``My grandchildren ask, `Am I Hawaiian or am I not?' What can I tell them?'' Kaulukukui said. The problem is especially troubling for Kaulukukui because he is chairman of the Office of Hawaiian Affairs, an agency established by the state to benefit Hawaiians _ those considered natives as well as those with any amount of native blood. By law, some OHA services are available only to those with 50 percent or more of Hawaiian blood. Realizing the number of such people will continue shrinking because of intermarriage, OHA is making this distinction the subject of a non-binding referendum, with Thursday the last day for mailing back ballots. OHA is asking descendants of these islands' first inhabitants whether all those with Hawaiian blood should be termed native Hawaiians and thus entitled to all OHA services. Federal programs define native Hawaiian as those with any amount of Hawaiian blood, Kaulukukui said. Although no precise figure is available, it is estimated that 200,000 of Hawaii's 1 million residents have at least some Hawaiian blood. As many as 60,000 of those have at least 50 percent Hawaiian blood. OHA receives money from the state and from income derived from trust lands turned over to Hawaii by the federal government upon statehood in 1959. The two sources each provide roughly half OHA's $2.5 million yearly revenue, Kaulukukui said. Only those with 50 percent or more Hawaiian blood are entitled to services funded by the land proceeds, but all Hawaiians may receive state-funded benefits. ``We are all one family. We shouldn't have this wedge between us,'' said State Sen. Mike Crozier, a supporter of dropping the two-tiered definition of Hawaiian. He is one-quarter Hawaiian. OHA mailed 63,000 ballots to voters registered with the agency _ including those with all levels of Hawaiian blood. The ballot asks whether OHA voters want to change the definition of native Hawaiian to ``all descendants of the indigenous people inhabiting the Hawaiian Islands prior to 1778,'' when the first outsider, Capt. James Cook of Great Britain, arrived. OHA will present the referendum results to the Democrat-controlled Legislature, where a bill to change the state Constitution has a good chance of passing if the survey favors dropping the two-tiered definition of native Hawaiian. Such a measure would require a two-thirds vote of both houses and ratification by the voters, Crozier said. OHA, a semi-autonomous agency with a board of trustees elected by voters of Hawaiian ancestry, serves an advocacy role for all Hawaiians and provides money for educational, legal and other programs. Kaulukukui said OHA programs should not be confused with the Hawaiian Homes Act, passed by Congress in 1920. It allows those with 50 percent or more Hawaiian blood to lease plots of government land for homesteads. Only Congress can change that blood requirement, Kaulukukui said. Kamaki Kanahele, president of Hawaiian Homesteaders, a state council representing Hawaiians, disagrees with Kaulukukui and is urging his group's 27,000 members to vote against the proposal. Kanahele said he fears Congress will take a change in the state Constitution as a signal to change the blood requirement for the homelands program. Since the homelands program was created, some 6,000 homestead leases have been awarded and there are about 19,000 names on the waiting list. Under state law, OHA is entitled to a 20 percent share of proceeds from leases on more than a million acres former crown and government land from the time before the overthrow of the Hawaiian monarchy. Kaulukukui said he hopes enlarging OHA's scope of responsibilities will persuade state leaders to give the agency a greater share of the land trust proceeds.

DOC.HEAD: Former Bank Regulator Blasts Cranston
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Sen Alan Cranston's attempts to blame former banking regulator Edwin J. Gray for the Lincoln Savings & Loan Association debacle were met with a harsh 4,000-word letter of reply. Cranston, who is seeking re-election, is a ``desperate, panic-stricken office holder,'' Gray wrote Monday. ``The fact that it happened partially on my watch is as much a reflection on your failure, yes your unwillingness, to help me obtain the reforms I sent up to the Hill,'' he wrote. ``Never once, Sen. Cranston, did you lift a finger to help me with the statutory reforms. ... Your big-giver friends didn't like me or my regulations.'' Cranston spokesman Kam Kuwata responded, ``Gray claimed he could do nothing, but he only claims that because he did nothing. He makes Pinnochio look like a piker when it comes to lying about his involvement in this scandal.'' Gray headed the Federal Home Loan Bank Board when San Francisco-based federal regulators recommended a takeover of Irvine-based Lincoln on May 1, 1987, three weeks after Cranston and four other senators held their second private meeting with regulators. Gray left office on June 30, 1987. Cranston, who continues to blame Gray for investors' losses, said Monday he would introduce legislation allowing the government to bail out consumers who lost $200 million on junk bonds purchased at Lincoln branches. He said that even though it was technically legal, regulators should never have allowed Lincoln to sell the unsecured bonds because investors could easily be led to believe they were federally insured. Cranston spoke at the latest in a series of news conferences intended to deflect blame aimed at him for the failure of Lincoln. The collapse is expected to cost taxpayers more than $2 billion, aside from any efforts to repay the junk bond holders. Cranston, the Senate majority whip, is one of five senators under investigation by the Senate Ethics Committee for intervening with regulators on behalf of Lincoln and Charles H. Keating Jr., chief of American Continental Corp. of Phoenix, Lincoln's parent. Keating and his family contributed $1.3 million to the senators and their causes. By focusing on the bondholders, Cranston hopes to disarm one of the most personally damaging allegations against him: bondholders' testimony that his intervention for Keating made him partly responsible for their losses.

DOC.HEAD: One Man Killed In Confrontation Between Deputies, Muslims
DOC.TEXT: A traffic stop escalated into gunfire and death for a young man Tuesday in a confrontation between sheriff's deputies and several Black Muslims, the second such incident this month. The two deputies who made the early-morning stop claimed they were surrounded by several men, one of whom disarmed an officer. That deputy pulled a backup weapon and fired several rounds, striking and killing Oliver Beasley, 27, who lived in an area west of suburban Compton, said sheriff's Deputy Chris Wahla. The two deputies ``were in a fight for their lives,'' said sheriff's Sgt. Steve Van Herpe. The sergeant said deputies described several of the assailants as members of the Nation of Islam religious group. Neither deputy was hurt. Authorities did not identify them. It was the second confrontation this month between Black Muslims and law enforcement officers, both sparked by traffic stops. Residents of the neighborhood complained Tuesday that deputies order black people to get out of their cars and lay spread-eagle on the street or stretch over the hood of their car for even routine stops, a demand they contend is not made of whites. While deputies conducted their investigation, several people shouted angrily at them, claiming some of the arrested men had been beaten while handcuffed. A crowd was ordered to disperse at one point. A man identified as David Hartley, 18, of Culver City, was wounded and later booked for attempted murder. He was being treated in the jail ward of County-USC Medical Center, listed in satisfactory condition with a shoulder wound. Five other men, ranging in age from 15 to 35, also were arrested and booked for investigation of attempted murder following a night-long search by of the neighborhood by deputies, including a SWAT team. The gun allegedly taken from the deputy was found on the stairwell of an apartment building where three of the men were arrested, authorities said. A man who answered a telephone call to Nation of Islam headquarters in Los Angeles on Tuesday said, ``No one will be making any comment ... until we've made a full investigation.'' The man said the organization would hold a news conference in a day or two. The fatal fight came a day after Los Angeles Police Department officials and Nation of Islam leaders met to discuss easing tense relations with law enforcement following a Jan. 3 street brawl between police and Muslims that followed a traffic stop. Two dozen police officers and 13 Nation of Islam members were involved in a melee Jan. 3 in the southwest side of the city. There were injuries on both sides. Police claim one of the Muslims interfered with the arrest process, then attacked officers when they tried to arrest him. Companions ran out of cars and joined the fray. Six Muslims attended Monday's meeting. ``I've been with the nation for 32 years and I know of no other time when Muslims and police have sat down and talked on this level,'' said Wali Muhammad, head of the western branch of the Fruit of Islam, the Nation of Islam's security detail. The Police Department is conducting an internal investigation of allegations that officers started the brawl.

DOC.HEAD: Staff Sergeant Pleads Guilty To Stealing Military Property
DOC.TEXT: A military judge on Tuesday sentenced an Air Force maintenance worker to seven years in prison and a dishonorable discharge for stealing and selling military equipment to undercover FBI agents. Staff Sgt. Chris L. London, Enfield, Conn., pleaded guilty to 20 charges during a court-martial Monday. London said he stole the $67,432 worth of equipment because he needed money to pay bills and child support. ``It's not an excuse,'' he told Air Force Judge Lt. Col. Linda Carter. ``I'm sorry that it ever happened. I'm glad the government property has been returned.'' London asked the judge for forgiveness and pleaded for a lenient sentence, saying lengthy confinement would prevent him from being a good father to his son. Carter accepted the guilty pleas and said she wanted to view a videotape showing transactions between London and the FBI agents before deciding on a sentence. She deliberated about one hour Tuesday and returned with her decision that evening. London, who had faced up to 171 years in military prison, dishonorable discharge and loss of benefits, showed no emotion when Carter read the sentence. He was charged in October as a result of Operation Punchout, a two-year FBI sting investigation. The stolen items included 42 automatic life preserver units, pilot helmets, gloves, chin straps, camouflage clothing and an insect head net. They were taken from Hill Air Force Base between 1986 and 1989 and sold to a mock military surplus store set up by the FBI in nearby Roy, officials said. Government attorney Brian Newby of Travis Air Force Base in California told the judge earlier that London deserved to be put in prison for 11 years and receive a dishonorable discharge because he disgraced the American flag by ``lining his pockets with money.'' ``We aim high ... we expect the best,'' Newby said. ``We demand the best.'' However, defense attorney Capt. George Horvath of Hill Air Force Base said London was remorseful and that financial strains led him to commit ``desperate acts.'' ``The property has been returned intact,'' he said. ``Allow him the chance to learn and grow from this.'' He recommended a two-year jail sentence. London, 26, was among nearly three dozen military and civilian personnel charged in the probe, which culminated last July in the theft of two F-16 jet engines from the base. Two Air Force security guards admitted stealing the engines and will be sentenced Friday in U.S. District Court. When the sting was first announced last summer, U.S. Attorney Dee Benson said it could eventually result in indictments gainst more than 100 people. The investigation targeted military thefts from bases in the West and Southwest.

DOC.HEAD: Colombia's Most Wanted Drug Trafficker Bids Anew for Peace
DOC.TEXT: The leader of Colombia's notorious Medellin cocaine cartel has written to a Bogota newspaper saying he wants to set them straight on a story: he still runs the cartel and his friends haven't deserted him. ``My freedom is the best proof I have to show the country that the people are not selling me out and that my friends are neither abandoning nor betraying me,'' Pablo Escobar wrote. An article Monday in El Tiempo quoted security force officials as saying Escobar's principal allies were abandoning him as police and the military moved in, pursuing an all-out drug war by the government of President Virgilio Barco. Escobar wrote on Tuesday to El Tiempo publisher Hernando Santos Castillo, saying he was still in control of the most powerful drug operation in Colombia and that it stood together in its decision to seek peace with the government. The letter carried Escobar's signature and bore what was apparently the imprint of his index finger, to prove the document was genuine. The document was also sent to other news media. Escobar, who heads the country's most wanted list with a $500,000 dead-or-alive price on his head, also said the Medellin cartel would keep up its war against the rival Cali cartel, based to the south of Medellin. He said Jorge Valasquez, a member of the Cali cartel, gave information to police that resulted in their killing of Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha in a shootout on Dec. 15. Rodriguez Gacha was Escobar's close associate and a man considered the most violent of the Medellin drug lords. Escobar said the entire cartel was behind a peace offer made by its leaders last week to Barco's government, asking for ``constitutional and legal guarantees'' in exchange for the cartel's agreeing to give up the cocaine business, stop its campaign of violence and free its hostages. The cartel is reckoned to still hold 16 people, after freeing five recently. Escobar's letter indicated the cartel still will demand an end to extradition, however. The Barco government has packed off 13 trafficking suspects to the United States since it intensified its drug war in August. The drug traffickers replied with a terror campaign that has claimed the lives of 209 people and included the bombing a Colombian airliner. Escobar indicated there was no disagreement within the cartel over the peace offer, which the government has refused to accept, saying drug bosses who surrender will have to answer in court for their crimes. His letter read, ``If the Colombian government someday decides to fight for the peace of our nation in a sovereign and courageous way, it will find an interminable list of extradition candidates, drug traffickers, hired assassins and paramilitary forces that want to join it in the process.'' Military forces said on Tuesday they were taking whatever measures were necessary to protect President Bush from Escobar and other drug barons when Bush attends an antidrug summit in Cartagena on Feb. 15. U.S. authorities have reportedly said traffickers are preparing an attempt on Bush's life in the five hours he will be in Cartagena. Bush, Barco, President Jaime Paz Zamora of Bolivia and possibly President Alan Garcia of Peru are to discuss cooperation in the fight against drugs. Garcia's participation was not certain. He said he would not attend while U.S. invasion troops remained in Panama.

DOC.HEAD: NBC's `Grand' Soars in Premiere and `Dear John' Falls
DOC.TEXT: It was a sweet ratings tune for the premiere of NBC's ``Grand.'' But ``Dear John,'' which was moved to make room for the comedy about a town that makes pianos, may feel it's gotten the proverbial goodbye letter. ``Grand'' made its debut in fifth place last week. It was broadcast in the Thursday night slot behind NBC's ``Cheers,' which finished No. 1. ``Grand's'' rating was 21.4, higher than ``Dear John'' had been getting. ``Dear John,'' which moved to Wednesday, fell to 33rd place from ninth the previous week, according to the A.C. Nielsen Co. Although its ratings dropped from 19.8 to 14.1, it was two points ahead of the show it displaced. ``My Two Dads'' was moved to Sunday in the shuffle. For the week, NBC finished first with an average of 14.6. ABC reclaimed second place with 13.5 and CBS had a 12.8 average. A ratings point represents the percentage of the nation's 92.1 million television homes tuned to a show. For the season, NBC leads with 14.8 to ABC's 13.0 and CBS' 12.3. Here are last week's Top 10 prime-time shows: NBC's ``Cheers''; NBC's ``The Cosby Show'' and ABC's ``Roseanne'' tied; CBS' ``60 Minutes''; NBC's ``Grand''; NBC's ``A Different World''; CBS' ``Murder, She Wrote''; CBS Sunday Movie ``The Operation''; ABC's ``The Wonder Years'' and NBC's ``Unsolved Mysteries.'' Brandon Tartikoff, president of NBC Entertainment, said recently he wanted to put ``Grand'' into the favored Thursday night position because the show needed to be protected nurtured. As Tartikoff had predicted, ``Grand'' got a higher rating than ``Dear John'' and closed the gap with ``Cheers.'' He said he had also wanted to improve the Wednesday ratings by moving ``Dear John,'' which had been consistently in the top 10, behind ``Night Court.'' ``Dear John'' did get better ratings than ``My Two Dads,'' but it still fell behind Fox Broadcasting's ``The Simpsons'' and ``Married...With Children.'' ABC's new series ``America's Funniest Home Videos'' was 11th. It could mean trouble for its CBS Sunday night competition, ``Murder, She Wrote.'' Especially when it is joined in February by another new ABC show, ``Elvis,'' about the early life of Elvis Presley. The ABC show has already had a devastating effect on NBC's ``Sister Kate'' and the newly placed ``My Two Dads.'' The two NBC shows were at the bottom of the network shows. ABC's ``World News Tonight'' won among the evening news shows and NBC and CBS tied for second. The ratings: ABC 11.8, NBC and CBS 10.8.

DOC.HEAD: Media Allowed at Pretrial Hearings for Man Accused of Killing His Family
DOC.TEXT: A judge rejected efforts by a man accused of killing his wife, mother and three children 18 years ago to bar reporters and spectators from pretrial hearings in his murder case. An attorney for the man authorities say is John E. List argued that widespread reporting of the case would prejudice potential jurors and deny him a fair trial. But Superior Court Judge William Wertheimer on Tuesday said closing the hearing ``is offensive to the general public and undermines public trust.'' Wertheimer set March 20 as the first day of jury selection. The defendant says he is Robert P. Clark, who authorities arrested in Virginia on a tip from a viewer of the national television program ``America's Most Wanted.'' Officials said List killed his family in their home in suburban Westfield in November 1971.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Capital Gains Tax Cut in Trouble Again
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's pet legislative project, a cut in the capital gains tax, is in trouble again on Capitol Hill even though congressional support seemed to be building at the end of last year. It ran head-on into a proposal by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., to cut Social Security taxes. The collision could derail the Bush measure, or at least complicate the process. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell of Maine once called the capital gains cut Bush's ``holy grail.'' Bush has been pushing the reduction with unabated zeal since early in his presidential campaign, and in fact, since he was a junior member of the House Ways and Means Committee during the 1960s. The tax on capital gains _ the profit from the sale of stocks, real estate and other investments _ was cut during the mid-1970s. But the major tax code overhaul of 1986 boosted the tax to the same rate as other income, 28 percent or 33 percent, depending on tax bracket. Bush associates say the president has a deep repugnance for the tax, stemming from his oil field business background and honed, perhaps, by his own unpleasant brush with the tax as vice president _ when the Internal Revenue Service rejected his attempt to claim a deferral. When Bush sold his family's five-bedroom home in Houston in 1981 for $843,273, he claimed a tax deferral on his $596,101 capital gain because he used the money to buy his family vacation home in Kennebunkport, Maine. But the IRS ruled in 1984 that Bush misused the deferral, saying it only would have applied if the Kennebunkport home was to be the new principal family residence. The IRS socked the Bushes $144,000 in back taxes and $54,000 in interest. Bush paid up, but accused the IRS of unfairly singling him out. White House aides are bracing for a new Democratic assault on the capital gains cut while trying to figure ways to separate the two tax cut issues. It may be a hard job in a congressional election year _ although just last fall the House voted to cut the capital gains tax to 19.6 percent from the current maximum of 33 percent and the Senate gave the plan majority approval. However, the measure died for the year in a procedural vote in the Senate. ``We think the Moynihan proposal will die of its own weight. It won't have any effect on capital gains,'' Bush spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Tuesday. However, other White House aides privately were far less optimistic, conceding Democratic attempts to link the two tax cuts likely would make it harder to win a reduction in the capital gains tax rate. As Congress reconvened after its two-month recess, Senate Majority Leader Mitchell spelled out the party line that will spell trouble for the capital gains tax cut. ``It's obviously embarrassing to the White House to be in the position of advocating a huge tax cut for the very highest people in the income bracket and at the same time opposing any tax cuts for middle-income and working people _ saying, in effect, let the little people pay, but let's cut taxes for the wealthy,'' Mitchell said. The White House strategy is to sniff at such reasoning and to belittle the Moynihan proposal _ which Bush himself calls a ``charade'' that will lead to either higher taxes in other areas or reduced benefits. They point to a measure introduced by Sen. Ernest F. Hollings, D-S.C., for a 5 percent national sales tax to help make up revenue that would be lost by the Social Security tax cut. Still, analysts suggest the administration's role will be a difficult one. The Moynihan plan ``has created some chaos out there,'' said Norman Ornstein of the conservative American Enterprise Institute. And Lawrence Chimerine, senior economic adviser for the WEFA Group, a private economic forecasting service based in Bala Cynwyd, Pa., said Moynihan's proposal ``will make it more difficult to pass the capital gains tax cut. How can you come up with that after rejecting a tax cut for the average guy?''

DOC.HEAD: New Congressman Faces Jail Term Back in Texas
DOC.TEXT: The newest member of Congress, Texas Democrat Craig Washington, says he didn't know about a court date he missed back in Houston _ an absence that prompted a judge to sentence him to 30 days in jail. Washington, a Houston lawyer, was found in contempt of court on Monday by State District Judge Jim Barr in Houston, one day before he took the oath of office to become a member of the U.S. House. It was the second time in two weeks a jail sentence has been ordered for Washington for not heeding notices to appear in court on behalf of clients. The judge said Washington had left clients ``in the lurch.'' ``I'm going to go about my work in Congress,'' Washington said shortly after being sworn in by House Speaker Thomas S. Foley. ``I think people in my district understand.'' ``To use an old East Texas expression, it doesn't touch me top, side or bottom,'' he said. Washington was elected to fill the seat left by the death of Rep. Mickey Leland, a Democrat who chaired the House Select Committee on Hunger and who died last year in a plane crash during a trip to Ethiopia. ``I can never replace Mickey Leland,'' Washington said. ``I'm merely his successor.'' Hearings have been scheduled in Houston for Washington to show cause why he should not be sent to jail. Washington introduced three of his five children to the House and received a hug in front of his new colleagues from fellow Texas Democratic Rep. Marvin Leath. Asked by reporters about the case that led to the judge's order on Monday, Washington said: ``I have no idea. You know more about it than I do.'' ``I was not aware that this man's case was set for trial yesterday,'' he said. But Barr said in Houston, ``I've done everything I know to get in touch with Craig, and he's done everything he can to avoid me. He had ample notice to be in the courtroom today.'' Washington defended his credentials as a lawyer, saying he was the Texas state bar's lawyer of the year in 1984 and recounting some of the cases he won as a defense attorney. ``There are many people who think I'm the best lawyer in Texas,'' he said. ``I enjoy an excellent reputation as a lawyer ... I am a good lawyer.'' Washington said his law firm ``is going through a transition,'' because of his election to Congress, and that if some clients were left temporarily unrepresented it was due to ``glitches.'' He said all ``will get first-class representation.'' ``We're going to work our way through this,'' he said. ``The day will come when all these clients will receive satisfaction with respect to representation.''

DOC.HEAD: Watergate Residents Want to Block Homeless Shelter
DOC.TEXT: Apartment owners in the luxury Watergate complex are suing the District of Columbia in an effort to block construction of a homeless shelter across the street. The Watergate owners were joined in the lawsuit by other area residents who want to bar the shelter, which would accommodate 108 homeless people. ``Nobody's going to want to live here,'' said Ruby Barnhard, who was among residents alleging that the shelter would reduce neighborhood property values. Sue Marshall, the homeless coordinator for the District Department of Human Services, said the arguments against the shelter were ``reprehensible in the sense that what you're doing is comparing a human life to your property value.'' Units at the Watergate, which overlooks the Potomac River near the Kennedy Center, sell for from $179,000 to nearly $2.7 million, according to real estate listings. The proposed shelter is part of a city effort to provide overnight shelter for every homeless person who wants it. District voters approved the measure in a 1984 vote. The district has been under a Superior Court order to expand its shelters since early last year and has been paying daily fines of $11,500 since Dec. 26 for not providing shelter quickly enough. A hearing has been set for Friday on the lawsuit's request for a preliminary injunction to suspend work on the shelter. The Watergate complex includes a hotel and offices.

DOC.HEAD: Some Lawmakers Unsettled Over Study of What Owls Spit Up
DOC.TEXT: A state study of owls' diets has unsettled some lawmakers who are queasy about spending $180,000 to learn more about the little hairy balls of indigestible bones, teeth and hair that owls upchuck. ``We can't educate kids in our schools, and we've got a person studying the diets of an owl,'' said Rep. Ted Leverenz, who wants to cut off funding for the study. But researchers said the Department of Conservation study of what owls eat during different seasons could help show how changes in the environment affect animals. ``We owe it to future generations to preserve as many species as we can. Without basic information, such as what they eat, it's rather difficult to do that,'' said Russell Graham, an Illinois State Museum geologist and bone expert overseeing the study. Since the three-year study began in July 1988, researchers have collected about 3,000 pellets made up of indigestible leftovers of what the owls ate. Graham said the owls' messy habit of spitting up pellets makes them the ideal bird for the study. ``With other birds, you'd have to watch them day and night to see what they're eating or shoot them and dissect their stomachs, which is not too conservation-minded,'' he said. The pellets have revealed that owls eat rabbits, opossums, ducks, pheasants, cardinals, shrews, fish and mice and other rodents. Pam Fortado Gibson, field coordinator for the study, said the information eventually could be used to help farmers reduce their dependence on pesticides. ``We have no knowledge of our natural pest control,'' she said. ``It would help farmers move away from using carcinogenic chemicals that pollute our streams.'' But Leverenz has an alternative explanation for the study. ``Apparently,'' he said, ``the owl was wiser than we were.'' The study also drew fire from would-be fiscal watchdogs in state government. ``I've heard of wastes of money, but this one really takes the cake,'' said Shawn Collins, a candidate for state comptroller. ``I don't doubt the answers would be useful, but what are your priorities?''

DOC.HEAD: Jackson Neither In Nor Out of DC Mayor's Race
With PM-Barry-Grand Jury, Bjt
LaserPhoto WX9
DOC.TEXT: Jesse Jackson is neither ruling himself in nor ruling himself out of the race for mayor of the nation's capital following Mayor Marion Barry's arrest on a drug charge. ``I have no plans to run for mayor,'' Jackson told a meeting of community activists Tuesday night in his first public appearance since Barry checked himself in to a Florida rehabilitation center. But moments later, Jackson said it would be ``irrational'' to rule out any political option and then said, ``Public servants, with all their options, never say never.'' The crowd of fewer than 100 people that gathered in a downtown church to hear Jackson press his campaign for statehood for the District of Columbia greeted him with a standing ovation, but some said they were not urging him to jump into the mayor's race. ``He's doing now what he does best,'' said Aurelia Corbett King. ``He's a national figure. We have local people who have worked in the trenches, but he has a national appeal that people can respect.'' Jackson referred to Barry as ``the hurt player,'' and said, ``you take that player off to the sidelines until that person can recover, but you don't forfeit the game.'' Asked how he would respond to those who are urging him to run for mayor, Jackson replied, ``In this time of crisis, let's not make premature and hasty judgments, but steady and mature judgments. ``The mayor has the time, both for recovery, and the time to make a judgment about his political future ... that decision will be made by the mayor and his cabinet.'' When pressed to rule out a run for mayor, Jackson referred to the political leverage he gained by winning millions of votes in Democratic presidential primaries in 1984 and 1988 and said, ``For me at this stage to declare what level we will not use for our freedom would be irrational.'' Ron Richardson, president of the local chapter of the Hotel Restaurant Workers' Union, is leading a move to draft Jackson and was at the meeting with community activists. He said further meetings of his group would be held later in the week but that ``we're not ready to go to him (Jackson) yet.'' ``I think Jackson might get into the race if he felt a groundswell of support from the voters,'' said Charlene Drew-Jarvis, a city councilwoman and another declared candidate for mayor. ``I don't think Jackson will do it,'' said David Clarke, city council chairman and the only white candidate for mayor of the predominantly black city. Should Barry resign his post, Clarke would become mayor, pending a special election. Also formally in the race are Councilman John Ray and Sharon Pratt Dixon, a utility company executive and Democratic Party activist. Speaking on condition of anonymity, one Jackson intimate described his wife, Jacqueline, as ``dead set against'' him entering the race for mayor. Another associate, also insisting he not be quoted by name, said Jackson was ``going over all the options,'' but ``doesn't want to look opportunistic,'' as if he were ready to jump into the race within days of Barry's arrest. Jackson received 80 percent of the District of Columbia vote in the 1988 Democratic presidential primary, and early surveys of voter sentiment in the mayor's race put him far ahead of all other potential candidates, including Barry. The mayor's office issued an appeal from Barry to the news media Tuesday to stay away from the Hanley-Hazelden treatment center in West Palm Beach ``for the sake of my privacy and that of others'' at the facility. In his statement, Barry said he and his family were undergoing ``a painful ordeal.''

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: There's no truth to the rumors that Michael Jackson's chimpanzee Bubbles has died, Jackson's publicist announced, and ``when Bubbles heard about his demise he went bananas.'' ``Like Mark Twain, his death is grossly exaggerated and he's alive and doing well,'' publicist Lee Solters said Tuesday. A fire in Jackson's Santa Barbara menagerie last month destroyed a giraffe barn, but the animals were evacuated safely. Jackson's private zoo includes ostriches, llamas and boa constrictors.

Kathleen Turner is thrilled to be playing the sultry Maggie in Tennessee Williams' ``Cat on a Hot Tin Roof,'' but stressed that she doesn't identify with any of the characters she portrays. ``Nah, come on, it's acting, guys. It really truly really is,'' she told reporters Tuesday. ``It's fun to be able to play these women with all this wonderful power and allure and intelligence I'd like to add. But it's acting. It's just fun. I'm really not like that at home.'' The play began a two-week run Tuesday at Pittsburgh's Benedum Center. After that, it goes to Boston, Philadelphia and then Broadway. Miss Turner said she always had intended to portray Maggie, a beautiful Southern woman who pines for a husband who shuns her. ``Maggie is so brave,'' she said. ``She changes so fast and thinks so fast. I like the level of aliveness.'' Appearing with Miss Turner are Charles Durning, Polly Holliday and Daniel Hugh Kelly. The production is nothing like the 1958 film with Elizabeth Taylor, Paul Newman and Burl Ives, Miss Turner said. Miss Turner, 35, started in theater but movies made her a star. Her credits include ``Body Heat,'' ``Romancing the Stone,'' ``Prizzi's Honor,'' ``Peggy Sue Got Married'' and ``The Accidental Tourist.'' She currently appears with Michael Douglas in ``The War of the Roses.''

Conductor Mstislav Rostropovich is returning to his native Soviet Union with a concert tour, but rejected any notion that he might end 16 years of exile in the West. Asked during an interview Tuesday on his feelings about next month's visit, he replied: ``How would you feel about going to the planet Mars?'' Rostropovich, music director of the National Symphony Orchestra, said he and his wife, soprano Galina Vishnevskaya, were happy Soviet authorities had decided to restore the citizenship stripped from them in 1978. But Rostropovich is reported to have told friends he cannot reconcile with the Soviets until they also restore the citizenship of his close friend, Nobel Prize-winning novelist Alexander Solzhenitsyn, who lives in Vermont. Rostropovich and the National Symphony leave Jan. 29 for a tour of Japan and the Soviet Union, where they will give four days of concerts in Moscow and Leningrad. The first concert, in the Bolshoi Hall of the Moscow Conservatory, will feature Tchaikovsky's ``Pathetique'' symphony, the last work Rostropovich conducted _ and on the same stage _ before he fled to the West in 1974, complaining of harassment and limits on his artistic freedom.

Ted Danson and the other regulars of ``Cheers'' left their studio barstools to march in protest of aerial pesticide spraying of the Mediterranean fruit fly. ``If we don't jump up and down and say toxins are not the answer, then nobody is going to look for other answers,'' said Danson, who plays bartender Sam Malone on the NBC comedy series. He was joined at the Los Angeles Federal Building on Tuesday by cast members Kirstie Alley, Woody Harrelson, George Wendt and John Ratzenberger. The demonstration was organized by the Coalition Against Malathion. State officials are spraying malathion in Southern California to stop an insect infestation that threatens the state's $1.5 billion fruit industry. The state says its biological control programs are inadequate to deal with the infestation.

_ MADRID, Spain (AP) _ King Juan Carlos opened a retrospective of 17th-century painter Diego Velazquez that has brought together more of the Spanish master's works than even his royal patron possessed. Juan Carlos on Tuesday toured the 79-piece exhibit that features 20 paintings of his royal ancestors, including Velazquez's patron, King Philip IV. In scope and size, the Prado retrospective dwarfs the exhibit that drew 550,000 people to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York last year. The one-time Madrid show is to run through March 30. Organizers borrowed far and wide to add to the 48 paintings from the Prado's permanent collection. The most important loans included ``The Rokeby Venus'' from London's National Gallery and ``Portrait of Juan de Pareja'' from the Metropolitan.

Rock star David Bowie announced a six-month world tour and said it would be the last time he sang his smash hits on stage. Publicists will advertise telephone numbers and ballots for fans to choose the tour's songs _ from hits like ``Young Americans,'' ``Rebel Rebel,'' ``Changes,'' ``Suffragette City'' and ``Let's Dance.'' ``I won't be doing them ever again,'' Bowie told reporters Tuesday. ``There's no point continually doing songs and reflecting on a past.'' The 42-year-old Bowie, whose real name is David Jones, will appear in Canada, Britain and Holland in March before going to the United States, Australia, Japan and the rest of Europe. The British-born musician said he will be accompanied by a four-piece band in simple stage settings but added: ``Knowing me there will be a fair amount of theatricality about it.''

DOC.HEAD: Most Federal Anti-Drug Aid Doesn't Reach Cities
DOC.TEXT: Only a small portion of federal drug enforcement aid goes to the nation's cities, says the U.S. Conference of Mayors, seeking to boost the mayors' call for a change in the way the government wages its war on drugs. The study, being released today, found city governments received just 15 percent of the $150 million in federal funds available for drug enforcement through the two main grant programs during the last fiscal year. That amounted to $22.1 million. ``Experience to date has shown that only a small percentage of federal anti-drug funds has actually reached city governments, and that it has taken a long time for those funds to arrive,'' said J. Thomas Cochran, executive director of the conference. The report was prepared for mayors gathering in Washington today for their three-day annual winter meeting. President Bush will address the big-city mayors on Friday, marking the first time in a decade a president has appeared before the Conference of Mayors while in office. The last was Jimmy Carter in 1980. The mayors _ who are overwhelmingly Democratic _ have long complained that cities suffered from neglect and cutbacks in federal aid under President Reagan. They have complained since enactment of the federal anti-drug program in 1986 that the government's war on drugs failed to provide adequate support directly to cities, where most of the drug problems are found. Mayors have urged the federal government to make direct grants to cities rather than providing block grants to states for distribution. Boston Mayor Raymond Flynn, in an interview on the eve of the conference, said he believed Bush's decision to address the mayors indicated the administration may be ready to provide more attention _ and money _ to the cities' problems of drugs, poverty and homelessness. ``I sense this time more a sense of urgency by federal officials about the condition of the cities, more of a concern,'' Flynn said. Flynn said urban leaders will be expecting some help as a result of the so-called peace dividend _ the anticipated defense savings resulting from the lessening of world tensions. ``It's not in the best political interest of congressional leaders or White House officials to ignore the messages that have been coming out of America's cities,'' Flynn said. Congressional leaders also will meet with mayors for talks on homelessness and drugs. One mayor who won't be attending is the host, Washington Mayor Marion Barry, who entered a Florida treatment center Monday following his arrest last week on a cocaine possession charge. The conference's study looked at the two grant programs making drug enforcement money available to state, city and other local governments. Under the formula grants program, which distributed $117.7 million to the 50 states plus Puerto Rico and the District of Columbia in fiscal 1989, 28 percent or $33.6 million went to state agencies, the conference reported. Another 17 percent, $20.7 million, went to anti-drug efforts that involved more than one government jurisdiction, and 16 percent, or $19.4 million, went to counties. Fifteen percent, or $18 million, had not been awarded, and only 12 percent, or $14.4 million, went to cities, the study said. The rest, about 12 percent, was retained by the states for administration, went to confidential awards or was given to other types of agencies, the conference said. Some of the multi-jurisdictional money went to cities, but served an area beyond the city limits and was not counted in the cities' total, the report said. The second program awarded $28.9 million in fiscal 1989 at the discretion of the federal Bureau of Justice Assistance. According to the study, 34 percent, or $9.7 million, went to non-governmental agencies, and 27 percent, or $7.7 million, went to cities. The remainder went to states, counties, other governments and federal agencies.

DOC.HEAD: Counties in 10 States to Get More Homeless Aid
DOC.TEXT: A federally funded program is dropping a rule that prevented counties in 10 states from receiving $1.1 million to feed and shelter the homeless. The rule placed a minimum requirement on the size of counties' urban labor forces, in some situations. The decision by the federally funded Emergency Food and Shelter National Board Program means that 18 counties that were denied direct assistance are being added to the list of 1990 qualifiers. The counties are in Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Maryland, Michigan, Mississippi, New Jersey, Ohio, Pennsylvania and Washington. The decision was made at a private meeting Friday of the program's national board, which includes representatives of the United Way and other charitable groups. It was announced this week by Rep. Paul Kanjorski, D-Pa. ``The dark period of uncertainty is over,'' said Kanjorski, whose home county of Luzerne benefited from the board's decision. ``Full funding for our centers provides a ray of sunshine for the needy and deserving people who are helped by this program.'' The seven-year-old program is charged by Congress ``to supplement and extend ongoing efforts to provide shelter, food and supportive services'' to the homeless. The program has recently come under fire from homeless advocates for dropping 126 counties that received aid in 1989 to distribute food, run homeless shelters, assist with mortgages or help the poor pay energy bills. The counties included 20 with double-digit unemployment. Although Congress did not cut the program, the counties lost out because they fell below 1990 eligibility levels for poverty, unemployment or labor force. Most still will get aid from so-called ``set-aside'' funds, although probably not as much as last year. Those funds, representing 15 percent of the program's $124.9 million budget, are administered by state boards trying to cushion the blow for communities denied direct assistance. The counties benefiting from the $1.1 million are Lake, Stephenson and Tazewell in Illinois; Floyd, Howard and La Porte in Indiana; Clinton in Iowa; Washington in Maryland; Jackson and Midland in Michigan; Lamar in Mississippi; Middlesex in New Jersey; Allen, Marion and Licking in Ohio; Delaware and Luzerne in Pennsylvania; and Thurston in Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Nursing Home Survey Finds Widespread Concern Abuse Goes Unreported
DOC.TEXT: A government survey of health experts and advocates for the elderly shows near-unanimous agreement that physical and emotional abuse is a problem in America's nursing homes and widespread concern that mistreatment often goes unreported. For each of seven types of abuse, more individuals thought the situation was worsening than believed it was improving, according to two draft government reports obtained Tuesday. ``While there are no exact statistics on institutional abuse, any abuse is unacceptable,'' the reports said. The costs of abuse ``are measured in the physical and psychological damage incurred by the resident as well as by the economic costs of treating the abused resident,'' they said. Both reports from the inspector general's office of the Department of Health and Human Services were based on a survey of 228 people in 35 states who work in state and federal government, nursing homes and advocacy groups. The reports are in draft form and subject to revision. No state-by-state breakdown was available. The reports conclude abuse-reporting systems are inadequate, follow-up on complaints is ineffective and state and federal oversight to prevent abuse needs strengthening. The reports also recommend the federal government require better training for nurses aides about aging, suggest ways to cope with stressful situations and promote more research and education on how to improve staff stability in nursing homes and control abuse. Medical personnel, other patients, families and visitors all contribute to the problem, but nursing home aides and orderlies are the biggest abusers, according to the reports. The reports said many things contribute to abuse by nursing home workers, including low staffing levels, high stress, inadequate training, high turnover, job frustration, belligerent patients, low wages, lack of empathy for the elderly and increasing numbers of severely ill residents. ``Faced with heavier levels of care, such as residents with more debilitating diseases, frustrated staff take out their stress on the residents,'' said one unidentified official who participated in the survey. The report divides abuse into seven categories: physical abuse, misuse of restraints, verbal or emotional abuse, physical neglect, medical neglect, verbal or emotional neglect and improper use of a resident's personal property. Ninety-five percent of those surveyed said there were problems in all seven areas. Thirty percent said physical neglect was the most prevalent problem; 16 percent said verbal and emotional abuse, and 14 percent selected verbal and emotional neglect. The reports said most research on abuse of the elderly focuses on family members and caregivers at home, and suggests 1 percent to 10 percent of the non-institutionalized elderly may be abused. Although there is less information about abuse in nursing homes, one 1988 study found 36 percent of surveyed nurses and nurses aides had seen at least one incident of physical abuse in the preceding year and 10 percent said they themselves had committed one or more physically abusive acts. The HHS survey found nursing home industry officials often view the abuse problem as minor, but a significant number of state oversight agencies and advocates for nursing home residents see the problem as serious. Fifty-one percent of those interviewed believed abuse is only sometimes or rarely reported by nursing home staff, suggesting many cases go unreported each year, the reports said. The reports said workers may not report abuse because they fear for their jobs, are loyal to other staff members, fear retaliation, fines, penalties and bad publicity, lack sufficient facts, and don't recognize less blatant forms of abuse. The survey also found doctors often fail to report abuse, with 66 percent of those interviewed reporting physicians who attend to patients at nursing homes rarely or never report it.

DOC.HEAD: Ag Department Foresees Barriers to Trade With Soviet Republics
DOC.TEXT: An Agriculture Department analyst says it may be some time before individual republics or business enterprises in the Soviet Union are able to engage in world trade on their own. Moscow's foreign trade organizations, or FTOs, hold centralized reins over agricultural trade, although economic reforms under Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev are opening other doors such as joint ventures and FTOs in the republics. Abraham Avidor of the department's Foreign Agricultural Service said despite the announced reforms, the central government continues to dominate foreign trade and the pricing, procurement, processing and retailing of food staples. ``Trade reforms, particularly the granting of trade rights to republics and qualified enterprises, have not yet had a major impact,'' he said. ``In many cases, republics and enterprises do not have enough exportable world-class products to generate hard currency sales.'' Writing in the current issue of AgExporter magazine, Avidor said the republics and enterprises also lack trading experience and are subject to export licensing aimed at assuring sufficient domestic supplies. ``Because of the limited impact of trade reforms, the central government remains the only major purchaser of U.S. agricultural commodities,'' he said. On the other hand, U.S. agricultural exporters have few problems with Soviet tariffs. Although a tariff schedule is maintained, it serves mostly as an accounting system to keep track of foreign trade. The largest Soviet barrier to greater trade with the West is a shortage of hard currency, the ruble's lack of convertibility, and government dominance over trade, Avidor said. American farmers have benefited from large grain sales to the Soviet Union since the early 1970s, particularly since 1976 when regular purchases were first specified in a long-term agreement between the two countries. But Avidor said the underlying goal of Moscow is to reach food self-sufficiency and that large imports ``continue to be viewed as temporary'' necessities.'' ``Recent reforms have focused on increasing food supplies, rather than on controlling (consumer) demand,'' he said. ``Steps have been taken to decentralize decison-making in agriculture, allowing more self-management by republics, enterprises and individuals.''

Snow in the nation's breadbasket is raising prospects for the 1990 winter wheat crop, according to the government's Joint Agricultural Weather Facility. The facility is operated by the Commerce and Agriculture Departments and reported Tuesday on crop and weather conditions for the week of Jan. 14-20. ``Precipitation fell in the Great Plains from Texas to central Nebraska, providing much-needed snow cover and moisture to the winter wheat crop,'' the report said. ``The moderate temperatures and moisture were beneficial to livestock producers as they helped pastures.'' However, the report added wheat farmers and fruit growers were ``concerned that the warm weather will start growth too soon, leaving these crops more vulnerable to a hard freeze later on.'' The report said the heavy, wet snow in the plains was the first moisture of the season for many stressed dryland fields of wheat. ``Livestock was responding favorably to above-normal temperatures,'' the report said. ``Texas ranges and pastures were showing some signs of improvement as mild weather and moisture returned to most areas.'' Pastures in Oklahoma were greening, although heavier supplemental feeding of livestock was necessary in areas of the central plains because of snow cover. ``Lambing and calving activity was increasing in Michigan and Idaho,'' the report said. ``Florida pastures were mostly fair-to-good in the panhandle and northern peninsula, and fair in the southern areas.''

Preliminary estimates by the Agriculture Department show last year's crop production was worth about $77 billion, up 10 percent from 1988. Corn output in 1989 topped all crops in value with a total of more than $17 billion, up from $12.7 billion in 1988, the department's Agricultural Statistics Board said Tuesday. The annual crop values are based on estimated production and prices during a crop's marketing year. The corn marketing year, for example, runs from Sept. 1 through the following August. Also, the preliminary dollar estimates represent the value of a crop, whether all is sold or partly used by producers. The figures are used mainly as comparisons from year to year and do not represent cash sales by farmers. Other leading crop values for 1989 included: Hay, baled, $11.8 billion; soybeans, $10.6 billion; wheat, $7.7 billion; cotton, $4 billion; tobacco, $2.4 billion; oranges, $1.8 billion; grapes, $1.7 billion; sorghum, $1.3 billion; and apples, $1 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Groups Accuse Watchdog Panel of Excessive Secrecy
DOC.TEXT: Two environmental groups contend a watchdog agency created by Congress to oversee nuclear weapons plants is operating in illegal secrecy. The chairman of the agency, the Defense Nuclear Facilities Safety Board, denied the allegation Tuesday, while a House panel chairman said he had urged the board to clarify its rules on public participation. The allegations were leveled by two environmental groups, the Natural Resources Defense Council and the Energy Research Foundation, which regularly press the Energy Department to be more open about operations of its nuclear arms plants. The environmental groups announced they will sue the board if it does not open its meetings to the public and release records of its meetings by Feb. 14. The board, created by Congress in 1988, began operating Oct. 25. Dan W. Reicher, an attorney for the Natural Resources Defense Council, said the watchdog agency was violating the 1976 Sunshine Act requiring executive branch agencies to hold meetings in public, and the Freedom of Information Act, which requires agencies to publish rules on public access to their records. ``The board is perpetuating the culture of secrecy it was supposed to eradicate at the Energy Department,'' Reicher said. John Conway, chairman of the five-member board, said in a telephone interview, ``I don't believe we've violated any federal laws.'' He acknowledged that some of the board's meetings were not open to the public, adding that ``we meet every day, we're a full-time board and we work every day.'' It would be impractical, Conway said, to issue advance notice of daily meetings and that some discussions would have to be closed to the public because they include classified material. Conway said no one had asked to attend the board meetings or to review its records. Rep. John Spratt, D-S.C., chairman of a special House panel reviewing the nuclear weapons complex, said Conway assured him Tuesday that he was committed to running the watchdog board ``in as open and public a way as possible.'' Spratt said Conway had encountered numerous bureaucratic obstacles to organizing the board's work, in part because of staff hiring problems. ``In the short term, I'm sympathetic to his plight,'' Spratt said, adding that he urged Conway to move quickly to clarify the board's rules on open meetings and public access to records. The board was established by Congress in response to growing indications that the Energy Department had hidden or failed to uncover many environmental, safety and health problems at the arms facilities.

DOC.HEAD: Webster Foresees Big Jump in US Dependence on Gulf Oil
DOC.TEXT: Private energy analysts agree with a new CIA forecast of a 2{-fold increase in U.S. dependence on oil imports from the Persian Gulf, but they say the increases may be more gradual than the spy agency predicts. William Webster, director of the Central Intelligence Agency, told the Senate Armed Services Committee on Tuesday that U.S. reliance on Persian Gulf oil will more than double in the coming few years. ``Western dependence on Persian Gulf oil will rise dramatically'' in the next few years, Webster said, adding the Gulf share of U.S. oil supplies would rise from 10 percent in 1989 to ``roughly 25 percent'' in a few years. He did not mention a precise time period and did not elaborate on the import issue. President Bush contends more reliance on the Persian Gulf will undermine U.S. national security because of the risk of a supply interruption. This argument, disputed by many environmentalists and members of Congress, is central to the administration's efforts to open more federal lands and waters to oil exploration. John Lichtblau, executive director of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation in New York, said in an interview that Webster's forecast was reasonable if he was projecting to 1995. He said ``it's a little bit exaggerated'' if Webster meant the rise to 25 percent would occur in two or three years. Lichtblau said his organization was projecting Persian Gulf oil will account for between 22 and 23 percent of U.S. supplies by 1995. He and other analysts tie the increase to growing U.S. oil consumption, continuing declines in U.S. oil production and declining exports by non-Gulf oil exporters such as Britain. Total U.S. oil imports last year rose to 7.9 million barrels a day. That was a 10-year high and meant 46 percent of U.S. oil supplies came from foreign sources, according to the American Petroleum Institute, an industry trade association. Dillard Spriggs, president of the consulting firm Petroleum Analysis Ltd. in New York, said ``in five years' time it's quite likely'' that the United States will be getting one-quarter of its oil from the Persian Gulf, but not before then. ``That's where it's got to come from,'' he said, since no major new oil fields are scheduled to come into production outside the Gulf in the next few years. The Energy Department's forecasting office does not publish projections of U.S. dependence on oil from specific regions of the world, said W. Calvin Kilgore, who directs the office. But Kilgore said he foresees ``at least a doubling'' of U.S. reliance on the Persian Gulf over the next five years.

DOC.HEAD: Members of Congress Return From Break With Bills in Hand
DOC.TEXT: A wide range of bills newly introduced in Congress would cut Social Security taxes, free billions of dollars for the nation's highways and cash in on the thaw in East-West relations by cutting Pentagon programs. Many of the bills introduced as lawmakers returned to work Tuesday after their winter recess would address the massive federal budget deficit and the gimmicks used to disguise the government's red ink. Also introduced were bills that would raise the Environmental Protection Agency to Cabinet status and allow women to serve in combat. The largest political storm has already formed over Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan's proposal to cut Social Security taxes. Moynihan was derided by the White House earlier this month when he announced the plan, which he formally introduced Tuesday. He would roll back Social Security payroll tax rate from the 7.65 percent it reached Jan. 1 to the previous 7.51 percent. That would save workers $7 billion this year and $55 billion in fiscal 1991. ``We must end the shameful practice of using Social Security revenues to finance budget deficits,'' said Moynihan, D-N.Y. The surplus in Social Security reserves is counted in the budget, making the deficit appear smaller than it actually is. The surpluses are the result of efforts to build up reserves for the Baby Boom generation when it ages and will dwindle after the turn of the century. But the Bush administration calls the move part of a Democratic plot to raise other taxes. Sen. Ernest F. Hollings, D-S.C., meanwhile, rolled various tax proposals _ including his perennial call for a national sales tax _ into a Tax Reform and Competiveness Act. The legislation embraces some of President Bush's proposal to lower the capital gains tax and includes Moynihan's Social Security proposal and a plan by Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, to restore the tax deduction for Individual Retirement Accounts. This is the fifth straight year Hollings has introduced legislation for a value added tax, as the sales tax is known. On another budget front, Sen. Richard Bryan, D-Nev., introduced legislation he said would release more than $10.5 billion in highway money being held in the federal Highway Trust Fund. The money represents the accumulated difference between revenues _ larely from the 9-cent-a-gallon gasoline tax _ and federal highway authorizations. Critics say the money is deliberately underspent to keep the deficit low and provide a cheap source for government borrowing. ``Over the last decade the federal government has used the money collected by the federal gas tax as a deficit-reduction gimmick,'' Bryan said. Legislation to elevate the Environmental Protection Agency to Cabinet level status was introduced in the House and Senate, with supporters saying they hoped a bill could clear Congress within several months. Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio, chairman of the Senate Government Operations Committee, said the EPA needs more clout and higher visibility because of the importance of environmental issues in the next decade. Sens. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., and Alan Cranston, D-Calif., moved to translate changes in the Soviet Bloc into less military spending, introducing legislation to cancel the B-1 stealth bomber program after the 15 bombers now in production are built. ``Recent events have made the argument against the B-2 even stronger,'' said Leahy. He said taxpayers would save $40 billion as a result. Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., introduced a bill she has been touting since the U.S. invasion of Panama last month that would remove existing prohibitions on women serving in combat. Cranston, under investigation for his role in the scandal over the failed Lincoln Savings and Loan, introduced legislation that would allow the 23,000 holders of worthless junk bonds sold through Lincoln to sue federal regulators for approving the sale. Cranston is one of five senators under an ethics inquiry for receiving contributions from Lincoln owner Charles Keating Jr. and intervening with federal regulators on Keating's behalf. A bill introduced by Sen. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn., would bar senators from taking honoraria and limit outside earned income to 15 percent of salary. The measure would bring Senate rules in line with those approved by the House last year. Sens. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., and Gordon J. Humphrey, R-N.H., introduced a proposed constitutional amendment that would limit senators and members of the House to 12 years in office. Humphrey said the amendment would ``go a long way toward restoring a truly representative Congress.'' In other legislation Tuesday: _Reps. Silvio Conte, R-Mass., and Joseph Brennan, D-Maine, introduced separate bills to raise low-income energy assistance subsidies after a cold snap and low inventories sent heating oil costs skyrocketing 50 percent last month. _Banks and thrifts that launder drug money would lose their charters under a bill introduced by Rep. Frank Annunzio, D-Ill, chairman of the House Banking financial institutions subcommittee. _And Rep. James Trafficant, D-Ohio, introduced a bill to repeal the 1985 Gramm-Rudman deficit reduction law, calling the law ``that turkey that should be shot down.''

DOC.HEAD: Webster Sees Diminished Soviet Threat
LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: Rapid changes in Eastern Europe have reduced the Soviet threat and could lead to the disintegration of the military agreement among the Warsaw Pact nations by the mid-1990s, say Bush administration officials. ``There can be no doubt ... that the conventional military threat in Central Europe has declined,'' Central Intelligence Agency Director William H. Webster told the Senate Armed Services Committee Tuesday. The sessions, the panel's first in a series of hearings on the Soviet threat to the West, will serve as a basis for the committee's crafting of a defense budget for the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1. The ties between the Eastern bloc nations and Moscow have been radically altered in the push toward democracy, and the Kremlin can no longer count on those countries to respond automatically to its military orders. In addition, the Soviet Union has been keeping pace with President Mikhail Gorbachev's December 1988 plan to reduce troop levels in Eastern Europe while the Soviets' economic problems have demanded more money normally earmarked for defense. ``Soviet and Warsaw Pact strength and capabilities have declined,'' Webster said. ``The reductions probably lengthen the time it would take for the Soviets to mobilize for any large-scale attack in Europe.'' Despite the diminished threat, the CIA director said the Soviet Union is still modernizing its strategic forces. That, combined with the threats from terrorism, illegal drugs, uncertainty in Latin America, Asia and the Middle East and weapons proliferation, highlights the importance of maintaining a strong U.S. intelligence capability. The comments appeared to be a plea to head off budget cuts for the CIA and other intelligence agencies, whose operations are hidden in the Defense Department budget. Although the exact figures are secret, U.S. intelligence reportedly spends $25 billion to $30 billion a year, just less than 10 percent of the defense budget. The director of the Defense Intelligence Agency told the panel he believes the push for freedom in Eastern Europe ``will likely lead to the phase out of the (Warsaw) Pact's collective military security role'' by the middle of the decade. Lt. Gen. Harry Soyster said a new type of security agreement between the Eastern bloc nations could emerge. ``The rapid turn of events in Eastern Europe may accelerate the removal of Soviet forces and may speed the evolution toward such a new security order,'' Soyster told the committee. Soyster said he believed the Soviet Union would view a large-scale offensive against the NATO countries with only their own forces as ``highly risky, if not impractical.'' Both Webster and Soyster expressed concerns over the new and more sophisticated threats, such as nuclear, chemical and biological weapons in the hands of nations that support terrorism. ``By the year 2000, at least six countries probably will have missiles with ranges up to 3,000 miles,'' Webster said.

DOC.HEAD: Military Rulers Censor News Broadcasts; Top Businessman Reportedly Arrested
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ In a widening crackdown to silence political foes, Haiti's military rulers have arrested a leading business figure and ordered radio and television stations to broadcast only the news they approve. Also Tuesday, the general heading the interior and defense ministries defended the weekend expulsion of four prominent politicians as retribution for their ``insulting the head of state,'' Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril. An Information Ministry statement told broadcasters that it must approve their local news reports, and ordered them to ``refrain from relaying or broadcasting any information on Haiti from stations broadcasting'' from abroad. In recent days, stations have relayed statements by exiled opposition leaders broadcast by Radio France Internationale and the Voice of America. Stations also were told not to broadcast anything ``likely to incite agitation.'' Radio is the main source of information in this impoverished Caribbean nation, which shares the island of Hispaniola with the Dominican Republic. Haiti has two TV stations, one government-owned and the other in private hands. Police were reported to have raided three independent radio stations on Monday. With the exception of a 6 a.m. newscast by a Protestant station, none of the dozen independent radio stations in Port-au-Prince broadcast local news Tuesday, but official Radio Nationale did. Newspapers were not affected by the ministry directive, but few Haitians read them. Interior and Defense Minister Brig. Gen. Fritz Romulus said on government television Tuesday night that the political leaders expelled and militants beaten and arrested over the weekend ``maintained a climate of tension ... and poisoned the atmosphere.'' Relatives said police on Tuesday arrested Antoine Izmery, 45, one of Haiti's main importers and a vocal critic of the government of President Avril, telling him he would be forced into exile. Izmery was arrested while driving to work. Police searched his downtown warehouse and went to his home for his passport, his wife said. The government declared a 30-day state of siege and beat and arrested dozens of militants and prominent politicians on Saturday, a day after unidentified assailants killed an army colonel, his wife and a servant. Most of those arrested are believed to have been released. Critics accused Avril of staging the killing of Col. Andre Neptune and using it as a pretext to clamp down on the opposition and renege on his promise to hold free elections in October. Romulus justified the arrests and expulsions of conservative leader Hubert de Ronceray; Dr. Louis Roy, co-author of the constitution; Communist Party deputy leader Max Bourjolly and leftist militant Abby Brun, saying they ``got into the habit of insulting the head of state.'' All had denounced what they called human rights abuses by Avril's government and demanded he resign. Romulus said those exiled could return in time for October presidential elections but did not specify a date or say if they would be allowed to campaign. Asked by the government TV news director, Judith Brossard, to comment on the ``rumor'' of police brutality, Romulus said he had not seen any. ``But, the president had told arresting officers to treat everyone correctly.'' He said once the police had ``terrorism'' under control, the government would lift the state of siege. The United States, France and Canada have condemned the government action. Avril gained power in September 1988 when a soldiers' rebellion ousted Lt. Gen.
