Henri Namphy, who took over after a popular uprising forced dictator Jean-Claude Duvalier to flee to France in February 1986. The last time Haiti attempted free elections, in November 1987, armed thugs in collusion with government troops shot or hacked to death at least 34 voters and the balloting was canceled.

DOC.HEAD: Dodd Proposes Ban on Honoraria With No Senate Pay Raise
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Christopher Dodd is setting the stage for another politically touchy debate over honoraria by proposing banning the speaking fees without giving senators a raise to compensate for the lost income. The Connecticut Democrat introduced the legislation Tuesday. It would apply only to the Senate, which decided last year to continue accepting honoraria in the immediate future. The House voted to ban the fees next Jan. 1 in return for a large raise. Dodd's bill would ban Senate honoraria on the same date. Because the Senate took a smaller pay raise than the House, passage of Dodd's legislation would leave senators earning significantly less than members of the House. Lawmakers are not eager to fight another pay or honoraria battle in an election year, especially since they approved salary increases and ethics reforms late last year. But Dodd, unhappy with the continuation of Senate honoraria, said he won't let the matter rest. ``When the doors closed on the first session of the 101st Congress, the Senate found itself in the bizarre position of being the only place in the federal government where the receipt of honoraria was still legal,'' Dodd said in a floor speech. Dodd said he preferred coupling the honoraria ban with a pay raise but added, ``Absent the political will to vote a pay raise ... the integrity of this institution remains threatened by the continued receipt of honoraria.'' Dodd stopped accepting honoraria in February 1989. Dodd did not include any pay raise in his legislation, and the Senate would be unlikely to attach a pay component to the legislation in an election year. However, the Senate could pass the honoraria ban now, and vote itself a post-election raise next year in time to avoid a net loss in pay. Congressional watchdog groups such as Common Cause and Public Citizen have strongly urged a ban on honoraria, saying the money comes mostly from special interest groups trying to influence lawmakers. Public Citizen said Tuesday that it surveyed senators and found 43 supporting an honoraria ban, 31 undecided and 11 who opposed the prohibition. Fifteen did not respond. Pay for senators is scheduled to increase to $98,400 a year next month, while the House salaries would increase to $96,600 at the same time. In 1991, House members will earn nearly $125,000, without speaking fees. Senators would earn about $101,400 with an additional $23,568 in honoraria permitted. In addition to banning honoraria next January, the Dodd bill would limit outside earned income to 15 percent of a senator's salary. The measure would allow senators to make speeches and send up to $2,000 per speech to a charitable organization.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 36,778.98, down 599.04 points, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Self-Esteem is Keen, California Task Force Reports
DOC.TEXT: A state task force that's been lampooned as an emporium of New Age buzzwords completed its three-year mission with a report enshrining self-esteem as a ``social vaccine'' that ``empowers us to live responsibly.'' Much of the rest of the country may be snickering, but 42 of California's 58 counties, including conservative rural ones, already have formed local self-esteem teams. In its 144-page final report issued Tuesday, the California Task Force to Promote Self-Esteem and Personal and Social Responsibility recommended more parenting courses, smaller school classes and pro-family worksite policies. When the task force was created with the blessing of Republican Gov. George Deukmejian, it was met with scorn. Cartoonist Garry Trudeau poked fun in ``Doonesbury,'' having his bubble-headed character Boopsie named to the task force, which she called ``the first official study of New Age thinking.'' The 24 task force members ``have brought the matter of self-esteem from a matter of ridicule to a subject of respect,'' said Assemblyman John Vasconcellos, the Democrat who sponsored the bill creating the group. Twenty-three of the members signed the report. The 24th, David Shannahoff-Khalsa, called it ``incredibly superficial and naive.'' ``Self-esteem cannot be administered, injected, nor given to any one,'' he said in a telephone interview from his Del Mar home. ``This elusive term ... is being promoted as a universal remedy for a society that is becoming increasingly complex and disfunctional.'' The report compared self-esteem to a ``social vaccine, something that empowers us to live responsibly and that inoculates us against the lures of crime, violence, substance abuse, teen pregnancy, child abuse, chronic welfare dependency and educational failure.'' But Shannahoff-Khalsa, a consultant to the National Research Council, said the commission did not address the subconscious mind adequately. ``Without probing the depths, one will never reach the heights,'' he said. At a March 1988 hearing, the first of nine, the $750,000 task force heard San Jose high school principal Ruben Trinidad testify: ``I love you, I really do.'' Another principal, Arvil Clark, said: ``I'm not sure I love all of you, but I'm sure I could like most of you.'' The hearings drew testimony by small-business owners in the timber-fishing town of Eureka near the Oregon line, AIDS patients in San Francisco, and masked members of rival street gangs in Los Angeles. Vasconcellos has said he created the task force because, as chairman of the budget-writing Ways and Means Committee, he saw much of the state's budget going to repair Californians with problems such as violence, drug and alcohol abuse, teen-age pregnancy, child abuse, welfare dependence and school failure. The task force's job was to research whether lack of self-esteem contributes to those problems and, if so, recommend ways society can improve individuals' self-esteem. Vasconcellos said he plans to send Trudeau a copy of the report. Trudeau, he said, satirizes things that are important, and his cartoon ``elevated the task force from an obscure California venture to one everyone knew about.'' The task force defined self-esteem as ``appreciating my own worth and importance and having the character to be accountable for myself and to act responsibly toward others.'' It concluded that ``the family is the incubator of self-esteem'' and that ``the parent's high self-esteem is vital to his or her ability to provide a health environment for the child.'' Vasconcellos said he did not know how much it would cost to put the recommendations into practice. He acknowledged that some, such as increased child care, would be expensive. According to the 1986 bill that created the commission, the state's 2 million adult alcoholics and its $3 billion illicit drug trade cost the state millions of dollars in medical expenses, lost productivity, law enforcement and corrections.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon: Noriega Guest House Cache `Not Cocaine'
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon says its military officers probably shouldn't have made claims during the Panama invasion that a large cache of cocaine was found in a guest house frequented by Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. ``You have to do lab tests on things to be 100 percent sure,'' said Defense Department spokesman Bob Hall. The spokesman acknowledged Tuesday the substance was not cocaine and tests on the material were made after the find was touted by U.S. military officers. Gen. Maxwell Thurman, the commander of the Panama-based Southern Command, had pointed to the alleged drug find as evidence of Noriega's alleged connections to narcotics. Pentagon officials were left trying to explain on Tuesday exactly what the powdery substance found wrapped in banana leaves was. One report said the substance may have been tamales, but the military says that's not so. Hall said he could not identify it with any certainty, saying he'd been supplied with ``less than satisfactory'' information by U.S. military officials in Panama. ``We said that our soldiers found some white powder wrapped in banana leaves in a refrigerator,'' Capt. Art Haubold of the Southern Command's public affairs office said in Panama. ``The substance was taken to a lab and it was determined after that is was not cocaine. ``The best they could determine was that it was some bonding substance used in voodoo rituals. That's the way it was described to us by Army experts. At first, it could have been mistaken by a layman as cocaine.'' Hall said U.S. officials were trying to get more information on the matter. The Washington Post reported Tuesday that the find amounted to tamales used in voodoo ceremonies. Shortly after the invasion, Thurman said 50 kilos, or more than 100 pounds, of cocaine was found. Thurman was quoted in a Dec. 23 New York Times article as saying the cocaine indicated Noriega ``condones or uses the stuff himself.'' Hall said Tuesday that ``clearly the guys who first saw this stuff did not know what cocaine was. When the experts checked, they said it wasn't.'' Hall said he didn't know when it was determined that the cache was not cocaine. ``In retrospect, probably you shouldn't be announcing something. ... You need to be very careful, obviously,'' he said. Hall said he could not provide any details about any other drugs that might have been found during the invasion because of ``legal implications.'' The day after the invasion, reporters were shown a so-called ``witch house'' that supposedly had been frequented by Noriega. Col. Mike Snell, the officer in charge of the area, said some 50 pounds of cocaine and voodoo paraphernalia were found there. Noriega is awaiting trial in Miami on federal drug-trafficking and racketeering charges. Panamanian tamales are generally wrapped in banana leaves and are made cornmeal and chicken meat in the capital and with pork in the provinces.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Consider How to Aid Romania
DOC.TEXT: Lawmakers say they are thinking of how to help Romania after the disastrous reign of Nicolae Ceausescu but have yet to provide specific ways of improving trade or providing more money. The members of Congress spoke in light of complaints by members of Romania's provisional government that the United States has done too little to help the emerging country. ``Many in Bucharest are disappointed by the slow, modest and cautious reaction to the Romanian events,'' Silviu Brucan, a member of the provisional government that replaced Ceausescu, told The New York Times in Bucharest in an interview published Tuesday. Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, were executed on Christmas Day by the provisional government. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler on Tuesday denied the Bush administration is dragging its feet on Romania. Instead, officials are ``looking for ways to be supportive,'' she said. ``I'm interested in helping Romania,'' said Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., who called the country a ``basket-case'' after the Ceausescu regime. Asked in an interview if he would propose additional aid for Romania, Dole said it would be difficult to find much money when foreign aid resources are stretched thin. The United States has sent about $750,000 in emergency aid to Romania, most of it medical supplies, since Ceausescu was overthrown. Last year, Romania received virtually no U.S. assistance, according to John Metelsky of the Agence for International Development. That compared to the special $400 million that Congress provided Poland and Hungary in the waning days of the 1989 legislative session. Rep. Frank Wolf, R-Va., has urged the Bush administration to move cautiously in providing trade benefits, known as most favored nation status, to Romania. ``Please do not grant MFN until free, fair, open and verifiable elections are held,'' Wolf wrote in a letter to President Bush. Wolf, who has long been interested in Romania, visited the country this month. Ceausescu withdrew his country's favored trade status two years ago in the face of congressional opposition. Since then, trade between the two countries has dropped to virtually nothing. Sen. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn., who was a leader in the drive to revoke Romania's favored trade status, would like to see its trade with the United States improve, but he hasn't introduced any legislation, according to his spokesman, Jason Isaacson. Tutwiler said the department would have to consult with Congress before any change is made in Romania's trading status. But she said the provisional government's ``steps towards freedom of travel and immigration as well as movement toward a pluralistic, multi-party democracy will obviously be relevant to our conversation of a waiver.''

DOC.HEAD: Angolan Leader Cancels Plans for US Visit
DOC.TEXT: Angola's leftist president is canceling a long-planned private visit to the United States in which he had hoped to shift American support away from Angola's U.S.-backed anti-communist rebel movement. President Eduardo dos Santos had been invited by 36 members of Congress to visit Washington early next month, and his sudden cancellation Tuesday touched off conflicting explanations of his motives. The cancellation was disclosed by Randall Robinson, head of a private group with close ties to the Angola government. He said dos Santos decided not to go ahead with the visit because of Bush administration pressure. The State Department denied the allegation, saying, ``The administration has not placed any obstacles in the way of his visit.'' The administration has accused the Angolans of disregarding efforts to achieve peace by launching a major offensive a month ago. Robinson blamed the UNITA rebels for the upsurge in the fighting but said the government is now prepared to call off the hostilities. UNITA Vice President Jeremias Chitunda said in an interview Tuesday that the fighting has claimed the lives of more than 300 government soldiers and 62 rebel troops. Word of the cancellation followed a meeting of the top Angolan leadership, which reaffirmed in a communique Monday its commitment to maintaining a one-party Marxist state. The statement contained no change in the government's longstanding opposition to direct negotiations with the rebels. The hard-line tone of the communique triggered speculation in UNITA circles that dos Santos canceled the visit because he did not have authorization to make peace concessions. The United States has no diplomatic relations with Angola but administration officials were willing to meet with dos Santos during the February visit if he agreed to certain conditions. These reportedly included signing a cease-fire with the UNITA rebels and a pledge to enter into direct negotiations with the insurgents. Recently, dos Santos invited the State Department's top African affairs diplomat, Herman Cohen, to visit the Angolan capital of Luanda. Cohen was due to arrive there tonight for a 24-hour stay. The invitation sparked speculation that dos Santos might be prepared to offer a peace proposal, possibly including a cease-fire. Angola's principal representative in the United States, U.N. Ambassador Manuel P. Pacavira, was in Washington on Tuesday but was unavailable for comment on the cancellation. But Robinson, who heads a group called TransAfrica, contended the administration opposed the visit because it was fearful of the public debate that would be generated about the $50 million in military assistance the United States reportedly gives to the UNITA rebels each year. ``Denying Americans an opportunity to hear other side is a very bad reflection on this country,'' Robinson told The Associated Press. The Angola conflict has raged for years, with Soviet weapons used by the MPLA government arrayed against the arms provided to the rebels by the United States. According to U.S. estimates, the Soviets send more than 10 times as much to the government forces as the United States sends to the rebels. The conflict is one of several examples of superpower competition that have survived the winding down of the Cold War. Robinson said dos Santos had planned to attend a dinner in his honor at the home of Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., and to visit with the widow of slain civil rights leader Martin Luther King.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Plunge, Dollar Also Down
DOC.TEXT: The key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange plunged Wednesday, while the dollar fell against the Japanese yen. The dollar closed at 145.80 yen, down 0.53 yen from Tuesday's 146.33-yen finish. The currency opened at 145.88 yen and ranged between 145.65-146.06 yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average lost 599.04 points, or 1.60 percent, ending at 36,778.98. It had gained 121.01 points Tuesday. The index's plunge came as arbitrageurs sold stocks in an attempt to widen the price spread between stocks and stock futures, said Kozo Hasunuma, a dealer with Yamaichi Securities Co. ``While there were massive sales by arbitrageurs, institutional investors remained on the sidelines, resulting in very little buying,'' he said. Japanese investors were largely discouraged by expectations of further weakness on the New York stock market, Hasunuma said. Despite a 14.87-point gain in the Dow Jones Industrial Average on Tuesday, Japanese investors still think the New York market looks weak, he said. In currency dealings, traders attributed the dollar's weakness to its downswing in New York overnight. Reports that unrest was subsiding in the southern Soviet republic of Azerbaijan halted the dollar's advance and rekindled buying of West German marks, they said.

DOC.HEAD: Freed: Brandley Released After 10 Years on Death Row
LaserPhoto HT1
DOC.TEXT: After nearly a decade on Death Row, Clarence Lee Brandley used his first day of freedom to go to the church where his family and friends had held regular vigils for his release. Amid applause and shouts of ``Thank you, Jesus'' from supporters, the soft-spoken Brandley emerged from the Creston Baptist Church in northeast Houston late Tuesday after praying with his family and church leaders. ``I just recall the words of Martin Luther King: `Free at last. Free at last. Thank God Almighty ... free at last,''' said the Rev. Ozell Brandley, who cheered his brother's release along with neighbors of the small church. Brandley, 38, who once came within five days of execution, was released on a $75,000 bond Tuesday, a month after the Texas Court of Criminal Appeals threw out his capital murder conviction for the 1980 rape-slaying of a 16-year-old girl. The court issued its final mandate Monday, confirming that Brandley did not receive a fair trial. ``We prayed for him continually,'' said Margaret Clark, Brandley's sister. ``This is where we prayed for him every Sunday and Wednesday and sometimes Tuesdays.'' Brandley said little except that he was happy to be off Death Row. He said he would spend time with his mother and four children and move anywhere except Montgomery County, where he was convicted. ``It's a great feeling just walking outside the gate, knowing I'm standing on some grass _ not concrete _ and no non-stop handcuffs,'' Brandley said as he left the Huntsville prison where he was incarcerated for more than nine years. ``I was doubtful this day would ever come.'' At the church, Brandley bowed his head and exclaimed ``Amen!'' as the Rev. Leroy Ross thanked God, saying, ``You have indeed freed an innocent man from execution and after nine and a half years of being on Death Row.'' Montgomery County District Attorney Peter Speers said he will ask the U.S. Supreme Court to review the case, but wouldn't seek another trial if the high court refused. Speers said he still believes Brandley is guilty of the murder of Cheryl Dee Fergeson, slain while attending a volleyball tournament at the Houston-area high school where Brandley worked as a janitor. Brandley's first trial ended in a hung jury, and an all-white jury convicted him of capital murder in his second trial. A third trial would be virtually impossible because of the time that has elapsed, lost evidence and corrupted witnesses, Speers said. Brandley's attorneys have claimed their client was the victim of racism. Brandley is black and Miss Fergeson was white. ``As much as we'd like to think this is the 1980s or 1990s and racial prejudices are behind us, race was a major factor in the prosecution and the investigation,'' said defense attorney Paul Nugent. In 1987, a judge recommended a third trial because the two others had been discriminatory. On Dec. 13, the state's high court agreed, saying the investigation ``lacked the rudiments of fairness.'' Evidence revealed during the 1987 hearing showed contradictory testimony from other janitors _ all of whom were white. Texas Attorney General Jim Mattox said he would not join Speers in seeking the U.S. Supreme Court ruling because the original trial was ``racially tainted.'' C.L. ``Buck'' Fergeson, the slain girl's father, said he was upset that Brandley was free. ``I'm still convinced he's guilty, and I hope Speers is going to do everything he can to rectify the situation.'' The janitor who found Miss Fergeson's body, Henry Peace, was charged with sexually assaulting two girls last year, authorities said. Peace, who was a co-worker of Brandley's at Conroe High School, was arrested Friday, said O.J. Stewart, sheriff in nearby Liberty County. Prosecutors said there is no evidence linking Peace to Miss Fergeson's slaying. Peace testified in the Brandley case, but gave conflicting testimony during several court hearings.

DOC.HEAD: Troops Patrol Rangoon After Scattered Protests
DOC.TEXT: Armed troops, some with drawn bayonets, patrolled downtown Rangoon today following two days of scattered demonstrations in support of detained opposition leader Aung San Suu Kyi, Western diplomats said. The diplomats in Rangoon said several hundred chanting protesters gathered near City Hall on Monday, anticipating a final ruling on whether Ms. Suu Kyi would be allowed to run in May 27 parliamentary elections. One diplomat said he had reports of another small demonstration in Rangoon Tuesday evening. Ms. Suu Kyi, running for a seat from a Rangoon district, was disqualified by a branch of the military government's Election Commission last week. Her party has appealed the decision to the commission's central body. Ms. Suu Kyi is he general secretary of the largest and most popular opposition party, the National League for Democracy. She has been under house arrest since July. The May election is to be Burma's first multiparty vote since 1960 but government critics have expressed doubts about just how free it will be. Western governments and Japan have condemned recent moves to bar opposition figures from the election. Last month, the co-leader of Ms. Suu Kyi's party, Tin Oo, was sentenced to three years in prison on charges of subversion. U Nu, the last democratically elected prime minister, was put under house arrest and barred from the elections. Diplomats say thousands of other dissidents have been detained. Millions of Burmese took to the streets in 1988 demanding an end to authoritarian rule. But the mass protests ended that September as the present government seized power, its troops killing hundreds of people. The Western diplomats in Rangoon, reached by telephone and speaking on condition of anonymity, said there were no violent incidents in the demonstration near City Hall but cited reports that at least 20 of the protesters were arrested on Tuesday. The building houses Election Commission offices. The mostly student protesters and some Buddhist monks chanted slogans supporting Ms. Suu Kyi and denouncing the pro-military National Unity Party, the diplomats said. It was an objection raised by a candidate of that party that led to the ban on Ms. Suu Kyi. The demonstrators, who faced armed troops with fixed bayonets and riot shields, dispersed after dark when it became clear no announcement concerning Ms. Suu Kyi would be made. The Election Commission disqualified Ms. Suu Kyi partly on the strength of allegations she had links with outlawed student groups. Today, troops guarded strategic points and sentries lined pedestrian overpasses, the diplomats said. ``There seems to be a deliberate show of force,'' said one. The disqualification of Ms. Suu Kyi's candidacy still has not been officially announced. ``If it was announced, it could generate an explosion of public anger and they may be trying to avoid that by keeping things as confusing as possible,'' a diplomat said.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf of 1st item to fix typo in `July'
DOC.TEXT: Nearly 15 feet of snow has fallen on northern Michigan's Keweenaw Peninsula so far this winter. But a Chicago mall is eager to take the flakes. The Keweenaw Chamber of Commerce on Friday trucked nine 8-foot-tall crates of its Upper Peninsula snow to Chicago's North Pier Mall. Elizabeth Lee, who owns a store in the mall, said the shopping area has planned a winter festival since July. Snow sculptors from China, Italy and Germany were due to arrive this week. But there was no snow for them to mold. A newspaper advertisement led Lee to the Upper Peninsula, where Lake Superior moisture has helped dump more than 174 inches of snow this winter.

DOC.HEAD: Alcohol Consumption Lowest in 2 Years But Still Most Widely Used Drug
DOC.TEXT: Americans are continuing the trend of drinking less alcohol, but it still is more widely used than any other drug or cigarettes, according to a government report. The 400-page ``Seventh Special Report to the U.S. Congress on Alcohol and Health'' issued by the Department of Health and Human Services says per capita consumption was 2.54 gallons of pure alcohol in 1987, the lowest level since 1970. The formula used for the calculation takes into account the relative differences in alcohol content of beer, wine and spirits. The report, issued every three years, has tracked a steady decline in alcohol consumption since 1981. It also cites a U.S. household survey of people over age 12 in 1988 by the National Institute on Drug Abuse showing that 73.4 percent reported drinking alcohol in the past year, while 36.2 percent reported smoking cigarettes. The report also found: _About 10.5 million U.S. adults show signs of alcoholism and 7.2 million suffer from alcohol abuse although they do now show signs of dependence. _High school seniors showed a decline in alcohol use during the 1980s, but in 1988, one study showed, 92 percent had tried alcohol, nearly two-thirds were current drinkers and more than a third were occasional heavy drinkers. _Nearly half of all motor vehicle accidents are alcohol-related. _About 25 percent of hospital patients have alcohol-related problems.
DOC.HEAD: Protesters of Salvadoran Aid Arrested As Congress Opens Session
DOC.TEXT: Actor Martin Sheen and 36 other protesters against U.S. military aid to El Salvador were arrested as they demonstrated in the Capitol rotunda on the opening day of the new session of Congress. Dan Nichols, information officer for the Capitol Police, said the protesters were charged with demonstrating within a Capitol building and unlawful entry. He said the offenses carry a maximum penalty of a $500 fine and six months imprisonment. The arrests Tuesday climaxed a day that began with an ecumenical prayer service at a nearby church and included a march to the Capitol by demonstrators carrying cardboard caskets in protest of killings in El Salvador. The demonstrators in the rotunda knelt, lay down, chanted slogans and lifted banners protesting aid to the Salvadoran government and calling for negotiations to end the prolonged civil war in that country. Sheen, who knelt rather than lay, was silent as he was led handcuffed from the rotunda.
DOC.HEAD: Conductor to Visit Homeland; Will Still Live in the West
DOC.TEXT: Conductor Mstislav Rostropovich says he will return to the Soviet Union for a concert tour next month with feelings of ``enormous emotion,'' but has no thought of ending 16 years of exile in the West. Rostropovich, music director of the National Symphony Orchestra, said Tuesday that he and his wife, soprano Galina Vishnevskaya, were happy that Soviet authorities had ``admitted their mistake'' and decided to restore the citizenship stripped from them in 1978. But Rostropovich made clear during a session with reporters at the Kennedy Center that the couple had no intention of abandoning their life in the West and returning permanently to their homeland. Rostropovich repeated his assertion last week that ``the almost 16 years spent in the West since our exile do not yet allow us to change our lives again.'' Rostropovich is reported to have told friends privately there cannot be a reconciliation until the Soviets also restore the citizenship of his close friend, Nobel Prize-winning novelist Alexander Solzhenitsyn, who now lives in Vermont. Rostropovich and the National Symphony are scheduled to leave Jan. 29 for a tour of Japan and the orchestra's first visit to the Soviet Union, where they will give four days of concerts in Moscow and Leningrad.

DOC.HEAD: General Says Noriega `Coward' During Invasion; Noriega Calls Home
DOC.TEXT: The ground forces commander in the U.S. invasion of Panama says Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega was a coward who ``never did anything worthy of a military man'' after the operation began Dec. 20. Noriega's main concern was to hide, Maj. Gen. Marc Cisneros said in an interview Tuesday. Noriega took refuge in the Vatican Embassy on Christmas Eve. Under pressure from the papal nuncio, he surrendered to U.S. forces on Jan. 3 and was flown to Miami, where he awaits trial on drug trafficking charges. ``He never fought, rallied his forces or did anything worthy of a military man,'' Cisneros said. Noriega's wife, Felicidad, and three daughters took refuge in the Cuban Embassy and is seeking safe passage to the Dominican Republic, but Panama has embezzlement charges pending against Mrs. Noriega. Noriega has been calling his family at the embassy from the United States, the Cuban ambassador said. ``He was interested in finding out about the health of his daughters and he didn't say anything about politics,'' Ambassador Lazaro Mora said. ``The calls have been brief.'' He said Noriega had called two or three times since turning himself over to U.S. forces. In the embassy along with Felicidad and daughters, Lorena, Sandra and Thais is Sandra's husband, Jean Rene Beauchamps, a Dominican, and their son Jean Manuel. The 5-month-old boy is Noriega's only grandchild. ``Noriega's family is fine. They are in good spirits,'' the ambassador said. Cisneros is commander of U.S. Army South, the ground forces of the U.S. Southern Command, or U.S. military headquarters for Central and South America. Born in Brownsville, Texas, he speaks Spanish and has spent nearly three years in Panama. In the interview, he said the invasion was necessary because it was evident there was no diplomatic solution and ``there was a real threat to U.S. interests here.'' Other sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the Bush administration decided on military action shortly after the Oct. 3 failed coup against Noriega. At least 10 officers involved in the uprising were executed, some reportedly by an enraged Noriega. ``After Oct. 3, we saw a complete degeneration of the Panamanian Defense Forces,'' Cisneros said. ``Indisicipline built up. ... There were also the Dignity Battalions, that consisted mostly of public employees forced to join, but had a hard core of criminals recruited by Noriega.'' The Dignity Battalions were paramilitary groups trained to act as shock troops. Rumor had it that Noriega's reliance on them and his arming of them increased as his control diminished over the Defense Forces. Cisneros said that after Oct. 3, ``a threat to U.S. interests here, to our country, to our families became very real. The culminating point came when the U.S. officer was shot and killed.'' A U.S. Marine lieutenant was killed at a Panamanian checkpoint on Dec. 16. Washington demanded an explanation and Panama accused the United States of provocations. ``It was clear at that point ... We had to do something,'' Cisneros said. The United States had applied economic and political pressure trying to oust Noriega since February 1988, when he was indicted on federal drug trafficking charges in two Florida courts. Noriega denied the charges. On Dec. 20, Cisneros' soldiers, normally charged with defending the canal, rolled out of Fort Clayton for the invasion in a combined operation with paratroopers from the 82nd Airborne Division. The invasion had been rehearsed. U.S. forces in Panama had been enlarged since May 1989. Cisneros said a Noriega bodyguard told the dictator the morning of the invasion that he was going out to seek another hiding place. ``Noriega begged him, `Do not abandon me,''' Cisneros said. ``It was then the bodyguard decided that it was fruitless to stay with Noriega, a waste of time. He did not want more damage for his country. ``He found a U.S. soldier who spoke no Spanish and it took a long time for him to come to me to tell me where Noriega was,'' Cisneros said. By the time U.S. troops arrived, Noriega was gone.

DOC.HEAD: Former NYC Mayor Hospitalized
DOC.TEXT: Former Mayor John V. Lindsay was ``doing fine'' at a hospital after collapsing at lunch, officials said. The 68-year-old Lindsay, who has had heart problems, was admitted Tuesday to New York Hospital for observation, said Solomon Torres, a hospital administrator. He was listed as stable today. His condition was not considered life-threatening, Torres said. Lindsay remained conscious after collapsing at the Century Club, police said. He underwent tests in the emergency room before being admitted. Mayor David Dinkins went to the hospital after hearing of Lindsay's illness. ``I'm pleased to report that he seems to be doing fine,'' Dinkins said. In January 1988, Lindsay underwent surgery to repair a leaky heart valve at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. Last March, he underwent tests in the coronary intensive care unit of New York Hospital. Lindsay was a three-term congressman when he was elected mayor in 1965 as a Republican. He was re-elected as an independent, switched to the Democratic Party and made a bid for the presidential nomination before leaving City Hall in 1973. He since has practiced law in Manhattan with the firm of Webster and Sheffield.

DOC.HEAD: Man Accused in Beating Death of Vagrant
DOC.TEXT: Three days ago, Rodney Sumter stood on a subway platform, waiting for a train with his 3-year-old son. Today, he stands accused of fatally beating a homeless man who had taunted him, spit at him and punched him in the face at the station. Friends and family of Sumter, who was fired last week from a job teaching construction skills to homeless men, said he acted in self-defense. ``He was protecting himself and his son from an unprovoked attack that he tried to escape,'' Sumter's lawyer, Lewis Tyson, said Tuesday as they left the Manhattan Criminal Court building. But an activist said the death was typical of the life-threatening horrors New York City's homeless face every day. ``This has been portrayed to me as, `New Yorkers now have reason to be afraid of the homeless.' I think the homeless have reason to be afraid of New Yorkers. This man is dead,'' said Keith Summa, advocacy director of the Coalition for the Homeless. Sumter pleaded innocent Tuesday to first-degree manslaughter and was released without bail. Although there are no statistics on violence involving the homeless in the subway system, ``there are more incidents now than compared to 10 years ago,'' said Transit Authority police spokesman Sgt. Robert Valentino. Two other men were in court Tuesday on charges they shoved a homeless man to his death beneath a subway train. Summa recited a litany of incidents where homeless victims were beaten, battered and set aflame. Little is known about the dead man in the Sunday night case involving Sumter. Identified only as John Doe, he was believed to be in his 60s. He was a denizen of the midtown Manhattan station where he died; he now seems destined for a Potter's Field burial. Sumter, 39, had no criminal record. He is married and lives in Harlem. He worked as a plumber at various construction sites since coming to New York in 1980. Earlier this month, he began work as a $20,000-a-year construction supervisor training homeless men recruited from a city shelter. The program is operated by the John Doe Fund, an advocacy group for the homeless. ``He is one of the nicest guys,'' said Greg Powell, a supervisor on the project. ``He would try to stop a fight, not start one.'' George McDonald, the fund's executive director, said Sumter was dismissed Jan. 17 because of personal problems at home. He said Sumter had been ``distracted, and had come to work late.'' According to police, the confrontation began at 11 p.m. Sunday as Sumter and his son waited at the 59th Street station for a train home after seeing the movie ``Back to the Future II.'' The homeless man began verbally harassing Sumter, and at one point spit at him, said transit police spokesman Al O'Leary. Sumter finally lashed out when the man punched him above the left eye, O'Leary said. ``The critical piece of information is that after the homeless man fell to the platform, Mr. Sumter took his head and banged it again into the concrete platform,'' O'Leary said. Sumter's wife, Michelle, who picked up their son, Patah, from police the night of the killing, rejected such talk. ``I know he was defending himself and his child,'' she said. Summa, whose group handles a variety of problems involving the homeless, remained skeptical that the case _ and John Doe's death _ would become anything more than statistics. ``What if this was someone's grandfather _ your grandfather _ and he spat at someone in the subway ... and the person killed him. How would you react?'' he asked. ``My guess is differently than in this incident. That tells us something.''

DOC.HEAD: Motorola Settles Dispute Over Claimed Overcharge on Air Force Contract
DOC.TEXT: Motorola Inc. has agreed to pay the federal government $750,000 to settle claims that it overcharged the Air Force on a contract for a radar-jamming device. ``We decided to settle it. There's nothing other than that,'' Motorola spokesman Lawrence Moore said Tuesday. The agreement between Illinois-based Motorola and the U.S. Department of Justice follows an investigation of charges that the company's Government Electronics Group in suburban Scottsdale overcharged the Air Force $325,317 in 1983 on a $28.3 million contract. The two sides agreed that Motorola did not disclose cost information related to the company's decision to buy rather than manufacture some transformer and inductor units used in the power-supply system for the devices. Under the federal false-claims act, a company is liable for up to three times the amount of an overcharge, said Michael W. Robinson, a Justice Department spokesman. Robinson said the $750,000 settlement was not considered a fine. Moore said it is not unusual for the government and contractor to disagree over the appropriateness of certain costs.

DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs next-to-last graf to update with Humana comment
DOC.HEAD: HHS Says Two Chains Owe Money for Recaptured Pension Assets
DOC.TEXT: A government investigator says two national hospital chains owe the Medicare program $27.6 million for Medicare's share of excess pension plan assets they took over. Humana Corp. owes $23.5 million and Hospital Corp. of America owes $4.1 million, said a report by Richard Kusserow, inspector general of the Department of Health and Human Services. ``Medicare, which paid its pro rata share of the pension contributions, did not share equitably in the gains that resulted from pension plan terminations,'' the inspector general said. Labor unions and their supporters in Congress contend the excess assets of terminated pension plans should go to the workers on whose behalf the plan was operated. But legally the money belongs to the plan sponsor. Plans may accumulate excess assets for a variety of reasons, mostly through pessimistic assumptions about the financial performance of investments. For example, a plan may assume its assets will earn 6 percent per year but actually earn 8 percent. When plans terminate, they must satisfy existing obligations, either by establishing new plans, paying cash to members or buying annuities for members. Both hospital companies established new plans. The inspector general said 19 other hospital companies terminated pension plans before 1983, realizing $3.7 million in excess plan assets. Those actions were not further reviewed because of the small amounts involved. HCA terminated its pension plan Dec. 30, 1982 and Humana Dec. 31, 1980. The report said the two chains recovered pension fund assets totaling $90.7 million and those assets should have been applied to offset hospital costs, leaving less for Medicare to reimburse. ``However, HCA offset only $20.2 million against costs and Humana made no cost offset at all,'' the report said. ``For the $70.5 million not offset against costs by the two hospital chains, we estimate the Medicare program is due $22.1 million plus accumulated interest of $5.5 million,'' the report said. In Louisville, Ky., Humana spokesman Charles Teeple said his company had not been notified of the HHS report. After receiving it, ``We will need to study and determine the course we will take,'' he said. In Nashville, Tenn., HCA spokesman David McFadden said his company had not been notified of irregularities, and HCA's payments contractor, Blue Cross-Blue Shield of Tennessee, had approved its handling of the pension assets. ``We believe that what is occurring here is that this is interpretation of rules after the fact,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Hunger Striker Rejoices at Court's Reversal of Life Sentence
DOC.TEXT: The state appeals court overturned the conviction of an inmate whose weight has dropped by more than a third during a 10-month hunger strike to protest his life sentence on drug charges. The court ruled Tuesday that the evidence used to convict Rene Acuna of cocaine delivery and conspiracy charges was inadequate. It struck down the conviction and life sentence and declined to order a new trial. Acuna, who has lived on water and sweet coffee since March 3, said he would continue the strike until he is freed to return home to his companion, Anna Sossa, and his two daughters. ``I will eat in the table of my house,'' said Acuna, a Cuban immigrant and self-employed handyman whose weight in prison has dropped from 180 pounds to 112 pounds. Assistant Macomb County Prosecutor Michael Suhy said he will seek a review by the state Supreme Court and oppose Acuna's release in the meantime. Acuna called the ruling a sign of divine power. ``I remember in the newspaper people said my hunger strike was cheap publicity, but that was not my intention. It was to show my innocence, and now my innocence has been shown,'' he said by telephone from the state prison near Jackson. Acuna contended that undercover agents had lumped him together with other Hispanics who were arrested during an undercover drug buy in a predominantly white neighborhood of Warren, near Detroit, in August 1988. Prosecutors claimed that Acuna was a lookout for the drug dealers. The other convicted men testified they had never heard of Acuna. ``This has been probably the most gut-wrenching case I ever handled as a lawyer, and the system has worked,'' said Paul Denenfeld, legal director for the Michigan chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union. ``We all believed this was simply a person who was in the wrong place at the wrong time, and I think Rene's courageous hunger strike has vindicated him.'' Denenfeld said Suhy should reconsider his opposition to bond for Acuna. ``The man has suffered enough,'' he said. ``We're in a situation where someone's life is on the line,'' said attorney Michael Schuck, who handled Acuna's appeal. ``He has been on a hunger strike about 10 months now, and his life is in danger every day.'' Acuna's weight plunged as low as 106 pounds in September, and doctors began force-feeding him. They removed the feeding tube when Acuna's weight rebounded.

DOC.HEAD: Six Arrested in Second Day of Mine Disturbance
DOC.TEXT: Non-union coal trucks rammed the cars of striking miners that blocked the entrance to a coal plant, and police arrested six men, including two union officials charged with illegal picketing. Tuesday's violence at the Rum Creek Coal Sales Inc. preparation plant came a day after clashes that injured two women at the site. The non-union coal trucks, with steel plates welded to their grills, brushed aside pickets on a bridge leading to the Rum Creek depot Tuesday and smashed into two cars parked across the road. State police arrested three of the drivers on charges of destruction of property and a fourth, Gaylord Conners of Williamson, with attempted murder for allegedly trying to run down a picket, police spokesman Ric Robinson said. Two United Mine Workers members, including international board member Howard Green, were arrested on charges of violating a federal judge's injunction against blocking the road, U.S. Marshal Walt Biondi said. The two also were accused of violating a provision of the order that limits the number of pickets at the site to 15. About two dozen union miners went on strike in August after a non-union contractor was hired to run the plant in southern West Virginia. The strike was not related to the UMW's 9-month-long, three-state strike against the Pittston Coal Group. A tentative agreement to end that strike was reached last month. A West Virginia miner was shot Jan. 16 in a conflict arising from another coal strike.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``He will be out there, free. He probably has people out there right now looking for me. I will have to live the rest of my life on the line ... always looking behind me.'' _ David Rothenberg, now 13 and severely scarred, saying he would always live in fear of his father, Charles, who was being paroled from prison today after serving seven years for setting fire to David in a murder attempt.

``This has been portrayed to me as, `New Yorkers now have reason to be afraid of the homeless.' I think the homeless have reason to be afraid of New Yorkers. This man is dead.'' _ Keith Summa, advocate for the homeless, on the beating death of a vagrant who taunted, spat at and punched a man who was standing on a subway platform with his 3-year-old son. The father, who lashed back, stands accused of first-degree manslaughter.

``These are 11- and 12-year-old youngsters. They are not grown men and they really aren't great athletes. We need to protect them from what adults sometimes do, which is overglorify them from the things they sometimes accomplish.'' _ Creighton Hale, national Little League president, on why he told the World Series-winning Trumbull, Conn., team not to make any more public appearances.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Who Killed Baby in 1952 Pleads Guilty to Reduced Charges
DOC.TEXT: A woman who admitted killing her baby and burying the body in her backyard in 1952 probably will not go to prison under a plea-bargain, a prosecutor says. Marion Allen, who confessed last year, ``has been confined to her own type of prison for the past 37 years,'' Rensselaer County District Attorney James B. Canfield said. ``It would appear her own mental anguish and guilt has exerted a more severe penalty than the state ever could,'' he said. ``Justice is not served by having a 69-year-old woman spend the remainder of her life in prison.'' Allen pleaded guilty Tuesday to second-degree manslaughter. She said she smothered her baby and buried it in the backyard of her home. Canfield said he believes Judge M. Andrew Dwyer Jr. would accept the agreement, under which Allen would receive five years' probation when sentenced March 21. ``To the best of our knowledge she hasn't injured anybody else,'' Canfield said. ``Since the death of her child, she's led a simple life.'' Allen, plagued by guilt, went to police in October and confessed that she had buried the child in her yard. ``She could see the grave site,'' said Troy Police Capt. Albert Prezio. ``It was only within a few feet from her window where she sat most every day.'' Authorities unearthed a small strongbox and the remains of the baby. Laboratory tests failed to determine its sex or cause of death. Allen spent about three months in a mental hospital following her confession. She was released a few weeks ago into the custody of her husband, George. The woman reportedly told police the baby was conceived from an extramarital affair. She said she killed the infant without the knowledge of her husband, who has refused to speak to reporters.

DOC.HEAD: Workers Barricade Parks Office And Demand Commissioner's Resignation
DOC.TEXT: A barricade was built around the office of the parks commissioner while members of city council demanded his resignation over allegations he had ordered pollution dumped in a city lake. ``I don't think there's any fiction writer who could have developed a more inane and criminally evil act,'' said Councilman James W. Pitts after Robert E. Delano refused to appear before the council's Finance Committee on Tuesday. Common Council members said they would subpoena Delano to answer questions about scandals in his department and would try to cut off his paychecks if he didn't comply. Meanwhile, a 3{-foot-high barricade was erected inside the parks building Tuesday to bar the public from the office suite where Delano and his top aides work. Office workers, who apparently were working at Delano's behest, denied the barrier was intended to keep television cameras out. They said it was put up because toxic chemicals are stored in the building. Controversy has surrounded Delano for the past two months, since the FBI confirmed it was investigating corruption charges against him. The charges include having parks employees do private work on city time, buying large quantities of supplies for which the city had no use and then reselling them to private parties, and harassment of parks workers, city officials and reporters. Last week, it was alleged that Delano ordered parks workers in 1987 to pour a salt-like chemical into Delaware Park Lake to keep it from freezing after the council took a refreshment-stand concession away from some of his close associates. The chemical did prevent freezing at one end of the lake. State environment officials are checking the lake's water quality and whether environmental laws were violated. ``It's a horrifying prospect to have your parks commissioner polluting a parks lake,'' said Eugene Fahey, council majority leader. ``We need to know whether it's true.'' Delaware Park is the city's showpiece, laid out by Frederick Law Olmsted, the designer of New York City's Central Park. A big celebration was held in 1986 when skating resumed after a $12 million cleanup of pollution that had kept it from freezing. ``That's the jewel of the city of Buffalo,'' said Councilman Alfred T. Coppola, whose district includes the park. ``We just stocked the lake a couple of years ago, and here ... he's ordering it to be polluted.'' Delano did not return telephone calls seeking comment. His only public comment on the charges has been the letter in which he refused to appear Tuesday before the council's Finance Committee. ``Unfortunately, the news media has made so many false accusations and blown this investigation so far from reality that I was forced to seek the advice of an attorney,'' the letter said. ``He has advised me not to make any statements pertaining to this investigation of my department.'' Mayor James D. Griffin, a longtime friend of Delano, also did not return telephone calls. The mayor has refused to answer reporters' questions about Delano, but has lavishly praised him in speeches and has labeled complaining parks workers ``stool pigeons.''

DOC.HEAD: Five Killed, 42 Injured in Fog-related Accidents
DOC.TEXT: A truck collided with a car in dense fog, killing five people in one of 28 accidents during rush hour on a Southern California highway, police said. As many as 50 vehicles were involved in the accidents on a two-mile section of Highway 99 Tuesday morning, and ambulance crews took about 30 people to area hospitals, the California Highway Patrol said. Another dozen were treated at the scene about 190 miles north of Los Angeles. In the most serious accident, a small truck ran into the back of a car that had just collided with a tractor-trailer. The tractor-trailer had been slowing for another accident, the highway patrol said. The driver of the small truck and four family members in the car, including two small children, were killed when fire engulfed the two vehicles, according to Sgt. Rick Fields. The identities of the victims were not released.

DOC.HEAD: Man Held in Connection With Sexual Assault on Young Girls
DOC.TEXT: A man was arrested for three sexual assaults on young girls a day after an anonymous donor offered $50,000 in rewards to help solve the attacks and others against children in two city neighborhoods. Donald Ray Gray, 34, was charged Tuesday with aggravated sexual assault for three attacks in the last 15 months, the last on Friday, said Dallas County sheriff's Sgt. R.L. Fitzpatrick. Gray was being held held early today in lieu of a $25,000 bond. Deputy Police Chief Lowell Cannaday said the arrest resulted from identification through motor vehicle records. In last week's attack, two children were abducted as they walked to school, driven away and raped and then dropped off near where they had been abducted. The earlier two attacks occurred in similar circumstances, police said. An anonymous donor on Monday offered two $25,000 rewards for information leading to the arrest and indictment of suspects in the attacks and in other attacks on the city's north side, about 20 miles away. ``I would like to think that the reward helped in the case,'' said Cannaday. But he provided no details on how the reward might have helped police. He said investigators would sort out the possible application of the reward money during the next few days. The victims in the Oak Cliff attacks in south Dallas were all black, ages 10 to 15, said Cannaday. He said victims in the north Dallas attacks were white, ages 7 to 10. An assailant there broke into homes late at night and abducted four young girls. The victims were sexually assaulted in three of the cases, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Telephone Company Hopes to Leave Wiretap Case Behind
DOC.TEXT: Cincinnati Bell Telephone Co. said it planned no further action after a jury ruled two former installers defamed the company with allegations of illegal wiretapping, but a judge said perjury changes may be warranted. The eight-member Hamilton County Common Pleas jury on Tuesday found that Robert Draise and Leonard Gates defamed the phone company and two managers by saying Bell had ordered hundreds of illegal wiretaps between 1972 and 1984. Jurors awarded the company and the managers, James West and Peter Gabor, more than $100,000 in compensatory damages. Judge Fred J. Cartolano can add punitive damages. ``My goal now is to look to the future,'' Bell president Dwight Hibbard said at a news conference at company headquarters. ``We've cleared our name. We've cleared the names of the employees involved.'' The company and its supervisors denied any involvement in illegal wiretaps, and sued Draise and Gates for $2 million after they publicized claims they had wiretapped criminal suspects, reporters, judges and political figures, including a U.S. president. Cartolano thanked jurors for settling a long-running public controversy. ``You have now placed Mr. Draise and Mr. Gates before the bar and before the people to be what they are _ thieves,'' Cartolano told jurors. ``They stole the truth.'' The judge said he, too, thought the men had lied. ``I am convinced that you and Mr. Gates have lied profusely,'' Cartolano told Draise. ``I am going to give the transcript to the county prosecutor to decide whether to charge you with perjury.'' The jury reached its verdict in the third day of deliberations, ending a trial that started Nov. 20. The jury awarded the company $10,000 from each of the two former employees; a total of $80,000 to company supervisor Peter Gabor and $10,000 to another manager, James West. The judge can add punitive damages. Compensatory damages are intended to compensate a wronged victim for loss of income, pain and suffering and other actual damages. Punitive damages are intended to punish. After the verdict, Gabor hugged his mother, Magda, and both wept. ``I just wish my wife could have lived long enough to see this,'' said Gabor, whose wife died last week. Gates and Draise said they set 1,200 illegal wiretaps at the instruction of West and Gabor, including one on President Gerald Ford during a 1975 visit to Cincinnati. Phone company lawyers contended the two men were seeking revenge because Bell fired Draise in 1979 and Gates in 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Rehab Clinic Uses Alcoholics Anonymous Method
With PM-Barry-Grand Jury, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The drug rehabilitation center treating Marion Barry stresses physical and spiritual recovery through a method largely developed by Alcoholics Anonymous. It's also a place where tears are inevitable, one graduate of the program said. The mayor of Washington, D.C., checked into the Hanley-Hazelden Center on Monday. Lurma Rackley, a spokeswoman for the mayor, said details about his health would be kept private but ``the most serious problem is alcoholism.'' The 66-bed non-profit clinic opened in 1986 as a satellite unit of the Hazelden Foundation in Center City, Minn. Treatment generally lasts 28 days and costs about $7,500. The foundation won't reveal the names of current or former patients. But famous figures who have said they spent time at the Minnesota clinic include Kitty Dukakis, wife of Massachusetts Gov. Michael Dukakis; former Washington Redskins player Dexter Manley and designer Calvin Klein. The weeks after detoxification are difficult but bearable, said Bill Hetland, a graduate of the Minnesota clinic. ``You're in such a frame of mind, it doesn't take much to get the people to cry,'' he said. The program near Minneapolis was founded 40 years ago by a group of Alcoholics Anonymous members and businessmen concerned about alcoholism among employees and relatives. Its goal, according to a center pamphlet, is to ``help chemically dependent people break through denial and to maintain ongoing abstinence and recovery upon return to the community.'' Depending on the severity of the addiction, patients spend the first day to one week in detoxification in a hospital-like setting. Then, the patient is moved to treatment wards where men and women are kept separate. Each ward holds about 20 people. ``You can have visitors,'' said Brenda Lyles, a former official in the state Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services who was involved in licensing the West Palm Beach center. ``You aren't confined there in the sense that you aren't locked down. The expectation is that you desire to be there for your own treatment.'' The day usually begins by 7 a.m. Patients are assigned chores, such as vacuuming and room inspections before breakfast. The rest of the day is spent watching films or listening to lectures. After each session, patients return to smaller groups for ``processing'' _ going over the content of the day's lesson. All patients keep journals. The rooms contain single beds and white Formica dressers. Television is allowed only during certain hours, and phone calls are discouraged. The entrance to the center's six-acre campus has a string of signs with sayings that include ``Let Go and Let God'' and ``One Day at a Time,'' the motto of Alcoholics Anonymous. State substance-abuse experts praise the Hanley-Hazelden center. ``They have a long record of excellence,'' said John Daigel, executive director of the Tallahassee-based Florida Alcohol and Drug Treatment Association. ``They are a national leader in substance-abuse treatment.'' Barry, in a statement issued Tuesday by his Washington office, asked the media to ``back away'' from the center. He said that he and his family were undergoing a ``demanding and painful ordeal,'' and asked that reporters not make it any worse, ``for the sake of my privacy and that of others.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Praises Anti-Crime Activists in Kansas City
With PM-Bush
DOC.TEXT: President Bush calls this city a model for driving away gangs and drug houses, but anti-crime activists here say the deadly trade won't go away soon. Bush walked with police and community activists Tuesday in a neighborhood where dealers peddled crack cocaine under a basketball hoop until neighbors took down the basket and chased out much of their business. ``What (Bush) really did was give us a pep talk and congratulate us for what we have done _ and acknowledge that there's a long way to go,'' said P. Albert Williams, a member of the Ad Hoc Group Against Crime. The community organization works with law enforcement authorities to close houses used by drug dealers. The federal government estimates that Kansas City ranks sixth in the nation in availability of crack. Ranking 29th in metropolitan population, the city had the ninth-highest murder rate in the country last year, according to FBI figures. ``To me, it's a genocide,'' Williams said. ``If we keep up the drugs, we're going to kill ourselves.'' Police Maj. Sylvester Winston said 45 percent of the city's record 136 homicides last year were drug-related, compared with only 10 percent in 1986. Bush spoke to about 1,300 metropolitan area law enforcement officials in a downtown auditorium, saying cooperation between police and the community could win major battles against drugs. ``People in this town refused to surrender to the drug plague. You took back what's yours. Took back your kids. Took back your streets,'' Bush said. But activists and Bush, himself, said the problem had not been solved in Kansas City. The message was that progress was being made. ``Certainly (Bush's speech) is going to galvanize the crime fighters,'' said Alvin Sykes, leader of a group to help crime victims. ``It's hard to gauge what kind of impact it will have on the drug dealers. They didn't come down here to hear it.'' U.S. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh and federal drug czar William Bennett joined Bush in a meeting with the Ad Hoc Group, which formed about a dozen years ago to ease tensions between blacks and police. Today, the group founded by city human relations Director Alvin Brooks marches around suspected drug houses. Clad in blue windbreakers, they shout down dealers with bullhorns. The group set up a hotline for people to report new houses. ``Our emphasis has been to try to raise the level of awareness and consciousness about what drugs and related crimes and violence are doing to our community, and we attack those crack houses,'' Brooks told the president. Guided by Brooks in an inner-city area, Bush visited a tree with a basketball backboard attached to it. The hoop has been stripped away by neighbors because it attracted drug dealers. Nearby, members of Black Men Together, an anti-crime group affliated with Ad Hoc, demonstrated their chant to harass dealers: ``Change! Change! Change! You better run, dope pusher, better run!'' At the speech to police, Bush stumped for a bill in Congress to reduce constitutional restrictions on the courtroom use of evidence seized illegally _ but in ``good faith'' _ by police. The concept won praise from Terry Storey, a police officer who works with drug-raid teams in suburban Independence. ``It's pretty amazing when we lose cases even when it's pretty obvious that the person's guilty,'' Storey said after the president's speech. ``I've lost cases because of technicalities.''

DOC.HEAD: Former Lynyrd Skynyrd Guitarist Dies
DOC.TEXT: Allen Collins, who lost fellow members of the rock group Lynyrd Skynyrd in a 1977 plane crash and was paralyzed four years ago in a drunken driving accident, died of pneumonia at age 37. Collins suffered respiratory failure Tuesday, said Memorial Medical Center spokeswoman Karen Bowling. He had been hospitalized since September, she said. Collins entered the hospital with pneumonia symptoms and was in a coma for the last few days, said longtime friend Ann Thompson. Ms. Thompson described Collins as the ``most energetic, caring, giving person I ever met.'' Collins began his rise to success as the lightning-fingered guitarist for the Jacksonville band formed in 1966 by a group of high school students. The band enjoyed national fame in the 1970s with such hits as ``Free Bird,'' ``Gimme Three Steps'' and ``Sweet Home Alabama.'' In 1977, lead singer Ronnie Van Zant, guitarist Stevie Gaines and Gaines' sister, Cassie Gaines, were killed in a plane crash. Collins and other band members were severely injured. Two years later, Collins, Gary Rossington, Bill Powell and Leon Wilkeson, all founding members of Lynyrd Skynyrd, joined with Barry Harwood and Dale Krantz to form the Rossington-Collins band. The group split in 1982, and Collins formed the Allen Collins band. In 1986, Collins' car ran off a road and crashed into a culvert, paralyzing him from the waist down and killing his girlfriend, Debra Jean Watts. He pleaded no contest to driving under the influence charges. As part of his sentence, he agreed to spend 50 hours helping get the message to young fans that drinking and driving can be deadly. When Lynyrd Skynryd began its reunion tour in 1987, Collins took to the stage in his wheelchair and told his story. His message was videotaped and played to audiences throughout the tour. Collins is survived by two teen-age daughters, Amie and Allison, his mother and father, and a sister, all of Jacksonville. Funeral arrangements were pending. Ms. Thompson said the family planned a private service.

DOC.HEAD: Government Moves to Protect Noriega Secrets
DOC.TEXT: The potential leak of CIA secrets in the trial of Manuel Noriega has led the government to draw up tough security guidelines that would force defense attorneys to sign oaths and submit their work for review. In another motion filed in U.S. District Court Tuesday, prosecutors asked for more time to go through mounds of documents being uncovered since the Dec. 20 invasion of Panama, according to a published report. Some defense attorneys balked at the proposed regulations, which must be approved by U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler. ``Who's going to decide what is and what isn't classified information _ the government?'' Kenneth Swartz, an assistant federal public defender representing Noriega co-defendant Luis del Cid, said Tuesday. But the motion by Assistant U.S. Attorney Michael P. Sullivan insisted the rules are necessary ``to protect the national security of the United States.'' ``The unauthorized disclosure and uncontrolled dissemination of such information would cause exceptionally grave damage to the national security of the United States,'' it said. The government requested a hearing on its motion, but no date has been set. Noriega is scheduled for a bond hearing Friday. Attorneys for the ousted Panamanian dictator have said they need some documents to counter the government's contentions that he should be denied bail because he was likely to flee. The government said the security guidelines were prompted by a Classified Information Procedures Act notification from Michael O'Kane, attorney for indicted pilot Daniel Miranda, another Noriega co-defendant in the February 1988 drug-trafficking indictment. O'Kane has been outspoken in calling Noriega a tool of the United States who acted with CIA approval. ``The hidden agenda of the government is not to release any of this stuff,'' O'Kane said Tuesday. He acknowledged his search for sensitive documents is designed to force the government's hand. The government's unwillingness to release such information could help free his client, he said. Defense lawyers also criticized the government's motion for more time to produce documents as evidence it is unprepared, The New York Times reported today. But the prosecution motion said, ``Due to the recent events in Panama, evidence is still being gathered and analyzed.'' Also filed Tuesday was a motion for del Cid demanding that he be released from an 4-by-8-foot punishment cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center southwest of Miami. Defense attorney Sam Burstyn said the confinment is cruel and unusual punishment. Noriega, by contrast, ``is being given guest quarters usually reserved for the most elite of federal prisoners,'' Burstyn wrote. ``The facilities that are being occupied by co-defendant Noriega are capable of housing several additional pretrial detainees,'' said the motion, which asked that del Cid be allowed to join his former boss at the federal courthouse apartment cell. Noriega's attorneys, meanwhile, have submitted addresses of two homes and three military offices raided by U.S. troops during last month's invasion of Panama, and are asking for an inventory of all materials taken from them. On Friday, U.S. Magistrate William Turnoff ordered the government to preserve all such evidence and submit a list of everything taken from the sites. The defense list included homes in Panama City and Rio Hato, along with offices at the destroyed Panamanian Defense Force headquarters, the joint U.S.-Panama base at Fort Amador, and the Departmento Nacional de Investigaciones. The Pentagon initially claimed it had confiscated large amounts of cocaine at one Noriega residence, but on Tuesday acknowledged that the wrapped packages were a material, possibly bonding glue, that resembled the powdered drug.

DOC.HEAD: Three-State Salmonella Outbreak Blamed on Tainted Cheese
DOC.TEXT: Contaminated cheese was the sole source of an outbreak of salmonella infection that sickened thousands of people in three states last summer, according to a state Health Department investigation. The outbreak, which officials say may have affected 15,000 residents of Minnesota, Wisconsin and North Dakota, was traced to mozzarella cheese that was contaminated through poor sanitation practices at the now-closed Kasson Cheese plant in Brillion, Wis. The tainted cheese was made into shredded cheese products at three other Wisconsin plants and one in Minnesota, said state epidemiologist Michael Osterholm. Investigators believe the cheese probably was heated enough at the Brillion plant to kill any salmonella present during processing, Osterholm said Tuesday. ``However, there was ample opportunity for contamination of finished cheeses, from employee handling or contaminated work surfaces, before the cheese was packaged,'' he said. Osterholm said employees also indicated ``that sanitation practices had deteriorated at the plant'' last spring, as it faced financial problems. The company filed for protection from creditors in bankruptcy court in May, he said. Telephone calls to the Kasson plant went unanswered Tuesday. A Wisconsin official said he was not certain the entire salmonella outbreak could be traced to the Kasson plant. ``It might have been other food on salad bars'' that made people ill, said Bill Hanson, of the Wisconsin Department of Agriculture, Trade and Consumer Protection's food division. The three other Wisconsin plants implicated by Osterholm in the outbreak has passed inspections, Hanson said. They were the Associated Milk Producers Inc. plant in Portage; Marathon Cheese in Marathon, and Schreiber Foods in Green Bay. Bill Coleman, director of the dairy and livestock division of the Minnesota Department of Agriculture, said no contamination was found at the Pueringer Distributors plant in Rice, Minn. Low levels of the two strains of salmonella blamed for the outbreak were found in two unopened packages of mozzarella produced at the Brillion plant, Osterholm said. The outbreak involved two relatively uncommon forms of salmonella: Salmonella javiana and Salmonella oranienburg. Confirmed cases represent only a fraction of cases that occurred, according to the report. Symptoms included diarrhea, cramps, fever, nausea and vomiting, and most of those who became ill would not have seen a doctor or undergone testing, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down, Gold Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell in early European trading today. Gold prices rose. Foreign currency dealers said the volatility of the past few days may have come to an end and, barring any political developments in the Soviet Union, they expected little movement for the rest of the session. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar fell 0.53 yen to a closing 145.80 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 145.40 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Tuesday: _1.6875 West German marks, down from 1.6965 _1.4930 Swiss francs, down from 1.5070 _5.7560 French francs, down from 5.7625 _1.9028 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9225 _1,255.00 Italian lire, down from 1,262.00 _1.1767 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1780 In London, the dollar fell against the British pound. It cost $1.6583 to buy one pound, compared with $1.6480 late Tuesday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $414.10 a troy ounce, up from $413.00 bid late Tuesday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $413.75. In Zurich, the bid price was $413.50, up from $408.50 bid late Tuesday. The Hong Kong gold market was closed today for the Lunar New Year holidays. Silver fell in London to a bid price of $5.28 a troy ounce from Tuesday's $5.32.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Disallows Statement in Racial Attack
DOC.TEXT: The videotaped statements of one of the murder defendants in the slaying of a black youth by a white gang cannot be used in court because he was not advised of his right to remain silent, a judge ruled. Justice Thaddeus Owens issued the ruling at a pretrial hearing Tuesday in Brooklyn's state Supreme Court. Pasquale Raucci, 19, one of six youths charged with second-degree murder and other crimes in the Aug. 23 shooting death of 16-year-old Yusuf Hawkins, made two statements to police early in the morning after the killing. Later that day, he made a videotaped statement to a prosecutor. Detective Michael Bisogna, who brought Raucci in for questioning, said Tuesday that Raucci was not advised of his right to remain silent because he was not under arrest and detectives considered him a witness, not a suspect. Owens replied he could not accept Bisogna's explanation. ``If you believe Detective Bisogna didn't know, then you believe in the tooth fairy,'' the judge said. In a 15-minute statement taped the day after the attack and played in court Monday, Raucci told prosecutors he had played a role in the attack, but said he was at the rear of the pack of rampaging young men. Prosecutors want the videotape and other police statements of the defendants submitted as evidence, but defense attorneys contend investigators failed to notify the youths they had the right to remain silent. The defendants, all white, are charged with attacking Hawkins and three of his companions, all black, when they went to the mostly white Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn to look at a used car.

DOC.HEAD: Shouting ``Banzai,'' Japan's Parliament Gears Up for Election
LaserPhoto TOK6
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 9th pvs, `At the...' to UPDATE with color from election headquarters. Picks up 10th pvs, `The Liberal...' INSERTS 1 graf after 24th pvs, `The Socialists...' to UPDATE with Socialists' statement. Picks up 25th pvs, `The Liberal...'
DOC.TEXT: Lawmakers shouted ``Banzai!'' as Parliament's lower house was dissolved today to make way for elections next month in which the once-invincible but scandal-plagued Liberal Democrats may lose their majority. Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, who took office in August after two disgraced predecessors resigned, told fellow party members after parliament dissolved that it was their duty to ``restore the people's confidence in our party.'' Shortly after the session began, Speaker of the House Hajime Tamura read an imperial edict written on parchment declaring the house dissolved. The legislators then shouted three resounding ``Banzais,'' _ literally ``10,000 Years,'' a wish for long life _ and disbanded. The 10-minute session allowed legislators just enough time to pass a bill on subsidies for rice growers and to approve plans for Emperor Akihito's younger son, Prince Aya, to marry commoner Kiko Kawashima this spring. The Cabinet met later and said it would officially announce on Feb. 3 that the election will be held Feb. 18. It was up to the 59-year-old Kaifu, a former education minster, to decide when to dissolve the lower house. He was believed to have wanted a later election date so he could make a major policy address to Parliament, but gave in to the wishes of party leaders with more clout. An election must be held by July, when the current four-year term of lower house members expires. Pressure for an early election has been building for a year as the Liberal Democrats became mired in scandals, and party leaders apparently chose mid-February to get the election out of the way before legislators become bogged down with the national budget, which must be passed by April 1. At the Liberal Democrats' headquarters today, each of the party's 270 incumbent candidates received a certificate of endorsement, a handshake from Kaifu and a brown paper bag of cash for campaign expenses. The legislators left laden with bags of new 10,000-yen ($70) notes. Legislators who have served in Cabinet posts said they received about $100,000 and those who hadn't got about $170,000 because they need more public exposure. Party officials said about $35,000 was a cash gift and the remainder was a loan. In Japan, even large transactions are often carried out in cash. The Liberal Democrats, who have governed Japan continuously for 34 years, could lose their majority in the lower house and with it the right to govern. In July, they lost control of the less powerful upper house as voters registered dissatisfaction over bribery and sex scandals and an unpopular sales tax. Taking responsibiilty for the loss, Prime Minister Sosuke Uno then resigned after just two months in office and Kaifu was the surprise choice for party leader. He is widely considered an interim leader. The upper house majority is held by opposition parties led by Japan Socialist Party leader Takako Doi, but it is the leader of the majority party in the lower house who traditionally becomes prime minister. The Liberal Democrats face a tough challenge in retaining the 295-seat majority they have held in the 512-seat lower house since July 1986, although recent public opinion polls have showed support for the governing party outweighing support for the opposition. A poll released Tuesday by the national newspaper Asahi Shimbun showed 49 percent of those surveyed supported the Liberal Democrats while 30 percent supported the Socialists. The Asahi did not give a margin of error for the survey of 3,000 people. Numerically, the Liberal Democrats are almost certain to outnumber any other party after the election.
