More than 300 Liberal Democrats are likely to run, while the Socialists are fielding just 160 candidates _ well below the number needed to secure a solid majority. While the opposition has a chance to form a combined majority in the lower house, analysts say ideological differences make unlikely a Socialist-led coalition with the second- and third-largest groups, the centrist Komeito (Clean Government Party) and Democratic Socialist Party. The centrists are more likely to side with the Liberal Democrats, the analysts say. Party sources say the Liberal Democrats have been negotiating behind the scenes to gain Komeito and Democratic Socialist support if necessary after the election. The Socialists currently hold 83 lower house seats, the Komeito 54, Japan Communist Party 26 and the Democratic Socialists 25. The remaining 29 seats are held by minor parties and independents or are vacant. The Socialists and the other major opposition parties met this afternoon and declared their determination to end Liberal Democrat rule, abolish the sales tax and cooperate ahead of the election. The Liberal Democrats have been struggling to restore their popularity since many party leaders became entangled in the Recruit scandal, in which over 150 members of the nation's elite were alleged to have profited from sales of shares supplied by Recruit Co., an information services conglomerate. Allegations of influence-buying led to Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita's resignation and, coupled with the unpopular sales tax introduced in April, contributed to the Liberal Democratic defeat in the upper house. The February election is widely seen as an opportunity for Japanese voters to pass judgment on the Liberal Democrats.

DOC.HEAD: Police Protest Army's Presence, Refuse to Work
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to UPDATE with strikers to return to work. Picks up 3rd pvs, `At least...' SUBS grafs 9-10, `Hitendra Narain...' with 2 grafs of details. Pick up 11th pvs, `Simmering tension...'
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of policemen waving rifles and shouting ``Death to the Indian army'' refused to work today, hampering government efforts to halt a violent Moslem separatist movement in Kashmir. By mid-afternoon the strikers agreed to go back to work, a police official and a strike leader said. At least 57 people, mostly Moslem militants, have been killed since the government on Saturday launched a crackdown on militant secessionists who want to become independent or merge with Moslem Pakistan. Jammu-Kashmir is the only Moslem-dominated state in predominantly Hindu India. About 64 percent of the mountainous northern state's 5 million people are Moslems. One death was reported today. A Moslem militant was killed when paramilitary forces, fearing imminent attack, opened fire on a mob, a senior police official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The striking policemen, many in the brown uniforms of the state constabulary, stopped police vehicles in the streets and urged their colleagues to join the protest. Head Constable Mohammad Iqbal, one of the striking policemen, said at least a third of the 40,000-man force had refused to report for duty to protest the deployment of the Indian army to control the agitation. ``This is the beginning of a new chapter in Kashmir,'' he said. ``We have been driven to the wall so we are reacting.'' A total of about 1,000 policemen were seen in three separate groups stopping cars driven by other policemen. One group of about 300 shouted: ``Death to the Indian army'' and ``Indians go back.'' Hitendra Narain Saxena, the top police official in Jammu-Kashmir state, said at mid-afternoon that the strikers had agreed to return to work. One of the strike leaders, constable Mohammad Afzal, said the strike had been postponed until Saturday. Simmering tension between Kashmir police and federal troops flared Sunday after a policeman was shot and killed by soldiers enforcing an around-the-clock curfew in Srinagar. Officers in Srinagar and a senior government spokesman in New Delhi said the killing was an accident. The striking policemen did not openly express support for the escalating Moslem secessionist movement but one said: ``The government calls us terrorists. If that is the case, why should we fire at our own people ?'' He spoke on condition of anonymity. About 300 protesting policeman marched to police headquarters. ``They (the government) call us Pakistani dogs. We are not ... Let the Indian army and others know we will smash them if they confront us,'' constable Mohammad Afzal told the crowd. Srinagar's police inspector general, Mohammad Azhar Nomani, appealed to the men to return to duty and to come to him with any grievances. Climbing atop his jeep, Nomani told the crowd: ``Don't get agitated. Don't get provoked.'' Afzal said the strikers had two demands: that the army and other federal troops leave Kashmir and the government re-instate a police union dissolved in 1979. Authorities said federal troops were patrolling the city but, to avoid confrontation, had been ordered not to leave their vehicles. An around-the-clock curfew confining people to their homes was lifted temporarily this morning. It had been scheduled to be lifted for four hours but was restored after just one hour because of the police situation, a government official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. On Tuesday, India repeated charges that Islamic Pakistan was fomenting trouble in Kashmir, but Pakistan again denied the charge. The two countries have a history of animosity and have fought three wars, two of them over Kashmir, since they gained independence from Britain in 1947. The last war was in 1971. A cease-fire line dividing Kashmir into Indian and Pakistani sectors is monitored by United Nations military observers. Nationwide, Moslems form 12 percent of India's 880 million peoeple and Hindus make up 82 percent. Srinagar, the largest city in the Kashmir Valley, is the summer capital of Jammu-Kashmir state. The Kashmir region is mostly Moslem, while the southern Jammu region is predominantly Hindu.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS surname of Reynolds' father in last graf of 2nd item; Separate moved on Collins as a0501 for PMs.
DOC.TEXT: Charley Eugene Johns, who was governor of Florida for 15 months in the mid-1950s, died Tuesday after a lengthy illness. He was 84. Johns became governor in 1953 after the death of Gov. Daniel Thomas McCarty. He was elected 14 times to the state Senate and once to the House, and served as Senate president in 1953. Johns was also the founder and former president of the Community State Bank in his hometown, where he also operated an insurance agency.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C. (AP) _ John Dillard Reynolds, grandson of former tobacco industry executive R.J. Reynolds, fell to his death from a hotel's 11th-floor balcony outside Orlando, Fla., on Monday. He was 54. Spokesmen for the Orange County Sheriff's Department said witnesses saw Reynolds climb the balcony and prepare to jump. Patrick Reynolds, a half-brother whose book, ``The Gilded Leaf,'' chronicles three generations of the Reynolds family, described John as a ``dear, sweet, good'' person who was the victim of a dysfunctional family. He was the second of four sons born to Richard J. Reynolds Jr. and his first wife, Elizabeth Dillard Reynolds.

Allen Collins, who lost fellow members of his rock group Lynyrd Skynyrd in a 1977 plane crash and was paralyzed four years ago in a drunken driving accident that killed his girlfriend, died Tuesday from pneumonia at age 37. Collins began his rise to success as the lightning-fingered guitarist for the Jacksonville band formed in 1966 by a group of Lee High School students. The band rose to national fame in the 1970s with such hits as ``Free Bird,'' ``Gimme Three Steps'' and ``Sweet Home Alabama.'' In 1977, lead guitarist Ronnie Van Zant, guitarist Stevie Gaines and Gaines' sister, Cassie Gaines, were killed in a plane crash. Collins and other band members were severely injured. Two years later, Collins, Gary Rossington, Bill Powell and Leon Wilkeson, all founding members of Lynyrd Skynyrd, joined with Barry Harwood to form the Rossington-Collins band. The group split in 1982, and Collins formed the Allen Collins band.

Flor Morales ``Ramito'' Ramos, 74, one of Puerto Rico's most famous folk singers, shot himself in the head Tuesday. Ramos, who had 18 children from six marriages, performed in dozens of countries and recorded more than 50 records in his 40-year career. He sang for Puerto Ricans serving in the U.S. Army during World War II and entertained during the Korean and Vietnam wars. Among his most popular songs were ``El Apagon de Nueva York'' (New York Blackout), ``Estrella de Oriente'' (East Star) and ``No Cambio A Puerto Rico'' (I Won't Change Puerto Rico).

Mariano Rumor, a former five-time Christian Democrat premier who led coalition governments in the tumultuous 1960s and 1970s, died Monday of a heart attack. He was 74. Rumor served in the Italian army from 1940 to 1943, and then joined the underground resistance movement to fight the German occupiers. After the war, Rumor joined the ranks of the Christian Democrats. He was first elected to Parliament in 1948, and appointed to his first Cabinet post _ agriculture _ in 1959. In 1963, he succeeded Aldo Moro as secretary of the Christian Democrats, traditionally a stepping stone to the premiership. In 1976, a year after his last premiership ended, he was investigated for suspected involvement in the 1969 Lockheed payoff scandal involving the U.S. aircraft company. Parliament cleared him of any wrongdoing. He also was exonerated of any participation in a coverup linked to the 1969 bombing of a Milan bank in which 16 people were killed. The bombing was blamed on neo-fascists.

Gabriel Estavao Monjane, the world's tallest man, died after a fall at his home in Maputo, Mozambique at age 45. Monjane began a career as a circus performer in 1967, gaining international fame as the ``Mozambique Giant.'' He was 8 feet, } inches, according to the Guinness Book of Records.

David G. Egbert, a sports writer at The (Findlay) Courier for almost 20 years, died Monday of natural causes at age 42. Egbert joined The Courier in 1970 as a general assignment reporter and moved to the sports department in September 1971. He covered Findlay High School sports for the newspaper and was named Ohio sports writer of the year by the Ohio Prep Sports Writers Association in 1977 and 1979. Survivors include his mother, LaVanne Egbert, and a sister, Barbara A. Ford, both of Findlay.

Richard E. Rentz Sr., former president, publisher and chairman of the New Castle News, died Tuesday after a short illness. He was 73. Following his father's death in 1954, Rentz took over as The News Co. president and publisher, positions he held for the next 30 years. He was chairman of the board from 1984 until 1988, when Lincoln Publishing bought the paper. Rentz is survived by his wife, Thelma; two sons, Richard and James, and one daughter, Gretchen Reynolds, all of New Castle; one brother and six grandchildren.

William H. Metcalfe, a pioneer Canadian journalist who was managing editor of the country's first co-operative newspaper and of the Winnipeg Free Press and Ottawa Journal, died Monday at age 83. His first job was with the Winnipeg Free Press, where he worked as a reporter and copy editor. In 1948, he took over as managing editor of the fledgling Winnipeg Citizen, owned by 13,000 member-shareholders. The paper was born out of discontent after the Winnipeg pressmen's strike of 1945, but lasted only one year before going bankrupt. Metcalfe rejoined the Free Press as an editorial writer in 1949 and became managing editor in 1952. He became managing editor of the Journal in 1960. Both papers were part of the old FP Publications chain of newspapers. He retired in 1972. In 1985, he published an autobiography, The View from Thirty.

DOC.HEAD: Azerbaijanis Gather at Iran-Soviet Border, Start Building Bridge
With PM-Soviet-Unrest, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of Soviet Azerbaijanis gathered along the Iranian frontier and some started building a new border bridge across the Araks river, Iran's official news agency said today. The Islamic Republic News Agency said women television announcers in the Azerbaijani border enclave of Nakhichevan wore black headscarves Tuesday, apparently in mourning for ``victims of the Baku carnage.'' The report came as Soviet military authorities banned demonstrations and strikes in Baku, the capital of Soviet Azerbaijan, and arrested 43 suspected activists. Soviet troops moved into Baku over the weekend to crush a nationalist uprising in Azerbaijan and end bloody ethnic clashes between Azerbaijanis and mostly Christian Armenians. Most Azerbaijanis, whose historic homeland extends into Iran, are Shiite Moslems, the predominant religion in Iran. Thousands of Soviet Azerbaijanis, bound by language, culture and religion to their Iranian kin, have crossed the border since the violence began. The Iranian news agency, monitored in Cyprus, said about 300 people gathered Tuesday on the Soviet side of the border about 12 miles west of the frontier town of Poldasht. Twenty-eight Soviet armored personnel carriers patrolled a military road that runs along the border, it said. About six miles farther west, Soviet troops stopped Azerbaijanis from building a bridge across the Araks river Tuesday, the agency reported. But following ``a gathering by the people and their ultimatum to the Soviet forces,'' the building work was later resumed and a section of bridge foundations was laid, it said. Soviet forces continued to observe the operation from a nearby village, the agency reported. Moscow Radio, clearly telling the Iranians not to interfere in Azerbaijan, declared on Tuesday: ``Any unconsidered nationalistic or religious appeals would be dangerous.... Brutal and illusory nationalistic flights of fancy have dragged the people to the brink of the precipice.'' The Soviets fear that Iran, whose religious leaders see it as the champion of the world's 1 billion Moslems, is becoming increasingly caught up in the crisis in Soviet Azerbaijan. In an earlier report, Tehran radio said 160 of the 270 members of Iran's parliament called on Moscow to treat the Azerbaijani Moslems with compassion. Parliament speaker Mahdi Karrubi, a staunch advocate of exporting Iran's revolutionary brand of Islam, on Sunday condemned Moscow for the crackdown in Azerbaijan and warned that Soviet actions could ``create more problems for the Soviet Union.'' Moscow radio, calling for restraint by Iran, accused Karrubi by name of ``political blindness'' in its Persian language newscast.

DOC.HEAD: Key Developments Leading Up to Japanese General Election
DOC.TEXT: Here are key dates leading to Wednesday's decision to dissolve the lower house of Parliament and hold a general election in Japan: 1988 June _ News of a scandal emerges affecting top leaders of the governing Liberal Democratic Party as well as other influential people who profited in bargain-priced share deals. The Recruit scandal, named after the Recruit Co. conglomerate, leads to accusations of bribery. Oct. 20 _ A Recruit official is arrested on charges of trying to bribe an opposition lawmaker to soft-pedal his investigation of the scandal. Nov. 16 _ A list of 26 politicians and government officials who received Recruit shares is released in Parliament, embarrassing Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita and other party leaders who were named. Nov. 17 _ The government pushes through Parliament its bill to impose a 3 percent tax on sales, which proves unpopular even though coupled with reductions in income taxes and other levies. Dec. 9 _ Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa resigns after repeatedly changing his explanation of an aide's Recruit stock purchases. 1989 Feb. 13 _ Recruit Co. founder Hiromasa Ezoe is arrested. April 11 _ Prime Minister Takeshita acknowledges he received the equivalent of more than $1 million in political donations from Recruit Co. April 25 _ Takeshita announces he will resign, and his secretary commits suicide a day later. June 2 _ Foreign Minister Sousuke Uno becomes prime minster and promises political reform, but inside a week his standing is threatened by published allegations he kept paid mistresses. July 23 _ An election for half the members of the upper house of Parliament results in a defeat for the Liberal Democrats, who lose their majority in the less-powerful chamber for the first time in 34 years. Uno says he will resign to take responsibility. Aug. 10 _ Toshiki Kaifu, a former education minister with no personal power base in the governing party, is named prime minster, the fourth to hold the post since the last lower house election in July 1986, when Yasuhiro Nakasone headed the government. Nov. 12 _ The opposition majority in the upper house passes a bill to abolish the unpopular new sales tax. It is the first instance in 43 years of either house passing legislation opposed by the government, and the move increases pressure for an early election. Nov. 24 _ Six separate trials start for 12 defendants in the Recruit scandal, including two members of Parliament, on bribery charges. The trials are expected to last through most of 1990. 1990 Jan. 8-18 _ Prime Minister Kaifu makes a whirlwind tour of countries in East and West Europe as politicians at home indicate that Feb. 18 will be the date to elect a new lower house of Parliament. Jan. 24 _ The lower house _ the more powerful house as it chooses the prime minister _ is dissolved and the election date is set for Feb. 18.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Air Force Jet Crashes, Pilot's Fate Unknown
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. Air Force F-15 jetfighter crashed today in the South China Sea about 50 miles northwest of Clark Air Base, and the pilot is missing, the U.S. Air Force said. An Air Force statement said the aircraft was taking part in the Cope Thunder exercise when it crashed about 8:10 a.m. Search and rescue planes from Clark Ai Base and the Cubi Point naval air station were sent to search for the pilot, the statement said. The name of the pilot was not released, but the Air Force said the jet was assigned to the 18th Tactical Fighter Wing at Kadena Air Base in Japan. Cope Thunder began Jan. 14 and ends Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Bundy's Final Confessions: Gamble Or Sincere?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with four grafs to fix noun-verb agreement in lead, typo in `Bundy' in 4th graf, `He had ...'; PICKS UP 5th graf, `But Dennis ...'
DOC.TEXT: The motive behind a series of final-hour confessions by serial killer Ted Bundy remains a mystery today, the first anniversary of his death in Florida's electric chair. Homicide investigators still question whether Bundy's confessions in 23 killings in Washington state, Idaho, Utah and Colorado shortly before his execution were merely a desperate gamble to prolong his life. An investigator with the attorney general's office in Washington said Bundy was trying to ``save his neck'' by exchanging information for time. ``He had two things in mind. One was to get law enforcement to intervene with the governor by saying he'd been cooperative and we need more time and the other was to play on the sympathies of the victims' relatives to have them contact the governor and speak on his behalf,'' said Bob Keppel, who interviewed Bundy in the days before the execution. But Dennis Couch, a Utah investigator, said by the time he talked with Bundy 36 hours before the execution, the serial killer ``looked like a whipped puppy. ``I had the feeling that he knew he was defeated and it was the end of the line,'' said Couch, of Salt Lake County. ``I felt at the time that he was sincere in trying to find the bodies for the families.'' In the end, the confessions won the former law-school student no extra time. He was strapped into electric chair on Jan. 24, 1989, for the 1978 kidnaping, rape and murder of a 12-year-old Lake County girl. Her body was found in an abandoned pigsty. He also was condemned for the slaying of two young women in a sorority in Tallahassee. Diana Weiner, an attorney who arranged the final interviews with investigators, said the day before his death Bundy filed a written request for a 30- to 60-day extension with the governor's office. He had offered to fully answer questions of investigators and be examined by doctors and psychiatrists in hopes they could better understand his behavior, Weiner said. ``He wanted to die having left a more full understanding with the public of what the underlying factors were in his behavior so that we as a society ... would be able to take steps to prevent the kind of behavior he committed,'' she said. Gov. Bob Martinez, who signed the death warrant Jan. 19, did not respond to the request. Investigators in Idaho, Washington and Utah said the information given by Bundy in his final days has not led them to any more bodies but helped tie Bundy to killings and disappearances. ``I think he just confirmed what circumstantial evidence we in the state of Washington assumed all along _ that he was the killer. We did not find any remains,'' Keppel said. Keppel said Bundy admitted to 11 slayings in Washington, but they had only tied him to eight. Bundy also told Utah authorities where he left three bodies. ``I wish we could have found something _ some kind of remains of some bodies. That's the frustrating part about the whole thing. I had a lot of hope there,'' Couch said. Jim Whitehead, chief of the Idaho Bureau of Investigation, said Bundy confirmed the slaying of a 12-year-old Pocatello girl, who authorities had suspected he had killed. Bundy also told officers about the slaying of a hitchhiker near Boise. No bodies were found. He also confessed to killings in Colorado. The FBI is working with local law enforcement agencies to try to develop a time line by tracking Bundy's travels using credit card receipts, arrest records and other documents. Bill Hagmaier, supervisory agent for the FBI's National Center for the Analysis of Violent Crime in Quantico, Va., said the profile and time line should be completed in two months. Hagmaier, who sat in on all the final law enforcement interviews, said Bundy gave information until minutes before his death. He confessed to 23 killings and gave information that authorities said might link him to other cases. ``The bottom line was, he said, `I did it because I enjoyed doing it and I wanted to do it,''' Hagmaier said of Bundy's motives for the killings. ``If there were two things that Bundy did in 10 years he spent on death row _ one was try to understand himself and others like him and the other was to trying to prolong his life,'' he said. ``He was a student of his own behavior.''

DOC.HEAD: Grand Jury Investigating Perjury Allegation: Sources
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs pvs 15th graf, The Washington, with sources now saying indictment not expected soon
DOC.TEXT: Grand jury testimony by a former model who helped the FBI arrest Mayor Marion Barry in a cocaine sting is part of an investigation of possible perjury by the mayor, law enforcement sources say. Rasheeda Moore, 38, testified for 2{ hours on Tuesday in the investigation of whether Barry lied under oath by denying he used drugs, the sources say. Ms. Moore, identified by law enforcement sources as the woman who cooperated with the FBI in last week's arrest of Barry on a cocaine possession charge, testified in secret. She has recently told investigators about using crack cocaine with Barry on numerous occasions during a lengthy romantic relationship, said the sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Ms. Moore's accounts of drug use with Barry during a weekend trip to the Virgin Islands in 1988 back up testimony by convicted drug dealer Charles Lewis, who also is cooperating with the investigation, according to the sources. Lewis, who Friday received a 15-month prison term for cocaine conspiracy, has testified he bought drugs for Barry and smoked crack cocaine with him in a downtown hotel in Washington and during the March 1988 weekend in the Virgin Islands. The year-long investigation of Barry was touched off by reports that the mayor was in Lewis's room at the downtown Ramada Inn on Dec. 22, 1988, when city police went to investigate reports Lewis was selling drugs. The officers abruptly and inexplicably left the hotel after learning the mayor was in Lewis' room. Last Thursday, the mayor was videotaped by FBI agents smoking a small amount of crack cocaine after purchasing the drug during a visit to Ms. Moore's room at the Vista International Hotel, according to sources. The mayor was arrested and later charged with misdemeanor possession of cocaine by FBI agents who monitored the episode on a surveillance camera in an adjacent room. Ms. Moore began cooperating with the investigation several weeks ago following her arrest in the Los Angeles area on a charge of driving while intoxicated, according to one source. The sting operation was approved at the highest levels of the FBI and was carefully planned to avoid any defense claims the mayor was entrapped, according to sources. The mayor, in sworn grand jury testimony last year, denied allegations of drug use, said the sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity. An undercover operation to catch the mayor on a misdemeanor drug charge would not have been approved if there had not been suspicions that Barry lied to the grand jury when questioned about drug use, the sources said. One source said an indictment from the grand jury was not expected soon, adding that the panel had to consider a complicated set of evidence. FBI agents instructed Ms. Moore not to suggest drug use and she was told not to use crack cocaine herself, sources said. Barry inquired about getting some drugs shortly after he entered the room, according to court papers. U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens indicated last Friday that more charges were likely to be brought in ``an ongoing investigation of a broader range of allegations our office has been pursuing since last January, following the Ramada Inn incident.'' The prosecutor said he viewed Barry's arrest ``not as the end of an event but as part of an ongoing investigation.'' The probe, sources say, also is focusing on allegations of contract fraud in the District of Columbia government, where several of the mayor's top associates have been convicted of federal corruption charges in the last five years, sources say. Prosecutors, meanwhile, opposed a request by Barry's lawyers to suspend weekly drug testing of the mayor, who checked into a West Palm Beach, Fla., drug rehabilitation center on Monday. The prosecution team filed court papers suggesting the mayor undergo tests at a federal pre-trial services office near the drug clinic where he is staying.

DOC.HEAD: Libyan Plane Searched After Tip Terrorists Were Aboard
DOC.TEXT: A Libyan airliner left Frankfurt airport today after West German authorities held the plane for several hours following a tip that terrorists may be aboard, officials said. Roland Bachmeier, a spokesman for the West German Interior Ministry, said three passengers were detained for carrying arms without permits, then released when it turned out they were the airline's security guards. The Libyan Airlines Boeing 727 left Frankfurt for Tripoli after the three guards rejoined the plane, Frankfurt Airport spokesman Wolfgang Schwalm said. Government officials refused to explain who told them that terrorists may have been aboard the plane, but security sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said: ``Nothing was found to confirm the warning.'' West German border police searched the plane shortly after it arrived in Frankfurt from Tripoli on Tuesday. The luggage of all 75 passengers was also closely inspected. No other weapons were found during the search. A Foreign Ministry spokesman denied Libyan reports that West German police mistreated some passengers during the search.

DOC.HEAD: Boy Accused of Raping 5-Year-Old Stepsister After Watching TV Sex Scene
DOC.TEXT: A 12-year-old raped his 5-year-old stepsister after watching a sex scene on television, authorities said. The boy, whose name was withheld because of his age, was charged Tuesday with rape, incest and lewd and lascivious acts on a child under 14. He was to appear in court today for a hearing on whether he should be released to his parents. The boy was taken into custody Sunday after the girl told her parents what happened and they took her to a hospital, police said. Hospital officials contacted police after finding that the child had been raped, police said. ``The boy told us that he assaulted his stepsister twice late Sunday afternoon while his parents were out shopping,'' said Lt. Thomas Hull. ``He said he got the idea while watching TV either the day before or earlier at his aunt's house.'' It was not known what program the boy watched, Hull said. If convicted, the boy could receive up to eight years in juvenile custody.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Minister Resigns in Argentina
DOC.TEXT: The defense minister abruptly resigned today in a disgreement with the army chief of staff. The minister, Italo Luder, quit after telling a radio station he had ordered the chief of staff, Gen. Isidro Caceres, to be disciplined for arranging a meeting last week with the president that exluded Luder. Caceres discussed military problems, including internal security, at the dinner meeting with President Carlos Menem and other top aides, Luder told Radio Mitre. ``I was in the city ... and did not know of the meal,'' he said. For that, Caceres ``merits a sanction,'' Luder said. There was no immediate response from Caceres, who helped the government of former President Raul Alfonsin put down the Villa Martelli army insurrection led by then-Col. Mohamed Seineldin in December 1988. Luder met with Menem this morning. Afterward, he told reporters he handed the president his ``undeclinable'' resignation. There was no immediate comment from Menem. The dispute comes at a time when the government has failed to solve several problems in the military, including low pay for soldiers, poor equipment, and a budget so small that the number of conscripts this year was reduced. Also, the army remains divided between a nationalist sector that staged three insurrections against Alfonsin between April 1987 and December 1988, and a sector led by Caceres that is loyal to the government. In October, Menem tried to resolve the thorny problem of officers accused of kidnapping, torture and murder during the 1976-83 dictatorship by pardoning several hundred, along with several dozen alleged left-wing subversives. Menem, who took office in July, said the pardon was necessary to achieve national conciliation, but he did not extend it to the former commanders of the juntas during the last dictatorship who not only were accused but prosecuted, convicted and sentenced. Caceres and other army leaders have publicly stated in recent weeks that the commanders should be freed from prison.

DOC.HEAD: Dissident Alliance Pledges to Fight New Party
With PM-Japan, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with dissident alliance announcing nationwide drive to oppose new party, differences emerging over leadership. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The largest dissident alliance today pledged a nationwide drive to stop President Roh Tae-woo's governing party and two opposition parties from joining forces to create a single conservative party. Differences were reported today as talks began on how to complete the merger. Officials involved in the negotiations said there was disagreement over who should lead the new party, which is to be inaugurated in May. The move, announced after talks Monday between Roh and opposition leaders Kim Young-sam and Kim Jong-pil, will join the governing Democratic Justice Party with the nation's No. 2 and 3 opposition groups, led by the two Kims. The new party, tentatively called the Democratic Liberal Party, would be the first in Korea's modern history formed by ruling and opposition parties. Police today said hundreds of officers were mobilized to protect the two Kims, whose homes and offices have been flooded with threatening telephone calls since the announcement. Roh says a new broad-based governing party will give the country the political stability it has never had, but some fear it will radicalize the opposition and cause anti-government violence. The United National Democratic Movement, the nation's umbrella dissident organization involving about 200 groups, agreed to launch a nationwide movement with ``all democratic forces'' opposing the new party, a spokesman said. The alliance played a key role in months of street protests that forced the government to carry out broad reforms in 1987. The spokesman, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the alliance was ready to work with radical students, workers and Kim Dae-jung, whose opposition Party for Peace and Democracy will be hurt by the merger. It called for immediate elections to form a new National Assembly. Kim Dae-jung has pledged to collect 10 million signatures on petitions calling for new elections to block creation of the new party. A 15-member working committee was formed today to discuss procedures on the merger of Roh's party with Kim Young-sam's Reunification Democratic Party and Kim Jong-pil's New Democratic Republican Party. Officials involved said there were differences over how to compose the new party's leadership and hierachy. Members of Kim Young-sam's party want their leader to head the new party and supervise its affairs, while governing party officials support a collective leadership controlled by Roh, the officials said. Roh defeated Kim Young-sam in the 1987 presidential election by a narrow margin. The merger could be a major victory for Roh, who will be assured of a two-thirds majority in the opposition-controlled National Assembly. But it could cause serious repercussions by isolating the Party for Peace and Democracy, the nation's most radical and largest opposition group. The party controls the underprivileged Cholla provinces, where one-fifth of the nation's 42 million people live. Kwangju, the scene of a civil uprising in 1980 that left 200 people dead by official count, is the capital of South Cholla province. The merger also could enliven dissident movements and touch off a new wave of violent anti-government demonstrations. Kim Dae-jung has declared a virtual political war against the Roh government, announcing that ``Our party is prepared to make any sacrifice to block the one-party dictatorship.'' Dissidents and radical students, denouncing the new party as an attempt by a pro-U.S. military dictatorship to prolong its power, also promised to fight. The planned merger came as a surpise. The two centrist opposition parties had been discussing a possible merger, but few expected Roh's governing group to join them. The merger generally is viewed as a result of Roh's desire for political stability by obtaining a parliamentary majority, coupled with the two Kims' ambitions for post-Roh leadership. Roh steps down in early 1993 at the end of a single five-year term. His party has been in an uncomfortable situation since losing its parliamentary majority in the 1988 elections for the first time in South Korea's 40-year constitutional history. Observers think Roh's dislike of Kim Dae-jung swayed him to choose the other two Kims as his merger partners. Roh, as an army general, helped former President Chun Doo-hwan seize power with military backing in an internal coup in 1980. Under the martial law government, controlled by Roh and Chun, Kim Dae-jung was given the death penalty on what he called ``trumped-up sedition charges'' in 1980. The sentence was later commuted to life in prison, and the opposition leader was freed a few years later under U.S. pressure.

DOC.HEAD: Retired Grocery Clerk Faces War Crimes Trial
DOC.TEXT: A retired grocery clerk charged with Nazi war crimes was ordered extradited to West Germany after waiving his right to a hearing. ``He just wants to get it over with,'' attorney Ronald G. Parker said of Bruno Karl Blach's decision. The 70-year-old Blach, imprisoned since October, has been accused by West German authorities of murdering three concentration camp inmates during a forced march between Nazi camps in 1945. Blach maintains his innocence. He was to be flown immediately to West Germany for trial, authorities said. Blach becomes only the fourth alleged Nazi war criminal to be extradited from the United States since 1973 when the U.S. government began searching out such people, said Murray Stein, senior counsel with the U.S. Department of Justice. Parker said he believed Blach could have fought extradition on technical grounds and won, but he said Blach knew other legal efforts would follow. Blach, a native of Czechoslovakia and a permanent resident of the United States with a West German passport, lived suburban La Habra until his arrest in October. Blach, who entered the United States in 1956, was ordered deported in 1987 but an appeal is still pending. During an emotional deportation hearing, a concentration camp survivor identified Blach as the Nazi guard who used a machine gun to kill an elderly Polish Jew who faltered during the forced march between the Wiender Neudorf concentration camp in Germany to the Mauthausen camp in Austria. Parker said that unlike three war criminals who were extradited and convicted, Blach was not in a position of power during the war. ``He was, at most, a private first-class,'' he said. The others extradited were Hermine Braunsteiner Ryan, a former concentration camp guard who became a homemaker on Long Island, N.Y.; Andrija Artukovic, a Los Angeles man convicted of ordering the deaths of several hundred people while serving as a cabinet minister in the Nazi puppet state of Croatia, and John Demjanjuk of Cleveland, who was extradited to Israel and convicted of mass murders at the Treblinka death camp in Poland.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Balks At Talking With Communists, Increased Calls for Unity
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To UPDATE with comments by British foreign minister, insert 3 grafs after 12th pvs, `The delay...' Pickup 13th pvs, `The Communist...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY9
DOC.TEXT: Opposition forces have postponed talks with Premier Hans Modrow on entering his caretaker government, indicating their reluctance to be associated with the still-dominant but increasingly unpopular Communists. In the latest demonstration of East Germans' growing impatience with the authorities, more than 10,000 skilled workers rallied in East Berlin on Tuesday to denounce communism for squelching craftsmanship. They demanded free-market reforms to revive artisanship, and many echoed increasing calls for reunification with prosperous West Germany. A new round of warning strikes, bleak new economic data and the announcement of price increases for farm products have added to the sense of crisis. The official news agency ADN said Tuesday that the East German economy posted its lowest growth of the decade last year, expanding by 2 percent instead of the 4 percent called for by central planners. The continuing exodus of workers to West Germany _ more than 340,000 left last year and they are fleeing at the rate of nearly 2,000 per day _ was a major factor in the slowdown in growth, ADN said. The agency also reported that a new round of price increases will make some farm products substantially more expensive starting Feb. 1. West German Economics Minister Helmut Haussmann, visiting East Berlin, said East Germany would move quickly toward free-market reforms to spur its sagging, centrally planned economy and make it appealing to West German businesses. Haussmann, attending the first meeting of an inter-German commission on economic cooperation, said Modrow had accepted an offer of $3.5 billion in West German aid for East German small and medium-sized businesses. Modrow, a Communist, has sought to draw the inexperienced popular opposition into accepting direct participation in his coalition government by offering the reform forces ministerial posts. He had called for talks to begin today, but on Tuesday, leaders of the splintered pro-democracy forces said they had postponed negotiations at least until early next week to coordinate their position. The delay showed how hesitant the opposition is to prop up the government before the country's first free elections May 6 _ when the Communists are expected to be voted out. British Foreign Minister Douglas Hurd completed a three-day visit to East Germany today and said Britain will look for ways to give economic aid to East Germany, including joint business projects and training for managers. He suggested there are few alternatives to Modrow's interim government and said further instability could hurt that nation's move toward democracy. ``It is very important that what the prime minister is trying to do will succeed and that he will have the support to carry this government through to May 6,'' Hurt said. The Communist Party has suffered mass defections since the peaceful October revolution that brought down its old hard-line leadership. Lothar de Maiziere, chairman of the Christian Democrats, a party in Modrow's coalition that once was aligned with the Communists, said he expected the Communists to gain at best 10 percent in the balloting. De Maiziere told West Germany's Bild newspaper he expects about 30 percent of the vote for his party and other newly-founded groups with a Christian orientation. The increasingly influential Social Democratic Party will also get about 30 percent, de Maiziere predicted in the interview. Currently, however, the opposition has difficulty projecting the impression it could actually run the country. East Germans are increasingly looking to unification with prosperous West Germany in hopes for a brighter future. Bild on Tuesday quoted an adviser to Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev as saying the Soviets would not block German reunification if the East Germans want it. But Nikolai Portugalov, Gorbachev's adviser on German affairs, was also quoted as cautioning against the forced acceleration of unification because it could undermine Europe. Unrest in the labor force intensified Tuesday, with workers in six cities staging brief warning strikes to press for higher pay and better working conditions, ADN said. Participating in the stoppages were employees in a psychiatric hospital in Ueckermuende, some 500 health workers in Suhl, taxi drivers in Leipzig and bank employees in Quedlinburg district, the agency said. Tuesday's rally of artisans in East Berlin was called on short notice and against the wishes of top union leaders still loyal to the Comunist system that rewarded them with comfortable bureaucratic positions. ``We absolutely and unconditionally need conversion to a full market economy,'' Burkhard Schmidt, spokesman for the Craftmen's Union, said before the rally.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela, ANC On Agenda For Crucial Cabinet Meeting
DOC.TEXT: The Cabinet met today for the first time this year, with an agenda that included the release of jailed black leader Nelson Mandela and the possible unbanning of the African National Congress. Decisions reached at the meeting ``will change the face of South Africa permanently,'' said The Sowetan, the country's largest black-oriented daily newspaper. The Cabinet traditionally does not announce its decisions immediately after its meetings, and the outcome of today's session might not be known until President F.W. de Klerk gives a speech Feb. 2 at the opening of Parliament. Mandela, the country's most popular black leader, has been jailed since 1962 and is serving a life sentence for helping plan the start of the ANC's anti-government sabotage campaign. The government has confirmed that he will be freed, and there is strong speculation the release could occur by mid-February. His release is one of several conditions which the ANC says must be met before it enters negotiations on a new political system that would extend voting rights to blacks. The outlawed movement also demands that it be legalized, that the state of emergency imposed in 1986 be lifted, and that the government halt trials and executions of political opponents. Government officials have indicated that these conditions could be met, at least to a large extent, leaving the ANC with a decision as to whether it should join negotiations. The state-run South African Broadcasting Corp., in a commentary today, said the ANC ``is being forced to move away from a strategy of violence and towards an acceptance of peaceful negotiation.'' Mandela, who has been meeting regularly with government and opposition leaders, last week submitted the outlines of a peace plan to the ANC's exiled leadership in Lusaka, Zambia. Details of the plan have not been disclosed. The Star of Johannesburg, South Africa's largest daily, said today the reason for the secrecy was that the plan ``contains proposals which are either extremely sensitive or embarrassing to the ANC.'' Justice Minister Kobie Coetsee, one of the Cabinet members who has met frequently with Mandela, said Tuesday that the 71-year-old prisoner might be asked at serve as a mediator between the government and the ANC. The ANC advocates a one-person, one-vote system in which the 28 million blacks would be able to control the government. De Klerk envisions some sort of system in which the 5 million whites would retain a veto over major policy decisions.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today defended his opposition to legislation to protect Chinese students from deportation and said Congress ``will have only itself to blame'' if it overrides his veto and Chinese authorities retaliate. In a morning news conference, Bush passed judgment on the use of force by Soviet authorities attempting to put down civil disorder in the distant region of Azerbaijan but indicated his trust in Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev. ``It is serious,'' he said of the Soviet unrest. Of Gorbachev's future, he added, ``I hope that he not only survives but stays strong.'' Bush faced a challenge to his veto of legislation to protect Chinese students, at risk due to the anti-Democracy crackdown in China. The president said he had taken steps to provide protection to Chinese students studying here at the time of the crackdown in Tiananmen Square last June. ``Not one was sent back,'' said Bush. The House was expected to vote to override the veto by a wide margin later in the day, and Bush met before his news conference with Republican senators in hopes of sustaining his veto. Congress has sustained each of Bush's previous ten vetoes. MORE

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Patrol Exchanges Fire Across Jordanian Border
DOC.TEXT: Israeli soldiers exchanged gunshots across the Jordanian border near an area where Jordanian troops were patrolling, but no injuries were reported and no inflitrations occurred, the army said today. It was not clear who fired the opening round from the Jordanian side in Tuesday's exchange, said an army official, who demanded anonymity. The incident occurred near Moshav Hatzeva, a communal agricultural settlement about 70 miles southeast of Jerusalem. Jordan's policy in the past has been to keep the border with Israel quiet and to prevent attempts by Palestinian guerrillas to infiltrate Israel. Tuesday's exchange of gunfire was the sixth shooting incident this year along the Jordan border, the army said. On Jan. 7, Israeli troops killed an infiltrator dressed in a Jordanian army uniform near the northern Israeli resort town of Tiberias. That incident prompted Israeli Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin to issue a tough warning holding Jordan responsible for any border infiltrations. Last year there were seven incidents along the Jordanian border, including six infiltrations, according to the army. Three Israeli soldiers were killed and at least seven soldiers and civilians were wounded in the 1989 incidents, the army said.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
DOC.NOTE: Eds: News conference still underway.
DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: dimensions.''
DOC.TEXT: ``I hope that he not only survives but stays strong because I think it is in our interest that Perestroika succeeds,'' Bush said. Bush was questioned closely about the veto confrontation with Congress over the Chinese student legislation, and he bristled at the idea that he was not concerned about human rights. ``That is absolutely ridiculous,'' said Bush, whose China policy has been widely criticized in the months since the pro-democracy movement in Beijing was crushed by military forces. As for the students, Bush said, ``Not one was sent back. They were safe then and they are safe now and they will be safe in the future.'' A questioner asked whether the issue with Congress was one of trust. Many members of Congress were angry or concerned after learning that Bush had dispatched top administration figures on a secret trip to China after saying publicly that high level exchanges were being curtailed due to the June crackdown. He said China, faced with the pending legislation, might well retaliate by cutting off other sorts of academic contacts with the United States. The price of the legislation ``is lost opportunity for the scholars of tomorrow ... Congress in my view will have only itself to blame.'' The Senate was: 5th graf a0435

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New material, Panama and Social Security. CORRECTS 2nd graf re Bush waiving judgment on Gorbachev actions.
DOC.TEXT: By CHRISTOPHER CONNELL=

President Bush today defended his opposition to legislation to protect Chinese students from deportation and said Congress ``will have only itself to blame'' if it overrides his veto and Chinese authorities retaliate. In a morning news conference Bush waived judgment on the use of force by Soviet authorities attempting to put down civil disorder in the distant region of Azerbaijan but indicated his trust in Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev. ``It is serious,'' he said of the Soviet unrest. Of Gorbachev's future, he added, ``I hope that he not only survives but stays strong.'' Bush faced a challenge to his veto of legislation to protect Chinese students, at risk due to the anti-Democracy crackdown in China. The president said he had taken steps to provide protection to Chinese students studying here at the time of the crackdown in Tiananmen Square last June. ``Not one was sent back,'' said Bush. The House was expected to vote to override the veto by a wide margin later in the day, and Bush met before his news conference with Republican senators in hopes of sustaining his veto. Congress has sustained each of Bush's previous ten vetoes. Bush also said a plan by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., to reduce Social Security taxes was a ``sleight of hand'' that could lead to increases in other taxes or to reductions in Social Security benefits. The president also said he had not yet settled on the details of an aid package for Panama. He said he regretted the loss of Panamanian lives as much as the lives of Americans lost. ``You have to feel concerned about that but you have to look at the broader picture,'' he said, claiming that a hige majority of Panamanian citizens approved of the invasion. The Pentagon says about 200 Panamanian civilians were killed during the fighting last month. Meeting with: a0536

DOC.HEAD: Defense Contractors Want to Work Together on Space Plane
DOC.TEXT: Four of the nation's biggest defense contractors have asked the government to approve a team effort to develop the National Aero-Space Plane, a futuristic aircraft that could go from runway into orbit. The move would allow the contractors _ who had been working independently on the project since 1985 _ to ``get more for our money,'' Jim Schlueter, a spokesman for St. Louis-based McDonnell Douglas Corp., said Tuesday. The other contractors are General Dynamics Corp., the North American Aircraft and Rocketdyne divisions of Rockwell International Corp., and the Pratt & Whitney division of United Technologies Corp. Theoretically, the experimental NASP X-30 aero-space plane would be capable of flying 25 times the speed of sound and 10 times faster and three times higher than existing commercial aircraft. The companies have created their own designs but have shared some research, mainly on construction materials. A prototype is scheduled to be flown in the late 1990s. The team agreement is subject to approval by the Air Force, NASA and the Navy. ``We don't anticipate any problems because this is consistent with the goal of the program,'' said J.W. Stout, a spokesman for St. Louis-based General Dynamics. Stout said the companies have worked together on researching and testing materials for use in the plane. Finding a material that is lightweight and can withstand intense heat is one of the linchpins of the plane's development. The team selected Barry Waldman, a veteran of 26 years of technical and management experience with Rockwell, as program director. The announcement ends a heated battle between Rocketdyne and Pratt & Whitney for the contracts to build engines for the plane.

DOC.HEAD: High School Begins Program, Testing 14 Students for Drugs
DOC.TEXT: A suburban high school's program of random drug tests on athletes began without protests, but with some raising the issue of privacy. ``It wasn't that bad,'' said Megan Mulcahey, a member of the girls' basketball team and one of the first group of 14 students who willingly underwent urine tests Tuesday at Homewood-Flossmoor High School. ``They treated you nice and everything.'' Amanda Levenberg, student government president, predicts opposition will grow as more students are called upon to undergo the procedure. Though not a first nationally, the program has gotten attention because of its scope. The school plans eventually to test all 1,200 sports participants among its 2,000-member student body. ``I was expecting a lot more friction from the student body. People are complying, and they're not complaining,'' said Miss Levenberg, 17. ``I think it won't hit kids until they have to go pee in a cup for someone to test them.'' Miss Mulcahey said she considers the tests a violation of privacy that unfairly singles out student athletes. ``I don't think it's fair that just us are being tested,'' she said in a telephone interview. ``If they're going to go ahead and have that, it should be everyone.'' The school board approved the program in September at the suggestion of the football coach, who suspected drug use by a couple of students, Athletic Director Ken Schultz said. Schultz picked the first students to be tested from those involved in such winter sports as swimming, basketball, wrestling and gymnastics, and their parents signed consent forms. The tests detect use of alcohol, steroids and several other drugs, including marijuana and cocaine. Students won't know when they will be tested until their day comes. Students and their parents will be notified of results within 48 hours, said Principal Charles Smith. Those who test positive must see a drug counselor within 48 hours. Students determined by the counselor to be abusers will be suspended from sports and required to undergo treatment. They will be tested again after 30 days and may return to athletics if they pass, Smith said. More treatment is ordered for those who don't pass. Schultz said the program probably will be expanded to include students involved in other extracurricular activities at the school, whose students come from several upper middle-class, largely white, southwestern suburbs. School officials say the tests will give kids an incentive to reject drugs. ``On weekends, when they go to the parties and alcohol is served, these kids can say, `No, because I might be tested next week,''' said Smith.

DOC.HEAD: High School Coaches Applaud District Reversal of Pass-to-Play Rule
DOC.TEXT: Coaches applauded the city School Board's dropping of a policy that barred students who get an ``F'' from taking part in sports. Board members supporting the reversal said they thought the no-pass, no-play rule adopted seven years ago in the nation's second-largest school system had discouraged students from taking challenging courses for fear of failure. ``The reality is we have students, in unfortunately large numbers, who are simply not taking academically challenging classes,'' said board member Jackie Goldberg. The board's 5-2 vote Monday put the Los Angeles district in line with a 1987 state law requiring students in grades 4 through 12 to have at least a ``C'' average to participate in sports, music, drama and other extracurricular activities. Los Angeles, which ranks in size behind New York City with 594,000 students, in 1982 became the nation's first major school district to approve a no-pass, no-play policy. In 1984, Texas adopted such a law statewide. A Los Angeles district study last year found most students, teachers and counselors supported the rule. Most principals, along with coaches and others who ran after-school programs opposed it. ``I've always been against the no-fail rule and not because I'm anti-academic,'' said Darryl Stroh, football and baseball coach at Granada Hills High School. ``The `C' average is a good enough rule. ``If a kid takes a fail and the rest of his grades are good enough to absorb it, then there's no justification for denying him eligibility.'' Dissenting were board members Leticia Quezada and Rita Walters, who introduced the rule. Ms. Quezada characterized the reversal as ``a step backward'' and said it was ``exactly the kind of message we don't need.'' ``The message (should be), if you fail in a subject, you must leave everything behind and focus on your school work,'' she said. The board also heard from parents and students, many of whom opposed dropping the rule. ``By repealing the `No-Fail' rule we are compromising academic excellence,'' said Kerry Lotts, a North Hollywood High School junior. ``If a student fails only one class, how will (he) be able to have time for these activities?'' Ms. Lotts asked. ``We need to support a badly eroding system.''

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Planned for Free Distribution in Washington
DOC.TEXT: A free five-day-a-week newspaper on government, politics and the law, designed for delivery to offices each morning, will begin publication in Washington on Oct. 1, its backers said today. Roger G. Kranz, publisher of the projected Washington Reporter, said a 20-page prototype would be published at the end of February. Kranz said about 5,000 copies of the prototype would be printed and the newspaper expects to have a circulation of about 30,000. He said the newspaper would be printed and distributed by contractors. In addition to contract distribution to Washington offices, Kranz said, there would be limited same-day distribution to Wall Street and midtown Manhattan and to air shuttle terminals in New York, Boston and Washingtill also be limited newsstand and box sales in on. There wWashington, he said. Kranz said it would provide ``news and information on the federal government, politics, lobbying, law and media for policymakers and opinion leaders in Washington.'' He said the newspaper would not provide sports, weather, local or foreign news coverage, although foreign developments would be covered from wire services and from embassies and other sources in Washington. He said four-color advertising was planned, including advertising re he resigned in August as group vice president in charge of advertising sales, circulation and manufacturing. John S. Prescott Jr., a former president of The Washington Post and recently retired president of the publications division of Whitney Communications Co. in New York, will be chairman of the board. The editor will be Barry Sussman, who runs an independent public opinion polling and consulting company in Washington and formerly served as an editor with The Washington Post and United Press International. Kranz said he and Prescott are investors in the paper, and Sussman is not. He declined to name other investors.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines a0544-a0536-a0538-a0435; editing to update and trim.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, lobbying to sustain his veto of legislation to protect Chinese students from deportation, said today Congress ``will have only itself to blame'' if it overrides his veto and authorities in Beijing retaliate. In a wide-ranging morning news conference, Bush also sidestepped a question on the use of force by Soviet authorities attempting to put down civil disorder in the distant region of Azerbaijan _ but indicated his trust in Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev. ``Anytime you have a use of force and a loss of life we have concern, but I don't believe I can judge that right now,'' he said. Of Gorbachev's future, he added, ``I hope that he not only survives but stays strong.'' The key event today for Bush was congressional consideration of his veto of the Chinese student legislation. The House was expected to vote to override the veto later in the day, and Bush met before his news conference with Republicans in the Senate in hopes of sustaining his veto there. Congress has upheld each of Bush's previous ten vetoes. Bush said he had taken steps to provide protection to Chinese students studying here at the time of the crackdown in Tiananmen Square last June. ``Not one was sent back,'' Bush said of the students. ``They were safe then and they are safe now and they will be safe in the future.'' He said the legislation was unnecessary and suggested it invited retaliation against American scholars in China. But many lawmakers, upset with Bush's diplomatic overtures to Beijing, favor legislation anyway to give automatic visa protection to the estimated 32,000 Chinese students in the United States. Meeting with reporters four days past his first anniversary in office, Bush also: _ Lambasted a plan by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., to reduce Social Security taxes as a ``sleight of hand'' that could lead to increases in other taxes or to reductions in Social Security benefits. _ Offered his widely anticipated endorsement for creating a new Department of the Environment. He said worldwide environmental challenges are ``so important that they must be addressed at the highest level.'' _ Indicated he would soon propose a change in the Pentagon budget that ``begins the transition'' to a military more geared to events outside Europe, while ``continuing to meet our inescapable commitment'' to NATO. Pentagon officials have been studying alternatives in military spending and strategy in response to the wave of democracy sweeping Eastern Europe. _ Said he would unveil the second phase of his anti-drug strategy on Thursday, continuing a busy period that includes submission of his first full budget next Monday and his first State of the Union address Wednesday night. _ Said he had not yet settled on the details of an aid package for Panama. He said he regretted the loss of Panamanian lives as much as the lives of Americans lost. ``You have to feel concerned about that but you have to look at the broader picture,'' he said, claiming that a hige majority of Panamanian citizens approved of the invasion. The Pentagon says about 200 Panamanian civilians were killed during the fighting last month. Asked about Soviet unrest in Azerbaijan, Bush said he didn't know whether the volatile situation there posed a threat to Gorbachev's political survival, but acknowledged, ``He's faced with an ethnic problem there, an internal problem of enormous dimensions.'' ``I hope that he not only survives but stays strong because I think it is in our interest that Perestroika succeeds,'' Bush said. His comments on Social Security were tinged with politics. ``it's a disguise for increased taxes around the corner,'' he said of Moynihan's proposal. He depicted himself as a Republican president ``protecting the sanctity'' of Social Security.'' Moynihan has proposed the cut in taxes, saying payroll taxes are creating a huge Social Security surplus and masking the true size of the federal deficit. Bush was questioned closely about the veto confrontation with Congress over the Chinese student legislation, and he bristled at the idea that he was not concerned about human rights. ``That is absolutely ridiculous,'' said Bush, whose China policy has been widely criticized in the months since the pro-democracy movement in Beijing was crushed by military forces. Bush drew especially strong criticism last month for sending two top aides to Beijing. The legislation would extend the stays of thousands of Chinese students who were in this country when the violence erupted last June in their homeland. He said China, faced with the pending legislation, might well retaliate by cutting off other sorts of academic contacts with the United States. The price of the legislation ``is lost opportunity for the scholars of tomorrow ... Congress in my view will have only itself to blame.'' The Senate was Bush's only hope on the Chinese student question, as administration officials viewed as a lost cause today's override vote in the House, which voted 403-0 on Nov. 19 for the legislation Bush vetoed. In pocket-vetoing the bill Nov. 30, Bush said he was taking administrative action instead to ensure no Chinese students were forced to return to their communist homeland following the brutal crackdown on democracy demonstrators. A law would just antagonize Beijing and end the flow of Chinese students, Bush argued.

Here is the text of President Bush's comments Wednesday at a news conference: Good morning, good morning. Well, as you know, I'll soon present my budget to the Congress, and as I prepare to do so, it strikes me that our nation faces challenges on many fronts. So let's give each the attention it deserves tomorrow. I'm going to announce the second phase of our strategy to fight drugs in the schools and the streets of America. The future of this country depends on whether we can give our children a chance to grow up drug-free. And secondly, I will soon present our plan to restructure America's defenses in the wake of the dramatic changes that are taking place abroad, and I'm proposing a defense budget that begins the transition to a restructured military, a new strategy that is more flexible, more geared to contingencies outside of Europe while continuing to meet our inescapable responsibility to NATO and to maintaining the global balance. And finally, Secretary Brady and Director Darman and Chairman Boskin will put the details of our budget before the American people. And as that occurs, other members of the administration, the Cabinet, key agencies will provide an in-depth outline of their efforts to address the many challenges of caring for the afflicted and uplifting the poor, cleaning the environment, educating our kids, as well as other important issues. All of this is preparatory to the State of the Union, one week from today, in which I will speak to the broader issues that we face as a nation. There are two items that I want to mention here today and then take some questions. First, I've decided that the environmental challenges that face America and the world are so important that they must be addressed from the highest level of our government. And at the beginning of this century, President Roosevelt, Theodore Roosevelt, helped pave the way for the establishment of the national park system. Twenty years ago, President Nixon established the EPA, Environmental Protection Agency, by executive order. That is now one of the largest and most important regulatory agencies in the government. And today, I'd like to announce another step forward in this important tradition of support for conservation and environmental protection. Many countries have environmental ministers, and now _ and with cabinet status. And I am convinced that that cabinet status will help influence the world's environmental policy. So, with so many difficult decisions ahead, I'll need Bill Reilly's counsel, I'll need him sitting at my side in the cabinet, and I'm pleased to endorse the elevation of the EPA to cabinet status by creating a Department of the Environment. Senators Glenn and Bill Roth, chairman and ranking members of the Government _ Senate Government Affairs Committee _ have introduced legislation that would create this department. Congressman Conyers and Horton are working on similar legislation. And I look forward to working with them and other interested members of the House and Senate to enact legislation that would bring EPA to the cabinet table, where it now belongs. And now, I'd like to address one other issue that I know is foremost on your minds. Every American should know _ I want to take this opportunity to state this as strongly as I can _ that I will not break faith with the Chinese students here. I have made that very clear from the very beginning. And right after Tiananmen, I moved to protect the Chinese students in this country. Not one was sent back. They were safe then, and they are safe now, and they will be safe in the future. And when Congress passed the Pelosi bill last fall, I was faced with a choice. If I signed the bill, the students would still be safe, but China would retaliate and cut off future student exchanges. You see, I think the exchanges have brought forward the reforms that have taken place in China. If you look back over your shoulders for a starting point and compare it to the Cultural Revolution days, some of the reforms have taken place, steps have been taken forward, and regrettably, Tiananmen was a step _ a gigantic step back. But I want to keep contact. I do not want isolation. If I vetoed the bill, I could take action to provide the students with even greater protection while keeping the door open for more Chinese scholars to study here. And the price of the Pelosi bill is lost opportunity.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Restates Opposition To Social Security Payroll Tax Cut
DOC.NOTE: EDs: This serves as a 1st Ld-Writethru for PM-Bills Rdp, a0442. New material, editing throughout with Bush statements.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today called Sen. Daniel P. Moynihan's proposal for a Social Security payroll tax cut ``a disguise for increased taxes'' and said he will continue to fight it. Bush told a White House news conference he believes Social Security ``has been basically a pretty fair system'' and this is no time to change it. Moynihan's proposal, formally unveiled Tuesday, would roll back the Social Security payroll tax rate from the 7.65 percent it reached Jan. 1 to the previous 7.51 percent. That would save workers $7 billion this year and $55 billion in fiscal 1991. ``We must end the shameful practice of using Social Security revenues to finance budget deficits,'' said the New York Democrat. The surplus in Social Security reserves is counted in the budget, making the overall federal deficit appear smaller than it is. The surplus is the result of efforts to build up reserves for the Baby Boom generation when it reaches retirement age and will dwindle after the turn of the century. But the Bush administration calls the move part of a Democratic plot to raise other taxes. ``I think it's a disguise for increased taxes around the corner,'' Bush said, ``and I don't want to to see the benefits of Social Security cut. .. I would say to those around the country, `Take a hard look now. Don't let that rabbit be pulled out of the hat'. '' ``This is a sleight-of-hand operation here,'' Bush said, noting that shortly after Moynihan disclosed his idea, another Senate Democrat, Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina, proposed enactment of a 5 percent national sales levy _ a value-added tax. Bush said Moynihan had been a member of the commission that restructured the Social Security system in 1983. ``I think the Mr. Moynihan of a few years back ought to talk to the Mr. Moynihan of today,'' he said. ``If we were all starting over, I think we could fine-tune the entire American tax system,'' Bush said. ``We're not starting over, and I think that system has been in and out over the years basically a pretty fair system.'' On another budget front, Sen. Richard Bryan, D-Nev., introduced legislation he said would release more than $10.5 billion in highway money being held in the federal Highway Trust Fund. The money represents the accumulated difference between revenues _ larely from the 9-cent-a-gallon gasoline tax _ and federal highway authorizations. Critics say the money is deliberately underspent to keep the deficit low and provide a cheap source for government borrowing. ``Over the last decade the federal government has used the money collected by the federal gas tax as a deficit-reduction gimmick,'' Bryan said. Legislation to elevate the Environmental Protection Agency to Cabinet level status was introduced in the House and Senate, with supporters saying they hoped a bill could clear Congress within several months. Bush gave his endorsement to that proposal, saying worldwide environmental challenges are ``so important that they must be addressed at the highest level.'' Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio, chairman of the Senate Government Operations Committee, also said the EPA needs more clout and higher visibility because of the importance of environmental issues in the next decade. Sens. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., and Alan Cranston, D-Calif., moved to translate changes in the Soviet bloc into less U.S. military spending. They introduced legislation to cancel the B-1 stealth bomber program after the 15 bombers now in production are built. ``Recent events have made the argument against the B-2 even stronger,'' said Leahy. He said taxpayers would save $40 billion as a result. Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., introduced a bill she has been touting since the U.S. invasion of Panama last month that would remove existing prohibitions on women serving in combat. A bill introduced by Sen. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn., would bar senators from taking honoraria and limit outside earned income to 15 percent of salary. The measure would bring Senate rules in line with those approved by the House last year.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Minister Resigns After Disagreement with Army Chief
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with further details on the dispute, Menem's comment, background on military, government. No pickup. ^By ED McCULLOUGH
DOC.TEXT: Defense Minister Italo Luder abruptly resigned today after the army chief of staff met with President Carlos Menem without informing him. ``I gave the president my undeclinable resignation,'' Luder, 73, told reporters after a half-hour meeting with Menem at Government House. It was the latest crisis facing Menem's government, which has been beset by economic and military problems since he took office in July. Menem told reporters he had not decided whether to accept what would be the third Cabinet resignation since he took office, but the president indicated he sided with the army chief, Gen. Isidro Caceres, in the dispute. Luder imposed an unspecified sanction on Caceres on Tuesday. ``It's very possible that by this afternoon I will lift the sanction,'' Menem said. ``I think in this aspect, Dr. Luder was not in full knowledge of the facts.'' He did not elaborate. Caceres met privately with Menem and Interior Minister Julio Mera Figueroa on Jan. 17 and discussed matters of internal security. Luder said he, too, should have been invited. Asked why he wasn't, he said in an interview broadcast this morning by Radio Mitre, ``I don't know.'' ``When I called him (Caceres) the next day, he didn't give a satisfactory explanation,'' said Luder, a lawyer and career politician. Neither Menem nor Luder specified Caceres' sanction, but it could have ranged from a disciplinary hearing to arrest. In any event, Caceres almost certainly would have been forced to resign, an army expert said. There was no immediate response from Caceres, who helped the government of then-President Raul Alfonsin put down the Villa Martelli army insurrection led by then Col. Mohammed Seineldin in December 1988. Though the uprising was quelled and Seineldin forced into retirement, the army remains divided between a nationalist sector that wants a greater say in politics, and the sector led by Caceres that has stayed out of politics. ``We believe that the solution to (Argentina's) problems should come from ... the political parties, the political leaders,'' Caceres said last month. Luder's resignation comes at a time when the government has failed to solve several problems in the military, including low pay for soldiers, poor equipment, and a budget so small that the number of conscripts this year was reduced. There was little indication beforehand that Luder and Caceres were at odds, although Caceres had complained about the military's low budget and had spoken of the climate of social unrest in this South American country that is beset by inflation and recession. Also, Caceres publicly called for the release from prison of four former commanders of the military juntas that ruled Argentina from 1976 to 1983. Two former presidents and generals, Jorge Videla and Roberto Viola, were convicted of human rights abuses committed during the so-called ``dirty war'' on leftist subversion. A government commission reported in 1984 that at least 8,960 alleged leftists were arrested and presumed executed by the military. The generals and three other officers convicted at the same time were not included in a presidential pardon in October of officers and alleged left-wing terrorists. Menem said the pardon was necessary for national conciliation. Since he took office, Menem has faced a series of crises, most of them economic. In that time he has had three economic ministers and three Central Bank presidents quit. Menem has promised to combat Argentina's chronic economic stagnation by curtailing a budget deficit that is seen as the prime cause of inflation, attracting foreign investment and selling state-owned money-losing companies. But interest rates have topped 600 percent a month and dollar buying has been rampant. The austral, Argentina's currency, lost nearly 50 percent of its value in December and there was widespread panic buying and hoarding by shoppers. From December to Jan. 3 the government six times ordered banks and foreign exchange houses to remain closed to hold down inflation and stabilize the austral.

DOC.HEAD: Girls Return to School in Moslem Head Scarves
DOC.TEXT: Two Moslem teen-agers banned from school for wearing religious head scarves were allowed to return to class today, and they received a rousing welcome from their classmates. Fatima and Aisha Alvi trudged up the snow-covered driveway at Altrincham Grammar School for Girls near Manchester to be greeted by their friends who leaned out of windows and cheered them in. Fatima, 15, smiled and said: ``All we want to do is get back to school and back to work.'' Her 14-year-old sister said: ``We are glad it is all over.'' The girls had been sent home every school day since Dec. 14 when they began wearing their scarves to school. Islamic law requires girls past puberty to cover their heads in the presence of men who are not close relatives. Three men teach at the school of 727 students, and there is a male caretaker. The school argued the scarves were a safety danger to the girls in school laboratories and the gymnasium. After a two-hour meeting Tuesday night, school governors changed their minds but said the scarves must be blue to match the school's uniforms and must be removed during science and physical education classes because of the safety concerns.
