In October, three Moslem girls in Creil, north of Paris, were banned from school because they refused to remove their scarves. France's state school system bans all outward signs of religion. The dispute caused public demonstrations and became a national political issue. France's highest administrative authority, the Council of State, ruled in November that Moslem girls may wear scarves to school as long as it causes no disruption.

DOC.HEAD: Two R.I. Cities Promote Prenatal Care Through Lottery
DOC.TEXT: Have a healthy baby and win a prize _ that's the message behind the Healthy Baby Lottery, an effort to get women to seek prenatal care early in their pregnancy. The Blackstone Valley Perinatal Network and Pawtucket's Memorial Hospital, with a $15,000 grant from the March of Dimes, will kick off the lottery Feb. 1. The program seeks to encourage women, especially poor women, to seek health care in the first three months of pregnancy, when the fetus is especially vulnerable to damage from drugs, disease and poor diet. ``We know of no other program in the country like this,'' said Dr. Larry Culpepper of the hospital's department of family medicine and the Brown University medical school. The lottery is open to any woman who is less than 12 weeks pregnant, lives in Central Falls or Pawtucket, and seeks prenatal care from a doctor in one of those cities. Up for grabs will be six monthly prizes ranging from $25 to $100, with winners' names drawn from entry forms women fill out in their doctors' offices. Women who keep all doctor's appointments throughout their pregnancy will be eligible for a $500 grand prize awarded every six months. If the two-year project is successful, the lottery may be expanded statewide, Culpepper said Tuesday. From the March of Dimes funding, $7,000 will go toward prizes, and the rest for administration and publicity. The agency, which fights birth defects, chose Pawtucket and Central Falls because of the high concentration of poor people and minorities. ``For every $1 we spend on prenatal care, we save $3'' by preventing sickness and prematurity, said Bernadette M. Farina, executive director of the organization's Rhode Island chapter. Culpepper said there are higher rates of prematurity, birth defects, cerebral palsy, mental retardation, stillbirth and infant death when the mother does not see a doctor in the first 12 weeks of pregnancy. He said poor women, teen-agers, single women, recent immigrants and minority-group women are least likely to seek prenatal treatment. Organizers were worried initially about the propriety of using a lottery for health promotion, but the prospect of reaching a hard-to-reach group took precedence, Culpepper said. ``We decided to take the risk that it would come across as a little tacky,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says He Hopes Gorbachev Stays Strong
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today he hopes Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev ``not only survives but stays strong'' in the face of crises triggered by a separatist rebellion in the Soviet republic of Azerbaijan and ethnic unrest in the Baltics. Bush told a news conference Gorbachev is being challenged by ``an internal problem of enormous dimensions.'' Asked if the Soviet president had gone too far in trying to quell the violence in Azerbaijan, Bush said, ``Any time you have a use of force and the loss of life, we are concerned. But I don't believe I can judge that question right now.'' Soviet troops killed dozens of people Saturday in storming the capital city of Baku to end bloody ethnic clashes that erupted Jan. 13 with anti-Armenian rioting. After 11 days of violence, the official death toll stood at 170. The uprising is considered the most serious crisis for Gorbachev in his five years as Soviet leader. While expressing support for the Soviet leader, Bush declined to predict whether Gorbachev would survive the test. ``We don't really know. It is serious,'' Bush said. He said the Soviet leader ``has always indicated a desire to restrain _ for peaceful change inside the Soviet Union. ... But I don't know (about his future), I can't make predictions about that. ``But I know that I hope that he not only survives but stays strong because I think it is in our interest that perestroika (Gorbachev's program of economic and political restructuring) succeed and go forward,'' Bush said. He restated the long-held position that the United States does not recognize the incorporation of the Baltic states of Latvia, Lithuanian and Estonia into the Soviet Union. ``However,'' Bush said, ``what I say that we want to do is to encourage Mr. Gorbachev's stand that peaceful change is the order of the day, and he's sorting out some very difficult internal problems in these three Baltic countries. ``I don't think it helps, facilitates things, for us to fine tune all that,'' Bush said. ``They know our position,'' he added, saying it was a subject that he discussed with Gorbachev during their summit in Malta in early December. ``In looking at the Soviet scene there, he is still adhering as best he can to the concept of peaceful change in the Baltics, and that's got to dominate,'' Bush said.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts graf 16, Called ``pure, on abortion.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, fighting to sustain his veto of legislation to protect Chinese students from deportation, today warned Congress it ``will have only itself to blame'' if it overrides him and Beijing retaliates with more repression. In a wide-ranging morning news conference, Bush also sidestepped a question on the use of force by Soviet authorities attempting to put down civil disorder in the distant region of Azerbaijan _ but indicated his trust in Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev. ``Anytime you have a use of force and a loss of life we have concern, but I don't believe I can judge that right now,'' he said. Of Gorbachev's future, he added, ``I hope that he not only survives but stays strong.'' The key event today for Bush was congressional consideration of his veto of the Chinese student legislation. The House was expected to vote to override the veto later in the day, and Bush met before his news conference with Republicans in the Senate in hopes of sustaining his veto there on Thursday. Congress has upheld each of Bush's previous ten vetoes. Bush said he had taken steps to provide protection to Chinese students studying here at the time of the crackdown in Tiananmen Square last June. ``Not one was sent back,'' Bush said of the students. ``They were safe then and they are safe now and they will be safe in the future.'' He said the legislation was unnecessary and suggested it invited retaliation against American scholars in China. But many lawmakers, upset with Bush's diplomatic overtures to Beijing, favor legislation anyway to give automatic visa protection to the estimated 32,000 Chinese students in the United States. Meeting with reporters four days past his first anniversary in office, Bush also: _ Lambasted a plan by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., to reduce Social Security taxes as a ``sleight of hand'' that could lead to increases in other taxes or to reductions in Social Security benefits. _ Offered his widely anticipated endorsement for creating a new Department of the Environment. He said worldwide environmental challenges are ``so important that they must be addressed at the highest level.'' _ Indicated he would soon propose a change in the Pentagon budget that ``begins the transition'' to a military more geared to events outside Europe, while ``continuing to meet our inescapable commitment'' to NATO. Pentagon officials have been studying alternatives in military spending and strategy in response to the wave of democracy sweeping Eastern Europe. _ Said he would unveil the second phase of his anti-drug strategy on Thursday, continuing a busy period that includes submission of his first full budget next Monday and his first State of the Union address Wednesday night. _ Said he had not yet settled on the details of an aid package for Panama. He said he regretted the loss of Panamanian lives as much as the lives of Americans lost. ``You have to feel concerned about that but you have to look at the broader picture,'' he said, claiming that a hige majority of Panamanian citizens approved of the invasion. The Pentagon says about 200 Panamanian civilians were killed during the fighting last month. _ Called ``pure, unadulterated malarkey'' a Newsweek magazine report that Bush, his wife Barbara and family were deeply divided over abortion. Bush defended his support for a constitutional amendment to outlaw most abortions, saying, ``I was elected to try to fulfill the platform and the programs that I believe in. And so that's my personal choice, but that doesn't mean I have lack of respect for others.'' Asked about Soviet unrest in Azerbaijan, Bush said he didn't know whether the volatile situation there posed a threat to Gorbachev's political survival, but acknowledged, ``He's faced with an ethnic problem there, an internal problem of enormous dimensions.'' ``I hope that he not only survives but stays strong because I think it is in our interest that Perestroika succeeds,'' Bush said. His comments on Social Security were tinged with politics. ``it's a disguise for increased taxes around the corner,'' he said of Moynihan's proposal. He depicted himself as a Republican president ``protecting the sanctity'' of Social Security.'' Moynihan has proposed the cut in taxes, saying payroll taxes are creating a huge Social Security surplus and masking the true size of the federal deficit. Bush was questioned closely about the veto confrontation with Congress over the Chinese student legislation, and he bristled at the idea that he was not concerned about human rights. ``That is absolutely ridiculous,'' said Bush, whose China policy has been widely criticized in the months since the pro-democracy movement in Beijing was crushed by military forces. Bush drew especially strong criticism last month for sending two top aides to Beijing. The legislation would extend the stays of thousands of Chinese students who were in this country when the violence erupted last June in their homeland. He said China, faced with the pending legislation, might well retaliate by cutting off other sorts of academic contacts with the United States. The price of the legislation ``is lost opportunity for the scholars of tomorrow ... Congress in my view will have only itself to blame.'' The Senate was Bush's only hope on the Chinese student question, as administration officials viewed as a lost cause today's override vote in the House, which voted 403-0 on Nov. 19 for the legislation Bush vetoed. In pocket-vetoing the bill Nov. 30, Bush said he was taking administrative action instead to ensure no Chinese students were forced to return to their communist homeland following the brutal crackdown on democracy demonstrators. A law would just antagonize Beijing and end the flow of Chinese students, Bush argued.

DOC.HEAD: Van Gogh From Met to Be Auctioned
DOC.TEXT: A painting by Vincent van Gogh, loaned to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in 1984, will leave the museum to be auctioned for an expected price of up to $50 million, Christie's auction house says. The painting, ``Portrait of Dr. Gachet,'' is from the collection of Siegfried Kramarsky, a German-born New York banker who died in 1961. It is being sold by a trust created under his will. Museum director Philippe de Montebello said he was not surprised that such a painting was headed for the auction block. ``The reduced tax advantages to collectors and the increased sale potential are a combination that is irresistible to collectors and fatal to museums,'' he said. The portrait of Dr. Paul-Ferdinand Gachet was painted six weeks before van Gogh committed suicide in 1890. It will be auctioned May 15, almost precisely 100 years after it was finished. Gachet, a practitioner of homeopathic medicine, was van Gogh's physician and a friend of Impressionist painters. The doctor, an artist himself, is shown seated at a table, head in hand, with what van Gogh called ``the broken-hearted expression of our time.'' Van Gogh painted a slightly larger version with less detail and flatter colors. It hangs in the Musee d'Orsay in Paris. Another van Gogh, ``Irises,'' was sold at auction in 1987 for $53.9 million, making it the world's most expensive painting. That sale, however, was made with a loan from Sotheby's auction house; when the buyer failed to pay what was owed, the deal fell through.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Repeats last graf of 1st take, bgng: `If I...,' which dropped off in mid-sentence
DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: want isolation.
DOC.TEXT: If I vetoed the bill, I could take action to provide the students with even greater protection while keeping the door open for more Chinese scholars to study here. And the price of the Pelosi bill is lost opportunity for the Chinese scholars of tomorrow. And people should understand that very, very clearly. The bill is totally unnecessary. The long-term policy consequences are potentially great. And Congress, in my view, will have only itself to blame. I can understand their emotion, but we've got to look at policy and we've got to be fair in what has already been accomplished by the Executive Order. It's a strong message. I want it to be seen exactly that way. And now I'd be delighted to take any questions. Terry and then Helen. Q: Mr. President, how serious a crisis is the nationalist rebellion in Azerbaijan for President Gorbachev? And what are the chances that he'll survive this test and the challenge from the Baltics? A: Well, I think the answer to your question unfolds every day. We don't really know. And it is serious. The _ Gorbachev has always indicated a desire to restrain _ for peaceful change inside the Soviet Union. And I refer to what he said on the Baltics. He's faced with an ethnic problem here and an internal problem of enormous dimensions. But I don't know, Terry, I can't make predictions about that. But I know that I hope that he not only survives but stays strong because I think it is in our interest that perestroika succeed and go forward. Q: Well, can I just follow up on that? A: Sure. Q: Do you think that he's gone too far in the crack-down in Baku? A: Any time you have a use of force and the loss of life, we are concerned. But I don't believe I can judge that question right now. Q: Mr. President, you're very concerned with drugs and drugs are intimately connected now to guns. What is it _ what do you tell your grandchildren in why you would ban semi-automatic foreign-made guns and not domestically produced? There are two students who were killed in the last 10 days, high school students here. Aren't you deeply concerned? I mean, where is the lethal _ legal justification A: I am concerned and I just don't happen to believe the banning of weapons will take them out of the hands of the criminals. And we've seen state law after state law violated by the bad guys getting the weapons. And I believe that, so I don't want to go for more federal gun control. I'm not going to do it. We've taken some steps that I think are helpful. Q: Well, we are sending weapons, though, to Colombia and so forth that are made in this country. How do you stop that? A: To Colombia? Q: And to other places where they're getting in. A: Well, if they're going to the Colombian government, I wouldn't stop it, and if they're going to the bad guys, we would undergo every possible _ follow every possible avenue to stop it. Yes? Q: Mr. President, back on China for a moment. It appears your veto will be overridden in the House today. That would require Senate action for the job to be complete. I know you met with Senate leaders this morning. Are you confident that just these remarks you've made out here today and whatever else you may have said will be enough or do you really feel that the Chinese leadership with whom you have dealt for so long kind of let you down here and didn't give you a strong enough hand? A: What I did in talking to the Senate leaders this morning _ the Republicans _ is to cite certain things that _ steps that China has taken. They've accepted the Peace Corps volunteers. You see, I think that's good. People will say, ``Well, in the face of Tianamen, that's not good. I think it is good because I think cultural contacts, educational contacts will benefit in the long run democracy and reform in China. They've accredited a VOA correspondent, who as you know were kicked out. They've muted the hostile propaganda against Americans and stopped harrassing the US embassy. That's good. That's important to me as president who feels a certain responsibility for the people there. They've given some assurances on missile sales. I want to see them follow up, but I think that's positive. They've reopened the Fulbright exchanges. I think that's good and I think that's positive. And I think if we let Congress have its head and do what is emotionally popular, these things would be changed. They've lifted martial law. I don't know a single member of Congress that, if I had said to them, ``Look, we think by sending General Scowcroft and Larry Eagleburger over there we can get martial law lifted, do you think it's worth it,'' I think most would have said, ``Sure, that would be a good step.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders New Trial in Newspaper Reporter Bombing
DOC.TEXT: A judge has ordered a new murder trial for a former plumber charged with setting off the remote-controlled car bomb that killed Arizona Republic investigative reporter Don Bolles in 1976. James Robison, 67, who is in prison on an unrelated assault charge, was scheduled for arraignment Feb. 2 after Superior Court Judge Thomas O'Toole ordered him Tuesday to stand trial. Robison and Max Dunlap were found guilty in the Bolles killing in 1977, but their convictions were overturned in 1980 because the defense wasn't allowed to question a witness adequately. Dunlap has not been charged again. A third man, John Harvey Adamson, was convicted in the slaying and is in prison. His death sentence was overturned. The motive for the slaying of Bolles, 47, at a Phoenix hotel has remained murky, with a tangle of theories involving the mob, race track owners, casino skimming and crooked bankers. No mastermind has been charged. Prosecution witnesses presented little that was new during a four-day preliminary hearing. But Attorney General Bob Corbin said Tuesday, ``Nobody ever puts on all of the good stuff at the preliminary hearing.'' Robison, formerly of suburban Chandler, did not testify, but prosecutors introduced a transcript of an unpublished interview Robison gave magazine writers in 1979 in which he denied killing Bolles but acknowledged having seen the remote control and withholding information from police.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: good step.''
DOC.TEXT: It happens and we see a lot of criticism of it. They've released 573 people that were detained after last June's events. And you can argue about any one of these points. But I asked the Senate and the House _ a little late for that one _ the Senate to take a look at these things and put it in the totality of a policy and you see, I think there are some real reasons, Asian reasons, if you will, Cambodia and Japan, that we should retain relations with China. That doesn't mean we endorse the lack of human rights. I tell you, one of the criticisms that gets to me a little _ and I vowed _ I didn't tell you my New Year's resolution was not to let it get to me _ but it is the idea that I don't care about human rights. That is absolutely ridiculous. I want to see China move forward, and some think isolation, some think a railroad up there in the Congress is going to do it. And I don't think so. I think we're handling it pretty well. Brit? Q: Mr. President, did you in any way convey to the Chinese leaders the idea that these steps taken so far would be enough to head off this action taken by Congress which they must ... A: We didn't give a timetable, but we've encouraged in every way we can these and more. But I'm just asking that people look at them. I have not seen, and maybe it's my fault, one account on whatever media of these steps put together as a package. I haven't seen one. So I'd like to suggest to the Congress that are debating this to take a hard look at this and see whether it's progress, whether it adds up to anything, or as some of our critics would say, ``It's pure, you know, boilerplate.'' Yes, Lesley? Q: Mr. President, in the voting, in the House particularly, you seem to be conceding that that's gone for you. Do you think that there's a _ there's a problem of trust here with you? Are they saying they don't trust you to go forward on this student thing? After all, you told them you weren't going to have high-level exchanges, and while you were telling them that, you were sending a high-level delegation. Do you have a credibility problem? A: But where was the exchange in that? What the exchange was, Lesley, was when the Secretary of Commerce was going to go to China and be _ in an exchange visit arranged by their Commerce Minister. That was cancelled. Q:Yeah, but they obviously thought it included high-level contact. The question is is ... A: Who were they? Q: ... do you think you have a problem with them not trusting you because of that? A: No, I don't think it's a question of trust. I think the students have done a very good job presenting their case to the Congress. I think there's some politics involved, crass politics. When you hear name calling, when you hear people saying ``kowtow,'' that is not the kindest word to say ``we have an honest policy difference with this president.'' And so there's some politics involved in this as well. And _ but I think there's some genuine feeling that these students have a very good case. And what I want to do is make the case that the way to continue reforms and have reform go forward is not through isolation and unilateral congressional action, but through the kinds of contacts that I foresee and through the _ and encouraging the kind of steps that have already been taken. Q: You talk about the lifting of martial law. What about the situation as it exists without the gesture? Are you at all disturbed that the repression goes on? Could you ... A: Yes. I'm very much concerned about the status quo. And I was terribly concerned at the time of the Cultural Revolution, when we made the original contact with China. And it was a good thing we did, because you began through contacts with the West to see China pull out of this ``Middle Kingdom'' syndrome and move forward. And I think I know enough about it that in China you get a couple of steps forward and then somebody steps back. You know, look at Deng Xiaoping's own _ own history. I think he was out three times and in four. And some will argue, ``Well, he's part of the problem.'' He's now retired. But the reforms, particularly on the economic side, that brought a new level of prosperity to the Chinese people really was started by him. So I'm not giving up on _ I mean, I'm not accepting the status quo at all. And China knows my position on this. But it's _ I do think that there's some indignation about students, there is some feeling that _ I'm talking about the Congress now _ there's a lot here of empathy with the students, right here, but I think there's also a dose of political rhetoric up there that certainly has diminished the other side. And I will readily concede, maybe I could have done better and sooner in presenting the facts of this case. The Attorney General's doing a good job telling the _ you know, the differences between the Pelosi bill and what we've already accomplished. But I don't know where we'll come out, but I'm going to keep on working the policy. Yes? We'll come over here, John, and then Charles.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Two Years' Probation For Secord
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs files a0558-a0563-a0567-a0571-a0451; CORRECTS date of crash to 1986 sted 1985 in 5th graf, Secord's lawyer; edits and inserts new material throughout
DOC.TEXT: Iran-Contra arms supplier Richard Secord today was sentenced to two years' probation for concealing from congressional investigators the fact that he paid for a $13,800 security system at Oliver North's home. Secord, who was enlisted by North to airlift supplies to the Nicaraguan rebels and assist the Reagan administration's secret arms shipments to Iran, has already suffered enough in the scandal, said U.S. District Court Judge Aubrey Robinson. Secord pleaded guilty Nov. 8 to making a false statement to congressional investigators. He could have faced up to five years in prison and a $250,000 fine. ``It is my judgment that there has been punishment in this case,'' Robinson told the retired Air Force major general. Secord's lawyer, Thomas Green, told the judge that his client's life has been ``in tatters'' since October 1986, when one of the airplanes in North's aid network was shot down over Nicaragua while carrying supplies for the rebels. The shootdown, which took place in the last days of a congressional ban on military aid to the Contras, led to the exposure of the secret resupply network overseen by North, then a National Security Council aide, from his offices in the Old Executive Office Building next to the White House. Iran-Contra prosecutor Reid Weingarten contended that Secord should be treated more harshly than North and former national security adviser Robert McFarlane, who also were sentenced to probation in the affair. ``I deeply regret not being more candid'' with congressional investigators about the `Enterprise' and North, Secord told the judge. ``If I could correct this I certainly would. I will regret it for the rest of my life.'' The Enterprise was the maze of offshore companies and Swiss bank accounts in the Iran-Contra scandal from which money was withdrawn by Secord to pay for North's home security system. Green said he and Secord were ``very pleased'' with the sentence and that Secord is ``now in a position to get on with his life.'' Secord was assessed a standard $50 in court costs. Weingarten told the judge that Secord, unlike North and McFarlane, had the benefit of personal legal counsel before making his false statement to congressional investigators, which occurred in 1987 after the Iran-Contra scandal had had come into public view. North was convicted of three crimes, including aiding and abetting an obstruction of Congress in 1986 in connection with a shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran in November 1985. McFarlane pleaded guilty to four counts of withholding information from Congress in connection with inquiries about whether secret assistance was going to the Contras. Weingarten also urged Judge Robinson to consider the fact that North and McFarlane committed their crimes in the context of their feeling that ``they had a higher duty.'' North and McFarlane were cases of ``misguided patriotism,'' said Weingarten, while ``we think General Secord has no such defense.'' ``The best that can be said'' of Secord's false statement is that he was motivated by the ``embarrassment'' of having paid for North's home security system, said the prosecutor. ``The worst'' that can be said is that he was trying to avoid ``the consequences of providing benefits to Colonel North,'' said Weingarten. ``This is the stuff of routine felonies,'' said the prosecutor. Secord is the fifth person sentenced in the Iran-Contra affair. No one has been given any jail time. In court papers, Iran-Contra prosecutors noted that Secord had been quoted as saying recently that the government's version of the facts in the case was ``asinine'' and that Arthur Liman, chief counsel to the Senate Iran-Contra committee, was a ``sleaze.'' ``While the government does not dispute that the defendant has suffered as a result of this case, it observes that his fall has not been accompanied by any public contrition,'' said the court filing. The article in which Secord was quoted appeared in the January issue of Vanity Fair magazine. In allowing Secord to plead guilty, the government agreed to drop its prosecution of him on 11 other charges, including allegations he lied to Congress by denying he made more than $1 million in profits. Secord, who has agreed to cooperate with prosecutors, has not ``recanted or modified much of the testimony regarding his financial activity,'' said a court filing Tuesday by Iran-Contra prosecutors. Secord testified he made only his $6,000-a-month salary in the affair. The prosecutors urged Robinson ``to find a sentence ... that balances the significant good'' the retired Air Force general has done in the past ``with the need to re-emphasize that our system of government ... will not tolerate intentional disrespect'' for the telling the truth while under oath. Secord denied the differences with prosecutors concern a significant portion of his congressional testimony. ``By our count, only about a dozen of his answers were even contested by the government,'' Secord's lawyers said in a court filing. They said the government was trying to circumvent the plea bargaining agreement, in which prosecutors said they would not recommend a specific sentence. ``It is fundamentally unfair for the government to implore this court to sentence General Secord on the basis of offenses for which he was never convicted,'' said his lawyers.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Backs Making EPA a Cabinet-Level Department
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts graf 10, Reilly said, with reaction.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, saying that environmental challenges ``are so important that they must be addressed at the highest level of government,'' today endorsed elevating the Environmental Protection Agency to a Cabinet-level Department of the Environment. At a news conference in the White House briefing room, the president backed legislation that has been introduced in Congress with bipartisan support. ``I am convinced that Cabinet status will help influence the world's environmental policies,'' he said, noting that many nations have environmental ministries. Bush's announcement represented a switch in his attitude toward creating a new Cabinet department. During his first year in office, he had opposed expansion of the Cabinet. The EPA, an independent regulatory agency created in 1970 to enforce environmental laws, would become the 15th Cabinet agency. The president met with sponsors of the legislation before announcing his endorsement and said he would work with Congress to draft acceptable legislation. Bush made the announcement in an opening statement in which he touched on a wide range of topics. ``I've decided that the environmental challenges that face America and the world are so important that they must be addressed at the highest level of government,'' he said. Bush said EPA, now headed by Administrator William Reilly, is ``one of the largest and most important regulatory agencies in the government'' and called elevation of it to Cabinet status ``another step forward ... in support of conservation and environmental protection.'' Reilly said ``the elevation of EPA is an important environmental milestone.'' Leaders of the House and Senate Government Operations Committees introduced bipartisan legislation Tuesday that would create a Department of the Environment and make the EPA administrator part of the Cabinet as environmental secretary. Similar legislation has been introduced in the past, but made little headway without support from the White House. Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio, chairman of the Senate Government Operations Committee, said the EPA as a regulatory agency without Cabinet status ``doesn't send the appropriate signal to the rest of the world'' at a time when critical environmental issues are global in nature. ``Environmental concerns have induced every major industrialized nation to create a ministerial post for environmental protection with the only exception being the United States,'' said Glenn at a news conference. Sen. William Roth, R-Del., another cosponsor and the ranking GOP member on the committee, called raising the EPA's status ``a first step to reorganizing government to face the problems of the '90s and the first problems of the 21st Century.'' In the House, Rep. John Conyers, D-Mich., chairman of the House Government Operations Committee, promised to push the EPA bill to the floor as quickly as possible and said he hoped legislation could be ready for the president's signature by the 20th anniversary of Earth Day in late April. Rep. Henry Waxman, D-Calif., said Cabinet rank would give the EPA additional cout needed to deal with other parts of the government on environmental issues. ``Too often EPA's initiatives have been ignored or stymied,'' he said. In addition to giving the EPA Cabinet rank, the House and Senate bills call for creating a presidential commission to examine the effects of current environmental laws and recommend ways to streamline them. The bills also would create an agency within the new Cabinet-level department to assemble environmental statistics similar to the way the Bureau of Labor Statistics provides employment and other economic data. ``This (legislation) alone will not solve our environmental challenges, but it's an important first step in giving the environment the priority attention for which it badly cries out,'' said Conyers.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: then Charles.
DOC.TEXT: Q: Mr. President, given the weakness of the dollar and the turmoil in the financial markets and the recent poor economic indicators, what are you going to do to calm the economy _ calm the markets and keep the economy from sliding into a recession? A: Well, one thing I'm not going to do is comment on levels of the market, except to say that there's been a substantial increase over the last year, and some are reading the recent couple of days as corrections, although I gather it recovered a little bit yesterday, and the market has always been an indicator, and it's been one that's been read quite positively. But I don't want to get into market levels. What I do want to do is establish sound policies, and I'm convinced that if we can get the cooperation of Congress that we need on reducing the deficit, that that will go a long way, not market prices but in terms of the fundamentals on the economy. It's slowed down a little. There's a lot of prediction that it will be slow for a while and then have a rather robust step-up come summer. But I don't know. All I know is that we've got to not bash anybody but get out there and try to enact policies that will help keep the longest recovery in modern history going. Q: You said that you felt that there was room for further reduction of interest rates. Given the need to attract foreign investment from overseas where rates are high, how do you square that with your call for lower interest rates? A: You mean to attract -- Q: Attract foreign investment to cover the U.S. deficit and yet though we're competing against the foreign investment _ A: I think that people see U.S. _ the U.S. still, regardless of what's temporary out there, as the safest haven for investment anywhere in the world, and I want to conduct the fiscal policies of this government so they will continue to see it that way. John, then Charles, then we'll take -- Q: Going back to the vote on the Chinese student visas, you and your people have been trying to get that vote delayed. Is that because you have some indications from the Chinese that they may soon release Fang Lizhi ... A: No. Q: ... and if this vote goes against you, it could hurt his chances? A: No, it is not, but I don't think it will help his chances. But I would love to see that step taken by the Chinese. But it isn't _ there's not a _ I think we're reconciled to the fact that the vote will go forward tomorrow in the Senate. Q: When you try to defend your China policy, one thing you never do is talk about the ``China card.'' You seem to hate that expression, even though when Kissinger and Nixon were doing it, it was considered a master stroke of foreign policy, playing the Chinese off against the Soviets. If Gorbachev does fall from power and is succeeded by men whose role model is Joe Stalin, aren't you going to have to play the China card, too? A: I don't think you ``play a card.'' I think that's gratuitously offensive to the Soviets and to the Chinese. But one of the reasons I want to stay engaged is that there are geopolitical reasons to have good relations or improved relations even under these unsatisfactory conditions. And it's going to be hard to do because of the human rights setback. But I want to have some contact. I want to retain contact because, as you look around the world, take a look at Cambodia. Take a look at Japan. Take a look at a lot of countries in the Pacific. China is a key player. And I'd like to think that our representations will have them move forward on the human rights side so we can have a more normalized relationship with them. Q: Mr. President, regarding the Soviet Union, have you in the course of these events going on in Baku, or any of your senior people _ I see General Scowcroft is here _ been in touch with Mr. Gorbachev or his people to discuss how severe it is, and ... A: Well, we've had contact with them. I don't remember when my last contact was with Mr. Gorbachev, but it didn't relate specifically to the Baku. Q: Could I then follow, sir, to ask you to reconcile, if you can, the position that you've taken that you say you want Mr. Gorbachev to survive and succeed, and on the other hand, you have areas of the Soviet Union such as the Baltics that you do not recognize as being part of the Soviet Union, and where you say you favor an independent pursuit of their own destiny. Does he succeed if they secede? A: Well, he _ that's again, at this juncture the U.S. position is well known, and you've stated it correctly, that we have not recognized the status of the Baltics. However, what I say that we want to do is to encourage Mr. Gorbachev's stand that peaceful change is the order of the day. And he's sorting out some very difficult internal problems in these three Baltic countries. And I don't think it helps facilitate things for us to fine tune all that. They know our position. I talked to him about this, incidentally, at Malta. But the thing I think is that, in looking at the Soviet scene there, that he is still adhering as best he can to the concept of peaceful change in the Baltics. And that's got to dominate.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Former Slovak Party Boss Charged With Abuse of Power
DOC.TEXT: Two more Communist officials have been charged with abuse of political power, the Communist Party's daily newspaper said today. The officials were identified as former Slovak party First Secretary Ignac Janak and Jan Svab, former head of the party's economic department. ``Ignac Janak was given a loan out of the operational funds of the party, which in itself is a misdemeanor or a criminal act,'' the newspaper Rude Pravo said. ``It is true that I. Janak paid the loan back, but circumstances of the whole case must be re-examined,'' the paper added. The date of the indictments against the men was not disclosed. The newspaper did not specify the charges against Svab, but it appeared he also would be tried in connection with the loan. Former Communist officials have been under investigation for possible abuse of power since the nation's peaceful revolution in November. Miroslav Stepan, the former Prague Party boss blamed for the bloody crackdown on student demonstrators that led to the revolution, was charged in December with abuse of political power. The revolution led to the downfall of the Communist government. The Communist Party then relinquished its constitutionally guaranteed monopoly on power, and free elections were tentatively set for June. The nation also plans to move toward a free-market economy and strengthen ties with the West as part of the democratic reforms that have swept the rest of the East bloc. In another development today, a Czechoslovak community took out an ad in one of West Germany's most respected daily newspapers to offer its statue of Josef Stalin to collectors for $50,000. The advertisement in the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung, placed by officials in the north Moravian city of Zabreh, said the larger-than-life statue was dismantled Dec. 8 after residents made it clear they wanted it out. ``The new owner will not only get a unique curiosity, he will also be supporting the struggle of the Czechoslovak people for freedom and democracy,'' the advertisement said. It said money from the sale would go toward refurbishing the local hospital.

DOC.HEAD: `Monster in Nurse's Whites' Gets 50 Years in Injection Deaths
DOC.TEXT: A nurse was sentenced to 50 years to life in prison today for killing four patients by injecting them with a powerful muscle relaxant in a scheme to revive them and play the hero. Richard Angelo, 27, of Lindenhurst, was convicted Dec. 14 of two counts of murder and one each of manslaughter and criminally negligent homicide in the 1987 deaths at Good Samaritan Hospital. He received the maximum sentence. ``You had no right to usurp God's function,'' said Judge Alfred Tisch. ``Each of those patients had a right to enjoy, in their own way, every day that was available to them.'' Angelo told police he injected patients so that he could revive them. At his trial the prosecutor called him a ``monster in nurse's whites.'' The most dramatic testimony against Angelo came from one of his victims who survived an injection, 75-year-old Gerolamo Kucich. The Yugoslavian immigrant told the jury that Angelo gave him an injection, saying it would ``make me feel better.'' Minutes later, Kucich testified, he was fighting for his breath. Officials exhumed the bodies of 33 patients who died suspiciously at Good Samaritan while Angelo worked there. Traces of the muscle relaxant Pavulon were found in six of the bodies. A Pavulon-laced syringe was found in Angelo's apartment the day before his arrest. Angelo was also convicted of five counts of assault _ against the four who died and Kucich. He was acquitted of assault against two patients who were found to have traces of Pavulon in their blood but whose deaths could not be proved to have been caused by the drug.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: to dominate.
DOC.TEXT: Q: Mr. President, President Jaruzelski of Poland recently suggested that the four big powers reconfirm -- or reaffirm the frontiers of Poland irrespective of whatever happens to Germany. Would the United States join such a reconfirmation of the frontiers? A: Well, we have recognized under Helsinki existing borders and I have no problem reiterating that. But whether that requires some kind of _ some kind of an international action on it, I just have no judgment on that. Yes? Q: Mr. President, Havel of Czechoslovakia proposed yesterday a summit in Prague between Mr. Gorbachev and you. Do you think it's a good idea? A: Listen, I respect him so much, and I don't just give him the back of my hand, but we've got a summit set and we have a very critical agenda that I want to see met _ goals that I want to see met. And so, I think at this time, that suggestion is not going to work out the way he suggests. But I was rather moved by the suggestion and by the conditions that make the suggestion possible. Who would have dreamed this a year ago, that the conditions inside Czechoslovakia would give them less than a, you know _ or would give him the freedom to make this kind of suggestion and have it rather _ I was rather moved by it. But I don't believe it's going to work for this summit. Ann? Q: Mr. President, you've opposed the Moynihan Social Security bill strongly. Would you endorse or work for or support a Republican alternative proposed by Congessman Porter that would take the Social Security increases for this and next year and allow people to keep those tax increases and put them in a separate account? A: The Porter proposal has some interesting ingredients to it. I am not prepared to endorse it. We don't have provisions for that in our budget proposals. It's worthy, though, of consideration, of some study, but I'm not prepared to endorse that, no, I'm not. Q: Is that not the first step to privatizing Social Security? A: Well, I don't think he would say that it is _ that that's the inevitable goal. But it has certain aspects there. But people are concerned about Social Security so when you have innovative thinking of that nature, I don't want to just gun it down. I'm not going to support it. Yes? Q: Mr. President, over the last few years there have been large increases in the Social Security tax and even though it's a regressive tax, people supported it or swallowed it because they were told that that was necessary to make the system solvent for the next generation. But, now everyone is finding out that, in fact, that money isn't there any longer and it's been used for debt reduction. Given the fact that people are now realizing that this is happening, do you think it's fair to ask them to continue to pay this increased tax for even one month longer? A: The commission that reformed Social Security was well aware of what you've just talked about. They considered it. I think the commission included Mr. Moynihan, I may be mistaken, but I think it did. And they considered this point, and we will have some innovative suggestions as we go along here as to how to compensate for this understandable concern on the part of some. But I would _ for now, for this year, we will _ we will not alter the recommendations of that bipartisan commission. Yes? Q: Mr. President _ yes, could I just briefly _ do you feel that this increase was sold to people under false premises? A: No. Because I think these were intelligent people wrestling with a very, very difficult problem, and I can't accuse them of selling the commission conclusions under false cover. Owen, and then Ann. Q: Well, as you know, the budget deficit has been coming down over the past few years solely because Social Security surplus has been rising. And, in fact, your own budget projections show $200-billion-a-year deficits in the indefinite future when you remove the Social Security surplus. Given the fact that you have such a large deficit in every other program, when will you and the Congress stop both bickering and counting gimmicks and deal with this problem that the American public has said for a decade -- A: Thank you for the endorsement of our approach, Owen. We would urge that we stop bickering and go forward with the proposal that we come out with, that I think will begin to address itself to Maureen's question, that is very sound, and nobody's trying to conceal the fact that the Social Security trust fund is operating at a surplus. That's not the _ there wasn't any concealment by the Speaker of the House, Tip O'Neill, and others that entered into this, you know, bipartisan agreement. Ann?
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: agreement. Ann?
DOC.TEXT: Q: Well, wait a minute (inaudible) your own budget proposal, that you will unveil on Monday, which shows a $64 billion deficit, in fact, if you remove Social Security ... A: But you're arguing ... Q: ... will be closer to $150 billion A: But you're making the argument of _ the old argument _ of taking the Social Security trust fund off budget. And at this juncture, we're not prepared to do that. But wait till you see the detail, and I hope you'll see the American people will see something here that _ that it begins to address itself to these fundamentals that I think are properly being asked about. Anne, and then Rita. Q: Mr. President, could you confirm this week's published report that there are divisions within your own immediate family on the issue of abortion? And in particular, could you confirm the widely held view that your own wife supports abortion rights? A: No, I couldn't confirm that, and I can't _ and the meeting that I read about in one of the most respected publications was pure, unadulterated _ um _ uh _ (laughter) _ ``malarkey'' is the word I like to use. It just wasn't there. Rita? Q: Mr. President? A: Yes? Q: If I could follow up, as I understand your position, you now say that the question of abortion is one of personal choice, one on which Republicans can have diverse views and still be good Republicans. A: I've always said that, Anne. I've campaigned for people that disagree with me on _ on abortion. Q: But my question is, you say it's an issue of personal choice and a question of conscience, and yet you support a constitutional amendment which would remove that choice for all Americans. How do you reconcile those two ... A: I reconcile that I was elected to try to fulfill the _ the platform and the programs that I _ that I believe in. And so that's my personal choice, but that doesn't mean I have lack of respect for others. And that _ that I'm going to go out and not campaign for people that disagree with me _ on this issue, on foreign policy or whatever it is. And so that's how I explain it. Yes, Rita? Q: Mr. President, last time you took questions here you were claiming success for the capture of Noriega, and also that you had protected American lives in Panama. But what do you have to say to the Panamanians about more than 200 civilians _ civilian Panamanians that were killed as a result of this invasion? And also, in your aid package to Panama, which hasn't been announced yet, do you plan to offer any compensation to the families of these people? A: Well, I'm not sure of the details on the aid package because we haven't _ I haven't signed off on it yet. But what I say to them is: Look, you lost some Panamanian lives, innocent life was lost. And yet 92 percent of the people in Panama strongly supported the action of the United States. Isn't that significant? And I mourn the loss of innocent civilians in Panama or anywhere else, and certainly mourn the loss of the life of Americans. But you have to feel concerned about that, but you have to look at the broad picture. And then you have to do _ and I'm very pleased with the strong support from the Panamanian people _ and then you've got to do what's right. You have to try to help, repair the wounds, repair the damage. We've got to go to the _ I know most of you are very anxious to be at the arrival ceremony out there. And I have to be there _ yes? Q: Mr. President, another question that's been raised by the Moynihan proposal is the fairness of the tax system. Over the past decade, even as income taxes have come down for high paid people, Social Security taxes have gone up, mostly for lower and middle income people. Do you think that's fair? A: Well, look, if we were all starting over, I think we could fine tune the entire tax system. We're not starting over and I think that system has been in and out over the years basically a pretty fair system. And while I'm here, don't think I've lost because of some arguments _ political arguments on the Hill that capital gains reduction is only for the rich, I support it. But the reason I do is that, in my view, it increases jobs for people. So, you have to look at what individual _ somebody has an idea that if some individual deduction that encourages, say, drilling when we are in an increasingly negative oil supply situation _ and some would say, ``Hey, that favors those who go out and drill.'' And I say, ``Wait a minute, that's true.'' And that may not be fair to some taxpayer here, but the national interest is best served by the encouragement and development of domestic resources. We're all fat, dumb and happy about our energy situation today, and I'm not. So, there's all kinds of provisions that some will argue are fair or unfair. Q: But sir, some of your favorite economist think tanks say that the Social Security tax acts as a great disincentive to work and to employing people. Isn't that to serve the same end? A: Well, I think that's a legitimate complaint about some of it and that's one of the reasons I favor holding the line on taxes. And one of the reasons I opposed Moynihan is I think it's a disguise for increased taxes around the corner. And I don't want to see the benefits of Social Security cut. It is odd that a Republican president, often accused by political opponents in an election year, is the one that is protecting the sanctity of the Social Security benefits. And I would say to those out around the country, ``Take a hard look now. Don't let that rabbit be pulled out of the hat by one hand and 25 other rabbits dumped on you in another.'' This is _ will be a very complicated situation and these _ this is a -- you know _ sleight of hand operation here. And the very day Moynihan proposed it _ or the next day _ what do we get? We get the call from another prominent, respected Democratic senator saying, ``Raise the sales tax on everybody.'' Before we go making a lot of changes, let's know exactly where everybody's coming from in this. And I think Mr. Moynihan of a few years back ought to go out and discuss it with Mr. Moynihan of today, because he was a part, I believe, of a Social Security compromise that didn't correct some of the injustices it made ... Q: Mr. President? A: Hey, listen, I've got to be out there looking very strict here at 10 o'clock. Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater: Thank you.

DOC.HEAD: Dog Who Mauled Baby to Death Destroyed by Animal Shelter Officials
DOC.TEXT: A Siberian husky that mauled to death a 5-day-old baby girl has been destroyed, officials said Wednesday. The 13-year-old dog named Bandit was put to sleep Tuesday at the request of the infant's parents, said Louise Cox, manager of the Burlington County Animal and Rabies Control Center. The dog will be tested for rabies. Authorities said the dog entered the infant's nursery and pulled Anna Lynn Pagliaro of Florence from her crib on Sunday. The infant, born Jan. 16, died from a broken neck. Animal shelter officials said the dog appeared jealous of the child, who was brought home from the hospital Friday. Ms. Cox said the shelter is also seeking a home for the couple's 12-year-old female Siberian husky. Only the male dog was involved in the attack.

DOC.HEAD: Major Opposition Party Demands Interim Government Resign
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of people demonstrated outside the headquarters of the governing National Salvation Front today to protest its decision to compete in national elections and to demand its resignation. The biggest opposition party, the National Peasant Party, said it feared the Front will put the Communist Party in power again, and it also demanded the leaders step down. The protests came in reaction to the Front's announcement Tuesday that it will run candidates in national elections May 20. Previously, it pledged not to field candidates. Protesters chanted ``Communists in disguise!'' and ``Elections without the Front!'' as they gathered by the tanks and soldiers guarding the Front's headquarters. ``The National Salvation Front must resign today as it can't be both a referee and a player,'' the Peasant Party said in a communique read by party leader Corneliu Coposu to party members. It accused the Front of trying to steal the victory of the young people and others who fought communism and dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. The Front took over after Ceausescu was overthrown Dec. 22. He was executed Dec. 25. More than 50 Peasant Party members jammed the hallway of the party's headquarters and cheered today's communique. Some then joined the demonstration at the Front's headquarters. ``If (President Ion) Iliescu wanted to gain power, he should have gotten signatures on petitions and formed a party,'' said one protester, engineer Adrian Mihalcea. Some opposition figures have alleged that members of the Front were the same men who played roles in Ceausescu's Communist government. Two weeks ago, Iliescu bowed to huge protests and outlawed the Communist Party, but the next day he reversed the decision, saying it had been too hasty. Instead, Iliescu said the public would get to decide the issue in a referendum Jan. 28. Last week, the Front canceled the referendum, saying the questions to be on it were moot and citing time constraints. The Front said U.N. observers will monitor the May elections, which were delayed from April to give the 15 new or revived political parties more time to campaign.

DOC.HEAD: Second Cruise Missile Test This Week
DOC.TEXT: There will be a test flight of an unarmed U.S. cruise missile over northwestern Canada on Friday, the second this week, a Canadian military spokesman said Wednesday. Maj. Jan Martinsen said it will be ``a carbon copy'' of a test flight that went as planned Tuesday when a cruise missile made a parachute landing on a snow-covered weapons range on the Alberta-Saskatchewan border. Tuesday's flight was the 14th test under a 1983 U.S.-Canadian agreement that allows the United States to conduct up to six tests a year between January and March. The test flight Tuesday ended when the missile touched down on the Primrose air weapons range at 1:49 p.m. EST, three hours and 47 minutes after it was released over the Beaufort Sea in the western Arctic. The missile had been flown to the launch site from an Air Force base in Texas by a U.S. B-52 bomber. The ground-hugging missile followed a 1,320-mile route from the Beaufort up the Mackenzie Valley, across northeastern British Columbia and over northern Alberta to the air weapons range, 130 miles northeast of Edmonton. About 100 people gathered at the Alberta legislature to protest Tuesday's test. Audrey Bath, chairman of the Alberta Citizens' Anti-cruise Committee, criticized Ottawa and the Canadian military for allowing the test amid easing tensions between Eastern Europe and the West. ``Our world is seemingly changing towards peacemaking and we continue to participate in readiness towards destruction,'' Bath said.

DOC.HEAD: Fed Says Economy Continues to Grow Slowly
DOC.TEXT: The nation's economy continued to grow slowly as it entered the new year and is expected to continue that expansion throughout 1990, the Federal Reserve Board said today. ``Economy activity is expanding slowly in most of the nation, with conditions somewhat stronger in the West than in the East,'' the central bank said in a survey of its 12 districts completed Jan. 13. Retail sales varied during the Christmas shopping period, ranging from ``disappointing'' in Boston to modest in Philadelphia and Atlanta and relatively strong in Chicago, Minneapolis and San Francisco. But the report added, ``widespread discounting generally reduced store profits.'' ``Manufacturing activity is generally sluggish, with production declines in some industries (autos, in particular) offsetting gains in others (such as commercial aircraft and oilfield equipment,'' the survey found. ``Several districts reported that the steel and computer industries, among others, may be `bottoming out.''' The survey by the Fed's 12 district banks was conducted in preparation for the Feb. 6-7 meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, the central bank's monetary policy-setting arm. It was compiled in what is known as the ``Beige Book'' by the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston. The slow economy has resulted from the Fed's battle to drive interest rates higher as a way of dampening demand and cooling off inflationary pressures. The Fed switched course last June and has permitted short-term rates to drop gradually in an effort to keep the slowing economy from stopping altogether and falling into a recession. But the central bank has not acted since then and just last week, the White House broke its usual no-comment stance on Fed activities and said ``lower interest rates are justified.'' As is usual, today's report by the Fed carried no recommendations, but said, ``The outlook is for slow growth in all regions in 1990; some respondents expect improvement late in the year.'' In other areas, the report's summary said, ``Unseasonably cold weather dampened construction activity in some areas, but real estate markets generally held steady. Cold or dry weather also adversely affected citrus, vegetable and winter wheat crops. Other agricultural and resource-related sectors did moderately well.''

DOC.HEAD: Navy Stunt Pilots' Training Flight Ends in Crash
DOC.TEXT: Two jets in the Navy's Blue Angels precision flying team collided while practicing a stunt, causing one plane to crash into a mountain, the Navy said. The pilot of the downed jet ejected safely. The FA-18 Hornet plunged into 759-foot Superstition Mountain about 20 miles from El Centro on Tuesday, said Mike Ray, a spokesman at the El Centro Naval Air Facility. In Hawaii, the Coast Guard, Marines and Navy resumed the search today for a Marine pilot whose helicopter crashed during training maneuvers. The CH-46 Sea Knight went down Monday about 25 miles from Oahu. Three rescued Marines were in satisfactory condition. In the El Centro collision, three other planes, including one involved in the collision, returned safely to the base, Ray said. The pilot who ejected, Marine Corps Capt. Chase Moseley, was treated at a hospital for facial bruises and cuts, authorities said. The Blue Angels use the desert base in the winter to practice the daredevil routines they perform at air shows around the country. The four aircraft were practicing a tight ``diamond roll'' formation when the lead plane flown by Cmdr. Pat Moneymaker struck Moseley's aircraft, Ray said. Moneymaker is the Blue Angels' commanding officer. The Navy is investigating how the collision occurred. In the maneuver, four planes fly skyward in a diamond formation from low altitude and perform a 500 mph loop while staying in a tightly packed group. The accident was the first involving a Blue Angels aircraft since February 1987, when an FA-18 crashed during practice. The pilot ejected safely.

DOC.HEAD: Lunar Probe Launched
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with satellite separating from rocket, orbiting the Earth. ADDS that craft is unmanned. Pickup 10th graf, `Just before...
DOC.TEXT: Japan's first lunar probe lifted off today, billowing clouds of smoke and carrying Japanese hopes of becoming the third nation to reach the moon. Launch officials said the unmanned Muses-A satellite separated from the rockets several minutes into the flight as planned. Mission chief Hiroki Matsuo said data from the satellite picked up by tracking stations in California and Australia showed it was orbiting the Earth at a maximum distance of 186,000 miles, compared with an eventual goal of 310,000 miles. The slender M3S-2 rocket disappeared into the night sky over the Pacific Ocean from its launch pad nestled between mountains on Japan's southern coast. The rocket blasted off on schedule at 8:46 p.m. (6:46 a.m. EST). If successful, the Muses-A satellite will be the first spacecraft to visit the moon since an unmanned Soviet vehicle landed on its surface in 1976. Only the United States and the Soviet Union have sent spacecraft to the moon. Originally set for Tuesday, the liftoff was postponed with only 18 seconds to go after an electrical switching problem cut off power to a hydraulic pump used to aim the nozzle of an auxiliary booster rocket. Matsuo said Tuesday's delay was the first time in five launches of the solid-fuel M3S-2 that the countdown had been stopped in the final 60 seconds. The three-stage red-and-silver M3S-2 rocket, which cannot lift much more than its 400-pound payload, carried Muses-A into an elliptical orbit that is to bring it to within about 10,000 miles of the moon in eight weeks. Just before crossing the moon's path, a smaller satellite will break off the Muses-A and go into lunar orbit and send data to the larger satellite on temperatures and electrical fields. The Nissan Motor Co., Japan's second-largest automobile maker, built the three-stage, 62-ton M3S-2 engine used in the lunar mission. Japan's first satellite was launched in 1970. Muses-A would be the 13th Japanese satellite in operation. The Muses-A mission is being conducted by Japan's Institute of Space and Astronautical Science, one of two government-funded space agencies. ``This time we are going to the moon. But our objective is not the moon itself,'' Matsuo said. ``Our institute is getting into interplanetary missions in the 1990s and for that we need to refine our technology.'' In recent years, Japan has achieved a respected aerospace launch record, despite its late entry into the field, low budgets _ $1.06 billion last year _ and a shortage of good launch sites. Japan's two main launch areas _ in Uchinoura and in nearby Tanagashima _ are only a tiny fraction of the size of space centers in other nations. The Institute of Space, affiliated with the Education Ministry, focuses on scientific research while the Science and Technology Agency, affiliated with the National Space Development Agency, develops satellites and rockets for applied uses such as communications and weather observation. The 12 satellites Japan currently operates include two marine observation satellites, two weather satellites, four communications satellites and one broadcasting satellite, which beams television programs directly to viewers' homes. The remainder are scientific or engineering test satellites. Japan's trading partners have criticized it for not buying more foreign-made satellites and rockets at lower cost. But the National Space Development Agency is developing a new rocket, the H-2, which will match U.S., Soviet and European rockets in payload capability and be competitive in price, director Tomifumi Godai said.
Here are excerpts from recent editorials in newspapers throughout the country. Jan. 2

Charleston (W.Va.) Daily Mail on Mayor Barry: Washington Mayor Marion Barry provides a good example of why Americans no longer believe public officials: Public officials all too frequently lie. Rumors of drug abuse dogged Barry for years. ... Barry vehemently denied the charges. In a twist on the old trick of a troubled politician wrapping himself in the flag, Barry said the investigation of his activities was racially motivated. Only afer Barry was arrested in a sting operation _ and only after he tested positive for cocaine _ did he admit he had a problem and seek treatment. Even at that, Barry sugarcoated his dilemma, saying, ``I spent so much time doing for others that I have not worried enough about ... caring for myself.'' Anybody buying that? No wonder the public is cynical about the political process.

Jan. 20 The Phoenix Gazette on the McMartin trial: It was the nation's longest and costliest trial. After $15 million, 2{ years of testimony, 124 witnesses, 2,000 exhibits and 100,000 pages of transcripts, the defendants were acquitted of 52 charges, the jury (was) unable to reach a verdict on 11 others. California's McMartin Pre-School molestation story was a feast for the media. Almost 400 children were alleged to have been molested at McMartin, eight people were originally charged and there were more than 50 uncharged suspects in a case that reportedly involved a kiddie porn ring, a Satanic cult, animals, mutilations and torture. In the end, however, there were just two defendants, Raymond Buckey and his mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey. After the verdicts, a few jurors said that while they believed that some molestations occurred at McMartin, the prosecution failed to prove where, when and by whom. The prosecution, in effect, had failed, and failed miserably. ... Media critic David Shaw says the McMartin story ``exposed several basic flaws in the way contemporary news organizations function. Pack journalism. Vigilantism. Laziness. Superficiality. Cozy relationships with prosecutors. A competitive zeal that sends reporters off in a frantic search to be first with the latest shocking allegation, responsible journalism be damned.'' Shaw may never get a conviction on those charges, but it seems clear that shoddy workmanship can be traced to many professions in the McMartin case and that the nation's longest and costliest trial will be remembered for little else.

Jan. 19 The Peninsula Daily News, Port Angeles, Wash., on congressional ethics: In Eastern Europe, 1989 may have been a great year for democracy. But on Capitol Hill, the democratic process appears to have taken a beating. A number of congressmen were caught in embarrassing ethics controversies. Five senators have been accused of improperly pressuring bank regulators on behalf of the owner of a California thrift in exchange for generous campaign contributions. Another senator is accused of seeking special favors for his political allies from the Department of Housing and Urban Development. And still another is accused of evading the limits on speaking fees from outside groups. There is a positive side to all this evidence of misbehavior. It should help those members of Congress who have been trying to require stricter ethical conduct on the hill. There currently are efforts to impose spending limits on congressional campaigns and curbs on political action committee donations. The opposition to such reforms has to have been weakened by the previous year's unhappy revelations.

Jan. 20 The World, Coos Bay, Ore., on health care: In a glimpse of where public health care may well be headed in the future, federal health officials issued a report ... that is fairly easy to interpret. Nine preventable chronic diseases are responsible for more than half the deaths in this country, but only 2 percent of the public health care dollars are spent for prevention of those deaths. The problem, of course, is in the nature of the diseases and their prevention. They tend to be illnesses brought on by personal habits that are hard to break: stroke, heart disease, diabetes, obstructive lung disease, lung cancer, breast cancer, cervical cancer, colorectal cancer and cirrhosis of the liver. To prevent them, or at least reduce their impact on death rates in America, we need to stop smoking tobacco, get our weight under control, exercise more, drink less, and watch what we eat. ... (W)e have to find out what makes us so willing to spend thousands of dollars on radiation therapy or surgery or special treatments, but unwilling to take the time or trouble or expense to prevent the problem in the first place.

Jan. 19 Winona (Minn.) Daily News on oat bran: Is anyone surprised at researchers' claims that oat bran isn't the panacea it has been made out to be? In our health-crazed times, foods are made out to be heroes and villains at a vigorous pace. What was good 10 years ago is bad today. What is touted as a cure-all for the '90s will be a carcinogen in the next century. The (new) study ... said that oat bran isn't bad, but it has been overhyped. Critics responded by saying that (the) report isn't accurate and is based on a small sample. But several leading scientists backed up the study's methods. Clearly oat bran is mired in a sticky controversy over its benefits. Don't bet your heart on oat bran; exercise and common sense give you much better odds. And then there's the question of what kind of cholesterol oat bran worked against. Was it the good cholesterol or the bad cholesterol?
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: bad cholesterol?
DOC.TEXT: Jan. 21 Picayune (Miss.) Item on health studies: We are growing weary of medical researchers who rush to get their latest findings in the headlines _ for whatever career or financial benefit that provides _ only to have someone else come along and refute their discovery with a study that produced a different result. The public is getting confused. After all the hoopla about oat bran lowering cholesterol, new research claims it ain't true. Cereal makers who have been hyping oat bran products are now accused of misleading the consumer. To be sure, this binge of selling processed foods with exaggerated health claims has been way overdone, but let's not forget who started the oat bran fad. It wasn't the cereal makers. It was doctors. ... The medical community could do a better job of policing itself on this. Official journals of medicine should demand more extensive study before publishing headline-grabbing ``findings.''

Jan. 18 The News-Herald, Panama City, Fla., on the economy: How are economic prospects for the 1990s? Even though the economy is chugging along in its eighth year of expansion, Rep. Lee Hamilton, chairman of the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, thinks prospects are bleak. Summarizing his committee's position, he writes ``While we have been successful in reducing unemployment without reviving inflation, we have not improved our prospects for long-term growth or spread the benefits of growth fairly among our citizens.'' Say what? Cutting inflation and putting people to work is no mean feat. And it's odd for a member of the House of Representatives, which just voted itself a tax-funded 35 percent pay raise, to be worried about spreading ``growth fairly.'' This hypocritical rhetoric is but a prelude to: ``We cannot eliminate the deficit without a moderate tax increase. We cannot grow out of the deficit.'' Spur the economy through a capital-gains tax cut. A tax cut, not a stifling tax increase, is the ticket to prosperity in the 1990s.

Jan. 20 Concord (N.H.) Monitor on education: Study after study ... demonstrate that American schoolchildren fare poorly when stacked up against students from other developed nations. They don't know geography, can't do math, give up on science; their reasoning powers are relatively undeveloped. So it is logical to presume that if the United States is, as President Bush has said, lavishing ``unsurpassed resources'' on children's schooling, it is not spending that money wisely. And it is equally clear that if we don't start spending money more wisely, the standard of living in the United States will continue to slide.

Jan. 22 Farmington (N.M.) Daily Times on drugs: The Bush administration and Colombian leaders are wise to give little credence to an offer by drug bosses that would, they say, end the bloody drug war being waged in the Latin American country. In recent days, members of the Medellin cartel have said they want a truce in the drug war that has resulted in the deaths of at least 209 people since last August. In exchange, the ``extraditables'' _ as they are also known _ seek complete amnesty. As the saying goes: If it sounds too good to be true, it usually is. The drug lords' offer indeed sounds too good to be true. It's hard to believe they intend to so easily give up the extremely lucrative drug trade. To agree to the amnesty demands would be a slap in the face of the direct and indirect victims of their terrorism and drug dealings. And should they be granted amnesty, it can almost be guaranteed the cartel would soon again be dealing drugs with impunity.

Jan. 23 Orange County (Calif.) Register on the Armenia-Azerbaijan conflict: President George Bush ... has given qualified support to (the Soviet) invasion (of Azerbaijan). ... The Red Army invaded after two weeks of the majority Azeris, who are Moslems, killing minority Armenians, who are Christians. But there's more to this than the Soviets wish us to know, as has been revealed by Gary Kasparov, the world chess champion and one of the most independent figures in the Soviet Union. He is also a native of Baku, the Azerbaijani city the Red Army just conquered, and the son of a Jewish father and an Armenian mother. ... Kasparov also noted that most Armenians had already been evacuated by the time the Red Army assaulted Baku. Reports the AP: ``Therefore, he said, he believed the military action was intended to crush the Azerbaijani independence movement, not stop the killing, as Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev said.'' ... What we may have here is a classic Soviet ploy. Stir things up among minority peoples (the KBG has been there all along). Then paint the Red Army massacre as a ``rescue,'' while getting gullible Western leaders to approve. ... Bush should reverse himself and call on Moscow to grant independence to Azerbaijan, Armenia and all other captive nations.

Jan. 18 Bridgeton (N.J.) Evening News on the Armenia-Azerbaijan conflict: Some Europeans, exuberant over the thought that they are breaking free of the Soviet government, have mistaken freedom for license. The result is ... chaos ... developed in Armenia and neighboring Azerbaijan where Christians and Moslems suddenly began slaughtering each other. What is going on in the absence of any government restraint is a conflict of religions, not of governments. Nonetheless, it will doubtless result in a serious crackdown by Soviet authorities. It should. The Armenian Christians and the Azerbaijanian Moslems must understand that true democracy allows the practice of both beliefs to continue beside each other.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: each other.
DOC.TEXT: Jan. 17 The News and Courier, Charleston, S.C., on El Salvador: By publicly linking members of El Salvador's military to the brutal murders of six Jesuit priests, their housekeeper and her daughter, Salvadoran President Alfredo Cristiani has courageously confronted the barbarous elements within his own armed forces. It was a courageous act because ... Cristiani risks alienating not only El Salvador's powerful military establishment, but his own right-wing constituency. ... Cristiani's vow to punish all those involved ``down to the last person implicated'' will be difficult in a country that lacks both a democratic tradition and an independent judiciary. ... To his great credit, ... Cristiani has promised to leave no stone unturned in his effort to find and punish all those responsible for these crimes. Having taken that courageous first step, he is now obligated to ensure that justice is carried out.

Jan. 19 The Westerly (R.I.) Sun on Panama: As American troops leave Panama, pollsters have moved in and the ultimate judges have had their say. Panamanians by a wide margin say President Bush was right in ordering the strike that toppled Manuel Noriega's government and eventually led to his being brought to the United States to stand trial on drug trafficking charges. The approval was given by 89 percent of 1,304 people of Panama living in both urban and rural areas polled Jan. 5-13 by a firm associated with the Gallup organization. The 89 percent said the action was necessary, 88 percent saw it as beneficial to the country and wanted U.S. forces to remain as long as is necessary to ensure order, and 86 percent considered the invasion a ``liberation.'' On the other side of the coin, 87 percent of those polled had unfavorable opinion of Noriega and 91 percent viewed Noriega's Panamanian Defense Force as unfavorable and ``repressive.'' The verdict is in, let it stand.

Jan. 18 The Gastonia (N.C.) Gazette on NASA's Mars mission: More than one pair of eyes popped at NASA's projected price tag for missions to Mars and the moon: $15 billion to $20 billion a year for 25 years. Now some space experts are questioning whether NASA has gotten too bureaucratic and hidebound to do the job. Vice President Dan Quayle, head of the National Space Council, gave the agency a tweaking in a recent speech. NASA, he said, ``has not done as well as it could have in marshaling the resources and the leadership necessary to keep us ahead in space.'' While rejecting the idea that NASA be replaced, Quayle recommended loosening the agency's monopoly on space by reaching out to universities, private businesses and even other government agencies in a search for new ideas and methods.
