One privately developed idea, for example, is using lighter, inflatable material in constructing space stations, cutting expenses and time. There are drawbacks to the plan, and it may never be used. But it illustrates the fact that the freshest ideas are generated outside government. NASA should take Quayle's friendly suggestions to heart; as much as any federal agency, it can use those fresh ideas.

Jan. 19 Stevens Point (Wis.) Journal on bar code scanning: It's sort of like one of those stories we read in Scholastic Weekly, way back in elementary school. You know, researchers predict that in a few years, we'll have video telephones. Well, it's been a few decades, and we're still waiting. Anyway, researchers at a Japanese university say they're working on a system to allow motorists to get information about their location through bar codes painted on highways and read by computers in their cars. Researchers say they think they'll be able to design a system that will work even if the bar codes fade or become obscured by dirt. If that's the case, maybe they can do something about bar code scanners in the stores of today.

Jan. 22 The Daily Times, Primos, Pa., on the NCAA: It's sad to see that college athletics has put the pigskin ahead of the sheepskin in the easing of academic requirements for scholarship athletes. The NCAA recently caved in to pressure from the powers that be (Georgetown basketball coach John Thompson and Temple coach John Chaney to name a couple) and ripped the guts out of a year-old restriction on financial aid to new athletes who don't fully meet academic requirements for scholarships. It was only last year about this time that the NCAA designed Proposition 42, which would have banned all scholarships and other aid for freshman athletes who meet only part of grade and test-score minimums created three years ago under another measure called Proposition 48. Under Proposition 48, partial qualifiers could receive full scholarships while only having to sit out their freshman year. Prop 42 was a good thing, because it told prospective college athletes that they would have to study. And isn't that what college is supposed to be all about? ... Thompson claimed that Prop 42 discriminated against underprivileged and minority students. We find that hard to swallow, considering that college entrance standards for athletes have always appeared to be considerably lower than those set for non-athletes. And now with the further relaxing of such minimal standards in this latest measure _ which has become known as Proposition 26 _ colleges will be discriminating against underprivileged and minority applicants who just might not happen to play sports.
DOC.HEAD: End Editorial Rdp
House Readies Veto Override Vote on Chinese Students Bill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts new graf after 5th graf pvs, ``I ask, with new Simpson vote count; deletes grafs 16-17 pvs, now outdated.
DOC.TEXT: The House, newly convened for its 1990 election-year session, is preparing to hand President Bush an overwhelming foreign policy defeat and turn up the heat on the Senate to follow suit. Leaders in both parties predicted a big bipartisan vote today to override Bush's Nov. 30 veto of legislation potentially extending the stays of thousands of Chinese students in the United States to shield them from political reprisals at home. Bush today pleaded anew with lawmakers to let his veto stand, saying the students ``are safe now and will be safe in the future.'' Describing a meeting he had with Senate Republicans, Bush said he sought to point out steps the Chinese have taken to ease relations with the United States, such as accepting Peace Corps volunteers, muting ``hostile propaganda'' against Americans and easing harrassment of the U.S. Embassy, where a prominent Chinese dissident has been in hiding. ``I ask the Senate and the House to take a look at these things and take into account the totality of the policy,'' the president said. ``I think there is some indignation about students (in Congress) but I think also there's a dose of political rhetoric up there. ... '' Senate Minority Whip Alan Simpson, R-Wyo., said he believed Bush had been persuasive and had pulled to within six or seven votes of the 34 he will need to maintain his position when the Senate votes, as early as Thursday. He said his comments of a day earlier conceding defeat on the issue were just ``exaggerating.'' The Senate began its year on Tuesday debating an issue left over from 1989: clean air legislation that is more far-reaching and costly than Bush wants. Other thorny issues left over from the 101st Congress' lackluster first session loom ahead as well, including child care, parental leave, Bush's capital gains tax cut and the federal budget deficit. The call to order brought the Capitol out of a two-month winter rest with friendly reunions, a flurry of bill introductions and speeches and optimistic predictions for the year ahead. Rep. Jack Brooks, D-Texas, led the Pledge of Allegiance in the House and received hugs and a long standing ovation. Brooks had a brush with death during the holidays while hospitalized for pancreatitis. And a new House member was sworn in. Rep. Craig Washington wiped away tears after he took the oath to succeed Rep. Mickey Leland, D-Texas, who died last year in a plane crash in Ethiopia. A day earlier, a judge back in Texas sentenced Washington to 30 days in jail for contempt of court, accusing him of leaving legal clients ``in the lurch.'' As it faces a new year, Congress and the president will have to confront a dramatically changing relationship with the Soviet Union and its implications for U.S. defense spending and relations with Eastern Europe. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley promised the new session of Congress would be more productive than the last, including passage of campaign finance reform. And he said lawmakers will give careful study to a proposal by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., to cut Social Security taxes. On the Chinese students issue Bush was making his fight in the Senate, where he hoped to win the 34 votes needed to prevent a two-thirds majority for an override. Republican senators were invited to the White House for breakfast today for a personal lobbying session with the president. Lobbying on Capitol Hill Monday, Secretary of State James A. Baker III warned Republican senators a veto override could lead to a cutoff of the flow of Chinese students to the United States and a shutdown of cultural exchanges. The bill's sponsor, Rep. Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., said her only motives in seeking an override vote were to offer irrevocable protection to as many as 32,000 students and to send a clear signal of disdain for Beijing's crackdown last June on pro-democracy demonstrators. Simpson criticized Democrats for using the bill as a political blunt instrument in an effort to pare down the high approval ratings Bush has achieved in the polls following the U.S. invasion of Panama. Meanwhile, Moynihan, formally introducing his Social Security tax cut proposal, said the administration is deceiving workers because the excess Social Security taxes being collected from them are being used to make the federal deficit appear smaller. ``These are insurance contributions, they are premiums paid,'' Moynihan told a news conference. ``They do not belong to the government. If we are not going to save them we should return them.'' His bill, which has drawn widespread interest but few sponsors, would roll back the tax increase that took effect Jan. 1 and reduce another increase scheduled for next year. That would save a worker with income over $51,300 about $600, and leave the Social Security system with just enough money to pay retirees' checks, Moynihan said. The Bush administration says such cuts would lead to reductions in benefits or to efforts to raise other taxes. The Senate Finance Committee has scheduled hearings on the issue for Feb. 5 and 8.

DOC.HEAD: Networks in Dallas-Fort Worth Combine to Broadcast Drug Special
DOC.TEXT: Four TV stations, in an unprecedented case of cooperation, pre-empted two hours of prime-time shows to simultaneously broadcast an anti-drug program, picking up at least three-quarters of the people watching TV. The locally produced program, ``Texas Crackdown!'' was shown Tuesday on all three major network affiliates in the Dallas-Fort Worth area and one independent station, and was accompanied by a radio version on three stations. Dallas and Fort Worth newspapers joined the effort with drug quizzes in their Tuesday editions, and teachers assigned light homework so students could watch the show. Many schools planned quizzes and school projects based on the program. A non-profit group sponsored an essay contest for students, based on the program. WFAA, an ABC affiliate, aired the program with CBS affiliate KDFW, NBC affiliate KXAS and independent KDTX. Three Spanish-language radio stations _ KESS-AM, KSSA-AM and KSSA-FM _ broadcast the two-hour show in Spanish. Nielsen ratings showed that 75 percent of the people watching television in the Dallas-Fort Worth market watched ``Texas Crackdown!'' on the network affiliates at 9 p.m., said WFAA-TV president and general manager Dave Lane. On a normal viewing night, the percentages would be in the mid-to upper 60s for the three network affiliates, Lane said. The independent station's ratings were not available in the overnight reports, he said. Although the programs were sponsored by local hospitals and Domino's pizza, there were no regularly scheduled commercials. The time block cost the stations an estimated $1 million. Lane said the purpose of the program, which featured reports on recovering drug addicts and the emotional and physical costs of drug use, was drug prevention. ``We were not naive enough to believe that you can take people who are hooked on crack cocaine, put them in front of a TV and cure them,'' Lane said today. Wendell Harris, vice president and news director at KDFW, said, ``I don't know if we cured a soul, but if we made them think, and showed them where to get help. I think we did what we set out to do.'' ``Texas Crackdown!'' was conceived last summer in meetings between WFAA and officials of the Greater Dallas Crime Commission. The pictures of six suspected drug dealers were shown during the program. Viewers with information on drug dealers were eligible to win a $10,000 reward for information leading to arrests and convictions. Greg MacAleese of the crime commission said response to the tip line was overwhelming. A toll-free number for people needing help with drug addiction was overwhelmed with calls, said Ruth Feldman of the Alcohol and Drug Abuse Council. She said the bulk of the calls came from girls ages 13 to 15 who said they had little adult supervision.

DOC.HEAD: Riot Police Disperse Thousands Demonstrating in Yugoslav Province
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to UPDATE with witnesses reporting demonstration broke up by police, 10 people arrested. Pickup 5th pvs, `At least...
DOC.TEXT: Riot police used tear gas and a water cannon today to disperse about 40,000 ethnic Albanians demanding the lifting of a state of emergency in the ethnically torn province of Kosovo, witnessess said. The action came after an officer repeatedly told protesters to end the peaceful demonstration in Pristina, the provincial capital, the witnesses told The Associated Press. They said about 10 people were arrested as the crowd withdrew toward Vranjevac, a predominantly ethnic Albanian suburb of Pristina, where sporadic demonstrations were reported to be continuing. The witnesses spoke on condition of anonymity. The crowd consisting mainly of university students and construction workers, had gathered to demand that authorities end the state of emergency and halt what they say are political trials, police brutality and the detention of political prisoners. A smaller protest with similar demands occurred in Pristina on Tuesday. The demonstrators demanded a change in what they described as ``anti-Albanian discrimination'' and called for free elections in Kosovo, said the witnesses. The crowd chanted ``Traitors! Traitors!'' and demanded the resignation of Rahman Morina, the province's Communist leader, and Ju suf Karakusi, the police chief, whom they accuse of human rights abuses. Hundreds of workers in several major Kosovo companies staged support strikes during the day, the state news agency Tanjug reported. At least 28 people died in violent demonstrations in the province last year after constitutional changes that limited Kosovo's autonomy and gave Serbia, Yugoslavia's largest republic, near-total control over the region. Hundreds of ethnic Albanians, who make up 90 percent of Kosovo's 1.9 million people, were jailed in the police crackdown that followed the unrest. A partial state of emergency, which authorities assert is necessary to protect the Serbian minority in Kosovo, has remained in force in the region. International human rights organizations and the media in Yugoslavia's liberal northern republics of Slovenia and Croatia have blamed Serbian authorities for alleged human rights violations in Kosovo. Slovenian Communists, backed by their Croatian counterparts, on Monday split from the federal Communist Party dominated by Serbia, citing irreconcilable ideological differences.

DOC.HEAD: Saint Laurent Triumphs, Montana Flops
LaserPhoto PAR7
DOC.TEXT: Yves Saint Laurent won a long, standing ovation Wednesday as he waltzed down the runway, kissing his models after a show of summer haute couture featuring clean, colorful classics as only he can make. The crowd's enthusiasm contrasted with Tuesday night's debut of ready-to-wear wizard Claude Montana as haute couturier for the celebrated house of Lanvin, a sad moment in which Montana seemed out of his element. ``Yves Saint Laurent was more to the couture point,'' said fashionable Paloma Picasso. ``I loved his evening wear, with so many ideas and such fabulous color combinations, as usual.'' Saint Laurent's day wear was both striking and wearable. It centered on sharp white, ivory or navy ottoman or shantung suits _ including sleek pants or short skirts with tailored jackets. Disregarding fashion critics who tell him to discard shoulder pads, Saint Laurent still shows his daytime clothes neatly padded out to give shape. But the blouses underneath have softer shapes in scoop-necked satin or organza models, with cap or raglan sleeves. He dedicated many models to past or present entertainment stars. Some looked downright odd, like the frog-buttoned black gazar coat over a pants suit dedicated to Rita Hayworth. But his homage to his home in Morocco was a simple white satin sheath topped by a stunning jacket that made the dress. Engineered by master embroiderer Francois Lesage, it was an extravaganza of mirror sequins, beads and crystals. In easy-to-wear daytime lines, Saint Laurent turned out a soft midnight blue silk chemise dress with big white buttons and several silk shirt waists in jungle-panther prints. His faultless use of fabric and color went from slinky little cream satin ``Mademoiselle de Paris'' short tea dresses to a fresh blue plaid organdy dance dress with puffy sleeves and deep decollete. Montana, by contrast, lacked the elegant elaboration of haute couture. ``It was pure Montana,'' tersely commented Ellin Saltzman, corporate fashion director of R.H. Macy Inc. Not that the clothes were bad; they had Montana's original touch, and the great ready-to-wear creator of blousons put on lots of them in luxury fabrics such as pink-lined copper satin over lean linen pants. But the poor reception would seem a setback for Midland Bank, which took over Lanvin last year and chose Montana to lead the couture creation. Some observers thought Montana had done better collections under his own label. The billowy white short gazar ``trench coats'' had Montana cachet. Brown and earthy colors like khaki, tobacco, chocolate and clay were featured in luxury fabrics. Montana based his silhouette on lean pants and jodhpurs, with most interest in the toppers like a striped sequined shortie duffel coat over navy shorts. But the audience looked mainly perplexed, with some sniffing that the combinations just did not make a couture look. Rich clientele who usually love Lanvin are unlikely to go for the austere evening wear, with spider web see-through effects on top. However, lovely late-day ideas in fabulous fabrics were paraded at the young couture house of Lecoanet-Hemant. The clothes were form-fitting, with clever draping, insertion of elaborate lace touches under waistlines, lashings of white organza on collars or skirt flounces adding dashes of fun. A typical little sexy cocktail outfit paired an asymmetrical fitted jacket over a tiny lean coral leather skirt. Designer Didier Lecoanet also worked with new raffia lace trim and gold braid effects in the bright outfits. Other summery touches were in the mother-of-pearl shell embroideries. With some cutouts revealing skin for summer, plenty of bouncy evening wear with short skirts in front and train effects in back, the festive outfits in light organza, brocade, taffeta faille and gazar were truly worthy of the haute couture label. The clothes, costing many thousands of dollars per outfit, are mainly for show. Only about 2,000 women regularly buy couture, which is meant to power the fashion houses' other activities, from accessories to perfumes.

DOC.HEAD: Psychologist Finds `Flashbulb Memories' of Challenger Explosion Off Base
DOC.TEXT: Some people insist they remember vividly where they were when the space shuttle Challenger exploded four years ago Sunday, but Ulric Neisser knows they're wrong. And the ``father of cognitive psychology'' has their handwritten accounts of the day to prove it. ``This really surprised me,'' said Neisser, a member of the National Academy of Sciences who pioneered the psychology of how people handle information. ``I suspected they wouldn't be 100 percent accurate, but I never thought they'd be this wrong.'' When Neisser, an Emory University psychology professor, heard that Challenger had exploded on Jan. 28, 1986, killing all the astronauts on board, he decided that surveying Emory students about the accident could help test the accuracy of ``flashbulb memories.'' That term, coined by Harvard psychologist Roger Brown, describes vivid and detailed memories of important and emotional events. In the 1970s, Brown wrote that events such as the assassination of John F. Kennedy are accurately recorded by a quasi-photographic mechanism in the brain. The morning after Challenger exploded, Neisser asked 100 students to record how, where and when they heard the news, who told them and how they felt. In the fall of 1988, and again in spring 1989, he and Emory graduate student Nicole Harsch tracked down 44 of the students and interviewed them, scoring their responses on a 7-point scale of accuracy. In the first interviews, 11 were ``dead wrong'' and only three received a score of 7. In the 1989 interviews, when Neisser even gave the students hints and eventually showed them the reports they had written, 12 students still failed completely. He added that even those people with a score of 7 were not totally correct in their memories. Of the 13 students whose confidence level was highest, three had scores of 0 and seven had scores of 2 or less. Only two were accurate. ``Hardly anyone remembered filling them out,'' Neisser said of the statements. ``Even then, nobody said, `Oh yes, now I remember.' You'd think they'd say that if only to be a good subject and please the interviewer. ``Some didn't want to believe it even then. They said, `I'm sure that's wrong.''' The typical response was that the student was passing a TV set and stopped to watch. ``After all, after hearing about it, almost all of us sat around that night watching it on television,'' Neisser said. ``They remember the television-watching experience.'' The concept of flashbulb memories has been around since at least 1899, Neisser said. He found an article published in an 1899 Psychological Review that said a man named Cole Grove surveyed people 30 years after President Lincoln's assassination. Although two-thirds of those claimed to remember how they heard the news, Grove said probably only one-third were correct. Neisser, who will present his findings at a conference on flashbulb memories at Emory Feb. 2, added that although such surveys have been done before, his is the first to have concrete facts to back it up in the form of the students' written statements. Now he and other psychologists, some of whom are planning similar studies of the San Francisco earthquake, must determine why people have such high confidence in their memories, Neisser said. ``At first it was thought that maybe the strength of the emotion and surprise stamps the memory into your mind in a particularly lasting way,'' he said. ``These are events they think a lot about, talk to people about. ``Eventually they only remember a few fragments. They construct a plausible story and then forget they constructed the story.''

DOC.HEAD: Ruling Party Gives Nearly $40 Million to its Candidates
DOC.TEXT: The Liberal Democratic Party distributed nearly $40 million Wednesday to help its candidates in the Feb. 18 parliamentary elections, which the scandal-plagued governing party is in danger of losing. Japan's largest trade union federation issued a statement urging voters to reject the ``money-oriented politics'' of the Liberal Democrats, who have strong support from big business. Money politics will be a central theme in the opposition campaign against the party that has governed Japan since 1955, the year it was formed. Liberal Democratic incumbents in Parliament's lower house each received either $103,000 or $172,000, with the smaller sum going to well-known politicians. Party sources said the total distributed was $38.6 million. The 270 candidates endorsed so far called at party headquarters to pick up brown paper bags bulging with cash. Earlier Wednesday, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu dissolved the 512-member lower house, in which the Liberal Democrats held 295 seats, to pave the way for elections. In July, the party lost its majority in the less powerful upper house because of an unpopular sales tax and a bribery scandal involving senior Liberal Democratic politicians. Recent public opinion polls show the governing party leading the opposition, but if the Liberal Democrats lose next month, a coalition led by the Japan Socialist Party probably would take over. After dissolving the lower house, Kaifu told fellow party members it was their duty to ``restore the people's confidence in the party.'' The Cabinet met and decided candidates should register and campaigning begin Feb. 3, when the date of the election will be announced officially as Feb. 18. Elections are required by July, when the four-year term of the lower house expires. Party elders apparently chose the February date to give the new Parliament time to consider the budget, which must be passed by April 1. A statement issued Wednesday by the governing party said: ``Socialist and Communist nations around the world are collapsing like an avalanche'' and a victory by the ``outdated, inflexible'' opposition would represent a return to the past. Liberal Democrats pledged action on political reform and agricultural, welfare and land policies. Kaifu said recently that, if his party lost, he would ``take responsibility'' _ apparently meaning he would resign, as his predecessor, Sousuke Uno, did after the election loss in June. Opposition parties condemned the long hold on power by the Liberal Democrats. ``Intra-LDP conflicts prevented Prime Minister Kaifu from addressing the Diet (parliament) with his policies before dissolution,'' the Socialists said. ``Policy questions by opposition party leaders were also blocked.'' Such actions resulted from ``arrogant one-party rule,'' the party said, and it appealed for unity behind a coalition that ``reflects the national interest and responds to radically shifting domestic and foreign affairs.'' The Komeito (Clean Government) and Democratic Socialist parties said they would hold to the center, seeking abolition of the sales tax, improvement in Japan's standard of living and progress in world peace and disarmament. The Japanese Trade Union Confederation, which has 8 million members, said the election centers on the controversial 3 percent sales tax. Eishiro Saito, chairman of the Federation of Economic Organizations, which represents Japan's largest corporations, said the election eould decide Japan's destiny in the next century. He said Japan's ``miraculous economic growth'' has been based on ``stable politics championed'' by the Liberal Democrats.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down Sharply
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with noon figures, market up from its lows. PICKS UP 4th graf pvs, `Traders learned ...'; SUBS grafs 10 to the end, bgng, `Losers among ...' with one graf; Version moved on financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices fell sharply today as worries about rising interest rates and pressure on the Japanese market continued taking a heavy toll on Wall Street. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which has fallen 195 points over the past three weeks, was down 43.92 to 2,571.40 by noon on Wall Street. At one point in early trading, the widely followed market indicator was down more than 61 points. Losers overwhelmed gainers by a margin of about 12 to 1 in the early tally on the New York Stock Exchange. Traders learned overnight of a sharp decline in the Tokyo stock market, which has been unsettled lately by rising interest rates in Japan. Analysts said that heightened fears that rates would have to climb further in this country to stay competitive in the international marketplace. A sale by the government Tuesday of 40-year bonds to finance a rescue plan for troubled thrift institutions drew a chilly reception from investors. As the outlook for interest rates has worsened, investors have begun to face the possibility that the recent slowdown of the economy might deepen in the months ahead. Brokers also said a weak attempt by stocks to rally on Tuesday left many traders unimpressed and disheartened. On Tuesday the Dow Jones industrial average rose 14.87 to 2,615.32.

DOC.HEAD: Man Who Set His Son on Fire Released From Prison
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with Rothenberg released; PICKS UP 13th graf pvs, `Rothenberg had ...'; DELETES 23rd graf pvs, `Kindel said ...' to tighten.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto SAN1
DOC.TEXT: A man who set fire to his son seven years ago was paroled today under a veil of secrecy and orders to wear an electronic leash and stay away from the boy, who is keeping a BB gun handy just in case. Charles Rothenberg ``is out on parole and he has reached his destination,'' said Tipton Kindel, spokesman for the state Corrections Department. Rothenberg, wearing an electronic device that will enable authorities to monitor his movements, left prison shortly after midnight, Kindel said, adding that Rothenberg is now the most-watched parolee in California history. David Rothenberg, who is now 13, said he was frightened by his father's release and keeps a pellet gun by his bed just in case. ``I'd shoot his eye out if he ever came over. I'd blind him,'' he said in a recent interview. The boy was severely disfigured by the fire set by his father in a custody dispute with his estranged wife. Prison officials were determined to keep Rothenberg's whereabouts secret during his three-year parole and wouldn't even confirm he was paroled within the United States. Earlier today, on NBC's ``Today'' show, Kindel said Rothenberg ``will be under the strictest parole ever for a California parolee.'' ``He will not be allowed to leave the jurisdiction to which he is being paroled. He will not be able to go to the county where his son lives. He will not be allowed to have any contact with his son, his ex-wife or her current husband,'' Kindel said. If Rothenberg violates parole, he will be returned to prison for up to a year. David lives in Orange County with his mother, Marie, and stepfather, police Officer Richard Hafdahl, who helped in the investigation of the fire. Asked on ``Today'' what is being done to protect David, Kindel said that if Rothenberg is ever ``not where he's supposed to be, then the family, David, will be notified immediately.'' Rothenberg, 49, set fire to his son in a Buena Park motel room in 1983 after a telephone argument in which his estranged wife said Rothenberg would not be able to see the boy again. Rothenberg had taken the boy on a holiday to Southern California from New York, where the boy was living with his mother. ``If I can't have him, nobody else can,'' Rothenberg said when arrested six days later. He told authorities he was going to kill himself but was too much of a coward. David, dragged from the inferno by motel guests, suffered third-degree burns over 90 percent of his body. Rothenberg was convicted of attempted murder, arson and other charges and got the maximum, a 13-year prison term. The sentence was cut in half because of good behavior. If he had been convicted today, Rothenberg would have faced up to life in prison. In a letter last month to the Los Angeles Times, Rothenberg called his own release ``an unforgivable act.'' Prison officials kept the relocation plans secret, fearing a repeat of the hysteria surrounding the 1987 release of Larry Singleton. Singleton, who had raped a teen-ager and left her for dead after hacking off her forearms with an ax, had to be moved repeatedly from Northern California communities, where he was rejected by an outraged public. Kindel acknowledged in the ``Today'' interview that if Rothenberg's location is revealed it could be a problem for the Corrections Department, and said ``another high-profile parolee'' _ an apparent reference to Singleton _ cost the state more than $2 million to move him from location to location. ``We're hoping to convince the public that not only is its safety assured, but so is the safety of David Rothenburg, so that perhaps they will simply ignore this man and shun him and not give him the media attention that we've learned he actually enjoys,'' Kindel said. David said he would always live in fear of his father. ``He will be out there, free. He probably has people out there right now looking for me. I will have to live the rest of my life on the line ... always looking behind me,'' the boy said recently.

DOC.HEAD: Health Minister Issues Warning on Hereditary Diseases, Illiteracy
DOC.TEXT: The health minister has warned that China's high incidence of hereditary diseases, disabilities and illiteracy is a threat to national development, it was reported Wednesday. Minister Chen Minzhang told a conference that China must use propaganda, education and legislation to improve the quality of its 1.1 billion people, according to the China Youth News and the overseas edition of the People's Daily. Chen said China has 51 million people with physical and mental disabilities, about 5 percent of the population. It has 22 million sufferers of hereditary diseases and birth defects afflict 1.3 percent of babies. Congenital diseases are so serious in some remote areas where marriages among close relatives are common that some communities have come to be called ``deaf and mute'' villages or ``simpleton'' villages, the minister said. He said 1.7 percent of children under 14 are classified as being of low intelligence. The nation has more than 200 million illiterates and semi-literates, one-fourth of the world's total. Eighty percent of the illiterates are women, and 40 million children, almost all in rural areas, have quit school. Chen noted that China has made significant progress in some areas since the Communists came to power in 1949, with the rate of mothers dying in childbirth dropping from 150 per 10,000 in 1949 to 5 per 10,000 today. The infant mortality rate has dropped from 20 percent to 3.5 percent. But Chen said the low quality of the population has become a ``heavy millstone around our neck in the journey to catch up with international competition and modernize.'' He called for legislation to improve the quality of new babies, but the reports did not say whether he was referring to strengthening the nation's one-child policy or controversial proposals to prevent some women from giving birth. Northwest China's Gansu province, in one of the nation's most impoverished regions, in 1988 passed a law prohibiting ``dull-witted'' and retarded people from having children, and saying such people could marry only after being sterilized. The Chinese Association for the Handicapped last spring also called for a national ``law of eugenics'' to improve population quality.

DOC.HEAD: Washington `Trade Newspaper' Aims for October Launch
DOC.TEXT: A free newspaper keyed to the industry of Washington, the federal government, will begin daily publication Oct. 1, the paper's backers said Wednesday. The Washington Reporter will be given away to ``people in the federal government, politics, media, lobbyists, lawyers and others who make up this industry in Washington,'' said publisher Roger G. Kranz. Limited newsstand and out-of-town distribution are also envisioned. Kranz likened the planned Monday-Friday newspaper to Daily Variety and The Hollywood Reporter, entertainment trade dailies published in Hollywood. ``There's a lot that goes on there, and there's an awful lot that goes on here that is undercovered,'' he said. ``This will be a trade newspaper for the industry in Washington, not a major metropolitan daily newspaper,'' the publisher said. The one-section, 16-page Reporter will not cover sports or the weather or have a foreign staff, he said, although he envisions supplementing the paper's own reporting with wire service stories. ``It will be a newsaper for and about people who work here, inside the beltway,'' he said. Kranz, 39, resigned in August as group vice president of the National Journal, where he was in charge of advertising sales, circulation and manufacturing. John S. Prescott Jr., a former president of The Washington Post and recently retired president of the publications division of Whitney Communications Co. in New York, will be chairman of the board. The editor will be Barry Sussman, who runs an independent public opinion polling and consulting company in Washington and formerly served as an editor with The Washington Post and United Press International. Kranz said he and Prescott are investors in the paper, but Sussman is not. He declined to name other investors. The publisher said he has raised enough money to keep the paper operating ``for quite a while,'' but he wouldn't say how long. The Reporter's first-year budget is $12.45 million. Kranz said that he expects the paper to have a circulation of about 30,000 and that a prototype will be published late next month. Kranz said the newspaper would have a staff of 100, including 50 on the editorial staff, and he expects to pay salaries competitive with those of other news organizations in Washington. He said he has talked with prospective advertisers and ``there is a great deal of interest in having a viable medium reaching a very upscale, targeted audience.'' Outside Washington, he said, there will be limited same-day distribution to Wall Street and midtown New York and to shuttle terminals in New York, Boston and Washington.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 6th graf, _Richard Miller, to delete erroneous reference to $150,000 fine
DOC.TEXT: Here is the legal status of key figures in the Iran-Contra affair: _Oliver North, former National Security Council aide. Found guilty at a jury trial May 4, 1989 of three felonies _ aiding and abetting the obstruction of Congress, destroying official documents and accepting an illegal gratuity. He was sentenced to two years' probation, fined $150,000 and ordered to perform 1,200 hours of community service. He is appealing the convictions, the fine and probation while serving the community service in an anti-drug program. _Robert McFarlane, former national security adviser. Pleaded guilty March 11, 1988 to four misdemeanors _ withholding information from Congress by denying that the NSC staff was soliciting support for the Contras' military activities and helping move supplies to the rebels and denying that he knew anything about third-country financing of the Contras. Sentenced to two years' probation, fined $20,000 and ordered to serve 200 hours of community service. _Richard Secord, a retired Air Force major general, sentenced Wednesday to two years' probation. He pleaded guilty Nov. 8 to making a false statement to congressional investigators when he said he wasn't aware of any money that went to the benefit of North from the maze of companies known as ``the Enterprise'' which Secord had used in the Iran-Contra affair. _Carl ``Spitz'' Channell, pleaded guilty April 29, 1987 to using his non-profit National Endowment for the Preservation of Liberty to raise more than $2 million to buy weapons for the Nicaraguan rebels. Sentenced to two years' probation for conspiring to defraud the Treasury of taxes due on the money raised with North's assistance. _Richard Miller, head of a Washington public relations firm, pleaded guilty in May 1987 to conspiring to defraud the Internal Revenue Service of taxes on contributions used to supply military aid to the Contras. Sentenced to two years' probation. _John M. Poindexter, former national security adviser. Facing trial Feb. 20 on charges of conspiracy, two counts of obstructing Congress and two counts of making false statements in connection with Contra aid and a November 1985 shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran. Has issued subpoena for records of former President Reagan and is seeking to subpoena Reagan as a witness at the upcoming trial. _Albert Hakim, Iranian-born businessman who with Secord ran ``the Enterprise.'' Pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor of aiding and abetting in supplementing North's income by paying for a security fence at North's home. Hakim will be sentenced Feb. 1 and could face up to a year in prison. A company he set up, Lake Resources, pleaded guilty to theft of government property in connection with Iran arms sale money diverted from the U.S. government, a felony that could carry a fine of up to $500,000. _Joseph Fernandez, former CIA station chief in Costa Rica. Charged with obstruction and making false statements in connection with his assistance to North's Contra resupply network. The judge in the case said the charges must be dismissed due to the attorney general's ban on the use of classified material Fernandez needs for his defense. Iran-Contra prosecutors are appealing.

DOC.HEAD: Afghan President Sees No Hint of Reduced Soviet Support
DOC.TEXT: President Najib said Wednesday there was no sign the Soviet Union plans to cut massive military and economic aid to his Marxist government in its war with Moslem guerrillas. At a news conference, he reiterated a pledge to step down if he believed such a move would end the 11-year-old civil war with the U.S.-backed insurgents. Najib said that despite Moscow's hands-off response to the democratic reforms that have toppled Communist governments in Eastern Europe, the Soviet Union appears determined to continue helping his country. ``We have not seen any sign which might demonstrate the unwillingness of the Soviet Union to fulfill its contractual commitment to its South Asian neighbor,'' he told foreign journalists. The burly former chief of the nation's secret police said his government already has carried out the kind of reforms that are transforming East bloc nations. ``There are great lessons that should be learned by us all from the developments there,'' Najib said. Flanked by army troops carrying automatic assault rifles, he responded to written queries submitted in advance and then answered questions directly from reporters. Security personnel frisked all of the reporters and searched their belongings. Najib called on the guerrillas to put down their weapons and talk peace. But, he added, ``If the opposition launches more attacks, our response will be stronger and more crushing than ever before.'' The major rebel leaders, based in neighboring Pakistan, have rejected any talks with Najib's government. They are fighting to topple his ruling People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan and replace it with an Islamic regime. The party seized power in a bloody military coup in 1978. Najib assumed office in 1986 after former President Babrak Karmal resigned, ostensibly for health reasons. Najib originally offered to resign for the sake of peace in 1987. Asked if the offer still stood, he said: ``If the need arises for stepping down, I can assure you that I will sacrifice everything for the sake of assuring peace in my country.'' An estimated 1.5 million people have been killed in the war and more than 5 million Afghans _ a third of the country's prewar population _ have fled to refugee camps in Pakistan and Iran. Soviet troops spent nine years fighting the guerrillas to a stalemate before Moscow withdrew the last of them in February 1989. About 100,000 soldiers moved into Afghanistan on Dec. 27, 1979, to replace one pro-Moscow government with another and stayed on to fight the insurgents. The guerrillas and many Western countries predicted Najib's government would fall soon after the withdrawal, but government forces have held their ground. They continue to hold Afghanistan's major cities and the guerrillas control most of the rugged countryside. The United States, Britain and several other countries closed their Kabul embassies a year ago ahead of an expected fight for the capital. While the insurgents have intermittently attacked with rockets, Najib's government remains firmly in control and France recently announced plans to reopen its embassy. Najib said he ``warmly welcomes'' the decision. ``We reiterate that the republic of Afghanistan is ready to assure the safety and security of all foreign diplomats,'' he said. He denied widespread claims that his party and its security force, known as Khad, have killed or tortured thousands of opponents in the nearly 12-year-old rule of the People's Democratic Party. ``The baseless allegations against the party are only a pretext for avoiding talks and continuing the war,'' he said. Najib said his formula for peace would begin with a six-month cease-fire and talks among officials of his government and guerrilla leaders. He also said he supports the formation of a coalition government and elections held under international supervision.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Battle Reportedly Ends Naval Blockade of Azerbaijani Harbor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 10 grafs to UPDATE with battle in Baku harbor. Pickup 6th graf pvs, ``Organizations that...''
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY4,5, LaserColor MOSB2
DOC.TEXT: Soviet forces today fought with Azerbaijani nationalists who blockaded the port of Baku with oil tankers to protest the government's military occupation of their war-torn republic, news reports said. Soviet television reported that nationalists aboard the tankers attacked a marine passenger terminal in the harbor, where people wait to board ships. ``There was an exchange of fire,'' TV said, and soldiers were wounded. It gave no further details of the harbor battle except to say that a group of people was later detained. Residents in Baku said in telephone interviews that they had heard there was a 40-minute gun battle in the harbor. Tass reported that the blockade of the port by Azerbaijani extremists, which had lasted several days, had been lifted. However, it was not clear whether the nationalists had chosen to end it or had been forced to do so. Before the battle, the captains aboard the tankers in the oil-producing Caspian Sea port had threatened to blow up their vessels if the Soviet military tried to break the blockade, an activist said. Earlier today, Soviet troops trying to crush the nationalist uprising in Azerbaijan arrested 43 people and seized copy machines from the offices of unofficial groups during overnight raids in Baku, news reports said. The media reported growing threats against the Russian population as Azerbaijanis reacted to Soviet troops sent to Baku to restore order. The official Tass news agency said today the Soviet military had evacuated more than 16,000 soldiers' dependents in the face of the threats. Demonstrations and strikes were banned in Baku, and activists were told they face 30 days in jail if they try to organize protests, Tass said. But Tass said a general strike called to demand the withdrawal of Soviet soldiers paralyzed factories and transport. The Foreign Ministry spokesman, Gennady Gerasimov, said militants continue to storm weapons depots and had stolen more than 5,000 guns and other items in the past two days in the southern republics of Armenia and Azerbaijan. Organizations that do not have formal approval to exist have been blamed by authorities for 11 days of violence, which began with anti-Armenian riots in Baku and led to Azerbaijani demands for independence. ``Forty-three people were arrested when the headquarters of illegally functioning informal organizations were neutralized,'' Tass said. ``Many copying machines and propaganda facilities were confiscated.'' But Tass said the National Defense Committee, a militant branch of the Azerbaijan People's Front, and allied groups were banned. Mamed Ali-Zade, one of the National Defense Committee's directors, was arrested at his home about midnight, his wife said. The People's Front, the underground group that has coordinated much of the resistance, has taken particular heat from authorities. Soviet television said gunfire continued Tuesday night in parts of Baku, but activists and news reports said the city was quiet this morning. The Azerbaijani Communist Party Central Committee planned to meet late tonight, said Azerbaijani parliament spokesman Nizami Sakyakhov. The late hour will ensure the meeting is conducted after curfew, when demonstrators are unlikely to surround the building, he said. Jeikhun Mula-Zade, a political scientist, said the party would consider breaking from the Soviet party in Moscow. The committee also is to elect a new first secretary to replace Abdul-Rakhman Vezirov, who was fired after Soviet troops poured into Baku and met violent resistance, Mula-Zade said. According to official reports, at least 170 people have been killed since ethnic violence broke out Jan. 13 in Baku between Azerbaijanis, who are mostly Shiite Moslems, and Armenians, who are mainly Christians. Azerbaijanis say the death toll is far higher. The republics both want control over the region of Nagorno-Karabakh, which is populated mainly by Armenians but under control of Azerbaijan. The violence spread from Baku as Armenians and Azerbaijanis took up arms against each other in the hills around Nagorno-Karabakh and on the borders between Armenia and Azerbaijan. Dozens of people were killed as Soviet troops entered Baku on Saturday to end the violence. The Soviet soldiers are ``more and more often being chosen as targets'' by local fighters, Tass quoted Interior Ministry Maj. Gen. Yevgeny Nechayev as saying today. Earlier in the week, there were reports of Azerbaijani soldiers fighting their Soviet colleagues, but the Moscow-based labor newspaper Trud said today those reports were lies. Trud reported attacks on Russians' apartments in Baku and said Azerbaijanis are refusing to sell bread to Russian residents. About 100,000 Russians live in the city of 1.8 million. Niayaz Gajiyev of a self-appointed citizens' investigation commission said Russians are following the example of the military families and fleeing Baku. He insisted there was no real danger, although he said anti-Russian sentiment is rising due to outrage over the troops' presence. Adding to the tension was the appearance of ``terrorists dressed in military uniforms,'' Tass said. Radio Moscow said negotiations between leaders of the two republics on how to stop the conflict continued, but little progress was reported. Azerbaijani lawmakers on Monday declared void a state of emergency declared by President Mikhail Gorbachev, and they said they would vote to secede if Soviet troops were not withdrawn. Elsewhere in Azerbaijan, there were reports of individual skirmishes but also claims of improvements.

DOC.HEAD: Leipzig Police Stage Pro-Democracy Rally; Strike in Dresden
With AM-East Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: About 3,000 police officers proclaiming solidarity with pro-democracy forces rallied Wednesday in Leipzig, where police last fall attacked demonstrators at the start of the popular reform movement. A major anti-Communist warning strike in Dresden and other worker demonstrations pointed to continued dissatisfaction with the country's political and economic state. Blaring police sirens accompanied the march through Leipzig, in which officers carried signs saying ``We Too Are The People'' and ``For a Democratic Police,'' the state-run news agency ADN said. Another sign said ``Police Are Not Stasi,'' a reference to the hated secret police that the Communist-led government has pledged to dissolve. At a rally, police demanded punishment for higher-ups who ordered the attack on Leipzig pro-democracy demonstrators in October, ADN said. Leipzig is considered the birthplace of the reform movement that brought down hard-line leader Erich Honecker on Oct. 18. Police there and in other cities violently broke up demonstrations in early October. Workers in Dresden left their jobs for one hour Wednesday to warn against continued Communist dominance and a revival of secret police spying, ADN reported. Organizers said workers in 200 businesses, including luxury hotels, street cleaners and members of the Dresden Philharmonic, heeded the warning strike call by a local state industrial enterprise, according to ADN. About 1,000 state health care workers took to the streets in Zittau to demonstrate for higher pay, ADN said. Employees at a Leipzig district hospital also demonstrated Wednesday, protesting a lack of doctors and nurses and the ``critical state'' of technical equipment, the agency said. The protest on the hospital grounds took place during visiting hours and involved only off-shift employees, so patient care was maintained, ADN said. East Germany has lost many of its most qualified workers in the exodus of citizens to West Germany. About 340,000 East Germans left last year and the outflow continues.

DOC.HEAD: Fed Survey: Continued Slow Economic Growth in 1990
DOC.TEXT: The nation's economy is expected to grow slowly in 1990, the Federal Reserve said Wednesday in a report that forecast improvements in some regions later in the year. ``Economic activity is expanding slowly in most of the nation, with conditions somewhat stronger in the West than in the East,'' the central bank said in a summary of its ``Beige Book.'' The report did not mention any inflationary problems _ the reason the Fed originally slowed the economy by driving up interest rates to dampen demand and cool off price pressures. The Fed switched course last June and has permitted short-term rates to drop gradually in an effort to keep the slowing economy from stopping altogether and falling into a recession. But the central bank has not acted since mid-December and just last week, the White House broke its usual no-comment stance on Fed activities and said that ``lower interest rates are justified.'' Nevertheless, the latest Beige Book report appeared to indicate that most participants in the Fed's survey, completed Jan. 18, thought the central bank has achieved its so-called ``soft-landing'' _ continued sluggish growth but no recession. ``The outlook is for slow growth in all regions in 1990,'' it said, ``Some respondents expect improvment late in the year.'' The survey is conducted eight times a year in preparation for meetings of the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed's monetary policy-setting arm. The next meeting is Feb. 6-7. Looking back on the economy in recent weeks, the Beige Book summary found that: _``Retail sales in the holiday season ranged from `disappointing' in Boston to modest in Philadelphia and Atlanta and relatively strong in Chicago, Minneapolis and San Francisco; however, widespread discounting generally reduced store profits. ... ``Retailers expect flat sales or modest increases through the first six months of 1990. Results in the first weeks of January were said to be encouraging.'' _``Manufacturing activity is generally sluggish with production declines in some industries (autos, in particular) offsetting gains in others (such as commercial aircraft and oilfeild equipment. Several districts reported that the steel and computer industries, among others, may be `bottoming out.' ... ``Most manufacturers expected slow growth in 1990, with a weak first half followed by gradual improvement.'' _``Unseasonably cold weather dampended construction activity in some areas, but real estate markets generally held steady.'' _``Cold or dry weather also adversely affected citrus, vegetable and winter wheat crops. Other agricultural and resource-related sectors did moderately well.'' _``Most districts discussing real estate reported steady or modestly improved conditions ... Expected declines in mortgage interest rates provided some reason for optimism in the real estate outlook.''

DOC.HEAD: Ten Named to Hall of Fame
DOC.TEXT: A record 10 new members, including the first two blacks, were named to the National Inventors Hall of Fame on Wednesday. ``The 10 individuals we honor here today are the real heroes of our age. ... They are the thinkers and the problem solvers. They have opened new doors and pioneered new frontiers in science and technology,'' said Jeffrey M. Samuels, acting commissioner of patents and trademarks. George Washington Carver and Percy F. Julian were among the inventors selected for inclusion this year, marking the first blacks to be selected since the hall was begun in 1973. Carver was selected for his work developing more than 500 uses for peanuts, including cooking oil and printer's ink, and for sweet potatoes, including synthetic rubber. He died in 1943. Julian, a Chicago chemist, was the first to synthesize cortisone and other human hormones. Before the synthetic cortisone came onto the market, the only cortisone available to treat rheumatoid arthritis was produced from oxen bile, at a cost of hundreds of dollars a drop. ``He was one of the most persistent men I have known,'' reflected Samuel B. Massie of the U.S. Naval Academy, once a colleague of Julian, who died in 1975. Tenacity was also cited as a necessary ingredient by another man being honored. Robert S. Ledley of Georgetown University in Washington said the prerequisite skills for success as an inventor include a pragmatic attitude, boldness, fortitude ``and stick-to-itiveness almost to the extent of obsession.'' Ledley was named to the hall of fame for his development of the computerized tomographic, or CT, scanner, a device similar to an x-ray machine that allows doctors to see the inner workings of the body in great detail. Another man honored was Herman Hollerith, described as having left behind a motto for the generations: ``do not fold, spindle or mutilate.'' Hollerith invented the punch-card system that helped pave the way to modern computers. A Census Bureau employee, he halved the time it took to tabulate the 1890 national head count and later went on to help found the giant IBM Co. In addition to Carver, Julian, Ledley and Hollerith, inventors selected for the hall of fame for 1990 are: _Graham C. Durant, John C. Emmett and C. Robin Gannellin, medical chemists who developed the drug cimetidine, which has greatly reduced the need for surgery for ulcer victims. It is known by the trade name Tagamet. _Charles P. Ginsberg, who led the engineering team that developed the first practical videotape. _Kenneth S. Olsen, developer of the magnetic memory core for computers and founder of Digital Equipment Corporation. _Eugene J. Houdry, a French-born engineer who developed the procedure that allowed crude oil to be processed into high grade gasoline and aviation fuel. The selection of 10 new members is the most since six were picked in 1985, and brings total membership in the Hall of Fame to 85. Founded at the U.S. Patent Office in Arlington, Va., the hall of fame will eventually move to Akron, Ohio, where construction on a new facility is to begin later this year.

DOC.HEAD: Suspect Denies Being in City When She Disappeared
DOC.TEXT: A Florida lawyer scheduled to stand trial next week on conspiracy charges in the July 1988 kidnapping of a missing Jackson heiress claims he was not in Jackson on the day she disappeared. Newton Alfred Winn, 65, said in a court document filed Monday that he was in his hometown of St. Petersburg, Fla., on July 26, 1988, at the time police believe Annie Laurie Hearin was kidnapped. She has not been seen since. Winn is scheduled to go on trial Monday in U.S. District Court in Hattiesburg on charges of conspiring to kidnap, mailing a threatening letter and perjury. A note found at her home after she was taken told her husband, Robert M. Hearin, to make payments to Winn and 11 others who fought legal battles with School Pictures of Mississippi Inc., which he owned. Hearin mailed checks totaling nearly $1 million to the 12 people named in the ransom note. Winn returned his check. Several witnesses may be called to verify Winn's whereabouts on the day of the kidnapping, the court document says. John M. Colette of Jackson, Winn's attorney, refused to comment Tuesday. The witness list includes Joe Donahey, a Clearwater, Fla., attorney who has represented Winn. Donahey said Tuesday that he could not discuss his contact with Winn. ``Any contact I had with Mr. Winn would have been within an attorney-client relationship,'' Donahey said. Other than July 26, Winn does not provide an alibi for six other dates, times and places as requested by prosecutors. The court papers said a federal court regulation ``calls for a response only concerning the time, date and place of which the alleged offense was committed.'' Three of the dates in 1988 that are significant to the conspiracy charge are April 7 or 8, July 19, and July 25. Neighbors of the Hearins testified a man resembling Winn was seen in the neighborhood before the kidnapping. Also, a superintendent for a construction crew working at Fondren Presbyterian Church recalled seeing Winn looking around the neighborhood two blocks from the Hearin home. The three other dates are significant to the charge that Winn caused a ransom letter to be mailed to Mrs. Hearin's home: _Aug. 5 or 6, 1988, at a hotel in Deland, Fla. Prosecutors said Winn met a woman there and asked her to mail a letter that arrived at the Hearin home on Aug. 15. The letter, in Mrs. Hearin's handwriting, said her captors would seal her in a cellar if their demands were not met. _A Saturday in late August, at a planetarium and museum in Bradenton, Fla. Prosecutors say the woman met Winn again and received the initial $250 of a $500 payment. _Feb. 18, 1989, at a hotel in Deland. Prosecutors said Winn paid the woman the remaining $250.

DOC.HEAD: 10 Killed in Van Accident in Florida
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf pvs, `The privately ...' with two grafs to ADD that area is sugar cane district intersected by canals. ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: A van carrying migrant farm workers ran off a foggy rural road and plunged into a murky canal today, drowning 10 people and injuring two, authorities said. The driver and a front-seat passenger crawled out of the submerged van through windows. Sheriff's deputies dived into the 12 feet of water but were unable to rescue the others trapped inside, said Lt. Bill Chamness. ``Some of them had stuck their arms out trying to get out, but they just didn't make it,'' he said. ``When the deputies dove in to get them, they were already dead.'' The privately owned van carrying 12 Mexican migrant workers ran off the road at a curve near this farm community about 100 miles northwest of Miami, Chamness said. The road cuts through a sugar cane district intersected by numerous irrigation and drainage canals. ``We think it was probably due to dense fog,'' Chamness said. ``Evidently they got on the curve quicker than they thought, and instead of turning they went straight into the canal.'' The survivors, both men, were taken to Hendry General Hospital with minor injuries such as scrapes and bruises and showed no immediate signs of broken bones or internal injuries, said emergency room nurse Maggie Kocher. The driver was admitted in stable condition for observation, and the passenger was treated and was to be released, she said. The sheriff's office didn't receive word of the 7:30 a.m. crash until 7:46 a.m., authorities said. A sheriff's diver who attached a tow-truck cable to the back of the van estimated visibility in the canal at 2 feet, Chamness said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Official: Mandela's Release and Major Reforms Expected Soon
DOC.TEXT: The top U.S. official on Africa said Wednesday that President F.W. de Klerk assured him black leader Nelson Mandela will be freed soon. In an upbeat assessment of South Africa's racial conflict, the U.S. assistant secretary of state for African affairs, Herman Cohen, said both the white-run government and the anti-apartheid movement seek to negotiate a political settlement. He said he believed the South African government had undertaken a commitment ``to make fundamental change in the South African political system so as to bring about democracy.'' ``Equally important is my impression that the anti-apartheid movement is also in the process of making a reciprocal ... commitment'' to a negotiated solution, Cohen told a news conference. Cohen's assessment of de Klerk's reforms was far more positive than the one offered by a U.S. congressional delegation that visited earlier this month. It came on the same day the State Department criticized South African police for using force to break up a peaceful protest Tuesday in Cape Town. Cohen spent three days in South Africa meeting government leaders, including de Klerk, and anti-apartheid figures such as Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu. Cohen was asked if de Klerk specified a date for Mandela's release, the country's best-known black leader. ``He (de Klerk) did not give me a date of release, though he said it would be soon,'' Cohen said. ``He said I could expect major developments soon.'' Mandela, 71, has been imprisoned more than 27 years and is serving a life sentence for sabotage and plotting to overthrow the government. Asked if he expected the government to lift the 3{-year-old state of emergency and legalize Mandela's African National Congress guerrilla movement, Cohen said, ``The answer basically is yes.'' Since de Klerk assumed power in August, he has sought to ease political tension with a series of reforms, and he called for negotiations with the disenfranchised black majority. The ANC says it will not negotiate until Mandela and all political prisoners are freed; political trials are halted; and the state of emergency is lifted. The ANC's armed wing said Wednesday it supports these conditions, as set by the group's political leaders, and will not put down its weapons until they are met. The guerrillas ``are loyal to the ANC and their position is no different ... if the enemy begins to show signs of seriousness to undertake negotiations, our people will be ready to go into dialogue. The onus is on the enemy,'' guerrilla commander Joe Modise said in Lusaka, Zambia, where the ANC has its headquarters. The last U.S. delegation to visit South Africa was led by Rep. Howard Wolpe, D-Mich., who said the de Klerk government was not prepared to establish a democracy. Wolpe said unless de Klerk makes major reforms soon, Congress should consider additional economic sanctions against South Africa. The United States imposes limited sanctions under 1986 legislation that demands South Africa undertake several specific reforms, including lifting the state of emergency, legalizing opposition groups and freeing political prisoners. In Washington on Wednesday, State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler reitered these demands. Speaking of Tuesday's incident in Cape Town, in which police violently dispersed about 5,000 black and mixed-race students protesting government education policies, she said: ``We deplore the use of force to stifle peaceful protest.'' ``We have long urged an end to violence and repression as an important step in the process of change in South Africa,'' Ms. Tutwiler said. Two black men were shot to death Wednesday when police opened fire to disperse a protest alleging police brutality, authorities said. Officers used tear gas and birdshot to disperse the protest after a rally by about 5,000 people at a stadium in Khutsong, 50 miles west of Johannesburg. Members of the crowd left the stadium and began causing disturbances in the streets, including stoning police vehicles, police said. Two men were killed, three were injured, and 13 people were arrested, they said.

DOC.HEAD: LaRouche Supporters Thrown Off Ill. Primary Ballot
DOC.TEXT: The Illinois Electoral Board today struck five supporters of imprisoned political extremist Lyndon LaRouche from the Democratic primary ballot. The board, in a 7-1 vote, agreed with a finding by its hearing officer that the slate of five pro-LaRouche candidates had only 3,865 valid signatures of the required 5,000 to get on the ballot for the election in March. The panel also agreed that LaRouche candidate Patricia Nobel-Schenk has not lived in Illinois the required three years to run for comptroller. The board disagreed with the hearing officer's finding that the petitions had been fraudulently represented to voters as supporting certain political causes instead of certain political candidates when they were circulated. Two of the candidates present for the vote _ Sheila Jones for lieutenant governor and Janice Hart for secretary of state _ stood afterward and said, ``We shall overcome.'' They unfurled a banner and likened the board action to ``Nazi justice.'' ``If the LaRouche candidates can be thrown off the ballot this way, then what's any citizen's protection against being thrown in the streets because their government thinks their life is useless?'' Hart asked. Jones said an appeal is planned. Also thrown off the ballot were Ronnie Fredman, running for treasurer, and gubernatorial candidate Mark Fairchild, who threw the state Democratic Party into turmoil by scoring an upset in the 1986 primary for lieutenant governor. The same year Hart upset the mainstream Democratic candidate for secretary of state. Hart and Fairchild lost in the general election, but their victories crippled Democrat Adlai Stevenson's effort to unseat Republican Gov. James R. Thompson. Fredman and Ms. Noble-Schenk are under indictment on charges of defrauding an elderly woman of $80,000 in cash and securities. The LaRouche followers' petitions were challenged by supporters of Democratic gubernatorial candidate Neil Hartigan, currently attorney general. John Kennedy, an attorney for the state Democratic Party, charged that the petitions were ``heavily tainted with fraud.'' Hartigan has called the LaRouche organization an ``anti-Semitic, racist hate group'' that ``does not belong on the ballot.'' LaRouche, a conspiracy theorist and frequent presidential candidate, is serving a 15-year federal prison term for fraud and conspiracy.

DOC.HEAD: Hrawi Reportedly Plans Crack Security Force For West Beirut
DOC.TEXT: President Elias Hrawi will create a crack security force to combat terrorism in west Beirut and encourage foreign diplomats to return to the city's Moslem sector, a military source said Wednesday. Also on Wednesday, rival Shiite Moslem militias dueled with howitzers and rocket launchers in southern Lebanon, and police said one person was killed and another injured. The renewed fighting in Iqlim al-Tuffah ended a 16-day relative lull in the latest round of clashes between the pro-Iranian Shiite Hezbollah, or Party of God, and the Shiite Amal militia. By police count, 98 people have been killed and 279 wounded since Dec. 23. ``No advances were reported by either side,'' said a police spokesman, who cannot be identified in line with standing rules. The military source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the new security force for west Beirut will be made up of 400 men drawn from the elite combat forces of the army and police. Hrawi said Tuesday that west Beirut would become a ``security oasis'' under the security force. All Western diplomatic missions have left the city since mid-1984 because of terrorist attacks and kidnappings of foreigners. Most of the acts were blamed on Shiite Moslem underground factions affiliated with Hezbollah. In all, 18 foreigners, including eight Americans, are missing and believed held hostage. The longest-held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, kidnapped in west Beirut on March 16, 1985. Asked whether the proposed security plan would also cover the slums of south Beirut _ a Hezbollah stronghold where most of the Western hostages are believed held _ the military source said: ``Most probably south Beirut will be included.'' He refused to elaborate. He said all militias will be banned from west Beirut as part of the plan, and that the commando squad ``will be trained on special assignments and might be equipped with helicopters for raid intervention in case it is needed to deal with special and sensitive assignments, such as protecting foreign diplomats.'' The source said a 3,000-man brigade from Hrawi's 22,000-member army will deploy in west Beirut in the first stage of the security plan. According to the source, the security plan also calls for a gradual withdrawal of Syrian troops from west Beirut. Hrawi and Syrian President Hafez Assad discussed the plan in three days of talks in Damascus that ended Tuesday. Hrawi on Wednesday summoned army commander Gen. Emile Lahoud and his senior military aides to a meeting at his residence in west Beirut for more talks, a presidential statement said. It gave no further details. Lahoud is to visit Damascus next week for discussions with Syrian officers, the military source said. Hrawi appointed Lahoud commander Nov. 24 after he was elected president by Parliament. Hrawi also dismissed rebellious Christian Gen. Michel Aoun as commander-in-chief of the armed forces and interim prime minister, but Aoun refused to leave the presidential palace. Hrawi and Assad said at a joint news conference in Damascus on Tuesday that ending the standoff over who runs Lebanon's government was a priority. ``If at the end there is no alternative, I shall use force,'' Hrawi said. ``I will use everything to stop the partition.'' Assad said he would commit whatever forces Hrawi needed to oust Aoun. Syria is the main power broker in Lebanon by dint of the 40,000 troops it has stationed there. They were deployed under a 1978 Arab League peacekeeping mandate and Syria has rejected Aoun's demands that they be withdrawn. Hrawi was elected president under an Arab League-brokered plan to end Lebanon's 14-year-old civil war. Aoun rejected the plan because it does not specifically call for Syria's withdrawal or give a timetable. He recently ordered Lebanon's media not to refer to Hrawi as president. The nation's seven daily newspapers did not publish Wednesday due to a strike called Tuesday by a press group to protest Aoun's attempts to censor the media.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Source Says Junk Dealer is a Suspect in Mail Bombings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with source saying junk dealer is a suspect, O'Ferrell's letter calling judicial system corrupt, other remarks today. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto XEN1
DOC.TEXT: A junk dealer whose property was searched by FBI agents is a suspect in the mail bombings that killed a federal judge and a civil rights lawyer, a law enforcement source in Washington said today. The source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Robert Wayne O'Ferrell failed a series of lie detector tests administered by the FBI. Meanwhile, court documents obtained today by the Associated Press show that O'Ferrell once complained in a legal brief that America's court system ``is corrupt.'' The letter was to the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, of which the slain judge was a member. Results of polygraph tests are not always reliable and are inadmissable in criminal trials. It could not be determined what questions O'Ferrell was asked when he gave answers the FBI polygraph expert considered deceptive. On Tuesday, the FBI declined to comment when asked if O'Ferrell is a suspect. ``I would not comment that he is a suspect, only that he is one of a number of people we have interviewed,'' said FBI agent Chuck Archer. O'Ferrell, who sued his former employer, Gulf Life Insurance Co., lost the case on appeal in April from the 11th Circuit. A member of that court, Judge Robert Vance, was killed Dec. 16 by a package bomb mailed to his Mountain Brook home. Two days later, a similar bomb killed black attorney Robert Robinson of Savannah, Ga. A letter claiming responsibility for the mail bombings was sent to an Atlanta TV station by a person or group calling itself Americans for a Competent Federal Judicial System. O'Ferrell said today that FBI agents have not found a typewriter that reportedly links his typewritten court correspondence with typed material sent by the mail bomber. The court documents obtained by the AP include a legal brief apparently typed by O'Ferrell while acting as his own lawyer. It states in part: ``The law and court system in THESE UNITED STATES is corrupt, that I never had anything to do with but, I know you can help clean it up. ... If anyone has been mistreated by Gulf Life ... the Courts, and two Attorneys, I really believe that I have.'' The capitalization is as it appears in the document. O'Ferrell's father, J.C. O'Ferrell, said the FBI had questioned him about the activities of another son, 49-year-old James ``Buddy'' O'Ferrell, an independent trucker who lives in McKenzie, 80 miles west of Enterprise. ``They were trying to say my two sons had something to do with that bombing up in Birmingham,'' J.C. O'Ferrell said. ``They asked had I ever heard either one talk bad about colored folks, or if my sons ever made threats on any judges. I said, `No, my children weren't raised that way.''' The father said the agents fingerprinted him and took blood and hair samples from his farm in southwest Alabama. FBI agents ate lunch with Robert Wayne O'Ferrell and spent much of Tuesday talking to him, but he has not been charged. ``I don't have anything to hide,'' he said. ``When it's all over with, I'll be glad to get with the media and go into details.'' O'Ferrell said he had received a bomb threat himself Monday night. ``I know nothing about bombs, how to put them together or anything like that,'' he said. ``That kind of stuff has never fascinated me.'' Federal agents used earth-moving equipment to dig up the tank beside O'Ferrell's rural home, and dug up another tank at O'Ferrell's tin-covered salvage store. The agents refused to say what they were looking for. Dozens of federal officers converged on Enterprise during the weekend. Robert Wayne O'Ferrell, a tall, silver-haired man, lives in a small wooden house about five miles west of Enterprise with his wife, Mary. They have two daughters, Tammy, 20, and Danielle, 13. The one-time rural preacher said he asked members of his church ``to pray for my family that we can get through this thing and I've asked them to pray for the FBI to find whatever they are looking for.'' ``They were looking for a typewriter that we may have sold,'' O'Ferrell said. ``It's possible we could have had the typewriter in the last two years. But we don't know what typewriter they're talking about. You don't keep a record of everything you sell.'' The FBI has speculated that the pipe bombs were sent by one or more white supremacists. Morris Dees, director of the Southern Poverty Law Center, said O'Ferrell's name is not in the files of white hate groups that the center's Klanwatch project maintains. In addition to the bombs that killed Vance and Robinson, two other bombs were disarmed after being found at the Atlanta office of the 11th Circuit and the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People office in Jacksonville, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: Electrician Killed in W.Va. Mine
DOC.TEXT: A shuttle car under repair in a coal mine fell off cinder blocks, killing a worker, authorities said Wednesday. Leonard Brown, 45, of Peytona died Tuesday after the shuttle car pinned him against a mine floor, said Sam Stafford, spokesman for the U.S. Mine Safety and Health Administration. Brown, an electrician with Toney's Branch Coal Co., was the first person to die in a West Virginia mine this year and the fifth in the country, Stafford said.

DOC.HEAD: Foreigners May Soon Have to Pay for Zimbabwean Brides
DOC.TEXT: Foreigners may soon have to pay for their Zimbabwean brides, a top law officer said Wednesday. Attorney General Patrick Chinamasa said the hopeful husbands would probably have to pay the traditional African ``bride price'' under proposed changes to laws covering the powers of tribal chiefs in this Southern Arican nation. The payment, known as ``lobola,'' is usually made in cattle, cash, clothing and household goods, and it is recoverable if the woman proves to be barren. In the past, whites did not come under the jurisdiction of traditional chiefs' courts, also known as community courts, where matrimonial issues arise. Most mixed marriages have been conducted in Western-style ceremonies. Under proposed laws, however, ``you could well find a white person in front of a community court'' in any dispute over bride price, Chinamasa told legislators. He was asking the parliament to approve proposals that restore some legal powers to chiefs and remove the exemption of foreigners from customary law. Chinamasa conceded that in cases where German and Danish aid workers in rural Zimbabwe married local women, they could be liable for backdated payments. The laws are expected to come into force later this year.

DOC.HEAD: Hearing Focuses on Unequal Educational Opportunities
DOC.TEXT: Money does make a difference, education officials told a House subcommittee Wednesday as disagreements erupted over public school finances that enable some districts to spend up to eight times more than others in the same state. ``The notion that money does not make a difference is preposterous on its face,'' said Arthur E. Wise, director of the Center for the Study of the Teaching Profession at the Rand Corp. ``When the advantaged have the better financed schools, and the disadvantaged the poorly financed schools, America continues to provide unequal education to those who most need what school has to offer,'' he said. Wise was one of five witnesses at an Education and Labor subcommittee hearing on a bill to require states to equalize education spending statewide or face the loss of federal aid. The committee chairman, Rep. Augustus Hawkins, D-Calif., who introduced the bill Tuesday, cited statistics from a congressional study that found most states spend widely different sums to educate children living in different areas. Illinois, New Jersey, New York, Texas and Vermont were said to have the sharpest disparities. K.
