Forbis Jordan, a professor at Arizona State University, said Census Bureau data show the levels of revenue disparity among the states ranged from 1.00 to 1 in Hawaii to 8.49 to 1 in New York. States with spending disparities below two-to-one include Alabama, Connecticut, Delaware, Florida, Maryland, North Carolina, Rhode Island, South Carolina and West Virginia. The common element in these states, he said, is a relatively small number of school districts. States with spending disparities above four-to-one were Alaska, Arkansas, Colorado, Minnesota, Montana, New York, North Dakota, Ohio, Oklahoma, Texas, and Vermont. The financing systems in Montana and Texas are being challenged. Rep. Peter Smith, R-Vt., questioned the accuracy of the statistics, from the Congressional Research Service, saying they were ``radically wrong.'' He said the data do not reflect differences among school districts, such as population and location. Albert Kauffman of the Mexican American Legal Defense and Educational Fund in San Antonio, Texas, said that in Texas, where the state Supreme Court recently found the system of financing public school education violates the state constitution, ``the richest districts pay half the taxes and spend twice as much on their students.''

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Jam Prado's Velazquez Retrospective
DOC.TEXT: Thousands lined up outside the Prado museum Wednesday to view 79 paintings by Diego Velazquez on the first day of what is billed as the most complete retrospective of the 17th-century Spanish master's work. Museum officials said they were forced to close the doors leading into the exhibition several times to ensure that no more than 500 people were in the nine rooms housing the works at any one time. During the first five hours after the doors opened, more than 4,000 people viewed the show, which is expected to draw up to 1 million visitors by the time it closes March 30. The Prado retrospective, inaugurated Tuesday night by King Juan Carlos and Queen Sofia, dwarfs the 38-painting exhibition that drew 550,000 people to New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art between October and Jan. 7. Loans from European and U.S. institutions brought together 80 percent of the known works by Velazquez, many of which come from the Prado's own collection, officials said. The most important loans included ``The Rokeby Venus'' from London's National Gallery, not shown in Spain since 1969, and ``Portrait of Juan de Pareja'' from the Metropolitan, never shown in Spain. Neither ``Venus'' nor ``Las Meninas'' was included in the New York show. Forty-nine of the works on display belong to the Prado, six to other Spanish institutions and the rest to foreign collections. Among other works assembled are ``The Forge of Vulcan,'' ``The Surrender of Breda,'' ``The Spinners'' and ``Equestrian Portrait of Philip IV,'' the painter's royal patron.

DOC.HEAD: Committee Approves `Beat Flag Burner for Buck' Bill
DOC.TEXT: The penalty for beating a person who burns the U.S. flag would be reduced to a $1 fine under a bill approved by a state House committee. ``For many widows or parents of loved ones who were killed in wars, all they have left is the flag,'' Democratic Rep. Shelby Rhinehart told the House Judiciary Committee. ``If they want to beat the heck out of someone who burns the flag, so be it.'' Assault normally carries a sentence of 11 months and 29 days and a fine of up to $2,500. Rhinehart, who sponsored the bill, said Tuesday it was prompted by the U.S. Supreme Court's ruling last year that burning the flag is a form of protest protected by the First Amendment, which guarantees freedom of speech. Rep. Tommy Burnett questioned Rhinehart's proposal, saying it would ``permit a constitutional act to now be assaultable.'' No committee member was recorded as voting against the bill when it was sent Tuesday to the House Calendar Committee. The measure is a long way from becoming law. It must be set for debate on the House floor by the Calendar Committee, which has the power to kill it. It also must be approved by both the Senate Judiciary Committee and the Senate.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Calls GOP Lawmakers' Social Security Plan `Innovative'
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Wednesday lambasted a proposed Social Security tax cut as sleight of hand but labeled as ``innovative thinking'' a plan that eventually would make the retirement system private. Bush said he was ``not prepared to endorse'' a plan sponsored by Rep. John E. Porter, R-Ill., and the House Republican whip, Newt Gingrich of Georgia. ``It's worthy, though, of consideration, of some study,'' he said. ``People are concerned about Social Security, so when you have innovative thinking of that nature, I don't want to just gun it down,'' Bush added. ``I'm not going to support it.'' Under the Porter-Gingrich proposal, Social Security taxes would be gradually channeled into a type of mandatory Individual Retirement Accounts. As workers' IRAs grew, their claim on Social Security would decline. By the time today's workers are retired _ about 50 years from now, Porter estimated _ Social Security would be fully privatized. Seldom since Republican nominee Barry Goldwater's losing 1964 presidential campaign has a national GOP figure spoken publicly of even the remote possibility of replacing Social Security with private retirement plans. The president's refusal at a news conference to reject the Porter-Gingrich proposal was quickly criticized by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat whose own tax-cut plan was dismissed by Bush. Moynihan, who is considered one of the government's top authorities on Social Security, said of the Republican congressmen's proposal, ``The president described that as `innovative thinking. Was it innovative thinking after 50 years of steady payments to start dismantling Social Security? I don't think so.'' The subject of Social Security arose at Bush's news conference when he was asked about Moynihan's plan to roll back this year's tax increase and reduce one scheduled next year. The aim of the bill _ which has attracted widespread interest, if not support, in Congress _ is to halt the use of surplus Social Security taxes to make the federal deficit appear far smaller than it is. Bush said he sees no need for any major change in Social Security at this time. ``I think the system has been, in and out over the years, basically a pretty fair system,'' he said. Moynihan's bill is ``a disguise for increased taxes around the corner,'' Bush said. ``This is a ... sleight-of-hand operation,'' he added, noting that shortly after Moynihan outlined his plan, Sen. Ernest F. Hollings, D-S.C., proposed to replace revenues from the reduced Social Security taxes with a national sales tax. ``There is no sleight of hand whatsoever,'' Moynihan replied, ``and I do not see that there was any need to make such a characterization.'' Lawmakers from both parties have expressed displeasure that Social Security surpluses _ which are building at the rate of $1 billion a week _ are being used for deficit reduction, rather than being invested solely for the benefit of future retirees. Moynihan has been speaking on this issue for months. But it grabbed public attention for the first time when, during a slow news period over the December holidays, he called for cutting the taxes if they are not going to be saved for Social Security. There were these other developments Wednesday: _ Bush said Congress should wait to see his own proposal for gradually taking Social Security surpluses out of the federal deficit calculation. That long-range plan, starting in 1993, would require that a growing portion of the surplus be used to retire publicly held debt. _ House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., said he has serious reservations about Moynihan's proposed tax cut, which would require Congress to find an additional $55 billion for deficit reduction this year. He said he fears that instead of raising taxes or cutting spending to make up that loss, Congress and the president would opt for increased borrowing. _ Reps. Byron Dorgan, D-N.D., and Richard Durbin, D-Ill., proposed to roll back only this year's increase in the Social Security tax rate _ which rose from 7.51 percent to 7.65 percent of the first $51,300 of wages. Congress then could use the rest of this year to devise a plan for ensuring that Social Security taxes are used solely for Social Security.

DOC.HEAD: Cardinal Calls For Independent Lithuania, Religious Freedom
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania's Roman Catholic cardinal has called for independence for the Soviet republic and said the church there is still not free, it was reported Wednesday. Cardinal Vincentas Sladkevicius told the weekly Roman Catholic magazine Il Sabato that he did not want to create problems for Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, but Lithuanians would not accept the Soviet occupation of the Baltic land. ``We say this only: let perestroika go its way, and let us go ours,'' the cardinal said. ``The church has promoted for more than 50 years the cause of national independence, and it will continue to do so. The annexation of 1939 is based on a villanous pact between the Soviets and Nazis, it cannot be defended in any way on the legal plane. Even Moscow has recognized this. We want to separate from the Soviet Union,'' Sladkevicius said, according to the excerpts of the interview released in advance by the magazine. The cardinal said a law on conscience being prepared by Soviet officials was new ``only in name'' and that ``the church in Lithuania is not yet free,'' the magazine reported. Lithuania, an independent country before World War II, was occupied by the Soviet Union in 1940 and has been considered a stronghold of nationalism. An estimated 2.5 million people, or 80 percent of Lithuania's population, are Roman Catholics.

DOC.HEAD: Czechoslovak Town: Have We Got a Dictator For You
DOC.TEXT: An enterprising Czechoslovak community on Wednesday took out an ad in one of West Germany's newspapers to offer its unwanted statue of Josef V. Stalin to collectors for $50,000. The advertisement in the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung from the local authorities in the north Moravian city of Zabreh said the larger-than-life statue of the late Soviet dictator was dismantled Dec. 8. Touting the monument as a collectors' item _ ``probably the last memorial of this symbol of violence in Europe,'' _ it offerd the statue for $50,000 it said would go toward refurbishing the local hospital. ``The new owner will not only get a unique curiosity, he will also be supporting the struggle of the Czechoslovak people for freedom and democracy,'' the ad pledged. Zabreh is not alone in trying to sell its Stalin monument. A similar project has been touted in the Czech town of Komarov, near Prague, while the city of Ostrava is to dismantle its giant two-faced monument showing Stalin and Soviet founder Vladimir I. Lenin. The statues survived the de-Stalinization campaign that saw thousands of similar monuments dismantled across the Communist world because Czechoslovak authorities were slow to take up the policy, adopted in the Soviet Union after 1956. A giant statue of Stalin that once dominated central Prague was dismantled only in the early 1960s.

DOC.HEAD: Budget Deficits Stuck at High Levels, Congressional Experts Say
With AM-Social Security, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Federal budget shortfalls seem stuck at the $140 billion level in coming years, making it ever harder for Congress and the White House to meet Gramm-Rudman deficit targets, congressional analysts said Wednesday. Congressional Budget Office Director Robert D. Reischauer also projected that the U.S. economy would sidestep a recession this year. And he predicted that Congress would be hard pressed to plug the huge budget gap Sen. Daniel Moynihan's proposed Social Security payroll tax cut would create. In remarks that came five days before President Bush reveals his 1991 budget, Reischauer said a healthy economy would not be enough to allay the government's persistent fiscal woes. ``Over the next few years, no further progress in reducing the deficit can be expected under current budgetary policies,'' Reischauer told the Senate Budget Committee. Reischauer said he expected the shortfall in fiscal 1990 _ which runs through Sept. 30 _ to be $138 billion. He predicted deficits of $138 billion next year, $135 billion in 1992, and $141 billion in 1993, the year the Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction law requires a balanced budget. The economic and budgetary projections issued by the non-partisan CBO were decidedly more pessimistic than estimates expected Monday when the White House's Office of Management and Budget releases Bush's budget. OMB is expected to assert that only about $35 billion in savings will be needed next year to meet the Gramm-Rudman shortfall target of $64 billion, $37 billion less than the savings the Congressional Budget Office says are needed. CBO's estimates have little legal significance in budget-writing. But they are relied on by many lawmakers _ especially Democrats _ as a voice of truth in the often partisan fiscal process. ``The Office of Management and Budget consistently understates the deficits by resorting to the most optimistic economic assumptions it can credibly _ and now sometimes even incredibly _ employ,'' said Senate Budget Committee Chairman James Sasser, D-Tenn. The CBO forecast that the economy would expand by a low 1.8 percent this year, measured from the final quarter of last year through the third quarter of 1990, well below the 2.6 percent the administration is expected to predict. The stronger the economy, the greater the revenues the government collects and the lower the budget deficit. Fifty-one private economists surveyed by Blue Chip Economic Indicators, a private publication, have projected that the economy will expand by an average of 1.7 percent this year. Reischauer said he believes that a looser monetary policy the Federal Reserve has practiced since last June will help drive interest rates down and thus avoid a recession. Most private economists agree that a slowdown this year is unlikely. ``CBO expects that the Federal Reserve will safely steer the economy between the shoals of a recession and higher inflation,'' he said. Reischauer was pressed by the committee's ranking Republican, Sen. Pete Domenici of New Mexico, on the wisdom of a bill introduced by Moynihan, D-N.Y., that would reduce the Social Security tax. Moynihan's cut would reduce government revenue collections by $7 billion this year and $55 billion in 1991. Reischauer referred to past failings of Congress and the White House to find large amounts of budget savings and said, ``It's hard to argue I think that we'd be out there raising income taxes or other taxes, or decreasing spending, in large amounts.'' Moynihan and others have argued that the growing annual surpluses in the Social Security are masking the true size of the federal deficit. Without this year's $66 billion Social Security surplus, the 1990 deficit would be $204 billion, Reischauer said.

DOC.HEAD: Calls Increase for Provisional Gov't to Step Down
LaserPhoto XBUC3
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of protesters broke through lines of police and soldiers Wednesday and surged toward government headquarters, demanding the leadership resign and accusing it of being a front for Communist rule. The crowd of about 1,000 people at Victory Square pushed through two lines of unarmed police and then through a line of armed soldiers who took no strong action to hold them back. The army moved in tanks very slowly and the crowd retreated, still chanting ``Communists in disguise!'' and ``Elections without the Front!'' _ a reference to the National Salvation Front's plans to participate in elections May 20. The Front, which has been governing Romania since dictator Nicolae Ceausescu was ousted Dec. 22, had said it would not run candidates in the election. On Tuesday, however, it reversed itself. Opponents have accused some Front members who served under Ceausescu of being sympathetic to the Communists, and they fear the Front will put the Communist Party in power again. Hours before the rally, the largest opposition party, the National Peasant Party, called on the Front to resign. ``The National Salvation Front must resign today as it can't be both a referee and a player,'' the party said in a communique read by party leader Corneliu Coposu. Some Peasant Party members left their headquarters after the communique was read and joined a small demonstration under way at a nearby university. The demonstration picked up supporters as marchers wound through Bucharest's icy streets, stopping at the major sites of the revolution and finally coming to Victory Square. The protesters singled out President Ion Iliescu, who heads the Front, shouting: ``Down with Iliescu!'' ``If Iliescu wanted to gain power, he should have gotten signatures on petitions and formed a party,'' said one protester, engineer Adrian Mihalcea. The Peasant Party accused the Front of trying to steal victory from the young people and others who fought Communism and Ceausescu. ``They are making us believe that they want to put the Communists in power again, even worse Ceausescu-ism. Only the words are different ... but the methods of the Salvation Front are the same as Ceausescu's methods,'' party vice president Ion Puiu said in an interview. Puiu said the communique would be circulated to all the traditional parties _ the National Liberal Party, the Social Democratic Party and the Green Party _ for comments and additions to demonstrate ``anti-Communist solidarity.'' The Peasant Party said it planned a major demonstration against the Front on Sunday. The National Peasant Party, founded in 1892, was one of the major forces in Romanian politics before the Communists came to power after World War II. It is the largest and best organized of the 15 new or revived political parties that plan to contest the election. Iliescu, a former Communist Party member who ran afoul of Ceausescu and was demoted from party secretary, told a rally Jan. 12 that the ``Communist Party is dead,'' and he outlawed it. The following day, Iliescu reversed himself, saying the ban had been a hasty decision and that voters would decide the party's fate in a Jan. 28 referendum. The referendum was canceled because of time constraints and because officials said the questions on it were moot. The decision to compete in May even alienated some Front members. The daily Romania Libera said Wednesday that a former leading dissident, Doina Cornea, resigned from the interim leading body, saying she did not want to take part in a ``power struggle.'' Puiu said the Peasant Party wants the Front to resign immediately and that the new government should be formed either by technical experts who can guarantee the administration of the country and conduct fair elections, or by all political parties committed to the same goals. The Front, meanwhile, said it planned to meet with all parties Saturday to discuss campaign funding and the proposed election law. It said U.N. observers will monitor the vote. Puiu said he supports a boycott of the meeting to protest the Front's decision. Adrian Jeara, a Peasant Party member, said his party has 150,000 members. ``The biggest problem of our party is that we haven't got the opportunity to appear on radio or television and we don't have our own journals,'' he said. When party members asked the government for paper to print a new journal, he said, the government told them there wasn't enough paper so they couldn't have any. However, Premier Petre Roman told the daily Adevarul recently there was no shortage of newsprint and that all parties which want to publish their own newspaper will get it.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead of LAS VEGAS-dated item to CORRECT to Redd, sted Red.
DOC.TEXT: Comedian Redd Foxx is trying to block an auction of his possessions, including jewelry, several cars and other personal property, by the Internal Revenue Service. A Foxx attorney, Paul Whitford of Beverly Hills, said the sale Saturday would conflict with efforts to liquidate the comedian's estate in bankruptcy court. The case, in which Foxx listed $2.1 million in assets and $2.5 million in liabilities, stems from a Chapter 11 bankruptcy Foxx filed in 1983. Some of Foxx's property has been sold off periodically to satisfy creditors. IRS agents seized the personal property and Foxx's home during a raid Nov. 28 on the comedian's Las Vegas house. The IRS scheduled the auction to try to reduce Foxx's tax liability of $900,000, including penalties and interest. A hearing is scheduled Friday before U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Clive Jones to consider an injunction blocking the IRS sale.

DOC.HEAD: U.S., Soviet Negotiators to Get Peak at Each Other's Nuclear Warheads
DOC.TEXT: U.S. and Soviet negotiators, seeking to speed work on a proposed arms pact, have agreed to the first ever peek at each other's nuclear warheads, U.S. spokesmen said Wednesday. Under the terms of a little publicized protocol signed in Geneva on Monday, U.S. and Soviet inspectors will take a close look sometime this spring at warheads atop one each of the other side's land-based and submarine-launched ballistic missiles, the spokesmen said. Determining the exact number of warheads aboard missiles and bombers will be key when the two sides complete work on the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, to cut superpower arsenals by 30 percent to 50 percent. Secretary of State James A. Baker III is to hold talks in Moscow on Feb. 6-7 with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze in an effort to speed work on the START accord for possible signing at an expected summit next June. Three previous arms control treaties have not been ratified by the Senate, in large measure because of doubts that they could be verified. Under the new protocol, the Soviets also will have a chance to look at two U.S. B-1B bombers, and the Americans at two Soviet Tupolev-95 ``Bear'' bombers. One version will be designed to carry cruise missiles and the other to carry standard bombs. The Soviet ballistic missiles to be inspected are the landbased SS-18 and the the submarine-launched SS-N-23, said Matthew Murphy, a spokesman for the U.S. Arms Control and Disarmament Agency. The Soviets say the SS-18, like the U.S. MX missile, carries 10 warheads, although one intelligence source said that the big Soviet booster can lift up to 20 nuclear devices. The Soviets will get a close look under the tip of an MX and the new D-5, to be deployed aboard submarines starting this March. The D-5 is designed to carry eight and the SS-N-23 to carry four warheads, according to information published by the two sides. ``This agreement marks the first time that the U.S. and the Soviet Union will inspect a number of each other's nuclear warheads on ballistic missiles,'' said a statement read by David Denny, a State Department spokesman. The exact time and place of the inspections has not been disclosed. President Bush last June proposed that the two sides test verification techniques before conclusion of START, an unusual step designed to enhance ability to monitor the compliance of the other side. At the 1987 Washington summit, the sides agreed on the number of warheads to be attributed to each existing type of stategic ballistic missile and on the need for inspections. Precautions will be taken to ensure that the inspectors learn as little as possible about the internal design of the warheads, possible by shrouding them in cloths so that opposing experts see only several lumps inside the delivery vehicles, said one source. ``It's the dance of the seven veils,'' said the source. In a separate development, the State Department said U.S. officials still hope to sign at the June summit an agreement on two unratified nuclear test treaties from the 1970s. However, the administration is balking at planned follow-on talks designed to lead to lower ceilings and numbers of underground nuclear tests, said sources who spoke on condition they not be further identified. The decision was reported earlier by The Washington Times and The Washington Post. The State Department statement said that ``in this round of the current talks, we are continuing to focus on the completion of protocols to provide for effective verification of the Threshhold Test Ban Treaty of 1974 and the Peaceful Nuclear Explosions Treaty of 1976.'' The treaties were never submitted to the Senate, but in 1986 President Reagan told Congress he would do so after reaching agreement with the Soviets on a means to verify that neither side was exceeding the 150-kiloton ceiling set by the pacts.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney: Freeze Construction Contracts
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney has ordered a three-month freeze on new military construction contracts, the Pentagon announced Wednesday. Cheney, in a statement, said he was forced to take the cost-saving step ``in light of the coming changes in the force structure and disposition of the U.S. Armed Forces.'' Several weeks ago, Cheney ordered a freeze on hiring civilian DOD workers in a similar effort to trim spending. The moratorium on construction contracts goes into effect immediately and lasts until April 30. It applies to the award of all new military construction contracts, including those for architectural and engineering design services, the statement said. The Pentagon's fiscal 1990 military construction budget as approved by Congress amounted to around $8.5 billion. The bill made wholesale cuts in President Bush's request for foreign bases, but added millions of dollars for domestic installations. The statement said the only exceptions are those contracts and options excercised: _To the extent that the United States has a legal obligation under a statute, treaty or international agreement. _To comply with the requirements of the defense authorization amendments and base closure act of 1988. _To meet urgent requirements upon the approval of the secretary. The secretary also ordered that the secretaries of the military departments and the directors of the defense agencies review their plans for military construction and report on their revisions by mid-April.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Bush Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Wednesday denied a report that his family members were split on abortion, calling the account ``pure, unadulterated malarkey.'' On the volatile issue that continues to bedevil him and the Republican Party, Bush also said he sees no problem in campaigning for GOP candidates who are pro-choice, even though he opposes abortion except for rape, incest or a threat to a mother's life. Newsweek magazine this week said abortion was discussed at a private meeting of the Bushes with their children and spouses, and the men all opposed abortion while the women all took a pro-choice stance. Bush was asked at a news conference if Barbara Bush supports abortion rights. ``No I couldn't confirm that ... And the meeting that I read about in one of the most respected publications was pure, unadulterated _ `malarkey' is the word I like to use. It just wasn't there,'' Bush replied. Mrs. Bush, when asked about abortion, refused to state a position, saying that no matter how she answers it will offend someone. Since the Supreme Court last year gave states greater authority to regulate abortions, pro-choice activism has escalated and many Republican officeholders have embraced that policy. Bush and the Republican Party have shifted from the hardline anti-abortion rhetoric to a policy of inclusion, stating the Republican Party has room for pro-choice advocates as well. Bush reiterated that point of view on Wednesday when asked about his support for pro-choice party members. ``I was elected to try to fulfill the platform and the programs that I believe in. And so that's my personal choice, but that doesn't mean I have lack of respect for others, and that I'm going to go out and not campaign for people that disagree with me on this issue.'' Bush once supported the Supreme Court 1973 decision that legalized abortion, but now opposes it. He opposes abortion except to save the life of the mother or in cases of rape or incest. He favors federal payment for abortions only to save the mother's life. Bush addressed the annual March for Life on Monday by telephone from the Oval Office, telling the anti-abortion activists before they marched to the Supreme Court of ``my deep personal concern about abortion on demand.'' ``Let me assure you that this president stands with you on this issue of life,'' said Bush, who supports a constitutional ``human life'' amendment to outlaw most abortions.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Lawmaker Announces Group to Push for Children's Rights
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Bill Bradley announced Wednesday the formation of an advisory council to push for ratification of a U.N. convention on rights for children and highlight problems plaguing youth worldwide. The convention stresses the importance of primary health care and education, and it recommends measures to protect against child labor, sexual exploitation and drug abuse. It also sets up steps to protect children in cases of adoption, foster care and juvenile justice proceedings. Bradley, D-N.J., said Americans must make a commitment to protect the rights of all children. ``If American children have the right to be free from polio and whooping cough and dysentery, so do the children of Ethiopia and Pakistan. If American children have the right to be free from famine, so do the children of the Sudan,'' Bradley said at a news conference. Twenty countries must ratify the convention for it to have the force of an international treaty. The U.N. General Assembly approved the document in November. A report issued in December by the U.N. Children's Fund said spending by Third World countries on armaments and debt service rather than health and nutrition could doom 100 million children to death by disease and starvation in the 1990s. The annual report by James Grant, UNICEF executive director, said that almost 8,000 children die each day because they are not immunized. Nearly 7,000 die daily from dehydration caused by diarrhea, and about 6,000 are killed each day by pneumonia, the report says. The cost of immunizing all these children and providing medicines for dehydration and pneumonia would be about $2.5 billion a year, the report says. Bradley said the advisory council will include a cross-section of people from throughout the United States. On Tuesday, Bradley and Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind., introduced a resolution in the Senate urging President Bush to send the convention to the Senate for deliberation as soon as possible.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Fault Bush for Slowness in Judicial Nominations
DOC.TEXT: President Bush made fewer nominations to the federal bench in his first year than either of his two immediate predecessors, leaving 52 of 75 vacancies on district and circuit courts with no nominee, the Democratic Study Group said Wednesday. In a study of presidential appointments to executive and judicial positions, the group also said that 28 percent of the 390 presidentially appointed positions in agencies and departments that require Senate confirmation remained unfilled as of Jan. 1. At the end of former President Reagan's first year in office, 82 percent of presidentially appointed positions in the agencies and departments were filled, according to a recent Library of Congress survey. The DSG, an organization of Democratic members of the House, said Bush had 75 vacancies to fill in federal courts during his first year in office. Of these only l5, five on the appeals courts and 10 on district courts, were nominated and confirmed in 1989. Separately, the White House announced Bush's appointment of two federal appeals judges and eight U.S. District Court judges on Wednesday. Chase Untermeyer, director of the White House Office of Presidential Personnel, and David Runkel, spokesman for the Justice Department, were telephoned for comment on the DSG study, but were not immediately available. Citing figures from the Administrative Office of the U.S. Courts, the DSG said 18 vacancies remained on appeals courts and 42 in the district courts, in which federal civil and criminal trials are conducted. Confirmation of some nominees has been held up by Sen. Jim Jeffords, R-Vt., in a dispute with the administration over the role to be played by Republican senators in the selection of judicial nominees. ``But the dispute between Senate Republicans and the White House cannot explain the slowness of the Bush administration this past year in filling judicial vacancies,'' the DSG said. It said the 15 confirmed nominees in the first year of the Bush administration compared with 40 in Reagan's first year and 30 in 1977, former President Carter's first year in office.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinan Sentenced to Seven Life Terms for Murders
DOC.TEXT: A Palestinian man convicted of Israel's worst mass murder was sentenced Wednesday to seven life terms in prison, one for each person he strangled, Israel television reported. A three-man Tel Aviv District Court tribunal also sentenced Mohammed Halabi, 32, to an additional 40 years in prison for conviction on two attempted murder charges, the television said. Halabi, who confessed to the murders, said he was recruited by the Moslem fundamentalist Hamas, or Zeal, movement and killed the four Jews and three Arabs to prove he was not working as an informer for the Israeli security service, news reports said. In its sentencing, the tribunal said it thought criminal motives were behind the slayings of the five women and two men. The seven victims were strangled with nylon rope and their bodies were found Oct. 20 in two apartments in Tel Aviv and neighboring Jaffa. The victims were all alleged to be involved in prostitution and drug dealing. Police said Halabi was from the Jabaliya refugee camp in the occupied Gaza Strip and had worked previously for Israeli's Shin Bet security service.

DOC.HEAD: Former Hard-Liner Says Scrap Missiles
DOC.TEXT: A former Pentagon official who helped guide and justify the defense build-up of the 1980s said Wednesday he now favors scrapping the MX and Midgetman missiles, but pressing ahead with ``Star Wars'' research and the stealth bomber. Richard Perle, a former assistant secretary of defense who was among the most adamant backers of the Reagan administration defense increases, said the liberalization of the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe also means the United States should consider proposing deeper weapons cuts in arms control negotiations. ``The Soviet empire in collapsing,'' Perle told the Senate Armed Services Committee. ``Time is on our side,'' said Perle, a resident fellow at the American Enterprise Institute, a think tank on the conservative side of the political spectrum. In response to the lessening threat of the Warsaw Pact, Perle suggested possibly reducing ground forces and ``skipping the next generation of weapons systems.'' ``I would not proceed with either the Midgetman or the rail mobile MX: The current generation of ICBMs (intercontinental ballistic missiles) should prove adequate and the next generation ... will benefit from further research and development if it is delayed for a few years,'' he said. The MX is a 10-warhead missile already deployed; the Midgetman is a smaller single-warhead missile being developed. The administration has recommended putting the 50 MX missiles, now based in underground silos, on rail cars. The trains would move about during an international crisis and present a harder-to-hit target than silos. The Midgetman would be placed on special off-road trucks for the same reason. Sen. John Warner, R-Va., the panel's ranking Republican, told Perle he objected to slashing both missile systems because that action would remove leverage in arms control talks. But Perle responded that the ``importance of these agreements has declined dramatically.'' The Pentagon should also think about ``making do'' with many of the current generation of conventional weapons, including fighter jets, Perle said. But he said he would proceed with the B-2 bomber, known as the stealth bomber for its radar-evading design. At $530 million a copy, the aircraft has been attacked by many members of Congress as too expensive, at least if the Air Force buys all 132 it wants. While the changing Soviet empire is good news for the West, Perle said it would be foolish for the United States to dismantle its defenses precipitiously. ``We would be wise to wait a little longer before confidently predicting that we can afford to be weak in the face of uncertainty,'' he said. The Soviet Union spend as much as 20 percent of its Gross National Product on defense, compared with 6 percent by the United States, he said. As for the Strategic Defense Initiative, known as Star Wars, Perle said the concept of a shield to protect the nation from all enemy missiles is unrealistic. At the same time, he said a ``serious program'' of research and development oriented towards a partial shield can and should go forward even in the face of shrinking defense budgets. ``As the prospect of nuclear proliferation draws closer, we should be reminded that the threat is neither exclusively Soviet nor, for that matter, exclusively deliberate. There are third countries and there are accidents and these two reasons alone would justify a vigorous research and development program,'' Perle said. Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., the panel's chairman, said the committee wants defense planners at the Pentagon to present a new five-year strategic plan before lawmakers make specific budget-cutting recommendations.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Asked to Halt Sales of Milk From Cows Given Synthetic Hormones
DOC.TEXT: Some farm and consumer advocates want the Food and Drug Administration to halt the distribution of milk from test cows treated with a synthetic hormone until the agency completes a scientific review. The group said Wednesday that, if there is not an immediate suspension, the FDA should at least require labels on milk and other dairy products that originate from test cows treated with bovine growth hormone, or BGH. Brian Ahlberg of the National Farm Coalition said a similar request for halting the distribution of milk from test herds was made to the FDA last August but the agency had not responded. The genetically engineered hormone is bovine somatotropin and is usually called BST by the Agriculture Department and the chemical companies that make it. Doses of the hormone, which also occurs naturally in a cow's body, boost milk production. Jeremy Rifkin of the Foundation for Economic Trends, a long-time critic of the synthetic growth hormone, told a news conference his organization is preparing a petition asking the FDA for ``a full, thorough, internal investigation'' into allegations that the agency has worked with the drug companies and has been hiding test results from the public. Rifkin said the hormone ``has no redeeming social value'' and is bad for farmers, cows, taxpayers and, perhaps, consumer health. During questioning, however, coalition spokesman Ahlberg said the group was not claiming adverse health effects from milk produced by hormone-treated cows. Rifkin also accused FDA of promoting the growth hormone before the agency has given it final clearance. ``This is outrageous,'' Rifkin said. ``This is activity that should have been condemned a long time ago.'' Rifkin said that if FDA approves commercial use of the drug, his group will seek court action to ban it. The FDA did not return calls for comment on Rifkin's allegation that the agency has been actively promoting the drug prior to its final approval. Speakers at the news conference said they had no information from the FDA about the extent of testing or how much milk is entering the U.S. consumer pipeline, although Rifkin and other have said they thought the percentage is quite small. They said producers include herds maintained by land-grant universities and private farmers. The common practice is to sell milk from test herds to local dealers, who then mix it with other milk for distribution. Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee, has asked the General Accounting Office to investigate allegations by Dr. Richard Burroughs, a fired FDA veterinarian, that tests of the chemical were inadequate. Burroughs has accused the FDA of toning down criticism of research on the hormone at the request of chemical companies. The FDA has said the hormone-treated milk is safe to drink. The hormone is manufactured by Monsanto, Eli Lilly, Upjohn and American Cyanamid, who have said the FDA review has been the most thorough of any study of animal drugs. And the FDA says it has not made any exceptions in its drug-testing standards.

DOC.HEAD: New Agreement Reached to Enforce Strip Mining Laws
DOC.TEXT: The Interior Department reached agreement with environmental groups Wednesday on a new plan to strictly enforce the nation's strip mining laws. Hailed as ``an unqualified victory for the environment'' by lawyers for conservation associations, the agreement is intended to make it easier to revoke coal mining permits issued to companies or individuals with records of past violations and to block the issuing of new permits in such cases. At the heart of the new enforcement system is the planned installation by July 1 of a new computer system with accurate and complete information on coal companies and their owners. The aim is to match permit holders and applicants with past violators of the 1977 strip mining law. The product of more than four months of intense negotiations, the agreement settles a legal and environmental dispute that began nearly a decade ago during James Watts' controversial tenure as secretary of the Interior. Manuel Lujan, the present secretary, signed the new agreement in exchange for the dropping of legal action against the department by Save Our Cumberland Mountains, an environmental group based in the coal-mining regions of Appalachia. Lujan said the agreement signals a new willingness by the federal government to coooperate with environmentalists. ``Our aim is fair, even-handed enforcement of the surface mining law,'' Lujan said in a statement. Brent Rushforth, an attorney who represented the environmental group, said: ``The agreement should put an end to years of neglect by the Department of the Interior, neglect which permitted mine operators to routinely violate the law, scar the land and pollute the water.'' But Rushforth said the department has made other agreements over the years to enforce the strip mining law and has not complied with them. ``It is now up to the department to live up to the promises,'' Rushforth said. ``You can be sure we'll watch them closely.'' Rushforth said that to comply with the agreement, the department's Office of Surface Mining Reclamation and Enforcement will most likely use a computer system developed by Save Our Cumberland Mountains and the National Wildlife Federation. The plan for the department spelled out in the agreement has these major components: _Coal-mining permit applications will be run through the computer system with approval given only to those applicants with no ties to violators. _A computer review of existing mining permits will be initiated and enforcement action taken if a permit was improperly issued. _Development by March 1, 1990, of a plan to enforce federal mining cessation orders. _Development of sanctions against people who intentionally give incomplete or false ownership information on coal-mine permit applications. The Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 was intended to ensure that land strip-mined for coal would be restored. Save Our Cumberland Mountains originally sued the department in 1981, contending the Surface Mining Act was not being enforced. An initial settlement was reached the next year but Rushforth said little or nothing was done to implement it. The environmental group complained that in Appalachia, in particular, ``shell'' companies have been used to evade the requirements of the act with an operator mining a site, then abandoning it unreclaimed. ``Enforcement efforts against the shell, which usually has no assets or is bankrupt, prove futile,'' the group said. ``Meanwhile the operator creates another shell company and repeats the `rape and run' process.'' In 1985, a court order was obtained requiring the department to establish a computer system to contain data on the identity of owners of mining permits and to match them with violators of the act. But Rushforth said a series of congressional investigations showed the system was ineffective and accomplished none of its objectives. Harry Snyder, director of the Surface Mining office, said he inherited ``a broken computer system that the government had spent millions of dollars on and which didn't work.'' Now, he said, ``You've got a new administration committed to enforce this law fairly and in a committed way.''

DOC.HEAD: Congress Informed of Sidewinder Sale to Turkey
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration has informed Congress that it intends to sell Turkey 310 Sidewinder air-to-air missiles and support equipment at a cost of $30 million, the Pentagon said Wednesday. The heat-seeking missiles, formally designated AIM-RS, will be used on Turkey's co-produced F-16 fighter aircraft, the statement said. The sale ``will contribute to the foreign policy and national security objectives of the United States by improving the military capabilities of Turkey in fulfillment of its NATO obligations,'' the statement said.

DOC.HEAD: Promotional Tambourines Said to Pose Danger of Choking
DOC.TEXT: A manufacturer is recalling more than 20,000 tambourines sold natiowide as a novelty promotion item by two restaurant chains because of sharp points and small parts that could cause injuries to children, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said Wednesday. The orange and white tambourines have a red, black, yellow and gray picture of ``Chuck E. Cheese'' and were sold since 1987 at pizza restaurants under that name. The items were also sold at Showbiz Pizza Restaurants, according to a statement issued by the CPSC. In agency testing, the plastic tambourines broke along with the wire holding metal cymbals attached to the side of the instrument. ``The cymbals could present a choking hazard and the wire parts could cause puncture or laceration injuries,'' the CPSC statement said. Neither the CPSC nor the California-based Dennis Poland Inc. Merchandising Service, which produced the toys, is aware of any injuries involving the tambourines, the agency said. The voluntary recall is being taken as a preventive action. Consumers can return the tambourines to the store where they were purchased for a full refund.

DOC.HEAD: US Blasts Repression in Haiti
DOC.TEXT: The State Department criticized on Wednesday as ``outrageous and indefensible'' the Haitian government's expulsion of democratic opposition leaders and other measures to silence dissent. In a followup to the weekend expulsion of four prominent politicians, Haitian authorities arrested a leading business figure Tuesday and ordered broadcast outlets to air only government-approved news. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler called the measures a ``blatant assault'' on civil liberties that puts at risk the democratic transition the government has promised. ``We call upon the government of Haiti to cease any actions which infringe on freedom of speech and other basic human rights and (to) rescind its emergency measures.'' Under questioning, Ms. Tutwiler raised the possibility that a $41.4 million program of U.S. humanitarian aid funneled through private groups might be curtailed. Later, however, other State Department officials denied that the option was being considered, noting that the funds benefit the Haitian people directly and are not handled by Haitian authorities. The only government-to-government aid provided to Haiti since November 1987 was $10 million in food assistance last year. ``The actions of the Haitian government have been outrageous and indefensible,'' Ms. Tutwiler said. ``They will affect U.S.-Haitian relations and the prospect for future aid. You cannot destroy democracy in order to save it.'' Elections are scheduled for October but Ms. Tutwiler said they will lack credibility if opposition leaders are not allowed full participation. A Haitian Information Ministry statement told broadcasters that it must approve their local news reports, and ordered them to ``refrain from relaying or broadcasting any information on Haiti from stations broadcasting'' from abroad. In recent days, stations have relayed statements by exiled opposition leaders broadcast by Radio France Internationale and the Voice of America. Stations also were told not to broadcast anything ``likely to incite agitation.''

DOC.HEAD: Tree Dating to Jefferson Coming Down
DOC.TEXT: A tree planted at the University of Virginia the year school founder Thomas Jefferson died has been given a reprieve from becoming a woodpile, but not for long. The majestic but moribund McGuffey ash, planted in 1826, was to have been taken down during the Christmas holiday break but will continue to stand in a garden until late next month. Then its trunk and limbs, weakened by decay and lightning, will be cut up and stacked under a protective cover while a subcommittee of the university's faculty arboretum and landscape committee decides what to do with the wood. J. James Murray Jr., the committee chairman, said he hopes ``at least one piece of ceremonial furniture for the university ... a table, a lectern or a chest'' is made from the tree's remains. The delay occurred because bidding for the job of removing the 164-year-old tree was redone to include preserving the wood for some time, said Jeffrey S. Ertle, the university's assistant vice president for landscape. ``I suspect that while we may use some of it right away, a lot of that wood is going to sit around for a while, so we're going to have to do a good job of preserving it,'' Ertle said. Albemarle Tree Co. won the contract with a bid of $6,480. The tree, which will be replaced with one of its offspring, was named for the Rev. William H. McGuffey, who lived near where the tree was planted but is better known as the developer of the McGuffey Readers once widely used in public schools.

DOC.HEAD: Suspended Miami Policeman Gets Seven Years for Manslaughter
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines urgent series. Leads with 8 grafs to UPDATE with quotes from judge and prosecutor, fix style to today sted Wednesday. Picks up, `At the sentencing....'
DOC.TEXT: A Hispanic police officer convicted of manslaughter in the deaths of two black men was sentenced today to seven years in state prison in a case that triggered three nights of racial violence. William Lozano, 31, who remained stern-faced throughout his daylong sentencing hearing, listened impassively as Dade Circuit Judge Joseph Farina imposed the sentence. ``We all value the sanctity of human life. We all value our police officers and the crucial and difficult role that they play in our community,'' the judge said. ``The incident in this case has been deepl felt by the court and by the jury.'' The defense, which promised an appeal beforehand, used the hearing to outline its objections, including the judge's refusal to exclude a black union official from the jury, his refusal to move the trial from Miami and his rejection of testimony during the sentencing hearing. The judge agreed to let Lozano remain free on $10,000 bond and ordered his attorneys to file an appeal within 30 days. Lozano was fingerprinted in court, standard procedure after sentencing. He and his attorneys refused to comment as they left court moments later. Outside the courtroom, lead prosecutor John Hogan said: ``It was obviously a very difficult decision. I think it's a fair sentence. I think under the circumstances I don't think anyone should complain. It's a substantial prison sentence.'' Lozano fatally shot an unarmed motorcyclist and his passenger died in the resulting crash, deaths that led to three days of rioting in Miami's black neighborhoods a year ago. At the sentencing hearing, a defense lawyer unsuccessfully asked for a new trial with the argument that the officer was prosecuted to prevent racial violence rather than to achieve justice and deserves a new trial. ``We don't have trials in order to satisfy mobs,'' attorney Roy Black said, pointing to the ``ring of steel,'' the armored security teams that surrounded the courthouse just before the verdict Dec. 7. Assistant State Attorney Richard Shiffrin said those arguments had already been rejected at trial and that the extraordinary security was needed to ensure justice, not prevent it. After attorney arguments, Adina Lloyd, mother of slain motorcyclist Clement Lloyd, took the stand to ask for justice for her son. She looked at Lozano and said bitterly, ``If it was my son that did it to him, my son would be behind bars now.'' Representatives of police organizations and Lozano's family argued for leniency. Lozano's mother, Haydee Lozano, said he had a hard childhood but ``has been the one who helped us through the difficult battles.'' Prosecutors maintained that under state guidelines, the suspended officer faced a 12- to 17-year prison term. The defense had argued a different interpretation, of three to seven years. But the judge sided with the prosecution. Dade County's Community Relations Board has stressed to blacks that it was unlikely Lozano would get the maximum sentence because of his background and because he is a first-time offender. ``They have to be a little realistic,'' said crisis coordinator Willie Sims. ``Not even Solomon could decide this one to satisfy everyone,'' said D. Marvin Jones, an associate professor of law at the University of Miami. A light sentence would send the message that ``black life comes at a discount,'' said Jones, who is black. ``The sentencing is very symbolic. This case is a metaphor for racial problems in Miami.'' Lozano shot and killed Lloyd, 23, as he fled from a squad car pursuing him for running a stop sign. Lloyd's passenger, 24-year-old Allan Blanchard, died of injuries suffered when the motorcycle crashed. The Jan. 16, 1989, deaths led to racial unrest here for the fourth time in the 1980s, all linked to the killings of blacks by white officers. In two of those cases, acquittals of the policemen had sparked racial violence, and police braced for renewed rioting as Lozano's trial neared an end last month. But on Dec. 7, a racially mixed jury convicted Lozano, and the black neighborhood of Overtown celebrated in the street where Lloyd and Blanchard died. Police did not anticipate any trouble after Lozano's sentencing nor were any plans made to mobilize the entire force today. ``We're not doing anything differently,'' said police spokesman Angelo Bitsis. ``It's going to be a normal operation.'' Many blacks have called for Colombian-born Lozano to receive the stiffest penalty possible. ``I don't know if he should get life,'' said Clemon Gardner, who lives in the predominantly black Liberty City section, ``but I think he should pay for the crime.'' But there also has been a groundswell of support for Lozano, especially from the Hispanic community and fellow officers, some of whom wore black wristbands in solidarity with the policeman. Carlos Lopez, station manager for Colombian-oriented WOCN-AM, said thousands of letters had been received urging the judge not to send Lozano to prison. The station also collected $40,000 for Lozano's defense, Lopez said.

DOC.HEAD: Hmong Traditions Result in Body Being Exhumed
DOC.TEXT: Religious beliefs among Hmong tribesmen from the mountains of Laos have led to the exhumation of a teacher to lift a curse, by removing from her casket photographs of her Hmong pupils. Buying a beloved picture ``is an honor to a lot of people'' but a ``disgrace and dishonor to the Hmong,'' said Angela Mann, director of the local Headstart program. Many Hmong, refugees from Southeast Asia, have Animist religious beliefs that involve spirits which control good and evil in the world. ``If you are still alive but your picture or hair or some other thing from the body is buried, it causes your spirit to leave your body. You are more likely to get sick,'' said Ying Vang, executive director of the Hmong social agency. The grave of Headstart teacher Charlotte Bell, 61, was opened Tuesday at the urging of several Hmong parents. Bell had been hospitalized in December for pneumonia. She received a get-well card made by a colleague that included photos of her 36 students, more than 20 of them Hmong, Mann said. Bell died after a stroke Jan. 1, and her family tucked the card in her casket before burial. Hmong parents learned the pictures had been buried and demanded them back. Burying the pictures separated the children from their spirits, exposing them to bad luck, illness and early death, they said. ``The parents felt their children were cursed. They would have bad luck for the rest of their lives. I didn't want that on my head,'' Mann said. Sixteen children were kept home by their parents until they were reunited with their spirits, Mann said. The $700 for the exhumation was raised from private sources, Mann said. She said she tracked down Bell's son in Mexico for permission to exhume the body. ``Her son readily agreed. Her sister and brother weren't too happy about it, but they didn't do anything about it,'' Mann said. Two officials from Lao Family Community, a Hmong social agency, were there when the pictures were removed and performed a spirit-calling ceremony to lure the spirits out of the grave along with the photos. The process of calling back the children's spirits requires two more steps, one requiring the photos. But Mann said Headstart can't release the photos without written permission from each parent and the children won't return to school until the ceremonies are complete. A meeting with Lao Family Community will be held to resolve the problem, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Nurse Sentenced to 50 Years to Life
DOC.TEXT: A nurse convicted of killing four patients by injecting them with a paralyzing drug so he could revive them and appear a hero was sentenced Wednesday to 50 years to life in prison. ``You had no right to usurp God's function,'' Judge Alfred Tisch told Richard Angelo in imposing the maximum sentence allowed by state law. Tisch said Angelo, who was emotionless as sentencing was pronounced, had violated ``in the cruelest, most inhumane manner'' the childlike trust a hospital patient places in a nurse. The patients, most of them sick and elderly, ``had a right to enjoy, in their own way, every day that was available to them,'' he said. Angelo, 27, of Lindenhurst, was convicted Dec. 15 of two counts of murder, one of manslaughter and one of criminally negligent homicide in the 1987 deaths at Good Samaritan Hospital. Angelo told authorities he injected the patients with Pavulon, a paralyzing drug, so that when they stopped breathing and he was the first on the scene, he could revive them and be a hero. Prosecutor John Collins said Angelo administered the fatal injections out of inadequacy and because of his deep-rooted contempt for authority. Collins asked the court to treat Angelo with the same compassion that he showed his victims, and urged the maximum sentence. ``These were no folks who took an ill-advised stroll in Central Park after dark,'' he said. ``These were sick, vulnerable people who had entrusted their care to this defendant.'' Angelo's attorney, Eric Naiburg, said he would file a notice of appeal. He said he had expected the maximum sentence. Angelo was handcuffed and led to the county jail, where he has been held since his arrest in November 1987, a month after the killings. He also was convicted of assault in connection with the deaths of four patients and the near-death of another. He was acquitted of assaulting two patients. Collins said authorities suspect Angelo was responsible for the deaths of several other patients, as he also used the drug anectine, whose detection in skin tissue disappears 24 hours after use. Outside the courthouse, family members of some of the victims said they wished that Angelo could have received the death penalty. That was the opinion of Kieran Greene, whose 57-year-old father Anthony died from a Pavulon injection. ``We have to put this behind us and move forward, but we'll never forget,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Health Workers Ignore Guidlines
DOC.TEXT: Health care workers are paying little heed voluntary guidelines for preventing the spread of AIDS and Hepatitis B, a microbiologist told a House panel Thursday. Describing his eyewitness surveys of practices at laboratories and hospitals, Joseph H. Coggin Jr. told a House Education and Labor subcommittee that: _A phlebotomist in the Mobile, Ala., hospital where he works took 10 or 12 blood samples without changing gloves, potentially exposing patients though not herself, then walked out and went down the elevator without removing the gloves. ``You go in a hospital and watch,'' he said. ``How many people wearing gloves are pushing the elevator button or using the phone?'' _A worker in a California laboratory who scooped up spilled blood and broken glass in his bare hand after six test tubes broke. The worker then discovered there was no biohazard disposal bag, so he opened the door with his hand and walked out carrying the blood. None of the 10,000 to 12,000 tubes of blood samples had a top, and a high-powered cooler blew across the tops of the tubes into the faces of workers. One in 30 samples in this laboratory contained the HIV virus, the cause of AIDS. ``This is a typical way that spills are managed in your blood labs across the United States,'' including hospital labs, said Coggin, a department chairman and associate dean at the University of South Alabama College of Medicine in Mobile. ``Just walk in and watch.'' _Out of ignorance and fear, workers are not reporting the many instances in which they are stuck by used needles or nicked by instruments. Many employers are not offering to vaccinate workers against Hepatitis B. The subcommittee on safety and health is reviewing proposed regulations by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration to require basic safety precautions, equipment and training for the nation's estimated 6 million health care workers, as well as Hepatitis B vaccinations for anyone who could be exposed to the virus that causes it. A set of voluntary ``universal precautions'' has been in effect since 1987, but Coggin said those are not being applied. The problem of AIDS exposure was highlighted this week in a Brooklyn, N.Y., courtroom, where Dr. Veronica Prego is suing the Kings County Hospital for $175 million. She says she caught AIDS after jabbing her finger in 1983 with a contaminated needle. Last week, the Centers for Disease Control acknowledged that the number of health care workers infected with the HIV virus on the job is higher than official figures. The CDC has reported 27 such cases worldwide, 19 in the United States. The agency is investigating 34 other cases, said David Bell, chief of AIDS activity in the hospital infections program at the CDC.

DOC.HEAD: Japan Puts Lunar Probe in Orbit, Young Space Program Gets Boost
DOC.TEXT: Japan's first lunar probe was put into orbit around the Earth on Wednesday, ending a 14-year gap between moon missions and giving new prestige to the country's young space program. Space center officials said the Muses-A satellite, as planned, separated from its Nissan-made rocket several minutes after liftoff Wednesday night from an oceanside launch site in southern Japan. Mission chief Hiroki Matsuo said data from tracking stations in California and Australia showed the satellite was orbiting the Earth at a maximum distance of 186,000 miles. The satellite in its highly elliptical orbit is to close within 11,250 miles of the moon by March 18. At that time, shortly before it crosses the moon's path in a so-called ``swing-by,'' it is to release a second, smaller satellite, which will be propelled into lunar orbit about 10,000 miles from the moon. The smaller satellite will send data its mother satellite detailing the lunar region's temperatures and electrical fields. The launch orginally was scheduled Tuesday, but the countdown was stopped with 18 seconds remaining because of an electrical problem in the hydraulic system. Only the United States and the Soviet Union have sent missions to the moon, the most recent being the 1976 landing of an unmanned Soviet vehicle. The mission is a symbolic step forward for Japan's growing space program, which has relied more on diligent engineering than large budgets. ``This time we are going to the moon. But our objective is not the moon itself,'' Matsuo said. ``Our institute is getting into interplanetary missions in the 1990s, and for that we need to refine our technology.'' As technicians prepared the M3S-2 rocket on the space center's only launch pad, officials shivered in buildings around the center where heaters were turned off to conserve electricity for the launch equipment. Around the site, volunteers from neighboring villages stood watch in the firefighters' traditional red-and-black uniforms. Both the Institute of Space and Astronautical Science (ISAS), which is conducting the moon mission, and Japan's other space agency, the National Space Development Agency, have plans for future manned space flights and interplanetary travel. NASDA, which focuses on applied uses of space, also is developing a small space shuttle and a new all-Japanese rocket, the H-2, that will handle a payload comparable to those carried by U.S., Soviet and European rockets. ISAS focuses on scientific research in space. The mission was sponsored by the government-funded Institute of Space and Astronautical Science, will give Japan valuable experience in targeting orbits and in the use of ``swing-bys'' to guide future spacecraft traveling to distant planets. The Nissan rocket used in the launch carried a payload of only 400 pounds. The H-1 rocket is expected to handle two tons. Japan's first satellite was launched in 1970. Muses-A is the 13th Japanese satellite in operation. In recent years, Japan has achieved a respected aerospace launch record, despite its late entry into the field, low budgets _ $1.06 billion last year _ and a shortage of good launch sites. Japan's two main launch areas _ in Uchinoura and in nearby Tanagashima _ are only a tiny fraction of the size of space centers in other nations.

DOC.HEAD: Biden Says War on Drugs Should Focus on Hard-Core Addicts
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Judiciary Committee chairman on Wednesday accused the Bush administration of waging its drug war on the wrong front, focusing on the shrinking number of casual users instead of hard-core addicts. Sen. Joseph R. Biden Jr., D-Del., told a news briefing that placing emphasis on casual uses represented ``a misapplication of those resources and those dollars.'' Biden unveiled a rival strategy for fighting the war on drugs. ``As for the casual user, we probably three years ago reached the apex'' in terms of numbers, Biden said in making public a strategy that would cost an estimated $14.6 billion in the fiscal year that starts Oct. 1, well above the Bush administration's expected recommendation. The plan also envisions providing drug treatment for all pregnant addicts within one year and ``full treatment on demand'' within four years. Biden, tapped to provide the Democratic response when President Bush addressed the nation on drugs last fall, said this report did not represent the views of either the Judiciary Committee or any Democratic Party group. He released his blueprint as the national drug policy director, William Bennett, prepared to present the second installment of the administration's plan for contending with the drug scourge. Biden acknowledged that the administration already is doing many of the things recommended in his rival strategy but said its emphasis has been different and the focus has been too much on casual drug abusers. ``That's allowing them to do nothing about the hard-core user,'' he said. ``The moral approbation of mainstream America has more impact on the casual user than anything we do,'' he said. He said the chief focus should be hard-core addicts because they have caused the ``increase in crime, drug-related medical emergencies, crack babies and drug-related child abuse.'' ``Under our plan, the hard core user must either go into treatment or go to jail and when they go to jail go into treatment in jail,'' Biden said. Biden also said the administration's so-called Andean plan focuses primarily on military aid while his approach envisions offering producer nations in South America relief of their international debt in return for planting substitute crops in place of coca. Biden's outline calls for doubling to 1,000 the number of FBI agents investigating drug rings as well as increasing the number of drug enforcement agents and prosecutors working on narcotics cases. It estimates expenditures on its expanded treatment provisions at more than $3.8 billion in the next fiscal year. Under Biden's plan, the government also would build 10 regional prisons and 12 boot camps on closed military bases to incarcerate federal, state and local offenders at a price tag of $850 million. A number of assault-style semiautomatic weapons would be banned under the measure but most would remain legal. And the plan would make $300 million available for ``drug emergency areas'' in contrast to the administration plan which calls for $40 million. ``In all honesty, $300 million is not going to make a fundamental change,'' Biden acknowledged.

DOC.HEAD: Police Officers Strike, Governor Urges Militants to Lay Down Arms
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of Kashmir policemen went on strike for five hours Wednesday to support Moslem separatists's demands that army troops called in to quell violence leave Jammu-Kashmir state. Gov. Jagmohan, who uses only one name, appealed to the separatists to lay down their arms on the fourth day of a crackdown on the violent pro-Pakistani secessionist movement in Kashmir. At least 57 people, most of them protesters, have been killed since an around-the-clock curfew was imposed Saturday on Srinagar and surrounding towns. One Moslem militant was killed Wednesday when paramilitary forces, fearing an attack, fired on a mob, a senior police official said on condition of anonymity. Jagmohan, who has a reputation as a tough administrator, was appointed governor of Jammu-Kashmir state by Prime Minister V.P. Singh two weeks ago in an effort to curb the rebellion, the most serious crisis Singh has faced since he took office Dec. 2. The Islamic militants, led by the Jammu Kashmir Liberation Front, demand either independence for the state or union with neighboring Islamic Pakistan. About 64 percent of Jammu-Kashmir's 5 million people are Moslems. Nationwide, Moslems account for 12 percent of India's 880 million people and Hindus make up 82 percent. Singh, a Hindu like Jagmohan, has sent hundreds of troops from the nation's predominantly Hindu army and paramilitary forces to Kashmir. Ethnic tensions flared Sunday when a Moslem policeman was shot to death by soldiers enforcing the curfew. Government officials said the killing was an accident. On Wednesday morning, hundreds of state policemen refused to work. About 300 striking officers gathered on a downtown street, waving rifles and shouting, ``Death to the Indian army!'' and ``Indians go back!'' The strike was called off in the afternoon after Jitendra Narain Saxena, the state's top police officer, and Mohammad A. Nomani, Srinagar's police inspector general, spoke to the protesting policemen. Saxena later said: ``It appears that over the years, some terrorist elements have infiltrated the state police force.'' There are 40,000 men in the police force. Moslem residents of Srinager were jubilant over the strike and many embraced officers when the curfew was lifted for an hour in the morning. ``Policemen were resentful of certain things. The incident took place due to lack of leadership and mismanagement,'' Jagmohan said without elaborating. ``The issue has been sorted out. I do not think there is any serious problem,'' he said. But one of the strike leaders, constable Mohammad Afzal, said another walkout was planned for Saturday unless the soldiers leave Kashmir and the government reinstates a police union banned in 1979. During the news conference, Jagmohan rejected suggestions by some reporters that most Kashmiris wanted to secede and join Pakistan. ``I have come here to help, to sort out the problems. Give me some time. There is no magic in human affairs,'' he said. India has often accused Pakistan of aiding separatists. Pakistan denies the charge. Claimed by both India and Pakistan, Kashmir was divided into Indian and Pakistani sectors by a cease-fire line that is monitored by United Nations military observers. The dispute over the territory, which has led to two wars, began after India and Pakistan were partitioned upon gaining independence from Britain in 1947.

DOC.HEAD: Congressmen Say USDA Lied in 1986 Report on WIC Program
DOC.TEXT: The Agriculture Department, under President Reagan, lied about the benefits of a popular nutrition program for poor pregnant women and children, several members of Congress said Wednesday. ``This report makes it plain that the Reagan administration sought to hide the facts'' in an earlier Agriculture Department study of the program, said Sen. Tom Harkin, D-Iowa. But an official of the General Accounting Office, a congressional investigative agency, said it was not clear that the Agriculture Department had intended to be deceptive in the report on the Women, Infants and Children food program. Keith Fultz of the GAO said investigators could not pin down the intent behind the changes made in a report on the benefits of the program that started in 1972, but said the effect was to mislead readers. He said the summary written by the original researchers was deleted by Agriculture Department officials and replaced by a compendium that ``did not fairly represent what the study team found.'' That, said Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., amounts to lying. ``GAO said that the results written by USDA to replace the research team's summary would `understate the effects of the WIC program and mislead the readers...,`'' said Leahy. ``In Vermont, we call that lying, plain and simple.'' The Agriculture Department study began in 1979 but was not released until 1986, a length of time that angered Congress. ``The project was to take 2{ years and cost $3.9 million,'' said Harkin. ``Instead it was a 6-year program costing close to $6 million.'' The comments about the study came at a joint hearing of the House Select Hunger Committee and the Senate Agriculture Committee, which had requested the GAO investigation. Budget figures for the last 10 years show that Congress appropriated $725 million for WIC in 1980 and increased the amount by at least $100 million each year. That was not always enough to keep up with inflation and has never been enough to reach all the eligible women and children, said a member of the Senate Agriculture Committee staff, but was consistently higher than the Reagan administration had requested. In 1982, Reagan proposed cutting the program from the $869 million of the previous year to $637 million. Congress appropriated $948 million. Reagan tried in 1983 to cut the program to about $637 million. That time Congress appropriated $1.1 billion. The 1990 appropriation is $2.13 billion, serving about 4.6 million women and children, said Birge Watkins, deputy assistant agriculture secretary for food and consumer services. He said that about two-thirds of the eligible recipients are getting help through the program. Watkins said the Bush administration supports WIC, believes the previous administration was wrong to change the report and would never let such a thing happen again. ``It's simply no way to do business,'' he said. ``We regret this whole incident happened.'' He said that if the administration had differences with the findings of the independent researchers they should have been expressed in a cover letter, leaving the original summary intact. The revisions were written by Thomas Sullivan, a special assistant to John Bode, who was assistant secretary for food and consumer services for the last four years of the Reagan administration. Bode, now an attorney in a Washington law firm, said that he now believes the compendium was wrong, but at the time thought Sullivan and others at the department who reviewed the study knew what they were doing. But ``to assert there was willful misrepresentation to Congress is wrong,'' he said in a telephone interview.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Secretary Defends Guided-Missile Destroyer
DOC.TEXT: Navy Secretary H. Lawrence Garrett III on Wednesday defended a new $1.2 billion guided-missile destroyer against charges of cost overruns, schedule delays and mischarges by the contractor. ``The DDG-51 program is on track to provide our fleet the most capable destroyer ever built,'' Garrett told a House Armed Services subcommittee on seapower and strategic ans critical materials. The subcommittee largely agreed with Garrett's assessment, but criticized the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, and questioned the propriety of another House panel, the Energy and Commerce subcommittee on oversight and investigations, getting involved in an area normally the Armed Services domain. It was the chairman of the Energy and Commerce subcommittee, Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., who wrote the Navy in September and complained publicly that the destroyer program is 17 months behind schedule and design costs have more than doubled, from $111 million to $247 million. Rep. Norman Sisisky, D-Va., questioned the source of reports that the Navy and the GAO had received fraud-hotline allegations of mischarging by the destroyer's manufacturer, Bath Iron Works of Maine. ``We do not publicly announce we have allegations,'' said Martin M. Ferber, director of the GAO's National Security and International Affairs Division. ``Congressman Dingell went public with the allegations.'' Dingell had been asked to testify before the Armed Services panel, but said he was unable to do so because of a scheduling conflict. In a four-page letter to committee Chairman Charles E. Bennett, D-Fla., Dingell reiterated his concerns about the program. ``The interim findings of the (Pentagon's) Defense Contract Audit Agency and the Navy indicate that mischarging did, in fact, occur,'' Dingell wrote. Ferber said the GAO and Navy are investigating those charges, but that he had no information to substantiate allegations of intentional mischarge. In April 1985, the Navy awarded Bath Iron Works a fixed-price contract for the destroyer, hailed as the world's most advanced surface combat ship. The DDG-51 destroyer is designed with a more expensive all-steel superstructure instead of one that was part aluminum and more prone to splintering and fire damage. The ship also is equipped with sophisticated Aegis computers and Tomahawk cruise missiles. The Navy plans to acquire at least 33 of the Arleigh Burke-class destroyer at a cost of $27 billion. Ferber said the total target cost for design and construction of the lead ship was about $500 million in May 1984 dollars.
