The Pentagon estimates that the total cost after integrating all the systems, including the Aegis computers, will be under $1.2 billion. Ferber testified that the GAO investigation found that design problems contributed to two revision's in the ship's scheduled delivery date of September 1989. Bath Iron Works has accelerated construction to meet the new date of February 1991. William E. Haggett, chairman and chief executive officer of Bath Iron Works, said his company did not expect ``any significant surprises completing DDG-51.''

DOC.HEAD: Revival of `Annie' Scrapped
DOC.TEXT: The sun won't come out tomorrow for ``Annie.'' On Saturday, the new $7 million musical ``Annie 2'' closed in Washington, its producers deciding not to open it on Broadway on March 1 as planned. But, the announcement continued in an upbeat vein, a revival of ``Annie,'' the 1977 musical hit, would open on Broadway instead. And the sequel, ``Annie 2,'' would go to the Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam, Conn., during the summer for performances and revisions. On Wednesday, David Powers, spokesman for ``Annie 2,'' said that the proposed revival of ``Annie'' has been scrapped. Danielle Findley, 11, who had the title role in ``Annie 2,'' was to have starred in the revival of ``Annie'' and Harve Presnell was to have shifted his Daddy Warbucks portrayal from ``Annie 2'' to ``Annie.'' Dorothy Loudon, who snarled her comic way to a Tony Award as Miss Hannigan in ``Annie,'' and who portrayed Miss Hannigan again in ``Annie 2,'' said that she was not interested in playing in the revival. Martin Charnin and Charles Strouse wrote the score for both shows and Thomas Meehan wrote both books. Powers said that ``Annie 2'' will still go to the Goodspeed Opera House during the summer.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: After a doctor said her cornea transplant appeared successful, Tatina roared her approval. Or was it maybe disapproval? ``I think she can see me just fine and she's not real happy to see me,'' Dr. Dan Skorich joked at a news conference Tuesday near the Siberian tiger's cage at the Lake Superior Zoo. Skorich and Drs. Susan and Jeffrey Abelt of Cloquet Animal Hospital last month transplanted a cornea from Tatina's mother after she died into the 10-year-old tigress' left eye to replace a cornea clouded by a cataract. Skorich removed the stitches from Tatina's eye Friday and he said the surgery appears successful. ``I'm happy about the fact that the cornea is healed,'' he said. The clear cornea should make Tatina more comfortable and improve her vision. But Skorich said it's impossible to test the tigress' vision. ``I guess we could hold up little mice and see how many she can count,'' he said.

Some legislators are up in arms and talking revolution because an $11.5 million Capitol renovation project has forced them out of their regular offices and into temporary cramped, cold quarters. ``My new office is about 40 degrees,'' complained state Rep. Joseph Wineke, one of 26 Assembly members who now have temporary offices at a building across the street from the Capitol. ``I feel like I'm in Alcatraz. I'm out of the (Capitol) building, I don't know where to hang my coat _ it's like being a person without a country. When you're out of the building, you're out of the network,'' Wineke said. When the Legislature convened its nine-week session Tuesday, a group of displaced lawmakers drafted a list of demands and huddled around Assembly Speaker Thomas Loftus, chanting ``Revolution'' and ``Storm the Bastille.'' ``I'll look into this,'' Loftus promised. The move was necessary because of a renovation of the Capitol's north wing, which will be remodeled and air conditioned. The project is expected to take about two years. Fifteen lawmakers were relocated to temporary offices in other parts of the Capitol while the 26 others and several state officials were moved across the street into leased office space. The lawmakers complain some of their new offices are noisy, poorly heated, small and unusually shaped, and lack security, janitorial services, parking and access for the handicapped. ``It's very bad, very cramped'' said state Rep. Spencer Black. Black moved into his new office Friday. Several staff members already were there, looking out the window at construction in progress on a building next door. ``They were agape,'' Black said. ``I looked out and saw why. There was this huge wrecking crane swinging back and forth, and it looked like it was coming right through the window.''

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Editors:
DOC.TEXT: The House has begun to vote on the override of President Bush's China student veto. It will take at least 15 minutes before we can lede a0620.
DOC.HEAD: The AP
Cancer Claims Life of Man Dubbed `Baby Bandit'
DOC.TEXT: Grady Lee Huffman, the bad-luck ``Baby Bandit'' of the 1930s who was shot 17 times in three decades of crime, died of cancer. He was 72. Huffman, who died at home Tuesday in this town about 40 miles southwest of Fort Worth, claimed he once met the legendary Bonnie Parker and Clyde Barrow while hitchhiking, said his son, Grady Lee Huffman Jr. ``He told them he wanted to join them, but Bonnie called him a snotty-nosed punk kid,'' said the younger Huffman. ``He said, `Well, I'll go make a name on my own.' ``He was born with a harelip,'' his son said. ``He was a freak and kids teased him. So he told them, `I'm going to rob all your mommies and daddies, just like Jesse James.''' Huffman was paroled in 1967 and had led a quiet life since then, said the younger Huffman, who didn't meet his father until 1968. When he was 16 years old, the elder Huffman stole a car in Waco, but collided with a car driven by the sheriff. Huffman picked up the ``Baby Bandit'' nickname at age 18 in 1934 after leading Fort Worth police on a wild, bullet-punctuated chase. He was captured after being shot in the face, and was sentenced to 25 years in prison. Huffman began his next career: escape. He tried to break out of prison in 1935, escaped for four days in 1942, broke out the next year and spent four months on the lam, and tried to escape again the same year. In 1944, he busted out and stayed free for 20 months. Huffman married Judy, the first of his two wives, during that last escape, his son said. ``That was when I was born,'' he said. ``In Dublin on Oct. 16, 1944. The night I was born, you'll find there was a jewelry store robbed there.'' In spite of his record, Huffman was one of 10 convicts pardoned in 1947 by outgoing Gov. Coke R. Stevenson. Two years later, Huffman was in trouble again. ``Of all times he picked to rob a Coca-Cola plant, he picked the night they were having a policeman's convention in Vernon,'' the son said. ``They all came shooting at him, but they were so drunk they didn't kill him.'' Huffman drew 399 years in prison. The younger Huffman said he once told his father of his plans to follow in his footsteps, and got some fatherly advice: ``Son, if I couldn't beat them before they had radios and computers, you don't stand a chance.'' ``He was a fascinating old man,'' said his son. ``A hellacious old man.'' Huffman's widow, Irene, said her husband became a Christian in his final months. ``I was just an Arkansas hillbilly when I met him,'' she said. ``I thought I saw a man who wanted to go straight, and he told me what he'd done. ``But I never in my wildest dreams _ well, I thought things like that happened only in the movies. I thought it was just a tall Texas tale.'' In addition to his widow and son, Huffman is survived by another son and a sister. Funeral services were scheduled Friday in Cleburne.

DOC.HEAD: Tehran Students Mourn Moslems Killed in Azerbaijan
With AM-Soviet-Unrest, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Tehran University students held a memorial service in the campus mosque Wednesday for Moslems killed by Soviet soldiers in Azerbaijan, the official Islamic Republic News Agency reported. It said the mourners read a statement that criticized Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet president, for ordering the army into Baku on Saturday. Ali Akbar Mohtashemi, the radical former interior minister, told the mourners Gorbachev's actions were a trap set by the United States and the Soviet leadership should ``rid itself of American traps,'' the agency said. Similar ceremonies were held in Tabriz, Ardebil, Astara and other provincial cities, IRNA reported. Nasser Hayrani Nowbari, the Iranian ambassador to Moscow, delivered a letter Wednesday to the Soviet Foreign Ministry from Iran's foreign minister, Ali Akbar Velayati. Velayati said Iran was concerned about the well-being of Moslems throughout the world, but committed to the principle of non-interference in the affairs of other states. Earlier Wednesday, IRNA said hundreds of Soviet Azerbaijanis gathered along the Iranian frontier and some started building a new border bridge across the Araks River, but Soviet troops stopped them. After ``a gathering by the people and their ultimatum to the Soviet forces,'' the work resumed, the agency reported. It said female television announcers in Iran's Azerbaijani enclave of Nakhichevan wore black head scarves in mourning for ``victims of the Baku carnage.'' Red Army troops moved into Caspian Sea port of Baku over the weekend to crush a nationalist uprising and end ethnic clashes between Azerbaijanis and ethnic Armenians, most of whom are Christians. Most Azerbaijanis, whose historic homeland extends into Iran, are Shiite Moslems, the predominant religion in Iran. Thousands ofSoviet Azerbaijanis, bound by language, culture and religion to their Iranian kin, have crossed the border since the violence began. The Iranian news agency said about 300 people gathered Tuesday on the Soviet side of the border about 12 miles west of the frontier town of Poldasht. Twenty-eight Soviet armored personnel carriers patrolled a military road that runs along the border, it said. Moscow Radio, clearly telling the Iranians not to interfere, declared on Tuesday: ``Any unconsidered nationalistic or religious appeals would be dangerous. ... Brutal and illusory nationalistic flights of fancy have dragged the people to the brink of the precipice.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Wants Democrats, GOP to Back Nicaraguan Candidate
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Wednesday called upon the Democratic and Republican parties to give money to the campaign of Violeta Chamorro, the candidate challenging President Daniel Ortega in Nicaragua's Feb. 25 elections. Bush's letter of request, released at the White House, caught both the Republican National Committee and the Democratic National Committee by surprise. The Democrats will not likely accommodate the president, said DNC spokesman Mike McCurry. ``I don't know why the president seems to think we're awash in money here,'' said McCurry. ``We don't have as much money as the Republicans and the money we do have we want to apply to electing Democrats here in the United States.'' The RNC ``has been extremely supportive of Mrs. Chamorro,'' and helped sponsor a fund-raising event for her recently in Washington, said RNC spokeswoman Leslie Goodman. But she could not immediately say how the GOP would respond to the president's appeal. ``We have been supportive in the past. We'll be supportive in the future,'' she added. The Bush administration has consistently criticized Nicaragua's election process, claiming the deck is stacked in favor of Ortega and the ruling Sandinistas, who control the media and have other advantages. Bush said in his letter that that Mrs. Chamorro and her party, the National Opposition Union, or UNO, are ``desperately short of funds needed for campaign rallies, distributing campaign literature and media time'' as the Feb. 25 election nears. Congress already has approved Bush's request for $9 million to help the electoral process in Nicaragua. That money, being channelled through the government-supported National Endowment for Democracy, cannot under NED's charter be spent directly on the campaign of a candidate. Rather it is to go to generic political activity, such as voter registration, and building of democratic institutions. ``The Sandinistas,'' Bush wrote, ``have imposed serious obstacles to delivery of the NED funds, and, to date UNO has been permitted to make use of only a tiny fraction of them. For these reasons, Mrs. Chamorro's campaign runs the real risk of being crippled for lack of money.'' Bush asked the two parties to make a joint contribution, amount unspecified, and to tap their individual donors for money as well. ``A joint contribution by both parties to the UNO campaign would make an immediate difference at this critical moment, as would individual contributions by your party's members,'' he wrote. But McCurry said ``It seems fairly curious that the president of the United States thinks that U.S. political parties should go donating to political candidates abroad.'' DNC Chairman Ron Brown was traveling in Egypt and did not know of the request, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Informed of Harpoon Sale to Egypt
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration has told Congress that it intends to sell Egypt 29 Harpoon missiles, support equipment and logistic assistance at a cost of $69 million, the Pentagon said Wednesday. The government of Egypt intends to equip four Chinese-built Romeo-class submarines with the medium-range, anti-ship cruise missiles. The prime contractor will be the McDonnell Douglas Missile Systems Co., of St. Charles, Mo., the Pentagon said in a statement. ``This sale will contribute to the foreign policy and national security of the United States by helping to improve the security of a friendly country which has been and continues to be an important force for political stability and economic progress in the Middle East,'' the statement said.

DOC.HEAD: Secord Gets Two Years Probation in Iran-Contra Affair
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New throughout with Secord criticism of Reagan, Meese, other details; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Iran-Contra arms middleman Richard Secord was placed on probation for two years Wednesday for falsely telling congressional investigators he was unaware any money in the affair had benefited Oliver L. North. After his sentencing, the retired Air Force major general accused former President Reagan of failing to support loyal subordinates and operatives in the worst foreign policy debacle of the Reagan administration. ``I think former President Reagan has been hiding out; I think it's cowardly,'' Secord said when asked about Reagan's role in the affair. In 1986, when the Iran-Contra operation erupted, ``I think that he should have stood up and taken the heat ... just as previous presidents have done (in failed covert operations),'' Secord told a news conference. ``But instead of that they built a wall around ... him.'' Secord said then-Attorney General Edwin Meese acted ``in panic and out of ignorance'' on Nov. 25, 1986, when he announced that the Justice Department would examine possible violations of criminal law in the affair. That was the day Meese disclosed that some funds from the secret Iran arms sales had been diverted to the Contras. Reagan maintains he didn't know about the diversion, and Secord said it would be ``speculative'' on his part to suggest otherwise. But ``the president did not stand up and say this (the Contra resupply operation and Iran arms sales) was ```done on my authority,''' said Secord. Secord said he didn't think there was ``anything illegal ... I thought at the time we were doing the president's bidding.'' The president told the Tower Commission on Jan. 26, 1987, that he did not know the National Security Council staff was engaged in helping the Contras. ``The Board is aware of no evidence to suggest that the president was aware of Lt. Col. North's activities,'' said the Tower Board's final report. Secord was enlisted by then-White House aide North to airlift weapons and other supplies to the Nicaraguan rebels and assist the Reagan administration's secret arms shipments to Iran. Secord, who paid for North's $13,800 home security system from proceeds of the Iran-Contra operation, told congressional investigators in 1987 he was unaware of any money going to North from the scandal. ``I deeply regret not being more candid,'' Secord told U.S. District Court Judge Aubrey Robinson. ``If I could correct this I certainly would. I will regret it for the rest of my life.'' Secord could have faced up to five years in prison and a $250,000 fine for the false statement, but Robinson said it was his judgment that there has already ``been punishment in this case.'' Secord is the fifth person to be sentenced in the Iran-Contra affair. The others were North, former National Security Adviser Robert McFarlane, Carl Channell and Richard Miller. North was convicted of three crimes, including aiding and abetting an obstruction of Congress, altering and destroying National Security Council documents and accepting an illegal gratuity from Secord, the security system. He is appealing. McFarlane pleaded guilty to four counts of withholding information from Congress in connection with inquiries about whether secret assistance was going to the Contras. Channell and Miller were both sentenced to two years probation. Each pleaded guilty to conspiracy to defraud the government of taxes due on contributions used to supply military aid to the Contras. Secord said his life since the Iran-Contra affair began has been ``pure hell.'' He said that he was paid about $240,000 in the Iran and Contra operations and that $700,000 to $800,000 has been raised for his defense since 1987, an amount he said doesn't cover all his legal expenses. He said he has his military retirement pay, but no job and that he had to sell his home and buy a smaller one. Secord said he hopes to start a television talk show which would deal with current events. One of his topics, he said, is the theory that Soviet intelligence actually exposed the administration's Iran initiative by planting the November 1986 story in a Lebanese magazine that the United States had sold arms to Iran. The government had alleged that ``the enterprise,'' the maze of offshore companies and secret bank accounts used in the Iran-Contra affair, managed over $1 million in profits that had been allocated to Secord. Some $8 million in ``enterprise'' funds is still frozen in Swiss bank accounts at the request of the U.S. government. Secord told reporters he might be entitled to some legal fees from the frozen accounts, but ``I make no personal claim on that money. ... I don't intend ... to put any of that money in my pocket.'' In approving a plea agreement between Secord and the government, Robinson dismissed 11 other criminal charges. They include allegations that Secord lied to Congress by saying that the only money he made in the affair was his $6,000-a-month salary. In court papers filed this week, prosecutors said Secord now is refusing to recant the earlier testimony about his finances. Iran-Contra prosecutor Reid Weingarten told Judge Robinson that Secord should be dealt with more sternly than North and McFarlane. Weingarten said North and McFarlane felt they were committing their crimes in the context of having ``had a higher duty.'' North and McFarlane were cases of ``misguided patriotism,'' said Weingarten, while ``we think General Secord has no such defense.'' ``The best that can be said'' of Secord's false statement is that he was motivated by the ``embarrassment'' of having paid for North's home security system, said the prosecutor. The worst that can be said is that he was trying to avoid ``the consequences of providing benefits to Colonel North,'' added Weingarten. ``This is the stuff of routine felonies.''

DOC.HEAD: Consumer Panel `Back in Business'
DOC.TEXT: The Consumer Product Safety Commission is ready to begin finalizing decisions that have been stymied since last year because the panel did not have a voting quorum, the head of the agency said Wednesday. ``Now that we do have a quorum, we are back in business and we're active,'' said Chairwoman Jacqueline Jones-Smith, acknowledging that much business had reached a bottleneck before she was appointed in November. The CPSC, mandated in 1973 as a five-member panel, must have at least three members before it can take official actions requiring a commission vote. Consumer groups criticized President Bush for allowing the agency to languish most of last year with just two commissioners. However, consumer advocates criticized the Jones-Smith appointment, saying she lacked experience on product safety issues and consumer affairs. Critics also called the appointment political patronage because her husband, Republican businessman Joshua Smith, helped raise more than $600,000 for the Bush presidential campaign. ``I think I have almost the perfect qualities that are necessary for this kind of job,'' Jones-Smith said. She was a staff attorney for the Federal Election Commission for three years before going to the CPSC. She also was an assistant attorney for Montgomery County, Md., for two years and for six years held various management positions in the Maryland-based Maxima Corp., an integrated information systems company owned by her husband. Among the items on the commission calendar are: _Recommendations for a new test cylinder to determine the smallest allowable size for toys and their parts. Currently, if a toy fits into a cylinder with a 1\-inch diameter and a depth ranging from 1 inch to 2\ inches, it is too small and considered a potential choking hazard to small children. _Whether mandatory labels are needed for balloons, marbles and small balls that are exempt from the small parts standards because they are marketed for children older than 3. _A vote on mandatory labeling for adult sleepwear. The commission Monday postponed a vote on staff recommendations to classify the garments by degree of flammability. _Performance standards for child-resistant cigarette lighters, pool barriers and immersion protection in hair dryers.

DOC.HEAD: Governor Rejects Clemency for Tyler In Racial Shooting
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Buddy Roemer on Wednesday rejected a recommendation of clemency for Gary Tyler, a black activist who claims he was framed for the murder of a white student during desegregation violence in 1974. Tyler's long fight for freedom has been supported by Amnesty International and other groups. Tyler, 31, is serving a life sentence with no possibility of parole. On Dec. 14, the Pardon Board voted 3-2 to reduce his sentence to 60 years, making him eligible for parole in five years. ``I do not concur with the recommendation of the pardon board, and I deny clemency and a reduction of sentence,'' Roemer said in a brief statement Wednesday. Roemer refused to talk to reporters about his decision, which was read by his attorney, Tom Casey. ``Gary Tyler was found guilty after a full jury trial,'' said Casey. ``His conviction has been reviewed extensively by the courts over the past 15 years. Those reviewing courts have found Gary Tyler's trial to be fundamentally fair by all legal standards. ``Also, I believe his efforts toward rehabilitation have not been sufficient.'' Tyler's case has been supported by marches and rallies. Petitions bearing 12,000 signatures were presented to the pardon board. The British reggae band UB40 recorded a song about Tyler, and he was described by the Soviet Communist Party newspaper Pravda in 1978 as a political prisoner. Tyler was a 15-year-old activist for school desegregation in 1974 when whites and blacks clashed at a high school in Destrehan, a small town on the Mississippi River 25 miles north of New Orleans. Whites surrounded buses carrying black students, shouting and hurling bottles, cans and rocks. A shot was fired from one of the buses. Timothy Weber, 13, standing with his mother across the schoolyard, fell dead. Witnesses said the pistol was held by a gloved hand. Tyler was the only one on the bus wearing gloves, said police. Those who believe Tyler was framed say that a student who testified against him was known as a liar and that police planted a pistol found in the stuffing of the torn seat where Tyler had sat. The pistol later disappeared and defense attorneys claimed the laboratory people who tested for fingerprints were incompetent. An all-white jury sentenced Tyler to die in the electric chair, but his sentence was automatically reduced to life when the Supreme Court struck down Louisiana's old death penalty law in 1976.

DOC.HEAD: Book Bags Bagged at Georgia High School
DOC.TEXT: A high school has banned students from using book bags in an effort to prevent drugs from being brought to school. Baldwin High School Principal Mike Stanton announced the ban last week after Sheriff Bill Massee told faculty members that many schools with drug problems have banned book bags. The ban took effect Monday. ``The parents have not been informed at any point that we have a drug and alcohol problem in the school,'' Elois Finney, a parent of a Baldwin High student, told the school board Tuesday. She said parents should have been consulted. ``If we have a problem of that magnitude the schools should come up with a program to solve it.'' The school of 1,400 students serves the county of 35,000 people. Milledgeville has about 12,000 people. Stanton said the school does not have a serious drug problem, ``but it's all relative. Even if there's only one student involved in drugs here, that's one too many.'' Stanton said the sheriff was invited to speak after teachers expressed concern about increasing drug use among students. The principal said the students are now getting to class quicker, partly because they must go to their lockers to get their books, giving them less time to congregate in the halls. Teacher Todd Shiver said students had become too dependent on their bags, using them not only for books but gym clothes and junk food. He said some book bags were so large and full students had to drag them down the halls. Some students complained about the difficulties of carrying their books without a bag; others said banning bags will have little effect on the drug problem. ``I've seen students with drugs in their socks,'' said Sharilyn Richardson, 15. ``If they want to get drugs in here, they'll find a way to do it,'' said James Jackson, 16.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Army Never Said Stuff in Noriega's Home Was Tamales
With AM-Noriega-Substance
DOC.TEXT: Yes, we know our tamales, members of the U.S. military said Tuesday, and the powdery substance found in Manuel Antonio Noriega's home was definitely not tamales. But it wasn't cocaine either. U.S. Army officers had first said that nearly 50 kilograms, or 110 pounds, of cocaine had been found in Noriega's home the day after the Dec. 20 invasion, bolstering U.S. charges of drug trafficking against the Panamanian strongman. But published reports this week said the Army acknowledged later that the substance found in the house was tamales, not cocaine. Southern Command spokesmen reacted angrily Tuesday, saying the Army never claimed it had found tamales. Many of the U.S. servicemen here hail from the Southwest and should be able to recognize a tamale when they see one. Tamales _ cornmeal and meat, either pork, beef or chicken _ come in many different forms. They vary from the thick, cornhusk-wrapped tamale of northern Mexico and southwestern United States to a rectangular tamale wrapped in a banana leaf popular along the Mexican Gulf coast, Central America and Panama. The Panamanian variety is most popular around Christmas and is made with cornmeal and chicken meat in the capital and with pork in the provinces. ``We said that our soldiers found some white powder wrapped in banana leaves in a refrigerator,'' said Capt. Art Haubold of the Southern Command's public affairs office. ``The substance was taken to a lab and it was determined after that is was not cocaine. ``The best they could determine was that it was some bonding substance used in voodoo rituals. That's the way it was described to us by Army experts. At first, it could have been mistaken by a layman as cocaine.'' Army officials also said Tuesday they never indicated any direct connection existed between the former dictator and drugs found by soldiers as they searched Noriega's homes and hundreds of other houses and offices in Panama. ``It was not our job to determine that,'' Haubold said. According to the Army, 415 kilograms of cocaine, 100 grams of crack cocaine, 10 kilograms of marijuana and 25.5 kilograms of heroin were found and confiscated by the U.S. Army from Dec. 20 through Jan. 9 in search operations throughout Panama. The total included small amounts found on suspects picked up for questioning and in private homes. A kilogram equals 2.2 pounds and a gram 0.035 ounces. A total of 283 kilograms of cocaine were found in the offices of the National Investigation Office, but a source said it could not be determined whether it had been previously confiscated by the law enforcement agency.

DOC.HEAD: Sailor Eulogized Amidst Family Allegations of Navy Coverup
DOC.TEXT: A sailor accused of murdering two shipmates at a top-secret nuclear submarine base and then killing himself was given a full military funeral Wednesday. Relatives said they suspect a Navy coverup. Three uniformed sailors removed a U.S. flag from Shyam David Drizpaul's casket and presented it to his mother at a service at a funeral home. After the ceremony, the sailor's mother, Seelochna Drizpaul, wept over the casket, crying: ``Oh God, this is not real. This is not real. You are not dead my son.'' The Navy has reported Drizpaul, 23, a fire control technician 3rd class aboard the USS Michigan, a top-secret Trident nuclear submarine in Bangor, Wash., shot and killed two shipmates and a pawn shop clerk in nearby Bremerton, Wash., before apparently killing himself last week in a motel room. But relatives claim Drizpaul, a native of Guyana, was an intelligent, responsible person who did not fit the description of a killer. The family was orginally told they would have to make arrangements to claim the body and that Drizpaul would not be given a military funeral, said an uncle, Yoganand Kumar. But calls to U.S. Rep. Les Aspin and Sen. Herbert Kohl, both D-Wis., helped persuade the Navy to provide the honor guard, Kumar said. ``They find the man dead and they say they're not responsible for him. We weren't satisfied,'' he said. Kumar said before the funeral that the family doubts the Navy's explanation and is upset because details about the deaths have not been released. ``Nothing makes sense. There are a lot of questions that haven't been answered,'' he said ``What's going on? What are they trying to cover up? We're not saying he didn't do it. We're saying, `Tell us what happened.''' Petty Officer Paul Gamache of Osseo, Wis., who escorted Drizpaul's body from Washington to Milwaukee, told mourners Drizpaul's co-workers aboard the submarine were surprised by the allegations. Gamache, who knew Drizpaul for 18 months, said the Navy's allegations about Drizpaul did not ``really seem like the guy we knew.'' ``He always performed every job ever asked of him in a very professional manner. He took pride in his work,'' Gamache said. Another uncle, Vasant Kumar, told mourners Drizpaul was a dedicated son who came to the United States at age 6 and joined the Navy after high school. ``He was the only son to his mother and the violent circumstances of his passing compounds the family's grief. It is a curious thing, but we know nothing about his work except he worked in a submarine. We feel he gave his life for his country,'' Kumar said. The family's attorney, Larry Scruggs Jr., said he planned to conduct his own investigation. But police Capt. Dennis Plumb, who is heading the civilian investigation in Bremerton, said police had talked to a witness to the shooting of the pawn shop clerk and had little doubt that Drizpaul was the killer. According to the Navy, Drizpaul shot and killed two sailors at the living quarters they shared at the base on Jan. 15. The next morning he killed a pawn shop clerk and critically wounded her brother while taking a pistol from the shop, the Navy said. Drizpaul was found dead from an apparently self-inflicted gunshot wound on Jan. 17 at a motel near Vancouver, Wash., authorities said.

DOC.HEAD: Top Ranking American Canal Official Shot to Death During Break-in
DOC.TEXT: The Panama Canal's finance director died Wednesday from a chest wound suffered after two hooded intruders shot him at his home during an apparent break-in, Canal Commission sources said. A commission source discarded any possibility the shooting Tuesday night of William Joyce, the fourth-ranking official of the nine-member Panama Canal Commission, was in retaliation for the Dec. 20 U.S. invasion of Panama. ``It has all the signs of being a criminal action,'' the source, who asked not to be identified, said. ``They entered his house, robbed him and in the action killed him with one shot to the chest.'' The intruders took money and jewelry, commission sources said. Joyce, 56, was taken to the U.S. military's Gorgas Hospital and died early Wednesday morning, they said. Joyce was born to American parents in the former Panama Canal Zone, studied at The Citadel in Charleston, S.C., and had worked for the Canal Commission since 1957, after serving as an infantry lieutenant in the Army. The U.S. invasion overthrew military leader Manuel Antonio Noriega, who was taken to Miami Jan. 3 for face trial on drug trafficking charges. Washington cited danger to Americans residing in Panama as one reason for the invasion.

DOC.HEAD: Police Arrest 24 in Capitol Demonstration
DOC.TEXT: Twenty-four opponents of U.S. policy in El Salvador were arrested Wednesday after disrupting a House hearing on recent events in that country, Capitol Police said. Fifteen demonstrators were arrested inside the hearing room in the Rayburn House Office Building and nine in the hallway outside, the police said. The disruption inside the room started during testimony by Bernard Aronson, assistant secretary of state for inter-American affairs. Some of the demonstrators, wearing black hoods and white masks, stood and pointed at Aronson while reading statements denouncing U.S. policy. One of the demonstrators said, ``El Salvador is Spanish for Vietnam'' and another shouted that death squad murders are ``on your hands, Mr. Aronson.'' A short time later, a group of demonstrators began shouting and chanting in the hallway. The hearing was conducted jointly by House Foreign Affairs subcommittees on Western Hemisphere Affairs and International Operations. All those arrested were charged with disrupting an orderly session of Congress and demonstrating within a Capitol building. Each charge is punishable by a maximum $500 fine, six months imprisonment or both. Those arrested will be arraigned at D.C. Superior Court.

DOC.HEAD: Floodwaters Ravage Tunisia, At Least 15 Dead
DOC.TEXT: Flooding from three days of torrential rains have left at least 15 people dead and destroyed 11,000 homes, authorities said Wednesday. Another 10 people are reported missing in central and southern Tunisia, the regions of the North African country hit hardest since the rains started Monday, according to Tunisian officials. The floodwaters washed away bridges and isolated some areas of this largely desert country, and emergency supplies have been flown in by helicopter to the communities of Gafsa, Sfax and Sidi Bouzid. The Tunisian Meteorology Institute predicted more rain Thursday from the storm. Rainfall in some areas since Monday has equaled a year's average for the region, or 7 inches, the institute said.

DOC.HEAD: Absent Host Barry Prime Topic at Mayors Conference
DOC.TEXT: Marion Barry, the absent host mayor, was a prime topic of private and sometimes-public discussion Wednesday as colleagues in the U.S. Conference of Mayors began a three-day meeting marked by growing concerns about the nation's drug problems. ``As we see him moving to get treatment for himself, we are caused to realize once again how important it is that treatment be available not only to those in high places, but to everyone who needs it,'' the conference's president, Houston Mayor Kathy Whitmire said after a speech at the National Press Club. Members of the big-city mayors' task force on drugs convened for a strategy session, meanwhile, with panel member Barry absent _ undergoing treatment in Florida. No mayor publicly mentioned Barry's arrest last week on a cocaine possession charge during the task force meeting, but he dominated their talk outside the meeting room. ``It was a tragedy for the mayor, and it was a tragedy for the District of Columbia,'' said Philadelphia Mayor Wilson Goode. ``I don't see how it has any impact on what we do here.'' ``It epitomizes, it symbolizes, the extent of the drug problem in this country,'' said Boston Mayor Raymond Flynn. Flynn said, ``I'd like to see an acknowledgement of Marion Barry's problem'' by the mayor. He said that if Barry is cured of any substance dependence problem, he should spend ``the rest of his life as an example'' to young people about the problems of drugs. Whitmire praised the Bush administration's anti-drug efforts in her speech at the press club, but said mayors are looking for more direct federal aid to the cities, without the grants going through state governments. Her only mention of Barry came in response to a question. She said the arrest and his decision to seek treatment at a Florida drug-and-alcoholism center underscored the broader need for drug treatment opportunities. She said that as long as there is a demand for drugs, dealers and producers will find ways to meet that demand. She and other mayors shied away from saying whether they believed Barry should resign from office because of the cocaine arrest. ``I'm not going to try to give any political advice to any other mayors,'' she said. Barry's appointed anti-drug official for the city, Sterling Tucker, sat in Barry's chair at the meeting of the drug task force. Barry is also chairman of the mayors' transportation committee. Conference spokesman Mike Brown said another mayor would fill in for Barry when the panel meets Thursday. The mayors are awaiting President Bush's latest plans for federal anti-drug efforts, and they released a study concluding that only a small portion of federal drug-enforcement aid has made it to the nation's cities. The study said city governments received just 15 percent of the $150 million in federal funds available for drug enforcement through the two main grant programs during the last fiscal year. Bush plans to address the mayors _ most of whom are Democrats _ on Friday. It will be the first time since Jimmy Carter in 1980 that an incumbent president has spoken to the organization of big-city mayors. Among black mayors, Sharpe James of Newark, N.J., said he did not embrace the suggestion of NAACP executive director Benjamin Hooks that the arrest was part of a pattern of harassment of black elected officials and a ``rising tide of racism.'' But he said racism would be a factor in law enforcement ``until we rule out racism in our country.'' Another black mayor, Cardell Cooper of East Orange, N.J., said: ``I do believe black leadership has come under, certainly, scrutiny. ... I don't know if you'd call it undue or not.'' He said Barry ``might have put himself in position to invite'' attention and scrutiny. A third black mayor said he did not see Barry's case as a particular embarrassment for black officeholders or one that makes their anti-drug efforts more difficult. ``It only proves mayors are human,'' said Mayor John Daniels of New Haven, Conn.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Deplores Police Force in Breaking up Cape Town Protest
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. government on Wednesday criticized South African police for using force to break up a protest in Cape Town. ``We deplore the use of force to stifle peaceful protest,'' State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler told reporters. ``We have long urged an end to violence and repression as an important step in the process of change in South Africa.'' Ms. Tutwiler commented when asked about the police's use on Tuesday of rubber bullets, tear gas and water cannon to disperse more than 5,000 black and mixed-race students who were protesting government education policies. She reiterated the U.S. call for the South African government to lift its state of emergency and restrictions on political activity and noted that President F.W. de Klerk has allowed several other political demonstrations to take place. Those protests, she said, ``were peaceful and contributed to the opening of a dialogue between all South Africans.'' ``During the difficult period ahead, in which the process of moving towards negotiations may sometimes become overheated, we ask all parties in South Africa to practice restraint and good sense in the search for a peaceful avenue for change,'' Ms. Tutwiler said.

DOC.HEAD: Germany Says Warning of Terrorists Prompted Search of Libyan Plane
DOC.TEXT: West Germany said Wednesday that a ``concrete warning'' about possible terrorists aboard a Libyan airliner prompted its police to hold and search the aircraft for hours at Frankfurt Airport. The action Tuesday drew a strong protest from Col. Moammar Gadhafi's Libyan government. The Libyan Arab Airlines plane was allowed to return to Tripoli Wednesday. Border police detained and searched the Boeing 727 at Frankfurt Tuesday shortly after it arrived from the Libyan capital with 75 passengers plus crew. Chief government spokesman Hans Klein refused to divulge the source of the ``concrete warning'' he said triggered the action and would not say if it was a foreign intelligence service. Federal security officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said there was a tip terrorists might have been aboard. Interior Ministry spokesman Roland Bachmeier told reporters three armed men were detained for carrying weapons without permits, but were released after they turned out to be the airline's security guards. Bachmeier defended the government's actions, saying West Germany must ``take seriously'' such a warning. He said any other eaction would be ``gross negligence and contrary to duty.'' He denied Libyan allegations that passengers were mistreated by police. Police detained and searched the plane shortly after it landed in Frankfurt at 3:49 p.m. Tuesday. All luggage was closely inspected. The search lasted until 9:45 p.m., but the captain refused to take off without the three guards who had been detained, Bachmeier said. The jetliner left for Tripoli at 11:06 a.m. Tuesday, Frankfurt Airport spokesman Wolfgang Schwalm said. The Libyan news agency JANA, monitored in London, quoted the plane's captain as saying after the aircraft returned to Libya that German authorities ordered a search of the plane without offering any explanation. JANA quoted him as saying passengers were searched, ``most of whom were women, children and sick people.'' The agency's account said the search caused ``trouble and delay, which led to a deterioration in the state of the sick and made the women and children distraught.'' The captain, who was not identified, was quoted as saying that armed West German police boarded the plane as soon as it landed at Frankfurt, the crew were prevented from disembarking and the airline's agents were not allowed on board.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Agree to Repatriate Dutch Drawings, Magazine Says
DOC.NOTE: For Release 6:30 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union is cooperating with Dutch authorities in trying to locate and return a valuable collection of Old Master drawings that was sold illegally to the Nazis and seized by Russian troops during World War II, ARTnews magazine reported Wednesday. A copyrighted article in the magazine's February issue, which will appear on newsstands Monday, said that after years of balking at Dutch diplomatic efforts to repatriate the drawings, the Soviets agreed to cooperate during a meeting with Dutch cultural official Jan Riezenkamp in Moscow last October. The focus of the Dutch government's search is a collection of 491 Old Master drawings, valued at $50 million to $75 million, that once belonged to Franz Koenigs, a German-born Dutch industrialist who assembled the art works in the 1920s. The collection included works by Correggio, Rembrandt, Titian, Anthony Van Dyck, Albrecht Durer, Jean-Honore Fragonard, Hans Holbein, Filippino Lippi, Peter Paul Rubens, Jacopo Tintoretto and Antoine Watteau. Dutch concern over recovering the missing drawings from the Soviet Union was heightened when two of the drawings surfaced recently in New York and London in the hands of private dealers and collectors, the magazine said. Their reappearance prompted the Dutch government to file lawsuits for the drawings' return. ARTnews said a large portion of the Koenigs collection was sold illegally to Adolf Hitler's agent, Hans Posse, in Rotterdam during World War II for an art museum that Hitler planned to build in his native Austria. Posse often bought art at forced sales from unwilling sellers, paying far below market value, the magazine said. The Koenigs drawings were moved to Dresden, Germany, which came under Soviet occupation. After the war, the drawings and millions of other art treasures were transferred to the Soviet Union, where the drawings disappeared and were feared destroyed. The magazine said Soviet and East German authorities repeatedly rebuffed Dutch efforts to locate and repatriate the drawings during the 1940s and 1950s. It quoted Riezenkamp as crediting Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's liberal policies for the recent change in Soviet attitude toward the Dutch requests. Riezenkamp now believes at least some of the drawings eventually will be repatriated with Soviet cooperation, said the magazine, which is published in New York.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Seeks Private Help to Revive East European Economies
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Wednesday called on private organizations to help revive East European economies. ``Government alone simply cannot get the job done,'' Bush said. The administration, he said, is considering funds for other countries in the region in addition to the assistance it has pledged for Hungary and Poland. The president's comments came as the new government of Romania said the United States had sent nothing in aid while providing more than $1 billion to Poland and Hungary. Ion Radulescu, who organizes distribution of foreign aid for the interim National Salvation Front government, said many other countries, even poor ones, had sent supplies and aid, but not the United States. However, Embassy spokeswoman Agota Kuperman said the United States gave $500,000 worth of assistance to Romania through the International Committee of the Red Cross. Bush said Romania shouldn't complain about not getting U.S. aid because private groups have been doing their share there. ``I'm not sure the people in Europe understand that yet,'' he told a group of leaders of non-profit organizations interested in Poland. The organization Americare has provided more than $1 million worth of assistance to Romania, he said. ``Many of you here, I'm told, are already involved in Eastern Europe doing work that the government could not possibly begin to do on its own, but there's more, much more to be done at this decisive moment in history,'' Bush said. The administration has announced a $200 million grant as part of a multilateral $1 billion stabilization fund for Poland. In addition, Bush has signed a $938 million aid package over three years for Poland and Hungary. ``We are now actively considering additional support for the other countries of the region as they move down the path of democratic reform,'' he said. ``But the government alone simply cannot get the job done _ don't have the resources, cannot do it. ``And we need the private sector _ non-profit and profit _ to engage its vitality and resources in this exciting process that's under way in Eastern Europe.''

DOC.HEAD: Moslem Fundamentalists Stage Week's Second Violent Protest
DOC.TEXT: Moslem militants chanting ``The blood of the martyr will not be wasted!'' went on a stone-throwing rampage Wednesday to protest the killing of a colleague in an earlier demonstration, officials said. Extremists also beat a village grocer and his family with chains because male and female family members worked together in the store, the security officials said. It was the second such attack in three days in this restive center of religious extremism 240 miles south of Cairo. On Monday, security police clashed with about 300 Moslem militants demonstrating outside a mosque. A demonstrator was killed and another seriously injured by bullets allegedly fired by policemen. Protesters on Wednesday smashed at least nine shop windows before owners opened fire and dispersed them. No injuries were reported. Police arrived and arrested nine people, said Attorney General Abdel-Mokhtar, but they were released later. Mokhtar said about 10 Moslem extremists used heavy chains in the attack on the grocer and his wife, daughter and three sons, all of whom work in the shop together. The family, also Moslems, were taken to a hospital for treatment of their injuries. But Mokhtar said they identified their assailants as Moslem extremists who warned the grocer last year against employing women. Some fundamentalists interpret Islam as forbidding mixing of sexes outside the home. In Mondays' attack, a Coptic Christian grocer was roughed up and his shop burned also because he employed a female relative. Assiut, a university center, has been a center of religious activism since 1981, when Islamic militants attempted a coup in its streets immediately after the assassination of President Anwar Sadat. Most of the more than 80 people who died were policemen. Since then, Moslem activist students and others demanding immediate implementation of the 1,350-year-old Islamic legal and ethnical code called Sharia often have clashed with police. They also have tried to impose their strict interpretation of Islam on other students by violently breaking up coed parties or plays and attacking male and female students seen together. Assiut has a laerge Coptic population. It has seen a few similar sectarian atacks over the years.

DOC.HEAD: Quake Measuring 5.7 Recorded in South China Sea off Luzon
DOC.TEXT: An earthquake measuring 5.7 on the Richter Scale was recorded in the South China Sea early Thursday, the Hong Kong Observatory said. The observatory said the quake was recorded at 3:36 a.m. (2:36 p.m. EST Wednesday). It was centered about 460 miles east-southeast of Hong Kong near the northern coast of the Philippines' main Luzon island. The observatory said no further details were immediately available. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. Every increase of one number means a tenfold increase in magnitude. An earthquake measuring 6 can cause severe damage in populated areas. The quake that struck northern California in October measured 7.1.

DOC.HEAD: Reporters Covering Bush at Drug Summit May File From Afar
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 3 grafs to UPDATE with Conyers comment
DOC.TEXT: The White House, worried about exposing reporters to danger during next month's drug summit in Colombia, may put most of the press corps covering President Bush in another country such as Panama, Costa Rica or Venezuela, spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Wednesday. He said there was ``a good chance'' the press would be located somewhere other than Colombia when Bush visits there Feb. 15 for several hours of talks with President Virgilio Barco and officials of Peru and Bolivia. Other countries under consideration for the press include Jamaica, Puerto Rico and Aruba. The alternate-site plan would run counter to a long-standing policy of having the press corps close to Bush on foreign trips. There have been numerous reports of threatened violence against Bush and others in Colombia by cocaine drug lords angry about a government crackdown against their operations. Most recently, CBS News said drug terrorists were buying surface-to-air missiles to try to shoot down Bush's plane. Fitzwater said the Secret Service was confident it could provide protection for Bush in Colombia, but that it has no authority to do the same for reporters. Tentative plans had called for the White House to set up filing facilities for the press at a commercial airport at Cartagena near the expected summit site. Fitzwater said there was ``a lot of deep concern about having it at the airport'' since it was exposed to the general population. ``The way to answer that concern,'' he said, ``is to put it someplace else.'' Traditionally, 11 reporters accompany Bush on Air Force One as a ``pool'' while the remainder of the press travel on a plane chartered by the White House and paid for by their companies. The pool frequently is expanded to permit more photographers, cameramen and reporters into situations where coverage is limited. Fitzwater said that under the plan being considered, a pool of undetermined size would accompany Bush to the actual summit, while the overwhelming majority of the press would go elsewhere. He said he had talked with a number of reporters about the idea and that they were ``generally favorable to having the filing center in another country.'' Fitzwater said that ``anybody who doesn't like it is free to go (to Cartagena) on their own.'' However, it was unclear how anyone who traveled independently could get access to Bush and the summit proceedings. The press secretary said he was examining logistics about an alternate site, such as how the press would be briefed on summit developments and the possibility that Bush might go to the filing center afterward for a news conference. ``The one thing I'm worried about are those SAM (surface-to-air) missiles that you can be back quite a distance and you can launch those numbers and you can create some trouble,'' said Rep. John Conyers, D-Mich., who just returned from a congressional trip to Colombia, Bolivia and Peru. Conyers discussed security with Bush after a meeting on the president's decision to support Cabinet status for the Environmental Protection Agency. ``I know that they can secure the immediate area around Cartagena,'' Conyers said. ``But if they've got SAM missiles, the insurgents ... that's a security problem I hope they've thought about.''

DOC.HEAD: Four Armed Albanians Escape to Yugoslavia
DOC.TEXT: Four armed Albanians escaped from their isolated, hard-line communist country over the heavily guarded border to Yugoslavia, the Tanjug news agency reported Wednesday. It said they crossed into Montenegro, a Yugoslav republic. The Yugoslav agency said the four carried weapons, but did not elaborate. Travel is heavily restricted in Albania, Eastern Europe's most tightly controlled country and the last holdout for Stalinism on the Continent, and escapes are extremely rare. In recent weeks reports of unrest in Albania have cropped up repeatedly in Yugoslav, Greek and other Western media but could not be independently confirmed. Few foreigners are allowed to enter Albania. Albanian leaders dismissed the reports as ``slanders'' and ``fabrications.'' Tanjug reported signs of ``increased military activity'' in Albania but gave no source for its information and offered no details. While reforms has swept the rest of communist Europe, Albania has jealously guarded its Stalinist system and sworn under Communist leader Ramiz Alia not to veer from its path. In Athens, 10 Albanian defectors chained themselves to the railings of the Albanian Embassy on Wednesday to protest a visit by Albania's foreign undersecretary, but police cut the chains and the demonstrators left, Greek authorities said. The Albanians, all of whom had been granted asylum in Greece, accused the Tirana government of suppressing political and religious freedom. Albania, sandwiched between Greece and Yugoslavia, has a population of about 3 million. In a gesture of good will Wednesday, the Albanian Embassy in Athens told the mayor of the northern Greek town of Ioannina that the remains of Greek soldiers killed in the 1940 Greek-Italian war would be returned. In 1987, Greece ended a technical state of war with Albania that had existed since Greeks battled invading Italian forces on the Albanian border in 1940.

DOC.HEAD: Chinese-Backed Sugar Mill Opens in Nepal
DOC.TEXT: King Birendra on Wednesday formally inaugurated a sugar mill built largely with Chinese aid in Sunuwal, 100 miles southwest of the capital Katmandu. The mill can produce 10,000 tons of sugar a year, meeting about 20 percent of the needs of this landlocked country that borders India and the Tibetan region of China, Radio Nepal said. Beijing reportedly provided $10.7 million in aid for the project, equivalent to 75 percent of the cost of the mill. The balance was funded by the government of Nepal, one of the least developed countries in Asia.

DOC.HEAD: Bush to Ask for More Than $10 Billion to Fight Drugs Next Year
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Tops with 7 grafs to update with total for 1991 being more than $10.5 billion, changes base figures for 1990 to account for revised total; picks up 5th graf pvs, Those areas.
DOC.TEXT: The second phase of the National Drug Control Strategy, to be unveiled Thursday by President Bush, will call for spending more than $10.5 billion on the war against drugs in 1991, at least $1 billion more than this year, an administration source said Wednesday. Money for the Pentagon's effort to battle drugs would rise about 50 percent, from $880 million this year to $1.2 billion in fiscal 1991, a draft of the strategy said. Congress allocated about $8.8 billion for the drug war this fiscal year, about $900 million more than the $7.9 billion sought by Bush in the strategy unveiled in September. But the new strategy, basing drug war expenditures on new base figures, says the country is now spending $9.5 billion, not $8.8 billion, said the source, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. ``They have gone through the accounts at the various agencies so you can make straight-line accounts from year to year,'' the official said. ``As part of the process of going through all this, they found that it is appropriate and possible to attribute moneys that had not previously been attributed to drugs.'' In the new strategy, the prior-year totals have been altered to reflect the changes so that the administration cannot be accused of improperly inflating the figures for 1991, the official said. The new strategy will also intensify federal anti-drug efforts in five areas immediately, said other administration sources, all of whom requested anonymity. Those areas _ metropolitan New York, Miami, Houston, Los Angeles and virtually all of the Southwest border _ will be designated as high-intensity drug-trafficking regions and will benefit this year from $25 million previously approved by Congress to fight drugs in the worst-afflicted regions and from as much as $21 million from the federal asset-forfeiture fund, the sources said. By and large, the strategy's focus will remain as it was in the original plan: _Harsh, state-imposed penalties for drug users. _Intensified treatment and prevention efforts. _Bigger budgets for law enforcement at all levels. One source said that the targeting of five areas in the war against drugs this year will not mean more money for local governments. Those governments ``won't see any checks,'' said the source. ``What they will see is increased awareness and cooperation from the feds, that type of thing. The money is going to the feds for them to increase their efforts ... to highlight their presence in those areas.'' The federal anti-drug effort will also target regions surrounding designated cities, the source said. He said the Los Angeles metropolitan area will include Los Angeles and Orange County. A draft of the strategy says the New York area includes Nassau County in New York and Essex County in New Jersey. The Miami area includes Broward, Dade and Monroe counties. The Houston area includes Harris and Galveston counties. The Southwest region includes 35 counties in California, Arizona, New Mexico and Texas. Other counties in each area may be included in the final version of the strategy, the source said. Whether these regions will be targeted for 1991 as well remains undecided, the source said. ``If we're successful, we would anticipate that these spots will move,'' the source said. ``As the emphasis increases on the Southwest border, (the drug traffickers) will go toward Louisiana or inland, or to Canada and come down. We'll have to monitor it to see what happens the second time around.'' The updated strategy also will propose a broadening of federal drug crimes for which the death penalty can be imposed, in line with changes Bush said last year that he wanted to make. Those proposals call for allowing the death penalty to be imposed on drug kingpins even when they or their organizations have not killed anyone, on kingpins who attemp to kill to obstruct justice and on federal drug felons whose offenses result in death, such as an overdose by a drug user. Another new idea in the draft strategy is for the ``development of large drug treatment `campuses' located on public land, serving thousands of patients with a range of state-of-the art treatment methods and associated social services.'' Other programs slated for substantial spending increases in 1991, if Congress approves, are block grants to states for treatment and law enforcement; the Drug Enforcement Administration and its state and local task forces; the FBI; the Immigration and Naturalization Service, for inspectors and border patrols; the Customs Service; the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms; the Organized Crime Drug Enforcement Task Force program and the U.S. Marshals Service's transportation and detention program, as well as its witness-protection program. The draft strategy also calls for greatly intensified efforts to eradicate domestic marijuana production and proposes more money for the National Institute of Drug Abuse, in part so that it can conduct its household survey of drug use annually, rather than every three years. William J. Bennett, director of the Office of National Drug Control Policy, and budget director Richard Darman were reported by an administration official last month to be ``apart by more than a couple of hundred million dollars'' on the 1991 drug war budget. Sources said Wednesday that Darman won the battle, saying Bennett originally had requested a 20 percent to 30 percent increase.

DOC.HEAD: Coleridge Biography Wins Whitbread Book Award
DOC.TEXT: A biography of Samuel Taylor Coleridge, the British poet who wrote ``The Ancient Mariner'' and ``Kubla Khan,'' was named the Whitbread Book of the Year on Wednesday. Author Richard Holmes was awarded the prize and $36,300 for his biography ``Coleridge: Early Visions.'' The volume is the first part of a major series on Coleridge, who was an opium addict and contemporary of William Wordsworth. ``The prize means basically that I will have time to write more,'' said the former teacher after receiving the award at Whitbread's, a brewing firm. Holmes's book was voted Biography of the Year by Whitbread judges in October. Competitors for the Book of the Year were October's winners in the categories of first novel, best novel, poetry and children's novel. Last year's Book of the Year award went to ``The Comforts of Madness,'' Paul Sayer's first novel about long-term psychiatric hospital patients who cannot speak.

DOC.HEAD: Vandalism Heats Up Conflict Over Inner-City Tobacco and Alcohol Ads
DOC.TEXT: The paintbrush-wielding ``magician'' who made several billboards disappear under coats of white paint said Wednesday he's fed up with glamorous ads touting tobacco and alcohol in inner-city neighborhoods. But a billboard company spokesman said the paint jobs are vandalism. The painter, who's taken the pseudonym Mandrake after the comic-strip magician, said billboard ads in predominantly black and Hispanic neighborhoods on the South Side are aimed at young people and promote dangerous vices. Mandrake, who described himself as a 54-year-old black professional but declined to give his real name, said he's taken a paintbrush to billboards three times in broad daylight because the ads corrupt young people. ``I have seen over the past two years a disproportionate amount of advertising in the black and Hispanic community,'' he said in a telephone interview. ``I believe it was time for us to stand up and fight back. ``I'm a firm believer in the Constitution and believe the law was broken ... but at the same time, there is a moral obligation, a right, that must be addressed,'' he said. Geoff Obrzut, a spokesman for national billboard company Patrick Media, said he filed a police report Wednesday. ``He's obviously vandalizing private property,'' Obrzut said in a telephone interview. ``We would be willing to prosecute if he's caught.'' Mandrake's actions have helped fuel a controversy over the targeting of minorities by alcohol and tobacco companies. On one side stand consumer advocates alarmed by the number of people from inner-city communities dying from smoking- and drinking-related illnesses. On the other side are industry representatives, who dismiss attacks on such advertising as an infringement of the constitutional right to freedom of speech. Industry representatives contend that ads specifically aimed at minorities are harmless and that people make their own decision about whether to light up or take a drink. However, the lung cancer rate has increased four times faster among blacks than among whites in the past 30 years, according to reports from the American Lung Association and the National Cancer Institute. A 1987 study by the Center for Science in the Public Interest, a health advocacy group based in Washington, found that black men have a 70 percent higher death rate from cirrhosis of the liver than whites. The health advocacy group contends that children are being encouraged by the billboard ads. ``Children on the way to school and back home or even at recess get the message that the way to be happy, glamorous, or athletic is to smoke and-or drink,'' a center publication said. Obrzut disagreed, saying that while 50 percent of billboard advertising does occur in the inner city, a company study found that only 16 percent of Chicago's 2,500 billboards were alcohol- or tobacco-related. Gary Miller, a spokesman for the American Tobacco Institute in Washington, said studies also show that young people become smokers primarily because of peer group pressures and parental influence. He said tobacco companies might advertise to minorities because more minorities than whites tend to be smokers. ``Just like an effective advertisement, you try to reach those people to whom it appeals,'' Miller said in a telephone interview. Janet Flynn of the Distilled Spirits Council of the United States, echoed Miller's sentiments, saying: ``We restrict our advertising to responsible adult customers.'' Advocacy groups say advertisers only respond to pressure. In Baltimore, pressure from various groups led an advertising company to remove much of its black-oriented advertising. And R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Co. recently scrapped plans to test market Uptown, a new cigarette aimed at the black community, after opposition from the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

DOC.HEAD: Rallies Banned in Baku; Battle Reported in Harbor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 20th `Militants continued' with theft from Yerevan War Museum and SUBS 25th `Azerbaijan's Communist' to update with meeting begun
DOC.TEXT: Azerbaijanis fired on Soviet forces in Baku harbor from merchant ships Wednesday but were routed and forced to lift a 5-day-old sea blockade of the city, Soviet media and residents reported. Soldiers rounded up 43 activists and banned rallies in Baku, where ethnic violence began Nov. 13 between Moslem Azerbaijanis and Armenians, most of whom are Christians. Soldiers' families and thousands of Russians were evacuated Wednesday. State television said the port terminal came under attack from ships of the Caspian Sea Oil Fleet and two soldiers were wounded. Tankers and other vessels with Azerbaijani crews had blocked the harbor because they suspected military authorities of planning to smuggle out bodies of people killed by Soviet soldiers, said Tunzala Kasumova, a journalist in Baku, a city with 1.8 million residents. Captains of the oil tankers and barges were said to have threatened to blow up their vessels if military vessels tried to break through. Red Army soldiers moved into the Azerbaijani capital Saturday to quell a nationalist uprising and anti-Armenian riots. Ms. Kasumova said the 40-minute harbor battle began when a military cutter tried to break through the blockade, and troops near the terminal joined in to help the cutter. ``I could hear the thunder, the shooting and cannonade,'' the journalist said of what she described as an exchange of artillery and automatic weapons fire. Ms. Kasumova spoke by telephone from her home near the harbor. Soviet television said several people detained in connection with the fight had weapons and drugs in their possession. It was the first involvement of ships in the conflict, which began with Azerbaijani attacks on Armenians but has become an armed confrontation between the Azerbaijani republic and the central authority in Moscow. Izvestia, the government newspaper, reported Wednesday that clashes between Azerbaijanis and Soviet troops were taking the form of a partisan war, including frequent night attacks on patrols. Violence began Jan. 13 with rioting by Azerbaijanis in which dozens of ethnic Armenians were killed. An estimated 16,000 Armenians left the city and ethnic war began in the hills around the disputed territory of Nagorno-Karabakh and on the border between the Armenian and Azerbaijani republics. At least 171 people have been killed. Baku residents said the city was quiet Wednesday for the first time in weeks, except for the harbor and some shooting around an army barracks. A general strike continued. Leila Yunusova, an Azerbaijani activist, said people observed the ban on mass meetings but many attended small gatherings to renounce their Communist Party memberships and protest the Soviet military presence. She said 100,000 of Azerbaijan's 380,000 Communists had torn up their party cards. Tass said demonstrations and strikes were banned in Baku beginning Wednesday and activists were told they could be sent to jail for 30 days if they tried to organize such protests. Soviet media reported growing threats against the Russian population of Baku from Azerbaijanis reacting to the army's attacks on militants and attempts to restore order. About 100,000 Russians live in Baku. Many Russians left the city and Tass said the Soviet military evacuated more than 16,000 wives and children of soldiers. Trud, a labor newspaper, reported attacks on the apartments of Russians and said Azerbaijani were refusing to sell bread to Russians. Militants continued storming weapons depots in Armenia and Azerbaijan and had stolen more than 5,000 guns and other materiel in two days, Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady Gerasimov said in Moscow. A tank, two 76mm cannons and an anti-aircraft gun were among items stolen Wednesday from the war museum in Yerevan, capital of Armenia, Tass said. Officials have blamed banned groups for inciting violence, but Sivinch Abdullayev, an editor at the republic's official news agency Azerinform, said leaders of the Azerbaijani People's Front apparently were not included in the roundup. Authorities have been particularly critical of the front. Soviet TV suggested Wednesday night that the government meet with all groups in Azerbaijan, including the People's Front. Tass said the National Defense Committee, a militant branch of the front, was specifically banned. Ms. Abdullayev reported that National Defense Committee member Neimat Panakhov said at a funeral rally Monday the leaders of the committee and front were going underground. She said none had been seen since. Azerbaijan's Communist Party Central Committee began a meeting after curfew Wednesday night so the building would not be surrounded by demonstrators, said legislative spokesman Nizami Sakyakhov. Jeikhun Mula-Zade, a political scientist, said it would consider breaking with the national party, as Lithuanian Communists did last month, and would elect a new first secretary to replace Abdul-Rakhman Vezirov, who was fired after Soviet troops entered Baku. Ms. Yunusova, the activist, said Vezirov had been expelled from the party and criminal charges might be brought against him. Talks between Armenian and Azerbaijani officials in the Armenian town of Yeraskh broke down Wednesday, Tass reported, but it said said efforts were under way to set up negotiations in other border areas. Some skirmishes were reported in Azerbaijan. In Armenia, industry and transport remained nearly halted because of a rail blockade by Azerbaijan that has caused a severe fuel shortage, Tass reported. It said 10 freight trains finally had been permitted through Azerbaijan, but a section of track in a predominantly Azerbaijani section of Georgia was dismantled, causing an accident that injured four passengers and cutting Armenia's last rail link with the rest of the Soviet Union. Nagorno-Karabakh, an enclave in Azerbaijan with a predominantly Armenian population, is at the crux of a conflict between the ethnic groups that began two years ago. Both sides claim the fertile, hilly region of about 160,000 people.

DOC.HEAD: O'Ferrell: `I Have Not Been Told I Failed a Lie Detector Test'
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: A junk dealer questioned in the mail bomb deaths of a civil rights lawyer and a federal judge who ruled against him insisted Wednesday the FBI has found nothing linking him to the slayings. A law enforcement source in Washington, speaking on condition of anonymity, said earlier in the day that Robert Wayne O'Ferrell is considered a suspect and had failed a series of lie detector tests administered by the FBI. O'Ferrell, who has seen his home, junk business and other properties pored over since the FBI converged on southeast Alabama Monday, once complained in a legal brief that America's court system ``is corrupt.'' O'Ferrell, who has denied any part in the mail bomb deaths, said agents have not found a typewriter that reportedly links typewritten court correspondence he filed in 1988 with typed material sent by the mail bomber. ``You can't keep looking when you don't find nothing,'' he told reporters as he fed dogs and horses at his rural home. O'Ferrell confirmed he took several polygraph tests this week, but said, ``I have not been told I am a suspect and have not been told I failed a lie detector.'' No charges have been filed against O'Ferrell, and FBI agent Chuck Archer, who has declined to use the term ``suspect'' in referring to O'Ferrell, said no suspects have been taken into custody. Agents are searching for clues in the package bomb deaths of Judge Robert Vance of Birmingham, who died Dec. 16, and black lawyer Robert Robinson, of Savannah, Ga., who was killed two days later. Vance was a member of a three-judge panel of the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta that ruled last year against O'Ferrell, who was sueing his former employer, Gulf Life Insurance Co. An Atlanta TV station received a letter signed ``Americans for a Competent Federal Judicial System'' that claimed responsibility for the mail bombings and included racist comments. The legal brief O'Ferrell filed in 1988 against Gulf Life included a typwritten document that says in part: ``The law and court system in these UNITED STATES is corrupt, that I have had anything to do with. But I know you can help clean it up.... If anyone has been mistreated by Gulf Life ... the Courts, and two Attorneys, I really believe that I have.'' The capitalization and grammar is as it appears in the document. But the court documents O'Ferrell filed do not mention racial topics, considered by many the motivation for the two killings. According to the law enforcement source, O'Ferrell gave answers considered deceptive by a polygraph expert when he failed the lie detector tests. Results of polygraph tests are not always reliable and are inadmissable in criminal trials. It could not be determined what questions the FBI asked O'Ferrell. Agents have searched O'Ferrell's home, junk warehouse, abandoned downtown store and two septic tanks, and more locales were on a list to be searched. ``They are obtaining more (warrants) and will be searching further,'' said Charles Steinmetz, a spokesman at FBI headquarters in Washington. At O'Ferrell's salvage business Wednesday, agents pumped out a septic tank and removed items from the tin-covered building onto a rented truck. Men wearing FBI jackets hung green tarpaulins on the front of the structure, and stacked up boxes to block the view of dozens of reporters and news cameras. The contents of the warehouse's septic tank, located in an adjoining shed, was pumped out after firefighters clad in bright yellow containment-suits tested for any build-up of flammable methane gas in the underground tank. The FBI also has canvassed town businesses asking for information on O'Ferrell's buying habits. O'Ferrell's father, J.C. O'Ferrell, said the FBI questioned him about the activities of both his sons, Wayne and James ``Buddy'' O'Ferrell. ``They were trying to say my two sons had something to do with that bombing up in Birmingham,'' the father told the Birmingham Post-Herald. ``They asked had I ever heard either one talk bad about colored folks, or if my sons ever made threats on any judges. I said, `No, my children weren't raised that way.'''

DOC.HEAD: Two Injured as Youths Battle Police Over Austerity Measures
DOC.TEXT: Hooded protesters exchanged gunfire with police Wednesday at Central University, and at least two protesters were wounded as unrest flared anew over the government's austerity measures. The street battle broke out about noon as the protesters, most of them teenagers, gathered rocks, assembled firebombs out of beer bottles and distributed pamphlets to students at Venezuela's largest university. Battles between police and rioters on university grounds had died down since riots last March over austerity cuts and steep price hikes on food and public transportation left about 300 dead. The 11-month-old government of social democratic President Carlos Andres Perez plans to cut subsidies on gasoline prices, and labor union officials said Wednesday they will stage protests beginning next month. Perez wants to reduce Venezuela's 80 percent annual inflation rate and the $34 billion foreign debt. ``We're a small group, maybe fifty, but we represent the discontents of the majority of Venezuelans,'' said a hooded teenager who called himself Cinco. ``We're out here again, after a year of quiet, to again do battle with the bourgeois forces of repression,'' said Cinco. ``We're hoping the people will take to the streets again.'' A student nearby called the protest a traditional activity. ``It's the student's duty to protest, because we are unhappy with a series of problems facing the country,'' he said, citing the rising cost of living. The government has warned that gasoline prices in Venezuela, some of the cheapest in the world, will be raised within a few months.
