The protesters, wearing hoods, edged close to the university's main gate, as lines of Metropolitan police in riot gear, with tear gas canisters on the ends of their rifles, crouched behind cars in a plaza outside. A hooded boy pulled out a homemade gun and fired at the police, setting off the battle. With battle cries, the group of protesters threw rocks and firebombs, while the police fired tear gas canisters. But the wind pushed most of the tear gas back at police. Occasionally, shotgun pellets whistled overhead from the police. After a few hours the fighting slowly finally died down after police advanced to the gate and the protesters _ along with students in team uniforms playing soccer on a field _ retreated into classroom buildings. Two protesters were hit by shotgun pellets as they braved the police fire head-on. Carlos Salgado, an economics student, was hit in the chest and arm and checked into the university infirmary. An unidentified protester was hit in the shoulder, but continued to do battle. Students began to troop out of the main entrance, tired of waiting for the protesters to give up. Police waited patiently. ``We have them behind the line. Its only a small number of troublemakers,'' said Sheriff Raul Vivas, commander of a Metropolitan police anti-riot brigade. He said police suffered no injuries. The nations' largest labor union, the Confederation of Venezuelan Workers, or CTV, said they would call for marches against the planned gasoline price hike starting February 15. The CTV paralyzed Venezuela for 12 hours last April in a nationwide work stoppage. Perez, inaugurated last Feb. 2, has instituted austerity measures in part to qualify for financing through the International Monetary Fund. The country's foreign debt is fourth largest in Latin America after Brazil, Mexico and Argentina.

DOC.HEAD: FCC Considering Stiffer Rules
DOC.TEXT: The head of the Federal Communications Commission told Congress on Wednesday he wants more stringent rules against drug involvement by broadcasters. The commission chairman, Alfred Sikes, wrote Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee, that he had asked the commission staff for a ``thorough examination'' of the commission's 1986 ``Character Policy Statement.'' The current policy, which was adopted under FCC Chairman Mark S. Fowler, does not say whether such things as drug possession and pending drug charges against broadcasters should be taken into account during license proceedings. Until the 1986 FCC ruling, any felony conviction automatically had been considered relevant to an applicant's suitability to hold a broadcast license. But the commission narrowed the scope of issues it was willing to consider. ``There is no scarcity of law-abiding citizens interested in being broadcast licensees,'' Sikes wrote Dingell. ``Today, there are also fewer objective requirements associated with holding a broadcast license. Consequently, in my view current or prospective broadcast licensees should be held to a higher standard than is reflected in the current policy statement.'' Dingell, whose committee oversees the commission, said Sikes' position ``is a refreshing change.'' ``His commitment to thoroughly reexamining that policy goes a long way toward restoring my confidence in the FCC's judgment and willingness to regulate in the public interest,'' said Dingell, who battled continually with Sikes' deregulation-minded predecessors, Fowler and Dennis R. Patrick. Sikes last September announced the commission automatically would consider drug dealing convictions as possible grounds for yanking a broadcasters' license, but he did not mention drug possession convictions. Congress, when it passed the 1988 Anti-Drug Abuse Act, denied ``federal benefits'' to drug violators, but it did not say whether an FCC license was a federal benefit. Sikes wrote that although the commission had some discretion in drug matters involving broadcasters, ``drug possession is not specifically mentioned as within the scope of the Character Policy Statement.'' Misdemeanor drug convictions that do not deny federal benefits under the 1988 drug law also are not mentioned in the policy statement, Sikes said. Therefore, such a conviction would not be considered relevant to an applicant's basic qualifications in a license renewal or transfer proceeding, Sikes said. The policy statement also does not mention drug-associated activities, such as money laundering, extortion, theft, burglary or robbery. It says specifically that homicide will not disqualify an applicant. But, Sikes said, the commission retains the discretion to consider misconduct that is ``so egregious as to shock the conscience.'' In felony cases, Sikes added, an applicant may buy or sell a station until the charges are proven. The commission could, however, grant approval of a license contingent upon the outcome of the pending criminal proceeding. Applicants convicted of misconduct at one station may not automatically be disqualified from owning other stations, Sikes said. The commission's drug policy was called into question when in 1988 it renewed the license of Williamsburg County Broadcasting Corp. to operate WKSP-AM, in Kingstree, S.C., after the company's principal owner, Gregory Knop, was convicted of a cocaine charge. In its September revisions, the commission said Knop's conviction raised questions about Williamsburg's qualifications to hold the license.

DOC.HEAD: Former Romanian Dissident Proposed for Nobel Peace Prize
With AM-Romania Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A petition signed by 181 French lawmakers has nominated former Romanian dissident Doina Cornea for the Nobel Peace Prize, the sponsor said Wednesday. Pierre Lequiller, a National Assembly member from the conservative Union for French Democracy, said the petition got broad support from parties of the left and right, but not from the hard-line French Communist Party, He said the nomination was sent Friday to the Nobel Peace Prize committee in Oslo, Norway. Lequiller said he had asked U.S., British, Italian and Spanish legislators to support it. Mrs. Cornea, 60, is an instructor at Cluj University and endured years of hardship for publicly opposing the repressive policies of dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, who was overthrown and executed in December. She suffered beatings by the security police and was under virtual house arrest. After Ceausecu fell, she became a member of the ruling National Salvation Front, composed largely of former Communists. The daily Romania Libera said she quit after the Front announced Tuesday it would run candidates in elections set for May 20.

DOC.HEAD: Peres Says He Discussed `New Ideas' With Mubarak
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 5th graf `In Washington' to UPDATE with Peres reax to Baker comment. Pickup 6th, `Peres, whose...'; EDITS thereafter to TRIM
DOC.TEXT: Israeli Labor Party leader Shimon Peres said he and President Hosni Mubarak discussed ``new ideas'' on Wednesday to overcome difficulties blocking Israeli-Palestinian peace talks. ``I think I will be going back home with some messages of importance,'' said Peres, deputy premier and finance minister, after a meeting of about 90 minutes with Mubarak. As he did when he arrived Tuesday night, Peres said agreement is close on convening an Israeli-Palestinian dialogue in Cairo as a step toward peace negotiations. But Israel radio on Wednesday quoted a spokesman for Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir as disputing Peres' optimistic appraisal. In Washington, Secretary of State James A. Baker III said when asked about Peres' optimistic statements: ``I'm not sure that I would have used the characterization that Mr. Peres used. I'm not sure that I'm that encouraged. I think we still have a long ways to go.'' Upon landing at Tel Aviv from Cairo, Peres called Baker's comment ``a matter of judgment. ``I think that the problems that are still outstanding can be solved now,'' he said. ``These are matters in which the immagination is richer than the problem.'' Peres, whose Labor Party joined Shamir's Likud Bloc in a coalition Cabinet in 1988 after inconclusive parliamentary elections, did not say who presented the ideas he discussed with Mubarak. Nor did he indicate whether the messages he was taking home from Cairo are Mubarak's views or the Egyptian president's reactions to Israeli ideas. Peres said, however, that some of the ideas concern composition of the Palestinian delegation to the proposed dialogue in Cairo, which Egypt and the United States are pushing. This and the agenda have been major stumbling blocks. ``The remaining problems between us and the Palestinians can be solved rather swiftly and in a very short while,'' Peres said. ``There are some new ideas introduced to do so.'' He reiterated that both he and Shamir oppose any participation in the peace process by the Palestine Liberation Organization. But unlike the hard-line prime minister, Peres favored including in the delegation Palestinians deported by Israel from the occupied West Bank and Gaza for ties with the PLO. ``The Palestinian delegation should be a non-PLO delegation representing the people in the (occupied) territories and not people active outside the territories,'' Peres said. He replied with a terse ``yes'' when asked if deportees included people who were not PLO members and were not implicated in terrorist acts. The PLO has insisted on playing a role in the peace process, on forming the Palestinian delegation and on being seen to do so. Israel refuses to deal with the PLO, dismissing its members as terrorists. In outlining his concept of the delegation, Peres said it should be free to consult with any Arabs since ``it is not made up of Israeli citizens but of Jordanians.'' He did not elaborate. The West Bank was under Jordan's control and Gaza was under Egypt's before Israel conquered them in the 1967 Middle East War. Peres always has viewed Jordan as a principal partner in peace talks, and Shamir contends that Jordan is the Palestinian homeland. On the agenda of the Palestinian-Israeli dialogue, Peres hinted at a possible compromise. He suggested that participants could address any subject in opening statements but confine themselves subsequently to discussion of Israeli-proposed Palestinian elections in the West Bank and Gaza. The polling would be to choose negotiators on limited interim autonomy. ``Once we have agreed that the heart of the agenda will be arranging the elections in the territories, the opening speech or speeches are becoming of secondary consideration,'' Peres said. Shamir wants the agenda restricted to the mechanics of elections. The PLO and Egypt, acting on the organization's behalf, say other subjects can be raised, and the United States agrees with that view. He urged Syria, which lost its Golan Heights to Israel in 1967, to join in the process and expressed willingness to meet with Syria's president, Hafez Assad, in Egypt, the only Arab state at peace with Israel.

DOC.HEAD: Parolee Leaves Prison; Son He Torched Is Terrified
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs to UPDATE with news conference, EDIT for transition; picks up 7th graf, `David lives ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY20
DOC.TEXT: David Rothenberg will never forgive his father for setting him on fire, saying Wednesday's release of the man who disfigured him leaves him terrified despite unprecedented measures to keep the felon away. ``I would like them to keep him in jail for the rest of his life,'' David, 13, told reporters 15 hours after Charles Rothenberg, 49, was released from prison. David told a news conference at the Buena Park Police Department that he feared Rothenberg may someday harm him. Asked when he thought he would feel safe, he said, ``When Charles dies.'' ``Obviously, he is very concerned and he has every reason to be,'' state Department of Corrections spokesman Tipton Kindel said in Sacramento. Charles Rothenberg, wearing blue jeans, a blue chambray shirt and an electronic leash to monitor his movements during three years' probation, ``was escorted out of the prison by motor vehicle'' at 12:40 a.m., said Kindel. ``He is out on parole and he has reached his destination,'' the spokesman said, declining to even disclose whether Rothenberg was paroled within the United States. ``He said he was afraid and upset, but he didn't elaborate.'' David, whose face bears severe scars from the burning as well as from repeated skin graft surgery and whose fingers have been amputated to the first joint, wore a Los Angeles Raiders ball cap and sat on a telephone book to see over a bank of microphones at the news conference. ``I want it known nationally that I don't ever want to see my father again. I want to make it clear to him,'' he said. ``I think he's a sick man. I can't see why he did this to his own son,'' said the boy, who was 6 years old when his father set him on fire in a Buena Park motel room in 1983. David expressed fear in an earlier interview, and said he keeps a BB gun by his bed just in case. ``I'd shoot his eye out if he ever came over. I'd blind him,'' he said. ``I will never forgive him.'' David lives in Orange County with his mother, Marie, and stepfather, Buena Park police Lt. Richard Hafdahl, who helped investigate the fire. ``He has nightmares that his dad is chasing him down the street,'' Hafdahl said. Asked what is being done to protect David, Kindel said that if Rothenberg is ever ``not where he's supposed to be, then the family, David, will be notified immediately.'' Hafdahl said he's also taken security measures. ``He's under the most restrictive parole ever for a California parolee,'' Kindel said. ``He will be accompanied by a parole officer 24 hours a day. We want to make sure that he is where he is supposed to be and that he has no opportunity to come into contact with his son.'' Rothenberg's parole will cost California taxpayers $18,000 a month. Rothenberg set fire to his son after a telephone argument in which his estranged wife said he would not be able to see David again. Rothenberg had taken the boy on a holiday to Southern California from New York, where the boy was living with his mother. ``If I can't have him, nobody else can,'' Rothenberg said when arrested six days later. Wearing a lapel pin reading ``Kids are the nicest people,'' he told arresting officers he was going to kill himself but was too much of a coward. David, dragged from the inferno by motel guests, suffered third-degree burns over 90 percent of his body. Rothenberg was convicted of attempted murder, arson and other charges and got the maximum penalty, a 13-year prison term. The sentence was cut in half because of good behavior. If convicted today, Rothenberg would have faced up to life in prison. But sentencing laws at the time required his release after less than seven years. Prison officials tried to keep relocation plans secret, fearing a repeat of the hysteria surrounding the 1987 release of Larry Singleton. Singleton, who had raped a teen-ager and left her for dead after hacking off her forearms with an ax, had to be moved repeatedly from Northern California communities, where he was rejected by an outraged public.

DOC.HEAD: Agrarian Party Asks Interim Government in Bulgaria
DOC.TEXT: The Agrarian Party, for more than 40 years a pawn of Bulgaria's Communists, on Wednesday proposed an interim government of national consensus that would hold free elections, the state news agency BTA reported. The Communist-dominated reformist government meanwhile said it will hand Parliament an economic reform program Thursday designed to lay the groundwork for a market economy by allowing ``pluralism of ownership in all its forms.'' The government wants Bulgaria's first free elections since World War II to be held in May. The opposition has requested most of the voting for Parliament be delayed until November to give itself time to develop campaign strategies. The Agrarian Party, a member of the governing coalition in the National Assembly, or parliament, has tried to distance itself from the Communists as elections approach. The National Assembly voted this month to abolish the Communists' guaranteed monopoly on power, setting the stage for an end to 42 years of authoritarian, one-party rule. On Tuesday, Justice Minister Svetla Daskalova, an Agrarian leader, asked that any reference to Bulgaria as a ``socialist state'' be deleted from the constitution. On Wednesday, the Agrarian Party's ruling council passed a motion calling for a ``broad-based, provisional government of national consensus'' made up of all factions now engaged in talks here, BTA reported. The talks among the Communists, the 12-party opposition Union of Democratic Forces, and other political and social groups are aimed at achieving national consensus on the speed and sweep of democratization in Bugaria. The Agrarian motion will be submitted to the National Assembly and the next session of talks, BTA said. The Communist leadership has agreed to an opposition newspaper and office space, but balks at giving the opposition access to radio and television _ a must for propagating democratic ideas and gaining electoral support in this largely rural nation. As proposed by the Agrarian Party, a government of national consensus would arrange free elections and move to remedy Bulgaria's economic crisis, aggravated by a foreign debt of up to $12 billion. Such an interim government would speed Bulgaria's economic integration with the outside world and its affiliation with Western-oriented world economic organizations, like the International Monetary Fund and the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, BTA reported. BTA said the government's economic plan would attempt to bolster Bulgaria's financial situation by cutting capital investments and administrative expenditures, acting to increase the strength of banks and the credit system. Further details were not available, such as a timetable for transforming Bulgaria's highly centralized communist economy into a market economy. The Union of Democratic Forces says Western aid is vital to conquer the economic crisis here and that it must be used for radical economic reforms. UDF Chairman Zhelyu Zhelev said on TV Wednesday that without economic reform, ``we can find ourselves in the same situation as before, when aid disappeared like water into sand,'' according to BTA. ``Economic aid should be associated with democratization. If there is no such link, the past can make a comeback.'' Zhelev denied the opposition is out to defeat the Communist Party. ``We are against the monopoly of the Communist Party, not against the party itself. In a law-abiding, democratic, multiparty state there will be room for the Commmunist Party and for all other political parties as well,'' he said. The reforms that coursed Eastern Europe last fall swept out Todor Zhivkov as Bulgaria's Communist ruler on Nov. 10 after 35 years in power.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Official: European Reforms Shouldn't Divert Development Aid
DOC.TEXT: Reforms in Eastern Europe should not divert aid from Third World countries and eventually could provide additional resources to underdeveloped nations, a U.N. official said Wednesday. Enrique ter Horst, assistant secretary-general for development and international economic cooperation, said at a news conference that changes in Eastern Europe are requiring large amounts of resources ``necessary for them to get out of their present quandry.'' But he said U.N. officials believe problems facing developing countries remain the most important concerns in efforts toward international economic development. ``It is to be expected, since these countries do have a large pool of well-trained professionals and technicians, that they should be on their feet economically speaking relatively quickly,'' the U.N. official said of the Eastern European nations. ``We hope that they will be able also to provide markets for commodities from developing countries ... and also join the Western developed countries in providing official development assistance for countries, mainly in Africa, which need it.'' A U.N. report on economic development released Wednesday said world economic growth and the average increase in per capita income in the 1980s were the lowest in three decades. According to the report, developing countries have suffered the most because of the decline in growth, with many people there worse off in 1990 than they were in 1980. Some developing countries in Asia, however, achieved steady income increases the past decade. The report cited China and India, the two most populous low-income countries, as having improved their economic conditions during the 1980s. But many countries, particularly in Africa and Latin America, experienced a collapse in commodity prices the past decade while facing mounting indebtedness, inadequate funds from foreign sources and falling income levels, the report said. In addition, increased protectionism eroded trade for the developing countries, the report said. ``Particular attention should be given to commodity-dependent economies who are already under pressure as a result of their structural rigidities, debt-servicing difficulties and the inadequacy of development finance. International financial flows to developing countries are regarded as an important catalytic device in the development process,'' the report said. The United Nations will convene a special session on economic development on Feb. 26.

DOC.HEAD: Heavy Rain in the Mississippi Valley, Snow in the Midwest, Rain in the East
DOC.TEXT: Heavy rain doused the lower Mississippi Valley on Wednesday, snow fell from Michigan to the Dakotas and rain showers stretched from Texas to the East Coast and over the northern Pacific Coast. The showers and thunderstorms that began Tuesday and continued Wednesday dropped heavy rain on Louisiana and Mississippi. In 24 hours up to 6 a.m. CST, 2.11 inches of rain fell on Lake Charles, La., and 1.45 fell on McComb, Miss. Light snow or show showers fell from Upper Michigan to Nebraska and the Dakotas, and heavy snow was predicted through Thursday for southeastern Wisconsin and northwestern Illinois. Rain showers developing ahead of a cold front extended from eastern Texas to the southern Appalachians and the middle Atlantic Coast, with a few thunderstorms over eastern Texas and the central Gulf Coast states. Heavier rainfall during the six hours ending at noon CST included 1.46 inches in Meridian, Miss., 1.18 inches in Montgomery, Ala., and .94 inch in Jackson, Miss. Rain was expected to spread across the Tennessee Valley and the Northeast through Thursday. Flash flood watches were issued for much of southeastern Tennessee for Wednesday night and for eastern New York state for Thursday and Thursday night. Light rain showers also fell over New England. Fog lingered over some central California valleys early in the afternoon, but otherwise sunny skies prevailed across the southwestern quarter of the nation. Strong winds accompanied the rain showers on the northern Pacific Coast. Gale warnings were in effect for the Washington coast and much of the coast of Oregon. Strong winds also blew over parts of Southern California, much of the Great Plains, parts of Wyoming, western Pennsylvania and western New York state. The low for the Lower 48 states Wednesday morning was 6 degrees below zero in Truckee, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Struggling Latin Countries to Have Less Foreign Financing
With AM-UN-Economic Development
DOC.TEXT: Latin American countries will have to rely less on foreign borrowing as they try to rebuild their economies from the debt crisis of the 1980s, World Bank President Barber Conable said Wednesday. ``Except possibly in Eastern Europe, no group of nations is facing such a daunting task of reform and reconstruction'' as Latin America, Conable said in a speech at the Colegio de Mexico, a graduate school and think-tank. To recover, countries will have to shrink the size of government bureaucracies that expanded from the Fifties through last decade into financing, industry, infrastructure, social services and security _ as well as increasing their foreign borrowings, Conable said. ``We have learned from the experience of developing countries and socialist countries of Eastern Europe that excessively centralized economic management leads to such inefficiencies that ultimately economic development comes to a halt,'' he said. In Brazil today, he said, salaries of public employees and interest on the domestic debt take up 90 percent of public sector revenue, leaving little for investment or public services. The World Bank will continue to participate in Latin American development, he said, but countries should look to direct foreign private investment to replace some of the public borrowing. ``The channels for the flow of commercial capital to developing countries have been damaged by the debt crisis,'' he said. ``External capital will no longer flow in quantities and with the ease with which it was available in the '70s. And even if it did, developing countries should not borrow as they did in the '70s.'' Three Latin countries head the list of developing countries that owe foreign debtors the most _ Brazil, then Mexico and Argentina. He said Latin America and Africa had been most severely hit by the crisis. ``More developing countries have suffered reverses in the past decade than have experienced success.'' Conable called Mexico's economic reform program ``one of the most ambitious, courageous and determined'' recently undertaken by any country and said it could serve as an example for other Latin nations. To bring foreign and domestic debt under control and rein in runaway inflation, Mexico has reduced subsidies, lifted trade barriers and restrictions on foreign investment, begun selling off state-owned companies and is applying wage-and-price controls. On Feb. 4, the government plans to renegotiate about half of its $96 billion foreign debt that is held by commercial banks.

DOC.HEAD: Panicked Haitians Flee Downtown of Capital; Businessman Exiled
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with explanation of soldiers' downtown action, businessman exiled, CORRECTS identification of one man exiled from Rene Theodore to Max Bourjolly. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ An attempt by soldiers to clear up the capital's congested streets created confusion and panic Wednesday as motorists, pedestrians and peddlers fled the downtown commercial district. Shopkeepers rolled down their steel shutters and street hawkers bundled up their wares and vanished. By 4 p.m. the normally bustling downtown district was nearly empty, witnesses said. Police Lt. Jean Zamor said on state television Wednesday night that soldiers using loudspeakers told street vendors at an open-air market to get off the street by 3 p.m. because they were blocking traffic. Zamor said police acted in the community's interest and blamed the panic on ``ill-intentioned'' people. Rumors and confusion have spread and anxiety has risen since all independent radio stations ceased broadcasting local news reports Tuesday after the military government told them they could only broadcast officially approved news. Radio is the main source of news in impoverished Haiti. Also on Wednesday, armed plainclothes police placed prominent businessman Antoine Izmery on a commercial flight and sent him into exile to Miami, a relative said. Izmery arrived in Miami about 7:30 p.m. EST. The relative, who spoke on condition of anonymity, told The Associated Press two carloads of armed police escorted Izmery to planeside at Port-au-Prince International Airport and he was put on a Haiti Trans Air jet. Izmery, a major importer, was arrested Tuesday. He was a proponent of democracy, an executive member of the Chamber of Commerce and Industry and a vocal crtic of the military government of Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril. The U.S. State Department on Wednesday called ``outrageous and indefensible'' Haiti's expulsion of democratic opposition leaders and other measures to silence dissent. Avril's government declared a 30-day state of siege Saturday, beat and arrested dozens of opposition militants, and exiled seven prominent civic and political leaders and other critics after mystery gunmen killed an army colonel Friday night. The Chamber of Commerce and Industry denounced the crackdown in a statement Wednesday and urged Avril to ``appeal to reason,'' complaining, ``Rights are no longer protected.'' ``We are not politicians. We are businessmen and concerned citizens defending fundamental human rights,'' Chamber President Ludovic Louisdhon told The AP. ``Banishment is a crime against humanity.'' Critics accused Avril of using the killing of Col. Andre Neptune as an excuse to arrest and exile opponents and renege on his promise to hold free elections in October. More than 50 political leaders and militants were arrested over the weekend. Most said they were released after being beaten, but at least seven opponents were banished. Those exiled included prominent conservative Hubert de Ronceray; Dr. Louis Roy, considered the father of Haiti's constitution; Communist party deputy leader Max Bourjolly and leftist militants Abby Brun, Michel Legros and Max Montreuil.

DOC.HEAD: `Black Widow' Gets Permanent Stay
DOC.TEXT: Florida's ``Black Widow'' got a permanent stay from the state Supreme Court Wednesday, less than 20 hours before she was to die in the electric chair. The reprieve given to Judi Buenoano, condemned for the fatal poisoning of her husband 19 years ago, is good for the rest of her death warrant. The court said it will schedule briefs and arguments later this week. Only one woman has been executed in the United States since the U.S. Supreme Court reinstated the death penalty 13 years ago. In 1984, Velma Barfield died by injection in North Carolina for poisoning her boyfriend. Ms. Buenoano, nicknamed the ``Black Widow'' by prosecutors, was under her first death warrant. None of the 21 men electrocuted in Florida since the state reinstated capital punishment have died under a first warrant. It is up to Gov. Bob Martinez to decide whether a second warrant is signed, but he is not expected to act until the state Supreme Court decides whether to grant Ms. Buenoano a second trial. Attorneys for Ms. Buenoano filed a notice of appeal with the high court Wednesday morning after the Orlando judge who sentenced her to death in 1985 refused to stay the execution late Tuesday. Ms. Buenoano, 46, was sentenced to death for the murder of her husband, Air Force Sgt. James E. Goodyear, soon after he returned from service in Vietnam. Goodyear's body was exhumed more than a decade after his death when officials began investigating a car bombing in Pensacola. Ms. Buenoano was convicted of that 1983 bombing, in which she was accused of trying to kill boyfriend John Gentry after he stopped taking poison-filled vitamin capsules. The levels of arsenic examiners found in Goodyear's body indicated he had suffered chronic exposure to the poison. Ms. Buenoano changed her name to a Spanish approximation of Goodyear after her husband's death. Ms. Buenoano was also found guilty of killing her 19-year-old paralyzed son, Michael Goodyear, by pushing him overboard during a 1980 canoe trip. Ms. Buenoano received life sentences for both of those crimes. She is suspected, but has not been charged, of using arsenic to kill a common-law husband in Trinidad, Colo., in 1977. In each case, Ms. Buenoano collected or stood to collect thousands of dollars in life insurance benefits. Ms. Buenoano was transferred from her death row cell in Broward Correctional Institution west of Fort Lauderdale to a special ``death watch'' cell in Florida State Prison Monday, spokesman Bob Macmaster said Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Parliamentary Committee Approves Deadline Extension
DOC.TEXT: Parliament's foreign affairs committee approved a bill Wednesday calling for a six-month extension on the May deadline for the United States to dismantle its military installations in Greece. Under the terms of a defense accord that expired in December 1988, the United States has until May 21 to remove personnel, property and materiel from four major bases and several smaller installations unless a new agreement is reached. The proposed new deadline for dismantling the bases is Nov. 21. The full Parliament will debate the bill on Monday, state ET-1 television said. Representatives of the conservative and socialist parties on the Standing Committee for Foreign Affairs and Defense voted in favor of the extension requested by the United States so negotiations on a new defense pact could continue. The Communist-led Coalition of the Left and Progress, the third party supporting Premier Xenophon Zolotas' administration, voted against the bill. It was passed by a simple majority in the 50-member committee. The conservatives and socialists hold 276 seats in the 300-member Parliament. The Communists are opposed to the bases but have said they would not withdraw from the government if a law is passed postponing the bases' removal. The Zolotas administration was appointed after inconclusive general elections in November. New elections are slated for April, leaving the next government to determine the fate of the bases with the United States. A previous five-year Defense and Economic Cooperation Accord negotiated by the former socialist government and Washington expired in December 1988. It gave the United States 17 months to dismantle the bases if no new accord was reached. The bases were established in Greece in the mid-1950s. After 17 rounds of fruitless negotiations, Athens and Washington suspended talks before national elections last June. A short-lived coalition formed by the conservative and Communist parties after those elections put the issue on hold. The socialist government headed by former Premier Andreas Papandreou had demanded any new defense accord include guarantees of aid in case of aggression by NATO ally Turkey, which the United States has been wary of providing. Greece and Turkey nearly went to war in March 1987 over disputed territorial waters in the Aegean Sea.

DOC.HEAD: Diabetic Mother and Son Win Fight for Their Lives
DOC.TEXT: A diabetic woman who felt ``God had a purpose'' for the infant doctors wanted her to abort has taken her newborn home from the hospital _ but not before both fought a battle for their lives. Deborah Jennings, 22, was warned at an early age never to have children. When she became pregnant, doctors urged her for the sake of her health to abort the baby. ``The doctors wanted me to get rid of it,'' she said Tuesday as she and her 8-pound, 9-ounce son, Billy O'Neal, prepared to leave Spartanburg Regional Medical Center. ``I told them that God had a purpose for this baby.'' Diabetic women are more likely than non-diabetic women to give birth to babies that are stillborn, suffer deformities or weigh less, said hosptial spokeswoman Debbie Dalhouse. Also, pregnancy puts a great deal of stress on a diabetic woman, her insulin level may fluctuate widely, and she is more likely to suffer complications during pregnancy and delivery. During Miss Jennings' pregnancy, she was hospitalized six times, once for more than two weeks. When she went into labor Jan. 16, some amniotic fluid escaped and blocked one of her blood vessels, resulting in cardiac arrest. Her heart stopped for four minutes. As one team of doctors worked to resuscitate Miss Jennings, another delivered the baby by Cesarean section. The medical staff forced oxygen into the infant's lungs for five minutes until the baby began breathing on his own. Although Miss Jennings's heart eventually began beating again, the new mother lay in a coma, suspended between life and death. Doctors didn't give the family much hope. ``They told us if she didn't respond in 48 hours, she would never respond,'' said Betty Jennings, Miss Jennings' mother. For Miss Jennings, the two days were a nightmare. From within her motionless body she could feel and hear, even see, but she could not respond. ``I could hear everybody talking,'' she said. ``You could hear what they were saying, but you couldn't respond. No matter what you did, you couldn't respond.'' Throughout the ordeal, nurses would ask Miss Jennings to show some sign of life _ squeeze a hand, raise an eyebrow, respond in some way. Inside, Miss Jennings said, ``I was squeezing her hand, talking to her, hollering at her, but it wasn't coming out. I was scared that they were going to bury me alive because I wasn't responding the way they wanted me to.'' A day after the delivery, a nurse came in with her newborn, Billy. ```Debbie, look, here's your little boy,''' Miss Jennings recalled her saying. ``I started crying. I thought, `That's my little man.''' Then came the moment when Miss Jennings realized how close she was to death. A cousin _ a Baptist preacher _ had come in to the room and knelt beside the woman to pray with her. ``I felt a part of my body leave me,'' Miss Jennings said. ``It was like a shield being over me. It's like the Lord held out his arms for me.'' But Miss Jennings fought to stay alive. ``I'm not a person to let go easily,'' she said. On Jan. 18, a nurse was telling Miss Jennings just how beautiful Billy was. As in the past, the nurse asked the young woman to signal if she could hear. This time, Miss Jennings raised her eyebrows. ``When I saw her I felt such a relief,'' Mrs. Jennings said of her first visit with her daughter after she had awakened. ``My heart was so full it felt like it would burst.'' By that afternoon, Miss Jennings was off her ventilator. On Saturday, she was transferred to the obstetrics unit. Billy was transferred on Monday out of the neonatal intensive care unit _ where doctors had stabilized his blood sugar levels _ into the regular baby nursery. Around the halls of Spartanburg Regional, the medical staff refer to Miss Jennings and Billy as ``our two little miracles,'' head nurse Cathy Askew said. Holding her alert, black-haired son, Miss Jennings said Billy is worth the hardship, but she won't have another child. ``Now I'm able to go home and take care of my little one,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Government Says It Will Permit Relief Airlift to South Sudan
DOC.TEXT: The government said Wednesday it will allow international relief organizations to airlift food supplies to war-ravaged areas of southern Sudan. Information Minister Ali Shummo said the government had authorized relief organizations to airlift 5,000 tons of food donated by the European Economic Community from Nairobi, Kenya, to Juba, the capital of south Sudan. He said the government has also given permission to the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) to airlift relief supplies to government-held Juba and areas controlled by the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army. ``The concerned authorities have authorized the ICRC to ferry reief materials to Juba area and even to those areas where the rebels are present if it (the ICRC) wanted to do so,'' Shummo said in a statement distributed by the official Sudan News Agency. The government suspended relief flights to south Sudan last August to guarantee the safety of relief workers after the collapse of a cease-fire in fighting between the government and rebel forces that took up arms in 1983 to demand greater autonomy and economic reforms. Shummo said preparations are underway to move a trainload of 1,500 tons of sorghum from Muglad in the south to Aweil in the Bahr Al Ghazal region. He said the relief train will operate flying the U.N. flag and will distribute part of its supplies at rebel-held areas. In New York, a U.N. official familiar with relief operations in south Sudan said meanwhile that heightened fighting in the region is interrupting attempts to move in supplies that agencies expect will be needed by June. He stressed that famine conditions haven't developed there yet. But relief workers want to have the supplies in place before the rainy season, which would prevent moving them when they will be needed. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Sudan could face the same kind of famine situation it encountered in 1987 and 1988, which resulted in the deaths of hundreds of thousands of people. However, a spokesman for the U.S. Agency for International Development said workers in Sudan had not received reports that movement of relief supplies had been interrupted by fighting.

DOC.HEAD: Five Officers Indicted in Separate Drug Cases
DOC.TEXT: A federal indictment Wednesday charged three police officers and four other men with robbing more than $1 million in cash, 110 pounds of cocaine and a ton of marijuana from drug dealers. A separate indictment charged two other officers in a cocaine case. The cases mark the widest-ranging police corruption indictments since 15 Miami police officers were charged in a drug-ripoff ring in 1984 and 1985. U.S. Attorney Dexter Lehtinen, speaking at a news conference after the indictments were unsealed, said the defendants arranged for the transfer of honest officers to other assignments as they engaged in ripping off drug dealers of cash, cocaine and marijuana between 1981 and 1987. ``They would come into the possession of information about where drug dealers were, where illegal drugs were, and should have engaged in proper law enforcement activities,'' Lehtinen said. ``Instead they would steal the drugs, engage in what in the street might be called a ripoff and subsequently resell those drugs,'' he said. Some of the ripoffs were allegedly committed by officers serving search warrants and others during traffic stops. A list of 39 acts mentioned thefts of $415,000 cash from a Dade County home in late 1982, $25,000 cash and $15,000 cash. The indictment alleges the men stole a total of $1.09 million, more than 50 kilos of cocaine and 2,000 pounds of marijuana while the ring was in operation. One of the officers, Ernesto Sanchoyerto, was convicted in 1989 for stealing drugs during a traffic stop and is now serving a 17-year federal prison term. Sanchoyerto, a former sheriff's deputy, faces another 50 years in jail if convicted on Wednesday's indictments. Also named in the indictment were Maj. Roberto Gonzalez, a department chief; his brother Detective Jose Gonzalez; and Detective Mario Beovides. Three businessmen, one of whom also was a former sheriff's deputy, were also named. The officers and businessmen face maximum sentences from 30 years to life in jail, and fines of $250,000 to $4.5 million, if convicted. Another grand jury indictment charged patrolman Edward Orrett with conspiracy and intent to distribute cocaine. His brother, Detective Charles Orrett, was charged with attempting to possess five kilos of cocaine.

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Students: Override Is More Than Symbol, It Is Protection
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 2nd to UPDATE with House vote to override.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Congress-China, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Chinese students in exile watched Wednesday's showdown between President Bush and Congress over legislation concerning their asylum here, arguing the bill offers extra protection they need. ``People here want to make sure they stay here safely,'' said An Wei, a Chinese national who works at the Chinese Student Information Center in Newton. Many students were anxious about the prospect of being sent back to China, where they faced probable political reprisals, he said. The House voted 390-25 Wednesday to override Bush's veto of a measure eliminating requirements that Chinese students return to their homeland before applying for a new U.S. visa. The matter now moves to the Senate, where a scheduled Thursday vote is expected to be a cliffhanger. Pei Min Xin, who was a leader of the pro-democracy protests in Beijing last spring, said he has learned that his name is on a blacklist in China. If he was forced to return, he would face life imprisonment or execution, said Pei. He said he felt disillusioned by the president's actions regarding China, which has included sending two advisers there in the past year. ``How can the leader of the United States be so accommodating to people back in our own country, who tried to kill us all off, to stamp out our legitimate demands for political change?'' said Pei, a Harvard University graduate student in government. By trying to not offend the current regime, Bush also was putting America behind a losing bet, he said. ``It is unlikely that regime will survive five years from now,'' Pei said. ``I can predict that 20 years from now people like us will be running the Chinese government. Are you going to deal with people in power now, or the future leaders?'' Pei holds a visa common to many of the students who fled to the United States after the Chinese government cracked down on the pro-democracy movement in Tiananmen Square in June. Under the visa's requirements, bearers must return to China when their visas expire and live there for two years before they can apply for a new one. President Bush said the bill to eliminate that requirement, which he vetoed in November, was unnecessary because he had signed an administrative order allowing Chinese students to stay in the United States. Bush also said the measure could damage U.S. relations with China, which has condemned the legislation. Chinese students said the override was crucial because an administrative order was not as solid as a law. The process of revoking an order is easier, and could happen at any time if the situation changes, they said. ``People would feel a lot more secure if they're staying here because of a law,'' An said. Even those students who were not a part of the democracy movement would come under suspicion in China because of their Western education, said An, who came to the United States in 1985. Pei said Bush made a mistake of moral and strategic importance when he urged lawmakers to sustain his veto and vote against the override. He was disappointed and saddened by the president's actions, Pei said. ``We invest a great deal of hope in the American system of government, in its ideals, in human rights, and now we are being taught a very cruel and cynical lesson,'' Pei said. ``The leaders of a great democracy are viewing other interests as more important than ideals.''

DOC.HEAD: Defense Minister Resigns in Dispute with Army Chief
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with three grafs to UPDATE with successor named. Picks up 3rd pvs, `Analysts said...'
DOC.TEXT: Defense Minister Italo Luder resigned Wednesday because President Carlos Menem sided with the army chief of staff in a dispute over whether the general bypassed Luder's authority. ``I gave the president my undeclinable resignation'' the 73-year-old lawyer and career politician told reporters. Humberto Romero, a former aide to Menem who resigned six months ago and is an elected member of the national assembly, was named new defense minister, presidential spokesman Humberto Toledo said late Wednesday. Romero will assume office Friday, Toledo said. Analysts said Luder's resignation was more a reflection of his poor standing with Menem than of problems within the armed forces. He was the unsuccessful Peronist candidate for president in 1983 and backed Menem's opponent in the party primary last year. After Menem won the presidency in May and Luder became defense minister, he was forced to accept Gen. Isidro Caceres as army chief instead of the general he wanted. ``Luder never has been close to Menem and he has never gotten along particularly well with Caceres,'' Rosendo Fraga, director of a center-right think tank, said in an interview. His departure illustrates the fragility of the alliance Menem is building for his program of selling money-losing state companies, deregulation, tax reform and encouraging foreign investment at a time of recession, high unemployment and double-digit monthly inflation. Four of Menem's Cabinet ministers have quit or been moved to other departments in five weeks. Since the president took office in July, the Central Bank has had four presidents and various policies on exchange rates, the money supply and subsidies to private businesses. Trouble began at the Defense Ministry with a dinner Caceres gave at an army base for Menem, new Interior Minister Julio Mera Figueroa and Juan Yofre, chief of the government intelligence service. Because he was not invited, Luder felt he was being bypassed in the chain of command. ``I was in the city (but) I was not informed about the dinner,'' he said in comments broadcast by Radio Mitre, and Caceres' failure to invite him ``merits punishment.'' Neither Luder nor Menem disclosed the punishment chosen, but merely the fact of its being ordered by the defense minister would have forced Caceres to retire. Menem told reporters Wednesday: ``I think Dr. Luder did not have full knowledge of the facts. ``I don't want to hurt the feelings of Dr. Luder, but it seems to me inappropriate that the president and commander in chief of the armed forces learns about such a sanction through the media.'' Any question involving the military is sensitive in this South American country, which has suffered six coups since 1930. The 50,000-man army is the strongest branch and wields influence on a level with the Roman Catholic church, labor and organizations of farmers, ranchers, businessmen and banks. Menem's predecessor, Raul Alfonsin of the Radical Civic Union, had to put down three barracks mutinies that threatened the return to democracy that began with his election victory over Luder in 1983. Menem, 59, tried for national reconciliation in October by pardoning dozens of officers still facing trial for human rights abuses in the last dictatorship, along with alleged leftist subversives and about 200 army rebels. In recent weeks, Caceras noted poor military pay _ an army private earns about $42 a month _ and recommended the release from prison of four former commanders of military juntas that ruled Argentina in 1976-83. Jorge Videla and Roberto Viola, generals who were junta presidents, were convicted of committing rights abuses during the ``dirty war'' against leftists, in which at least 8,960 people disappeared and were presumed killed. Menem excluded them from his pardon, along with two other officers convicted at the same time and Mario Firmenich, the Montonero guerrilla leader who was convicted of murder and is serving 30 years in prison.

DOC.HEAD: President of North Yemen Visits Bush, Urges Recognize PLO
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 4th graf pvs `I look ... ' to UPDATE with toasts at state dinner. Picks up 5th graf pvs `The White ...'
DOC.TEXT: The president of North Yemen on Wednesday called on President Bush to urge Israel to allow self-determination for the Palestinians living in occupied Israeli territory. ``You are fully aware of the suffering of Palestinians who wish to see an end to occupation and to live free on their land,'' President Ali Abdullah Saleh said in arrival remarks with President Bush on the White House South Lawn. Both Bush and Saleh expressed hopes about the prospects for the decade-old move to unify North Yemen with Marxist South Yemen. ``I look forward to receiving President Saleh's views on ... the prospects for improving relations between the two Yemens and the importance of these developments for regional peace and stability,'' Bush said in welcoming Saleh, the first North Yemini president to visit Washington. Later, at a state dinner, Bush called Saleh's visit ``an opportunity to assure you of America's commitment to security in the Middle East and to the pursuit of a just and lasting peace in the region.'' Bush, who visited North Yemen in 1986 as vice president, praised Saleh as ``a man of extraordinary accomplishment'' who ``has led his country at a time of great economic progress and is responsible for Yemen's growing role in Middle Eastern affairs.'' Saleh said he hoped ``to establish closer linkage between the very ancient in our country and the most modern in yours.'' The White House said the two presidents in their private meeting agreed to work for a solution to Middle East peace and discussed efforts to reunify North and South Yemen, as well as the situation in Afghanistan ``and our shared support for self-deterination for the Afghan people.'' Calling the United States ``a nation which advocates with conviction the respect of human rights throughout the world,'' Saleh said he wanted to remind Americans ``about the fate of the rights of Palestinian Arabs and their occupied territory,'' which has been under Israeli control since the 1967 Six Day War. ``Despite all the suffering, we trust that the United States of America ... will be able to convince the Israelis to accept peace initiatives and to abide by international decisions which give the Palestinians the right to self-determination under the leadership of their sole and legitimate representative, the Palestine Liberation Organization,'' he said in his arrival remarks. The United States does not recognize the PLO as the sole representative of the Palestinians and only agreed to talk to PLO officials in the last two years. Saleh also told Bush that his country is working on unification with South Yemen ``in a democratic and peaceful way.'' He was expected to press Bush during their private meeting to restore relations with South Yemen, a Soviet ally. Recent reforms in South Yemen revived the effort to unify north and south, with the two countries agreeing this week to prepare a joint constitution for a referendum by Nov. 30. U.S. officials have said the administration is considering restoring diplomatic ties with South Yemen, which is one of six countries under U.S. economic boycott for their support of international terrorism. The others are Libya, Cuba, North Korea, Syria and Iran. Washington has had diplomatic relations with North Yemen since 1946, and has provided large amounts of development aid and military assistance. South Yemen, a British protectorate until it gained independence in 1967, broke with the United States when it aligned with Moscow. Located at the tip of the Red Sea, it became a major facility for Soviet naval units in the Indian Ocean. U.S. Ambassador Thomas Pickering met with the representative of South Yemen at the United Nations several times last fall to discuss renewing relations, a U.S. official, speaking on condition of anonyity, told reporters.

DOC.HEAD: Arthur Miller Accuses Theater in U.S. of Being Superficial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 4 with correct name of play `The Price.' Picks up 5th, `The issue...'
DOC.TEXT: Playwright Arthur Miller, in London for rehearsals of his play ``The Price'' that opens next month, accused U.S. theater Wednesday of being superficial. Contrasting unsubsidized theater in the United States with the state-aided British theater, Miller said American theater has often degenerated into a search for titillating ways to fill unsubsidized and expensive seats. ``Theaters in the States are finding it very difficult to continue because they feel they have got to constantly excite audiences in a most superficial way,'' the 74-year-old playwright told reporters. Speaking during a break in rehearsals for ``The Price'' at the Young Vic theater, he said standards in British theater could fall if subsidies were reduced or stopped. The issue is a hot topic in Britain, where Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's government is accused by critics of starving state-aided theaters and other arts of sufficient public funding. Her Conservative government favors funding of the arts by private business sponsorship. Miller, one of America's best known playwrights with works like ``Death of a Salesman'' and ``The Crucible,'' said: ``In Britain, the only reason you have not gone up the flue is that there are some subsidies for major theaters in many parts of the country. If that stops or goes down sufficiently you will be thrown on to the market and that cannot support theater because costs are too high.'' He said unsubsidized American seat prices made an evening at the theater so expensive that general audiences would not go unless a critic said the production was a masterpiece, even if the critic was wrong. Miller said that meant theater audiences in the United States have become a self-serving clique and that the plays appear tailored to match the audience. ``If the British cease or cut down subsidies you are going to lose everything and the first thing will be American tourists who come here (to London) to see subsidized theater and then go home and vote against it,'' he said. Referring to Czechoslovakia's new president, former imprisoned dissident and playwright Vaclav Havel, Miller said: ``The final resistance to tyranny is culture. It is the writer who cannot give up his art who shows the regime for what it is. ``By some miracle, that is exactly what has happened in Czechoslovakia where a writer, of all things, generated the resistance with his irreconcilability to the lies the (former Communist) system stood on.'' Havel was named president last month by parliament in Prague.

DOC.HEAD: Cambodian Prince Again Quits as Resistance Chief
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS four grafs to UPDATE with relief officials saying Khmer Rouge moving refugees to border, sted U.N. camps.
DOC.TEXT: Prince Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia said Wednesday he was quitting again as head of the resistance coalition battling Cambodia's Vietnamese-backed government. The exiled chief of state said his resignation is in protest of foreign accusations that he is an accomplice in the Communist Khmer Rouge's drive to regain power in Cambodia. Disputes with his coalition partners caused him to step down several times before. He said he would stop meeting with most foreign diplomats and reporters and would not attend any international conferences on the Cambodian situation. Sihanouk said he will run for president if a political situation is worked out and general elections are held. Sihanouk, a non-Communist, has headed a resistance coalition that also includes the Communist Khmer Rouge and the non-Communist Khmer People's National Liberation Front. The Khmer Rouge, which conducted a reign of terror in Cambodia from 1975 until early 1979 in which 1 million people died, when it was ousted by Vietnam, is militarily the strongest of the three factions. The Khmer Rouge has claimed major battle victories since September, when Vietnam said it pulled the last of its troops from Cambodia. The victories have raised fears the Khmer Rouge could rule again. Sihanouk always had an uneasy relationship with the Khmer Rouge but insisted that the only way to contain the group was to include it in any political settlement. In his statement, Sihanouk said he would retain the title of chief of state of Cambodia that he held before being ousted in a 1970 coup led by the U.S.-backed Lon Nol. He said the Lon Nol government was illegal and thus his old title is still in effect. He said that after several scheduled appointments over the next few weeks he will stop meeting all foreign officials, diplomats and journalists. The exceptions are to be his ``friends'' from China and North Korea, the two countries where he lives most of the year. In his statement, Sinhanouk said without elaborating that ``certain governments of the free world'' in addition to journalists, intellectuals and parliamentarians ``have decided to attack me and accuse me of complicity with the Khmer Rouge.'' He did not defend his alliance with the group. Sihanouk is still widely revered in his homeland and is believed to be the one person who could hold the country together. Sihanouk has given qualified support to an Australian proposal to dismantle both the resistance and the Vietnam-installed government and set up an interim U.N. administration to run the country and prepare for a general election. In another development, a U.N. official said Wednesday that Khmer Rouge guerrillas moved nearly all the refugees from a United Nations-aided Borai camp toward the Thai-Cambodian border, closer to the fighting. The Communist fighters apparently wanted to prevent U.N. officials from transferring them to nearby Site K, a new camp that is safer and has better medical and other services but is not Khmer Rouge-controlled. Only about 200 refugees remained at Borai Wednesday afternoon, said Patrick Van de Velde, deputy director of the U.N. Border Relief Operation, after a visit there. Borai originally housed up to 4,500 people, but three-fourths of them have been moved toward the border since Jan. 15, said an aid official, speaking on condition of anonymity.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Threatens Legal Action Against American Heart Association
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS grafs 6-13, bgn `Vicki Anderson...,' to move up reference to products that are affected by the first phase of the program. Picks up 14th graf pvs, `The makers...'
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration threatened legal action Wednesday against an American Heart Association food labeling program it said could mislead consumers, but the heart association decided to go ahead with the the program. The FDA said in a letter that the food labeling program could be ``risking regulatory action.'' It said there is a ``very real possibility that the FDA would find one or more foods under your program to be misbranded,'' meaning they might carry misleading labels. The program, known as Heartguide, is an ambitious effort by the heart association to make consumers smarter shoppers by identifying products low in saturated fat, total fat, cholesterol and sodium. Products tested and approved by the association, for a fee, would carry a symbol made up of a red heart and a check mark. The FDA has authority to act only after products go on sale. It can then require that companies change labels. The agency can also block the sale of improperly labeled items or seize them, said Jeff Nesbit, an FDA spokesman. Vicki Anderson, a spokeswoman for Heartguide, said the program, scheduled to begin officially Monday, has been under development for three years. It has been discussed with the FDA throughout the past year, she said. ``We were expecting a letter from the FDA, but we did not anticipate this,'' she said. Heartguide officials thought the FDA would take a neutral stance on the program, ``not one where they would exercise their regulatory jurisdiction.'' The heart association, however, is proceeding with its launch of the program Monday. ``We've already talked to the companies'' participating in the program, and ``they are in,'' said another Heartguide spokeswoman, Jamy Poth. More than 100 brands of margarine, oil, crackers and vegetables already have been tested and approved. They include Mazola corn oil, Promise margarine, Pam cooking sprays, Melba Toast and Hanover frozen vegetables. However, the next phase of the program, in which cereals, cheese, cookies, pasta, salad dressings and other foods will be included, has been put on hold while the heart association negotiates further with the FDA, Anderson said. None of the labeled products in the first phase is currently available on the shelves. Anderson said manufacturers had begun printing containers with the labels, but that products were not yet ready for shipment to supermarkets. ``We all knew that something was coming'' from the FDA, said John Cady, president of the National Food Processors Association, which has vigorously opposed the program. ``What we see here is a realization by the government agencies that you have a nonprofit, private organization, a nonregulated organization, trying to establish a set of rules and regulations on labeling _ for a fee. I think that's wrong.'' The makers of Mazola products said they had not yet decided how to react to the FDA's action, said Gail Griffin, spokeswoman for CPC International of Englewood Cliffs, N.J. That is the parent company of Best Foods, which makes Mazola. The FDA's letter was addressed to heart association President Dr. Myron L. Weisfeldt of Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore. Acting Commissioner James S. Benson wrote that the Heartguide program could ``increase consumer confusion and hamper any comprehensive solution to the food labeling problem.'' He invited the heart association ``instead to join with the FDA and other groups in our current initiative to develop a comprehensive revision of the food label to promote good nutrition. ...'' Weisfeldt said in a statement, ``On behalf of the 2.7 million AHA volunteers across the United States, I want to say we are deeply disappointed by Mr. Benson's letter, particularly since it has come just a few days before our program was to begin.'' But, he said, ``I would like to emphasize that we are not closing down the Heartguide program.'' The program has been controversial from its inception. The National Food Processors Association has opposed the program on the grounds that it charges a hefty fee _ up to $640,000, depending upon a product's sales _ and that competitive pressures make it difficult for eligible companies to refuse to join. ``It also opens the door to similar programs by other groups who want to charge money to food processors for getting their endorsement,'' said Ellen Morton, a spokeswoman. The program has also been criticized on the grounds that it promotes certain foods instead of promoting the idea of a healthy overall diet. The heart association said its educational program will make clear that Heartguide-approved foods should be incorporated into a diet that is beneficial overall.

DOC.HEAD: Industry Says Government Will Suspend Below-Cost Timber Sales
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf pvs `Barry Bolsky ...' to CORRECT name to Polsky
DOC.TEXT: An industry spokesman said Wednesday that President Bush has decided to suspend below-cost timber sales from 10 national forests in the fiscal year that will begin Oct. 1. Barry Polsky of the American Forest Resource Alliance, which includes timber companies, sawmills and other enterprises, said the shutdown will be announced in Bush's budget proposals sent to Congress next week. A spokewoman for Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter, who was out of town, referred the question to Agriculture Department budget director Stephen B. Dewhurst, who declined comment. Polsky said the 10 forests in fiscal 1988 harvested 262 million board feet of timber and provided about 3,000 jobs. Local communities received $59.8 million as their share of federal revenue from the timber sales. Polsky, in a telephone interview, said that ``preservationists want to stop timber sales'' of all kinds and have been partially successful in limited areas where protected species of animals exist. ``In some forests, they can't find a species to protect, so they've gone after forests that sell timber below costs,'' he said. Admittedly, Polsky added, some forests do sell cut-rate timber, but there's no federal rule against that and national forests, on the average, do make money for taxpayers. But below-cost timber sales are losing practices in specific forests, so there has been pressure to end the practice, he said. Polsky identified 10 national forests which tentatively have been earmarked for terminated timber sales: _Montana, Beaverhead. _Colorado, Arapaho-Roosevelt, Pike-San Isabel and White River. _Illinois, Shawnee. _Indiana, Hoosier. _Ohio, Wayne. _Virginia, George Washington. _Tennessee, Cherokee. _Georgia, Chattahoochee-Oconee.

DOC.HEAD: Japan to Deport 378 Chinese Who Posed as Vietnamese Refugees
DOC.TEXT: Japan will deport 378 more Chinese who entered the country posing as Vietnamese refugees, bringing to 679 the number to be returned involuntarily to China, the Justice Ministry said Wednesday. Yoshinori Sato, an official of the Immigration Bureau at the Justice Ministry, said the Chinese to be deported are among 2,804 boat people who made their way to Japan in 22 landings last year. The government has determined that about 2,000 are Chinese, Sato said. Other officials indicated the government intends to deport all 2,000 as soon as it can work out details with the Chinese authorities. The government has said the Chinese boat people were only seeking economic opportunities. Sato declined to specify when the 378 will be deported. On Dec. 21, Japan deported 301 Chinese who had been classified as illegal entrants after arriving in Nagasaki from China's Fujian province posing as Vietnamese refugees. Japan began screening boat people in September. It has accepted 4,425 refugees from Vietnam since 1978, whom it deemed to be fleeing political persecution.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Voices Support for Gorbachev Facing `Enormous' Unrest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 4th graf pvs `Bush conceded ...' to UPDATE with Bush, Sununu quotes on Thursday's Senate vote. Picks up 5th graf pvs `Earlier Wednesday ...'
DOC.TEXT: President Bush expressed hope Wednesday that Mikhail S. Gorbachev ``not only survives but stays strong'' in the face of ``enormous'' problems. He declined comment on whether the Soviet leader has gone too far in trying to quell civil strife in Azerbaijan. ``Anytime you have a use of force and the loss of life, we are concerned. But I don't believe I can judge that question right now,'' said Bush of the Soviet crackdown on rioting in the largely Moslem Soviet republic. The president, at a news conference, also announced support for elevating the Environmental Protection Agency to the Cabinet, castigated a ``sleight-of-hand'' plan to cut Social Security taxes and mounted a last-ditch effort to prevent an override of his veto of a bill protecting Chinese students from deportation. Bush conceded it was too late to prevent the House from voting to override the veto _ as it did, 390-25, late Wednesday. He rested his hopes on the Senate in trying to avoid the first override in 10 vetoes. ``We've got a fighting chance,'' Bush said Wednesday night at a state dinner for the president of North Yemen. Chief of Staff John Sununu predicted that the Senate vote would be close. ``You never know until it happens,'' he said. Earlier Wednesday, Bush argued his case on the China veto to GOP senators over breakfast at the White House. Later, after a meeting there on the EPA, three Republican senators _ John Chafee of Rhode Island, John Warner of Virginia and David Durenberger of Minnesota _ predicted the Senate would sustain Bush's China veto. Asked if Bush already had the 34 votes needed, Warner said, ``We're closing the gap on that question right now.'' Bush also presided at a full-dress military welcome for the president of North Yemen, Ali Abdullah Saleh, and hailed him as ``a man of extraordinary accomplishment'' at a state dinner. Saleh urged Bush to prod Israel to give Palestinians in the occupied territories the right of self-determination. Bush assured his guest of America's commitment ``to security in the Middle East and to the pursuit of a just and lasting peace.'' Gorbachev ordered thousands of Soviet troops into Azerbaijan last week to stop anti-Armenian rioting and restore order. The military killed dozens of people Saturday in storming the capital city of Baku. After 11 days of violence, the official death toll stood at 170. With the strife in Azerbaijan and demands for independence from the Baltic states of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia, Bush said Gorbachev is ``faced with an ethnic problem here and an internal problem of enormous dimensions.'' Bush said he ``can't make predictions'' about Gorbachev's chances of surviving the challenges, but added: ``I hope he not only survives but stays strong. Because I think it is in our interest that perestroika succeed and go forward.'' The United States regards the Soviet Union's annexation of the Baltic states a half-century ago as illegal, and Bush said he and Gorbachev discussed the U.S. position at last month's Malta summit. But he said he did not want ``to fine-tune all that,'' emphasizing instead that what ``we want to do is to encourage Mr. Gorbachev's stand that peaceful change is the order of the day.'' Bush bristled at the prospect of his veto on the Chinese-students bill being overridden. ``One of the criticisms that gets to me a little ... is the idea that I don't care about human rights. That is absolutely ridiculous,'' said the president. ``Not one'' student was sent back to China after last June's government crackdown on demonstrators, he said. ``They were safe then and they are safe now and they will be safe in the future.'' He attributed the strong sentiment in Congress to override the veto both to persuasive lobbying by the students and ``crass politics'' by lawmakers eager to hand him a defeat. He said China took a ``gigantic step back'' last year on human rights. But the onetime China envoy said, ``I think I know enough about it that in China you get a couple of steps forward and then somebody steps back.'' Suggesting China may shut the door to future exchanges, Bush said, ``The bill is totally unnecessary, the long-term policy consequences are potentially great and Congress, in my view, will have only itself to blame.'' On other topics, Bush: _Called Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan's idea of a rollback in the Social Security tax ``a disguise for increased taxes around the corner.'' He called it ``odd that a Republican president ... is the one that is protecting the sanctity of the Social Security benefits.'' But Bush also said a proposal by conservative House Republicans to allow workers to shift part of their payroll taxes into private retirement accounts ``has some interesting ingredients'' and is worthy of study. _Said he ``can't confirm'' reports of deep division within the Bush family on abortion, denying a magazine account that disagreement surfaced at a family meeting but stopping short of saying there is no such division. _Said he wants the EPA in his Cabinet because of the magnitude of environmental problems confronting the United States and the world. _Offered a polite no-thank-you to Czechoslovakia President Vaclav Havel's offer to have the next Bush-Gorbachev summit in Prague instead of the United States. But Bush said, ``I was rather moved by the suggestion.'' _Said he had not decided how much aid to help ``repair the wounds'' in Panama from last month's U.S. invasion. _Said the new budget, due Monday, will include ``our plan to restructure America's defenses in the wake of the dramatic changes that are taking place abroad.''

DOC.HEAD: Miami Policeman Sentenced In Manslaughter Deaths That Led To Riots
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT that Lozano is 30, sted 31.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto XMH2
DOC.TEXT: A police officer was sentenced Wednesday to seven years in prison for the deaths of two black men in an incident that ignited three days of racial violence a year ago. William Lozano, 30, was convicted last month on two counts of manslaughter for fatally shooting an unarmed black motorcyclist on a street in the Overtown section, sending the vehicle crashing into a car and killing the motorcycle's passenger. ``This court cannot do perfect justice in this case,'' said Dade Circuit Judge Joseph Farina, who called the deaths and resultant trial a ``tragic incident.'' The Colombian-born officer showed little reaction as the judge read the sentence, but his supporters cheered when Farina said the officer could remain free on $10,000 bond pending appeals. The Jan. 16, 1989, deaths led to the city's fourth round of racial unrest in the 1980s, all linked to the killings of blacks by white officers. In two of those cases, acquittals of the policemen had sparked racial violence, and police braced for renewed rioting as Lozano's trial neared an end last month. But on Dec. 7, a racially mixed jury convicted Lozano. Police said the city was quiet after Wednesday's sentencing. ``Everything is good, there's no disturbance, no nothing,'' said police spokesman George Law. After the sentence, Lozano stared briefly at lead prosecutor John Hogan, but said nothing. Lozano thanked his supporters at a news conference later and predicted he would be vindicated through appeal. ``My attorney, my family and I will continue to fight within the system for what is right, and at the end, I will win,'' he said. Outside the courtroom, Patricia Lloyd, sister of slain motorcyclist Clement Lloyd, 23, said only: ``I wish it had been longer.'' Ray Fauntroy, head of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference here, said he was disappointed with the sentence. Blacks ``get seven years just for stealing a loaf of bread,'' Fauntroy said. ``This officer was just given a pat on the back. He'll be out in two or three years. Hogan, who had recommended a 12-year sentence, said he was satisfied. ``It's a just sentence,'' he said. Lozano could have faced a punishment of 12 to 17 years under state sentencing guidelines. Lozano and his attorneys left by a back door and did not immediately speak to waiting reporters. But mostly Hispanic supporters clapped as they filed out of the courtroom. The convicted officer's mother, Haydee Lozano, recounted the family's struggles in the United States and said her son worked from the time he was 9 to help the family. ``We are not people to destroy, but unite,'' she said through a translator. ``Leave my son free.'' Defense attorneys from the beginning bitterly criticized the case as an effort to ease racial tensions in Miami rather than give their client a fair trial. ``If Officer Lozano was black, he never would have been charged with a crime. If the two people on the motorcycle were white, he never would have been charged with a crime,'' defense attorney Mark Seiden told the judge. Earlier, the judge turned aside defense efforts to force a retrial, dismissing their arguments that the case was replete with mistakes. Defense attorney Roy Black said the judge had unfairly prevented the defense from challenging a black union official during jury selection and he said the atmosphere of violence surrounding the case should have persuaded the judge to move the trial out of tense Miami. Before the sentencing, Lloyd's mother called for justice for her son. Adina Lloyd praised the conduct of the trial and told the judge to use his conscience. But at one point she turned to Lozano and said: ``If it was my son that did it to him, my son would be behind bars now.'' Lozano shot and killed Lloyd as he fled from a police car pursuing him for running a stop sign. Lloyd's passenger, Allan Blanchard, 24, died of injuries suffered when the motorcycle crashed. Ellis Rubin, attorney for Blanchard's family, called the trial a turning point for the community. ``For too long in Dade County Florida, the black minority has felt ignored, felt frustrated, felt there was no equal justice under the law,'' Rubin said. But he said a ``spark was lit'' by the Lozano verdict, telling the judge ``we ask you not to douse that spark of justice.'' Police spokesman Sgt. David Rivero described the sentence as average for someone convicted of manslaughter. ``This is a democratic system, and we (police officers) have to accept that,'' he said of the sentence.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Preparing $1 Billion in Panama Aid
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top three grafs rewritten into four grafs with second official and his comment
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is preparing to propose an aid program for Panama totaling more than $1 billion to help the country recover from recent warfare and long years of corrupt military rule, U.S. officials said Wednesday night. Congressional leaders were briefed on the program Wednesday and a formal announcement is expected Thursday, said one official, asking not to be identified. A second senior official, confirming the amount on condition of anonymity, cautioned, ``Not all of it is new money.''
