DOC.HEAD: Drug Treatment: Private Glut, Public Gap
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Middle-class drug addiction was good business for American hospitals until too many of them figured that out. Clinics, hospitals and health-care companies that jumped to capitalize on the high-profit field of residential drug and alcohol treatment now frequently find themselves with empty beds, while public programs for those unable to pay struggle to keep pace with demand. Addicts in some parts of the country wait six months or more to get into a publicly financed program, but about 40 percent of the beds in private treatment centers lie empty, experts say. ``If you can pay, you can get treatment. If you cannot pay, you're going to be put on a waiting list in most places,'' said Bill Butynski, executive director of the National Association of State Alcohol and Drug Abuse directors. This disparity is growing, the experts say, despite an increase in public funds for substance-abuse treatment over the last decade and a growing awareness among employers, and society in general, of the need for treatment. ``The need for treatment is higher than it has ever been, but the demand is a little different,'' said Mike Ford, president of the National Association of Addiction Treatment Providers, which represents private treatment centers. Treatment options are being dictated increasingly by economics, as the government, employers and insurers try to rein in the soaring costs of health care, he and many other experts say. ``The economic tail is wagging the clinical dog,'' said Norman Hoffmann, a clinical psychologist at the Ramsey Clinic in St. Paul, Minn., and director of the clinic's Chemical Addiction Treatment Outcome Registry. The result is intense scrutiny over the need for residential or in-patient treatment, which can run upwards of $15,000, and an increasing reliance on less expensive out-patient programs. Hospitals rushed into the extended-care, live-in treatment business but many now find they cannot fill their spaces. Studies have shown residential and out-patient treatment to be about equally effective, and insurance companies have seized on this in arguing that more addicts should be channeled into the less expensive programs. But treatment providers say residential treatment, typically about 28 days, is more appropriate for some addicts, especially those who need to be physically separated from their everyday environment to break their dependency. Private, residential treatment programs began popping up in the mid-1970s after Medicare began covering live-in treatment. Private insurance companies also began including coverage in their packages. By the early 1980s, residential coverage was common practice, the number of free-standing treatment facilities was growing and more hospitals were setting aside beds for drug and alcohol treatment. But in 1983, Medicare _ which often drives medical practices in this country because of its huge budget, now more than $100 billion _ implemented a program designed to cut hospital costs. Under this program, Medicare agreed to pay hospitals a specified amount for treatment of various disorders and illnesses, categorized in diagnostic related groups, or DRGs. Before DRGs, a hospital could be reimbursed at the same rate for all in-patient care, whether it applied to a cancer patient requiring intense medical supervision or an alcoholic in for detoxification and needing less attention. But under DRGs, hospitals can no longer get top dollar for addiction treatment beds. Some have begun converting those beds to more profitable uses, including units for organ transplant and cancer patients, which need the higher levels of medical staffing hospitals provide, said Ken Estes, spokesman for the National Association of Addiction Treatment Providers. Employers and insurers, meanwhile, are feeling the effects of skyrocketing health-care costs, some rising more than 15 percent a year. They began their own efforts to cut back, usually by reducing coverage and scrutinizing use of benefits. Now, companies and insurance companies increasingly are turning to ``managed care,'' in which an outside company reviews claims to determine whether treatment was medically necessary. ``This leads to decisions on a level of care based not on what a patient needs, but on economic considerations,'' said Ford. As a result, he said, private treatment programs have found it more difficult to get patients to fill their beds because more employers and insurance companies are steering away from residential treatment. Though out-patient programs are usually less expensive, participants sometimes wind up paying more out-of-pocket for them because insurance coverage is generally not as good as for in-patient programs. ``The treatment industry is struggling to match up with what the buyers of services want to pay for, and in a nutshell, they want it very cheap,'' said W. James Nicol, president of Comprehensive Care Corp., one of the largest providers of residential treatment services. Nicol blames many of CompCare's recent financial troubles _ it reported a $4.7 million loss for the third quarter of 1989 and occupancy rates that have fallen to 46 percent _ on government and business efforts to cut health-care costs. His company and others like it are responding to the financial austerity by shifting some of their emphasis to out-patient programs, although historically these have never been as profitable, he said. Since fiscal 1982, federal block grants to states for alcohol, drug and mental health services have risen from $429 million to $765 million in fiscal 1989. This year, the total is expected to reach $1.2 billion. More than $3 billion in federal, state and local funds were spent on alcohol and drug abuse treatment in 1987, according to government data. In fiscal 1988, the National Association of State Alcohol and Drug Abuse Directors counted 6,926 substance-abuse programs that received public money, a 50 percent increase from fiscal 1984. Federal government data counted 984 private for-profit centers in 1987. These data, based on a voluntary survey, also showed 4,503 private non-profit programs that year, some of which may receive public funds and may also be counted in the state directors' numbers. Few programs are financed and operated solely by the government. Most of the time, states use their federal and state dollars to contract with private, non-profit centers for treatment services. These funds also usually require the programs to provide service to anyone who needs it, regardless of ability to pay. ``That's probably the biggest reason for the waiting lists,'' said Olive Jacob, an Albany, N.Y.-based consultant on alcohol and drug issues. Adding to the problem, she said, is that the federal government and many states prohibit their funds being used for private, profit-making programs. She and others say the problem of waiting lists, which is most severe in the larger East and West Coast cities, could be eased if the federal and state governments were more flexible in the use of their treatment dollars. Ford said that if the government set a price for a treatment service, offered it to private providers and said ``take it or leave it, they'd take it.''

DOC.HEAD: With BC-Drug Addiction, b0764
Public Drug Centers Swamped, While Private Facilities Have Empty Beds
DOC.TEXT: Paul A. Lara started using marijuana, alcohol, PCP and LSD when he was 14 years old. In time, he went to school only to see friends who could sell him more drugs. It wasn't until he was 25, a veteran of a 30-day hospital drug treatment regime and a six-month live-in program, that he was ready to get off the drugs and get on with his life. But the county of Los Angeles wasn't ready for him. Lara, with his insurance depleted years ago and little money left, was put on a waiting list for the county-financed Impact program, an intensive six- to nine-month stay at a residential treatment center with 90 beds. ``I had to call every day for three weeks before they told me I could come in for an interview,'' said Lara. ``When I got here, they said they've got a space and it's now or never. I went into this place with the clothes on my back.'' Lara, who was admitted in November, was in some senses one of the lucky ones. He managed to keep calling. Many of the 1,500 to 1,800 people on waiting lists for Los Angeles County's live-in treatment centers disappear. Before anyone can help, they sink deeper into their addictions, sometimes getting arrested, even killed, because of their craving. Los Angeles County, four times the size of Rhode Island and home to 8.7 million people, has just 650 treatment beds available through 18 publicly financed programs. Only two hospitals in the county offer publicly financed detoxification _ usually the first step in treatment in which an addict's body is flushed of drugs. After detox, people in need of live-in treatment programs can be placed on waiting lists for as long as six months. Methadone clinics and outpatient programs have four- to five-month waiting lists. ``We cannot provide treatment on demand. It's as simple as that,'' said Irma Strantz, the county's drug program administrator. ``The number of people waiting for treatment far exceeds, by multiples of two or three, the available spaces,'' said Maury Weiner, who heads the Tarzana Treatment Center in the San Fernando Valley. Officials at public centers say the situation will only get worse. They point to a drug problem that shows no signs of abating, erratic state and federal financing and the difficulties of treating an increasing number of addicts who are pregnant or suffer AIDS. ``There are people screaming for treatment, and it's heartbreaking that we are not able to provide the treatment for them,'' said Clyde W. Oden, president and chief executive of the Watts Health Foundation. For somebody seeking public treatment, persistence is key. Officials at Joint Efforts, a San Pedro outpatient program, tell people on waiting lists to call twice a day to see if a bed is available for detoxification. When beds open up, it's up to the addicts to get themselves to the hospital for the four- to seven-day detox before coming back to Joint Efforts for counseling. Joint Efforts' executive director, Pat Herrera Duran, said the wait is at least three weeks for detox, in which time addicts often deplete family funds, and rob and assault to sustain a drug habit. ``Whatever it is they're doing to get their drugs, they'll continue to do,'' she said. While public centers struggle, privately operated treatment facilities have beds to spare. At prices as high as $1,000 a day for treatment, only the rich _ or those with good insurance _ can afford it. In Pasadena, a few miles from the Impact center, the Summit Share Unit at St. Luke Medical Center has occupants for just 10 of its 20 beds for a month-long program that costs about $11,000. Summit sponsors drug and alcohol awareness seminars as part of its marketing campaign. ``It's a real tragedy,'' said Diane Cullen, community relations director at Summit. ``I get lots of people calling from pay phones on the street needing methadone but (who) don't have insurance. We can't take them. As cold as it sounds, this is a for-profit organization.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, Jan. 28

DOC.TEXT: The federal budget deficit increased $14.64 billion in December, putting the deficit so far this fiscal year at more than two-thirds permitted for the entire year, the government said. Combined with the $55.05 billion deficit for October and November, the imbalance at the end of December totaled $69.69 billion, compared to $67.58 billion at the same point in fiscal 1989, the Treasury Department said Tuesday. That means that although the government has a lower deficit ceiling this year, it has spent 3.1 percent more than it did during the first three months of fiscal 1989.

Personal income growth in the Rocky Mountain region topped the national average for the first time in six years in the third quarter of 1989 while slowing in New England, the government reported. The Commerce Department also said Tuesday that the Plains states registered the fastest growth rate, 9.2 percent, followed by a 9.1 percent advance in the Far West. The department said Rocky Mountain income in the July-September quarter grew 8.7 percent over the same period of 1988, compared to a national average growth rate of 8.5 percent.

A new financial evaluation of the thrift industry may show that a second installment is needed on President Bush's $50 billion savings and loan bailout, a senior Treasury Department official said. Deputy Secretary John E. Robson, the department's No. 2 official, told the House Banking Committee on Tuesday that the $50 billion may be inadequate. Robson also said the Treasury's Office of Thrift Supervision is compiling a new ``watch list'' of weak S&Ls that ``may indicate resolution costs beyond the original estimates.''

Federal regulators have suspended trading of CenTrust Savings Bank stock and charged the thrift with manipulating fiscal reports to conceal its precarious finances and massive junk-bond holdings. The week-long stock trading block against Miami-based CenTrust, implemented Tuesday, is the first such action by banking officials since 1983 and unleashed speculation the thrift could be the first to sink under the burden of volatile, high-risk junk bonds.

Billionaire financier Michael Milken was subpoenaed by a congressional committee investigating the role of high-risk junk bonds in thrift institution losses. The House Banking Committee on Tuesday voted 31-1 to summon Milken and two men involved in land deals with Charles H. Keating Jr.'s Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif. Committee Chairman Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, said the appearance of Ernest Garcia and Fernando Acosta would complete phase one of the panel's probe of Lincoln, expected to be the nation's costliest S&L failure.

Eddie Antar, founder of collapsed electronics retailer Crazy Eddie Inc., reaped more than $60 million by selling company stock based on falsified financial records, a federal judge said. U.S. District Judge Nicholas H. Politan found Tuesday that Antar ``was at the head of a scheme'' to overstate the company's income from 1985 to 1987 and benefited from the resulting higher stock price when he sold his own Crazy Eddie shares. The judge also ordered Antar to repatriate $52 million that he allegedly had transferred in 1987 to bank accounts in Israel.

Moody's Investors Service Inc. has lowered its credit rating for $12 billion in Merrill Lynch & Co. long-term debt because of doubts over the impact of the firm's $470 million charge for restructuring costs. Merrill objected to the downgrading Tuesday, saying its broad but costly restructuring that includes layoffs and sales of some of its business would improve profitability in 1990.

Four of the nation's largest defense contractors unexpectedly ended their fierce competition over the contract for the National Aero-Space Plane and said they would work on the project together. The aircraft, which has been in the planning stage since 1985, would be able to take off from a runway and fly directly into orbit. A prototype is scheduled to be built and flown in the late 1990s. General Dynamics Corp., McDonnell Douglas Corp., the North American Aircraft and Rocketdyne divisions of Rockwell International Corp., and the Pratt & Whitney division of United Technologies Corp. said Tuesday they would collaborate on the project.

The Federated and Allied department store groups may get quick approval when they ask a U.S. Bankruptcy Court judge Thursday for permission to continue paying employee benefits. U.S. Trustee Conrad J. Morgenstern said Tuesday that in his view the requests by Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. are necessary in order to assure continued funding of benefits that the companies' 100,000 employees nationwide are expecting.

Prices were widely mixed in a choppy session on Wall Street Tuesday as pessimism about interest rates and corporate profits lingered in the stock market. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 14.87 to 2,615.32 following a 77-point drop on Monday. The dollar lost value against all major foreign currencies. Bond prices tumbled reflecting disappointment with the results of a $5 billion auction of 40-year bonds being sold to finance the government's thrift bailout. Gold futures prices climbed sharply; oil futures finished mostly lower; grains and soybeans were mixed; and livestock and meat futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Exxon Still Feeling Fallout From New And Old Spills
DOC.TEXT: Investors are still concerned about Exxon Corp.'s sullied image after two oil-polluting incidents in less than a year, analysts say. After a bad 1989 following the disastrous March spill off the Alaskan coast, the nation's largest oil company began the year with a Jan. 2 pipeline rupture that left 567,000 gallons of heating oil floating in the Arthur Kill waterway between New York City and New Jersey. The latest spill has resulted in new lawsuits and accusations against the oil giant on top of more than 150 other suits stemming from the Alaska spill. The state of New Jersey is one of the plaintiffs over the latest pollution, which Exxon officials at first blamed on a faulty leak-detection system. ``What happened in New York-New Jersey further blackened the eye,'' said Frank P. Knuettel, oil industry analyst for Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. Exxon's stock lagged behind the overall industry's performance last year after the Alaska spill, remaining relatively flat at about $45. In comparison, stocks of Mobil Corp. and Chevron Corp. had gains of about 20 percent during that period. In composite trading on the New York Stock Exchange Tuesday, Exxon stock closed up 12{ cents at $47.12{ a share. The total financial impact of the Arthur Kill spill is unknown. Exxon has offered to pay for environmental studies and damages associated with the leak. Cleanup of the Alaska spill, which resulted when an Exxon tanker ran aground in Prince William Sound, has cost Exxon $1.9 billion so far, according to a U.S. Transportation Department estimate. Exxon officials acknowledge only ``over $1 billion'' in cleanup costs, with about a third of that covered by insurance. Exxon took an $850 million charge against second quarter earnings to cover its estimated out-of-pocket expenses for the spill, the worst in the nation's history. Analysts say Exxon's fourth-quarter earnings, expected to be released this week, should be in line with the overall industry, showing lower refining, marketing and chemicals earnings and higher results in the exploration and production sector, due largely to higher crude oil prices. But Exxon could decide to take a reserve against earnings for environmental costs associated with the most recent spill as well as future environmental programs, said Paul Ting, analyst with Oppenheimer & Co. ``It wouldn't be anything as big as that for the Valdez spill'' but it could affect earnings, Ting said. Next Monday's criminal trial of Joseph Hazelwood _ captain of the supertanker Exxon Valdez at the time of its March 24 spill _ also could bring Exxon more negative publicity. Exxon has played down the financial and social impact of both the Alaska and New York-New Jersey incidents, but analysts say Exxon's tarnished image and the possibility of damages not covered by insurance has made a difference to investors. William L. Randol, analyst for First Boston Corp., wrote in his letter to investors late last year, ``Investors have quite rightly avoided this stock, not because of the actual cleanup costs involved ... but because of the unquantifiable financial threat of billions of dollars of potential punitive damage awards stemming from the 150 or so lawsuits filed against the company.'' Randol said Tuesday he has upgraded his investment opinion of Exxon to a ``buy'' from a ``hold.'' While the potential magnitude of the lawsuits is significant, ``on the other hand Exxon may end up paying pennies on the dollar,'' he said. Randol also said Exxon's stock represents good value in the long term. Other analysts disagreed. ``I think oil stocks are going to do better, not in the very near term, but Exxon will not be in the vanguard of that movement,'' said Knuettel, whose investment firm continues to rate Exxon stock a ``hold.''

DOC.HEAD: Moody's Downgrades $12 Billion in Merrill Lynch Debt
With PM-Wall Street Cuts Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Moody's Investors Service Inc. has lowered its credit rating for $12 billion in Merrill Lynch & Co. long-term debt because of doubts over the impact of the firm's $470 million charge for restructuring costs. Merrill objected to the downgrading, saying the broad but costly restructuring that includes layoffs and sales of some of business would improve profitability in 1990. The lower credit rating is expected to increase Merrill's cost of doing business. Borrowers with lower credit ratings must pay higher interest rates, and financial companies rely on borrowed money to conduct much of their business. ``In many of the businesses in which they operate, (profit margins) are already quite thin, so it's not going to help during a difficult period of time,'' said John Keefe, a securities industry analyst with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. Merrill on Monday said it was taking a $470 million pretax charge against fourth-quarter earnings to cover severance payments, writedowns of existing assets, and office sales and lease payments. The charge gave Merrill losses of $362 million in the fourth-quarter and $213 million for the year. It was the first annual loss since 1971 for the nation's largest securities firm. Moody's said it downgraded Merrill's senior domestic debt and European debt to a rating of A2 from its highest rating of A1. Other long-term debt also was lowered. The credit rating agency said Merrill's restructuring, which is expected to include 3,000 job cuts this year, should reduce the firm's overhead in the future. But Moody's said it was ``concerned that Merrill's prospective returns will be pressured due to the presence of considerable overcapacity in the securities industry in both the institutional and retail sectors.'' Moody's also said the firm's credit standing was supported by strong retail and institutional franchises and an ``acceptable level'' of risk-adjusted capital. ``We disagree with Moody's action because we are confident that our restructuring program will respond effectively to the adverse industry environmental factors Moody's cited as a justification for its action,'' Merrill said in a statement. ``The A1 rating that we held reflected the many financial strengths enjoyed by Merrill Lynch,'' the firm said. ``We believe our restructuring program will further enhance that financial position and lead to significantly improved profitability in 1990 and beyond.'' Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., the second-largest Wall Street firm, late last year avoided a downgrading being considered by Moody's by enacting a recapitalization plan designed to raise about $900 million.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Enjoins Antar from Securities Violations, Orders Funds Back to U.S.
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge told Eddie Antar, whose Crazy Eddie Inc. electronics chain collapsed amid fraud charges, to bring $52 million back to U.S. shores. The Securities and Exchange Commission alleges the sum is part of more than $60 million Antar gained by selling Crazy Eddie stock at prices falsely inflated by illegal bookkeeping. U.S. District Judge Nicholas H. Politan said Tuesday that Antar ``was at the head of a scheme'' to overstate the company's income from 1985 to 1987, and benefited from a higher stock price in selling his shares. The judge stressed that his finding was limited only to a motion filed by the SEC in its insider-trading lawsuit against Antar and was not a criminal finding. The motion was to bar Antar from violating securities laws, which Politan granted. The judge said he based his finding only on the record before him, which included legal briefs and testimony by company officials. Antar did not submit a statement. ``The public deserves protection from persons against whom ... strong prima facie showings have been made of securities fraud,'' said Politan. He also granted the government's request to require Antar to repatriate $52 million that he allegedly had transferred in 1987 to bank accounts in Israel. The money is to be placed under the supervision of a trustee. The government has said Antar transferred as much as $68 million overseas. The SEC wants the money on hand in case it wins an insider-trading case and a restitution order against Antar. ``It would be a compounding of a fraud to permit Mr. Antar free reign over $60 million,'' Politan said. Antar, who was raised in the New York borough of Brooklyn, built his single store there into a 43-outlet chain known through the New York area for its loud-mouthed advertisements touting ``insane prices!'' The SEC accused him and other former top management of insider trading and doctoring the company's books. The company went into involuntary bankruptcy in October. Antar and former officials also face a shareholder's lawsuit in federal court in Brooklyn, and a criminal investigation by the U.S. attorney here. SEC attorney Richard Simpson said an indictment, if returned, would not come for another three months. Politan put the SEC civil case on hold for the next four months. Antar's lawyers asked for the stay because they were unsure if the U.S. attorney would seek forfeiture of Antar's legal fees. Under the federal racketeering law, the government can try to seize legal fees if they represent illegally gotten funds. Antar's lawyers argued that it was unfair for one branch of government _ the Justice Department _ to seek lawyers' fees in a criminal case, possibly depriving Antar of legal defense against a civil lawsuit from another arm of the government _ the SEC. The stay prevents the SEC from interviewing Antar and his co-defendants under oath.

DOC.HEAD: Federated, Allied File Motions
DOC.TEXT: Federated Department Stores and Allied Stores Corp. have asked a U.S. Bankruptcy judge to let them restore benefits for 100,000 employees and draw on $700 million in credits to help them through Chapter 11 protection. Carol Sanger, a Cincinnati spokeswoman for Allied and Federated, said the companies hope for quick approval of three motions at a hearing Thursday before Bankruptcy Judge J. Vincent Aug Jr. ``Most of this is housekeeping stuff,'' Ms. Sanger said. The two retail divisions of Federated Stores Inc. filed the motions seeking approval to restore employee benefits, authorize $700 million in credit lines from two New York City banks and resume normal credit operations at Allied. U.S. Trustee Conrad J. Morgenstern, who is helping steer Federated and Allied through Chapter 11 proceedings, said the requests appear valid. ``The company wants to continue to have support and the goodwill of its employees, including those that are retired,'' Morgenstern said. ``We think it is appropriate and customary for a company such as this to ask for this authority.'' The benefits for some 100,000 employees nationwide include health and education plans, disability insurance, workers' compensation, bonuses, drug and alcohol abuse programs and 401(k) retirement plans. The retailers also want permission to reinstate the 20 percent discounts given to retirees. Morgenstern supported that proposal because it would generate additional sales for the companies, he said. ``We hope Judge Aug is sympathetic with the argument,'' said Mark Cohen, chairman of the Cincinnati-based Lazarus store chain. ``We have a lot of retirees, and we value their tenure. We believe it should be restored.'' Federated and Allied, the American retailing divisions of Toronto-based Campeau Corp., filed Chapter 11 reorganization petitions Jan. 15 in Cincinnati to obtain court protection from creditors. The Cincinnati-based companies that operate nine department store chains listed $7.5 billion in debts. Under the Chapter 11 proceedings, the companies must obtain the approval of a U.S. Bankruptcy Court to pay operating expenses and other bills. Morgenstern's office is assigned to assist the courts, and his staff will attend Thursday's hearing, along with lawyers for Federated, Allied and their creditors. Federated and Allied formally asked Aug to authorize $700 million in cash reserves from New York City banks. Chemical Bank has offered a $300 million credit line _ known as debtor-in-possession financing _ to Allied, and Citibank has offered a $400 million line of credit to Federated. Another filing asks approval for normal credit operations at Allied's stores. ``This simply allows the systems in place to continue functioning,'' Ms. Sanger said. ``This allows the companies to fund ongoing operations on a normal basis without any delays.'' Morgenstern said he thinks Aug may give approval Thursday for the employee benefits, but may take longer to approve the financing requests.

DOC.HEAD: Playboy Opens Doors To New Hutch
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto CX2 of Jan. 23
DOC.HEAD: LaserColor CX3 of Jan. 23
DOC.TEXT: High on a shelf in Christie Hefner's office, almost lost amid the stainless steel gleam of Playboy Enterprises Inc.'s new headquarters, sits a battered old manual typewriter. The machine _ the same model as the one on which Hugh Hefner produced the first issue of Playboy magazine in 1953 _ is a link to the past of a company that is looking excitedly toward the future. ``It's a reminder of our roots and a connection to the beginning,'' Ms. Hefner said Tuesday as the Chicago-based publishing-and-video company celebrated its move with a posh party at the new offices. ``Even as we've changed the company and we're moving into new markets, at the heart of everything is still the same commitment to quality and entertainment we've always stood for,'' she said. Hugh Hefner wasn't at the invitation-only bash. At 63, the one-time king of the swinging singles is working on his autobiography and settled in his Los Angeles mansion with pregnant wife and former centerfold, Kimberley Conrad, 26. He still owns about 70 percent of the stock but daughter Christie, Playboy's chairman since November 1988, has run the company day-to-day for about eight years. Several Playmates were on hand at the party but the only bunny in sight was a bronze sculpture of Playboy's rabbit-head trademark by Chicagoan Richard Hunt, one of many artworks on display in the new offices. Playboy bunnies disappeared with the last of the company's U.S. key clubs in 1988, but Playboy has saved some of the cotton-tailed costumes along with other icons of its hedonistic heyday. Joining those relics in storage next month will be the 9-foot-high Playboy sign atop the company's former skyscraper headquarters on Chicago's Michigan Avenue. The new digs are slightly smaller, but the workspace is airier and provides better opportunities for displaying works from the company's 4,000-piece modern art collection, Ms. Hefner said. The new offices are on the top two floors of a 16-story downtown building fronting on Lake Michigan, less than three blocks from the 36-story tower that housed the corporate offices for more than 22 years. Playboy says the move will save it $11 million over the 15-year term of the lease. Ms. Hefner said the new headquarters ``make a symbolic statement about this company being renewed, re-energized and entering another era of creativity.'' Playboy is indeed showing renewed vigor, 37 years after Hefner launched the company's flesh-and-fashion flagship magazine from his kitchen table in Chicago with a $600 investment. Although Playboy magazine's circulation is nowhere near its 1972 peak of 7.2 million, it has held at roughly 3.5 million for almost five years while sales of harder-core men's magazines such as Penthouse and Hustler have continued to fall. Under the direction of Ms. Hefner, 37, who became president in 1982, Playboy has made a successful push into home video, retooled its broadcast television operations, increased product licensing and expanded its publishing business into art prints and catalogs. Ever watchful for new markets, Playboy moved quickly to exploit the democratization of Eastern Europe with a Hungarian edition of Playboy magazine that sold out its 95,000-copy printing. A second Hungarian issue is on the stands. The company blamed restructuring costs for a $3.8 million net loss in the fiscal year that ended June 30 after two profitable years. Playboy reported a $5 million profit on revenues of $39.3 million in the first quarter of its new fiscal year, and some analysts see growth in Playboy's future. ``They have an awful lot on their plate and the potential here is quite significant,'' said analyst David Leibowitz of American Securities Corp.

DOC.HEAD: More Than One-Third U.S. Firms Plan to Hire Middle Managers in 1990
DOC.TEXT: More than one-third of the nation's companies plan to hire more middle-level managers during the first six months of 1990, according to a private survey. ``It's definitely good news,'' said Nancy Kovalcheck, director of advertising and public relations for Management Recruiters International, Inc., which conducted the survey. ``It has never looked better for middle management and business. ``In fact, if anything, there's going to be a crisis in the 1990s in finding people to fill these positions because the unemployment rate right now for middle managers is only 1.9 percent,'' she said. ``We're creating more jobs than can be filled.'' According to the survey issued Tuesday, only 11.8 percent of the 2,700 executives who responded to the Management Recruiters poll said their companies planned cutbacks during the first half of 1990. Another 51.6 percent told pollsters their companies would maintain the same middle management workforce. And 36.2 percent said they would hire middle managers during the first six months of 1990. The telephone survey has a margin of error of 0.5 percent, according to Management Recruiters, the nation's largest search and recruitment firm with offices throughout the United States. The company has conducted similar polls for the past 24 years. According to the poll, the Mountain region including Nevada and seven other states west of California had the best outlook, with 48.7 percent of the executives questioned saying they planned to hire more middle managers in early 1990. That compares to 41.6 percent in the Pacific region, 35.8 percent in the Midwest, 38.9 percent in the Southwest, 33.2 percent in the north-central states, 32.5 percent in the south-central states, 35.3 percent in the south Atlantic region, 41.5 percent in the middle Atlantic, and 34.5 percent in New England.

DOC.HEAD: Wall Street Turning Into Mean Street for Brokerages
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Sim is cq in 6th graf
DOC.TEXT: Wall Street is turning into Mean Street for the nation's big brokerages, and even leaner regional firms are struggling to cope with an exodus of small investors since the 1987 stock market crash. A slumping stock market, declining corporate takeover activity and faltering junk bonds point to a continuing industry shakeout that analysts say will mean more cuts in businesses and jobs. The trend was dramatized by Merrill Lynch & Co.'s stunning announcement Monday that it would spend $470 million to pay for such cutbacks. Outside New York, regional brokerages are retrenching. A 190-point stock market drop in October and steady declines this year haven't helped prospects for an industry still trying to rebuild the trust of small investors following the 1987 crash. Many brokers are offering new services, such as managing the assets of wealthy individuals or small companies, in order to stay afloat. Some regional firms have been swallowed up or are imperiled. Rauscher Pierce Refsnes Inc., a Dallas-based brokerage, has trimmed its retail force to 270 brokers from a peak of 350. ``Most of those who departed simply were not making it in a tough market,'' Sim Trotter, Rauscher Pierce's senior vice president for marketing, said Tuesday. Advest Inc. last fall acquired Newhard, Cook & Co., of St. Louis. Dain Bosworth Inc. in late 1988 acquired the 100-broker Milwaukee Co. And the 112-year-old B.C. Christopher Securities Co. of Kansas City is suffering because of the retail industry slowdown, analysts said. Still, the regional firms continue to outperform their full-service Wall Street brethren, which expanded dramatically in the go-go days of the mid-1980s. According to the Securities Industry Association, national firms reported profits of $106 million in the first nine months of 1989, compared to losses of $68.2 million for all of 1988 and $193 million in 1987. Regional firms had $165 million in profits for the nine-month period, compared to $107 million in 1988 and $273 million in 1987. ``Although we are not insulated from many of the problems affecting national brokerage firms, we have a modest and more disciplined cost structure ..'' said Charles Hayssen, chief financial officer of Minneapolis-based Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood Inc., which on Tuesday reported an almost 50 percent surge in commission revenue. Regional firms avoided many of the problems of Wall Street's giants because they have low overhead and their businesses often are limited to stockbrokering and other basic investment services. So-called ``full-line'' firms engage in a wide range of activities, and many houses have relied for profits on huge fees from investment banking services such as arranging mergers and takeovers, which are on the decline. Industry analyst Perrin Long of Lipper Analytical Services predicted brokerage firms' 1989 fourth-quarter profits would fall 40 percent to 50 percent from the third quarter _ to about $240 million from $471 million. In 1990, he predicted, earnings of the more than 350 New York Stock Exchange member firms doing public business would drop as much as 15 percent. ``And that's if the environment doesn't get any better,'' Long said. ``At the rate we're going the environment is going to get worse.'' Merrill Lynch's record fourth-quarter charge gave the nation's largest brokerage its first annual loss since 1971. Merrill, which analysts considered bloated by overexpansion, plans to reduce its staff by about 3,000 by yearend. Overall industry employment has shrunk by more than 35,000 jobs since before the crash, SIA figures show. ``I don't think it's over,'' said Lawrence Eckenfelder of Prudential Bache Securities Corp. in San Francisco, who expects cuts to continue for 12 to 18 months. Analysts say costs remain too high for national firms such as Merrill or Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., partly because of New York real estate prices, high salaries and broad expansion during the boom years. Shearson on Tuesday reported slender fourth-quarter earnings of $3.8 million, compared to a $13 million loss a year earlier. ``Wall Street is the most expensive place in the world to do business except Tokyo,'' said Donald F. Howard, deputy chairman of the consulting firm Gray, Judson & Howard, of Cambridge, Mass. ``We're no longer in a high margin business.'' With the exception of Merrill, Wall Street firms generally are reporting higher profits and revenue for 1989. However, financial statements indicate much of the gains are from interest and commissions. Also, 1988 was a weak year for the industry.

DOC.HEAD: Toshiba to Mass Produce High-Definition Color Picture Tubes
DOC.TEXT: Toshiba Corp. said Wednesday it will build a new production line to mass produce color picture tubes for high-definition television, which brings motion picture sharpness to television images. Masao Mochizuki, spokesman for Toshiba, said his company would be the first to launch mass-production of HDTV picture tubes in Japan, though some other consumer products makers are producing them on a trial basis. The applications of HDTV technology, pioneered in Japan, range from entertainment to medicine to national defense radar systems. At its plant in Himeji, 360 miles west of Tokyo, Toshiba will invest the equivalent of $36 million for new production lines scheduled to begin operation in August, Mochizuki said. He said Toshiba initially would produce 200 HDTV picture tubes a month _ 32-inch and 36-inch tubes for home use, and 36-inch tubes for business purposes. Mochizuki declined to estimate the cost of a monitor with a high-definition tube, but it has been estimated that HDTV sets would cost between $34,000 and $54,000 in Japan. Regular HDTV broadcasting is scheduled to start by the end of this year, and the demand for next-generation television sets is expected to grow steadily, Toshiba said.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Overturns Verdict Against Polaroid
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Court of Appeals has overturned a verdict that might have cost the Polaroid Corp. $30 million in payments to shareholders in a case involving the failure of Polavision, an instant movie system. The three-judge court cited errors by the trial judge, including incorrect instructions to the jury, in overturning the 1987 verdict. In a suit by investor Irving Backman, Boston attorney Thomas Shapiro argued that Polaroid founder Edwin Land and company executive Julius Silver sold stock in 1979 knowing that Polaroid stock was high at the time because of the undisclosed failure of Polavision technology. Polavision was a $68 million failure and was withdrawn from the market in 1979. Land and Silver settled with Backman out of court, but in July 1987, a jury found Polaroid liable for damages to shareholders equal to $9.75 a share. A Polaroid spokesman said Tuesday the company had not seen the ruling and could not comment. The Boston Globe said Shapiro was out of town and neither he nor Land, who is retired, could be reached for comment.

DOC.HEAD: Hill Experts See Higher 1991 Budget Gap Than Administration
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 11 grafs new to UPDATE with CBO testimony; picks up at pvs 7th graf, `As a ...' Also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Congress' budget experts said today that lawmakers and President Bush will need to find $74 billion in savings to meet next year's deficit target. The estimate by the Congressional Budget Office, made to the Senate Budget Committee, is more than double the amount the administration is expected to say it needs in savings. It also continues a long tradition of disagreeing deficit forecasts between the two branches. Bush submits his fiscal 1991 budget to Congress on Monday. He is expected to say $30 billion to $35 billion in new revenues and spending cuts are needed to meet the $64 billion deficit target mandated by the Gramm-Rudman balanced-budget law. The report by CBO _ Congress' fiscal analysis arm _ projects a $138 billion deficit for fiscal 1991, which begins Oct. 1, unless savings are found. Bush is expected to ask for $1.23 trillion in spending for next year. The CBO report contains even more bad news for the future. Gramm-Rudman requires declining deficits every year until 1993, when the budget is required to be balanced. But according to CBO, deficits are projected to be $135 billion in 1992 and $141 billion in 1993, declining slowly over the next two years. ``Without spending cuts or tax increases, the deficit in 1993 is likely to be no lower than in 1990,'' CBO Director Robert D. Reischauer told senators. The huge difference between the CBO projections and the administration's numbers are due to differing expectations about economic performance. The White House Office of Management and Budget is expected to forecast that the economy will expand this year by about 2.6 percent, measured from the fourth quarter of last year through the third quarter of 1990. CBO's projection is 1.8 percent. As a rule of thumb, every 1 percentage point in economic growth adds $25 billion to federal revenue collections, because a healthier economy means more robust tax collections. Fifty-one private economists surveyed by Blue Chip Economic Indicators, a private publication, have projected that the economy will expand by an average of 1.7 percent this year. That would be the slowest U.S. economic growth since 1982. By law, the administration's shortfall forecast is binding, leaving the CBO figures little more than advisory. But the projections by the non-partisan CBO are considered by many lawmakers and budget observers to be more reliable than those from the White House. Under Gramm-Rudman, automatic spending cuts are triggered in most federal programs should Congress and the president fail to agree to savings that meet the deficit target. That happened last fall, but a compromise between Bush and Congress was enacted that will lift the cuts early next month. The deficit targets set by Gramm-Rudman, however, apply only to the coming fiscal year. The law sets no penalties if the actual deficit ends up exceeding the legal target, an eventuality that has occurred every year since Gramm-Rudman was enacted in 1985. Meanwhile, the Treasury Department announced Tuesday that the budget deficit grew by $14.64 billion in December, bringing the total shortfall for the first three months of the 1990 fiscal year to $69.69 billion. That is more than two-thirds the $100 billion deficit that Gramm-Rudman permits for the entire year and compared with a $67.58 billion deficit for the first quarter of fiscal 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Mazda May Produce Compact Cars With Ford In West Germany
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Rewrites to CORRECT reference that Mazda is first Japanese automaker to gain manufacturing presence on European continent. Minor editing throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Mazda Motor Co. and Ford Motor Co. plan a joint venture to produce compact cars in Europe based on existing Mazda models, a Mazda official said. Japan's fourth-largest automaker and its U.S. partner expect to produce the cars in Saarlouis in southwestern West Germany, said a Mazda official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. He declined to say whether the venture would build a new factory or use an existing Ford plant. ``We'd thought about Belgium, England, Spain and West Germany, and West Germany seems to be the best,'' he said. Mazda and Ford will produce cars similar to two existing Mazda models, Familia and Capella, the official said. Japanese automakers currently don't have any factories on the European continent, although Nissan began producing small cars in Britain in 1986 and Toyota and Honda plan to begin producing cars in Britain in 1992. ``West Germany is an important place in many ways. It has a lot of know-how in technology and designs that we can learn, for instance,'' the Mazda official said. Mazda and Ford have a long partnership in finance and technology, and Ford owns more than a 23 percent of Mazda's stock. Local media reported Mazda and Ford are to produce 120,000 cars beginning in 1992, with each company selling 60,000 cars each. Mazda reportedly is to invest some 50 million yen in the project. Bert Serre, director of international public affairs at Ford in Michigan, said he couldn't confirm the reports. ``Nothing has been agreed on. We have had discussion with Mazda, they are partners of ours,'' he said. ``Nothing has been finalized.'' The Mazda official said the two sides are negotiating details of the plan. The amount of investment could be smaller than reported, and production also may not come as early as 1992, he said. ``Since our exports to Europe are still growing, we'd like to decide on the amount of local production in West Germany so that it will not harm the exports,'' the official said. In 1989, Mazda exported 288,475 cars to Europe, including Familia and Capella, according to Mazda. Nihon Keizai Shimbun, an economic newspaper, said the American and Japanese automakers chose West Germany because it is the best place to obtain access to the Eastern bloc, which is seen as a big market in the future following the recent democratization movements there. The venture would make Mazda among the first Japanese automakers to gain a manufacturing presence on the European continent. Ford already is one of the biggest automakers in the European market. Suzuki Motor Co., Japan's largest minicar producer, announced Jan. 9 that it has reached an agreement with Hungary to set up a joint venture car plant near Budapest.

DOC.HEAD: Santa Fe Plans Reducing Payroll by 2,700 Jobs Over Five Years
DOC.TEXT: Santa Fe Pacific Corp. plans to reduce employment on its railroad by 2,700 jobs over five years, officials of the company say. The reductions would take place through job buyouts, attrition and possible layoffs, and would affect both union and white-collar workers, said Robert Gerht, spokesman for Chicago-based Santa Fe. The cuts would likely affect Santa Fe Railway across its 11,500-mile system, officials said. There is no specific timetable for the cuts, which would reduce employment with the railroad from the current 18,000 to about 15,300, according to the company. ``Some buyouts will be voluntary and some won't,'' Gerht said. ``This is part of an overall plan to make the railroad more efficient and competitive.'' In a statement issued Tuesday, Santa Fe Pacific Corp., parent company of the railroad, said it lost $209.4 million, or $1.33 a share, in the fourth quarter because of a charge taken to establish reserves for covering costs of the workforce reduction and other railway restructurings. The pre-tax charge totaled $389.6 million. The quarterly loss compared with net income of $156.1 million, or 99 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1988, reflecting a $136 million gain on the sale of a portion of the company's pipeline operations. The railway actually had an ``excellent quarter'' to finish out 1989, said Robert Krebs, chairman and president of Santa Fe Pacific. If not for the charge, he said, the railway would have reported a 40 percent increase in operating income. Santa Fe Railway reported fourth-quarter operating income of $67 million before the restructuring costs, up from $47.7 million a year earlier. For the year, Santa Fe Pacific reported net income of $14.6 million, or 9 cents a share, compared with a net loss of $46.5 million, or 30 cents a share, in 1988. The Santa Fe Railway has been steadily reducing employment for several years. About three years ago, it took 85 crew members to run a Santa Fe train from Chicago to Los Angeles. The railroad currently uses 40 crew members on the same run, and company officials expect to cut that number to about 30, Gehrt said. Company officials said that the proposed union job cuts are provided for in recently negotiated labor contracts with some units of the United Transportation Union and the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers. The railroad is negotiating to reach similar agreements with other bargaining units, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Regulator Says $50 Billion `Probably Too Low' for Bailout
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Top 9 grafs new with testimony today; picking up 7th pvs, `Robson was ...' Editing throughout to shorten. Also moved on general news wire.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX8
DOC.TEXT: A top regulator told Congress today that President Bush's $50 billion bailout of the savings and loan industry is ``probably too low.'' L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. and chairman of the new bailout agency, the Resolution Trust Corp., said the money provided in legislation last August would be adequate only if the government seized no more than an additional $40 billion worth of S&Ls. As of Jan. 16, the RTC had seized 333 institutions with assets totaling $136 billion. The loss on those is about $42 billion, he said. However, the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision is predicting that another 225 to 295 institutions, with assets of $160 billion to $200 billion, will fail. ``We have found no reason to question the reasonableness of (those) estimates,'' Seidman told the House Banking Committee. ``The likely size of the loss, $50 billion as provided (by the S&L bill) ... is probably too low a figure,'' he said. However, he added, ``it is very difficult to provide a more definitive number'' and said ``under any scenario, the $50 billion ... should, as far as losses are concerned, carry the RTC into 1991.'' Seidman went a step beyond testimony on Tuesday from Deputy Treasury Secretary John E. Robson, who said, ``I can't tell you with certainty that the $50 billion is going to be enough.'' On Tuesday, Robson said the thrift office was compiling a new ``watch list'' of weak S&Ls which ``may indicate resolution costs beyond the original estimates.'' Robson was representing an administration oversight board which controls the purse strings and policy of the bailout. Also appearing were oversight board members Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and Jack Kemp, secretary of housing. In other S&L developments Tuesday: _The House committee subpoenaed financier Michael Milken to testify in its investigation of the role of junk bonds in the collapse of Charles H. Keating Jr.'s Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif., and other thrifts. A spokesman for Milken declined comment. The former junk bond trading chief for Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. is expected to stand trial later this year on securities fraud charges. In April 1988, he invoked his constitutional protection against self-incrimination to avoid testifying to Congress. Also subpoenaed were Ernest Garcia and Fernando Acosta, Arizona businessmen involved in land deals with Lincoln. _The government sold $5 billion in 40-year bonds to finance its bailout of the savings and loan industry, the first time in 35 years it has sold paper of more than 30 years' maturity. The bonds, issued by the Resolution Funding Corp., sold at an average yield of 8.6 percent. With Tuesday's sale, the government has now raised $29.5 billion to finance the cleanup. _The Office of Thrift Supervision penalized a fifth officer of the failed Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association, Denver. But it postponed for up to 10 days a decision on Neil Bush, the president's son, who had served as a director of the failed thrift. Russell M. Murray, former executive vice president of Silverado, agreed to an order prohibiting him from working for a federally insured financial institution without advance permission from regulators. _The thrift office suspended trading of stock in CenTrust Savings Bank of Miami, Florida's largest S&L. Regulators levied the one-week suspension after accusing the thrift of filing misleading and inaccurate financial reports. Analysts say the thrift, which invested deposits in an expensive art collection, is close to being seized by regulators. Private analysts and some members of Congress have been saying for months that the $50 billion will amount to little more than a down payment on the cost of resolving the nation's worst financial problem since the Depression.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Steady After Lower Opening
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were mostly higher in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade, rebounding after an opening decline linked to stock-market jitters. Analysts said grain traders focused on the stock market amid a dearth of significant supply-and-demand news in the grain markets. ``There's no big feature overall,'' said analyst Dale Gustafson of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. in Chicago. Grain and soybean futures opened slightly lower across the board in brisk trading after the stock market's opening dive of more than 60 points in the Dow Jones industrial average. But crop futures recovered as the stock market steadied. The Dow was down about 50 points at 11 a.m. EST. In early trading, wheat futures were unchanged to 1 cent higher with the contract for delivery in March at $3.93 a bushel; corn futures were \ cent to } cent higher with March at $2.41{ a bushel; oats were 1 cent to 1{ cents higher wiith March at $1.39{ a bushel; soybean futures were { cent to 2\ cents higher with March at $5.69{ a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were lower in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange ahead of this afternoon's quarterly Agriculture Department cattle-on-feed report. The report is expected to show a slight increase in the number of cattle on feedlots being fattened for slaughter. Live cattle futures were .17 cent to .38 cent lower with the contract for delivery in February at 78.30 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .12 cent to .45 cent lower with January at 84.30 cents a pound; live hogs were .10 cent to .52 cent lower with February at 49.35 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .75 cent to 1.10 cents lower with February at 55.60 cents a pound. Cattle futures settled mostly lower on Tuesday while pork futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Aeroflot Orders First Western Commercial Jets
DOC.TEXT: In its first purchase of Western commercial aircraft, the Soviet airline Aeroflot has ordered five Airbus A310-300 wide-bodied jets, Airbus Industrie said Wednesday. Officials of Airbus, a Western European aircraft manufacturing consortium, declined to disclose the value of the order. Aircraft industry sources said the contract is worth abut $310 million. Airbus Managing Director Jean Pierson said the Aeroflot order represents ``the new kind of relations between Eastern Europe and Western Europe.'' State-owned Aeroflot also has taken an option to buy five additional Airbus jets, Airbus officials said. Each plane can carry 195 passengers. The planes will be delivered between November 1991 and June 1992 and will be used for Aeroflot's flights between the Soviet Union and the Far East, Europe and North America. Alexander Aksenov, the Soviet Union's civil aviation vice minister, told reporters in Toulouse that Aeroflot is holding talks with Western European airlines on a maintenance contract for the new jets. A full maintenance base in the Soviet Union would be uneconomical for such a small number of planes, he said. Aeroflot must still choose between General Electric or Pratt and Whitney engines to power the aircraft. Airbus already has sold jets to two Eastern European airlines. East Germany's Interflug has taken delivery of three A310-300s and has another three on order, while the Czech airline Ceskoslovenske Aeroline has ordered two A310-300s. Airbus, based in Toulouse, is comprised of Aerospatiale of France, Messerschmitt-Boelkow-Blohm GMBH of West Germany, British Aerospace PLC and Construcciones Aeronauticas SA of Spain.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down Sharply At Midday
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 new grafs to UPDATE with noon figures, market up from its lows. Picks up 4th graf pvs, Traders learned...
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices fell sharply today as worries about rising interest rates and continuing pressure on the Japanese market continued taking a heavy toll on Wall Street. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which has fallen 195 points over the past three weeks, was down another 43.92 to 2,571.40 by noon on Wall Street. As the outlook for interest rates has worsened, investors have begun to face the possibility that the recent slowdown of the economy might deepen in the months ahead.

DOC.HEAD: Nymex, Comex Pursuing Merger; Joint Governing Board Formed
DOC.TEXT: The New York Mercantile Exchange and the Commodity Exchange Inc. said today they would pursue merger negotiations and announced the formation of a joint board that would govern a consolidated entity. The exchanges issued a statement saying that the executive committees from Nymex and Comex met Tuesday and agreed to form the joint governing board. The exchanges also said the respective boards instructed their executive committees ``to pursue further negotiations with the intent of devising a means by which the administration and operations of the two exchanges could be consolidated most efficiently.'' ``Essentially they've agreed on a governing body if there would be a merger and the two executive committees are going to continue talks,'' said Nymex spokeswoman Nachamah Jacobovits. Spokespeople for both exchanges refused to say why the markets were considering a merger or what the benefits of such a consolidation would be. The two exchanges reportedly have discussed the possibility of a merger several times over the last decade. Nymex and Comex, which have been housed in the same lower Manhattan facility since 1933, trade a variety of commodities, including oil, gold, silver, copper and aluminum. The joint body will include a chairman who is a Nymex member, a vice chairman who is a Comex member, 16 Nymex member directors, eight Comex member directors and six public directors. ``Many of the terms upon which the consolidation would occur, including the extent and basis upon which either exchange's liquid capital reserves would be made available to the consolidated entity, remain to be determined,'' the statement read. The two exchanges also said any agreement reached by the executive committees and board is subject to membership and regulatory approval. Nymex, the largest energy exchange, trades crude oil, heating oil, unleaded gasoline, residual fuel oil, propane, platinum and palladium futures. Comex, the most active metals exchange, trades gold, silver, copper and aluminum futures. Comex traded 19 million contracts in 1989, while Nymex traded 38.5 million. A futures contract is an agreement to buy or sell a fixed amount of a commodity or instrument at a set price on a future date.

DOC.HEAD: Many Lenders Tightening Home Equity Credit In Face of Housing Slump
Graphic planned
DOC.TEXT: The owner of a Denver printing company surrenders the keys of his two-bedroom condominum to a lender because the unit's net value is far less than the balance of a second mortgage. A government employee in Florida worries he won't have enough money after lowering the selling price on his house to repay a home-equity loan plus put a down payment on new property. The slumped housing market not only is erasing homeseller profits, it's beginning to put a damper on the $111 billion industry for home-equity loans and lines of credit _ which only a few years ago ballooned into one of the nation's most popular forms of borrowing. Peddled by bankers eager to lend money, these loans have been used by homeowners to finance everything from vacations to college for the kids, backed by the properties themselves as collateral. They are especially popular because the interest generally is deductible under the 1986 tax reform, which is phasing out the deductibility of other consumer loans. The rates also are much lower compared with personal loans. Borrowing against the house remains a convenient way to tap into one of the nation's greatest pools of wealth _ an estimated $4.5 trillion in homeowner equity. But eroding housing prices in many parts of the country have reduced some of that equity, limiting homeowners' borrowing power and leaving some past borrowers with more loan than equity, experts say. As a result, some banks, thrifts and other lenders have tightened their credit policies, and at least one expert predicts a significant number may start to flee the home-equity business this year. ``I think more people will be looking at their homes as shelter than as an investment,'' said A. Gary Shilling, head a New York economics firm that bears his name. ``They thought they had this never-ending appreciating asset that they could tap, but it's not.'' Ken K., a Denver printer who preferred not to reveal his last name for publication, found that out the hard way. He said he recently returned to a lender the two-bedroom condo bought as an investment five years ago after the balance on a second loan came due. Since the condo's market value had fallen to around $30,000 from the $52,500 purchase price, he realized that even by selling the condo he couldn't come up with the $9,000 needed to repay the lender. The situation isn't quite as grim for a Florida government official, who also wished to remain anonymous. However, he is concerned that by consistently lowering the $200,000 asking price of his home, there'll be little left to put a deposit on another house and repay a $25,000 home-equity credit line. Despite these types of problems, many financial institutions remain optimistic about home-equity loans, noting that defaults remain relatively rare and prudent credit policies should forestall serious defaults. The American Bankers Association said that in 1988, the last year for which complete data was available, losses from home equity loan defaults among all commercial banks totaled $220 million. That's considered negligible compared with the billions in potentially bad Third World loans, for example. Some delinquency rates, however, have risen. At the end of the third quarter of last year 0.93 percent of all open-end credit lines were delinquent, or at least 30 days past due, up from 0.86 percent the same time in 1988, ABA figures show. The delinquency rate on closed-end loans was 1.69 percent in the third quarter, down from 1.76 percent, it said. An open, or revolving line of credit, lets borrowers set aside an amount of money to be used when needed. A closed-end loan, or second mortgage, provides a fixed dollar amount. A softer real-estate market, coupled with a rise in delinquency rates, has prompted many lenders to emphasize borrowers' ability to repay rather than a home's appraised value. ``A home equity loan is more a personal loan than a real estate loan,'' said Paul Fritts, director of the division of supervision at the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. ``Unless you have good solid equity together with a good work record ... I think it will be more difficult to get those loans.'' Fritts said some banks that may have taken a chance on homeowners who were considered riskier than average when housing values rose are rejecting their loan applications now. A few bankers said privately that they've started restricting home equity credit lines and loans mainly to homeowners on which they hold the primary mortgage or to longstanding customers with reputable credit histories. Banks also are less likely to lend beyond their standard credit limits, which typically run to about 80 percent of the available equity in a home, Fritts said. When housing values were firmer, a few banks extended credit to as much as 90 percent, he said. At Connecticut National Bank in Hartford, the maximum credit limit was trimmed several weeks ago partly because ``we saw that the New England real estate market was starting to soften,'' said Donald Grigley, who's in charge of the bank's installment finance businesses. He said that although losses from defaults remain low, the bank had noticed a slight increase in late payments. Frequent late payments will prompt lenders to review a loan contract and borrowers' credit record, and in some cases, to order a reappraisal of the property used as collateral. However, as long as borrowers pay on time they have little to worry about, even if the balance exceeds the equity in their home because of declining real estate prices, experts say. Still, Paul Havemann, a vice president at Butler, N.J.-based HSH Associates, which publishes mortgage market information, predicts the housing slump will help prompt some lenders to stop offering home-equity credit altogether this year. Havemann said he already has seen some signs of a pullout. It's harder to find lenders in the home equity business for his monthly survey of rates.
