DOC.HEAD: Traders Say FBI Coerced Them Into Confessions
DOC.TEXT: Three indicted traders from the Chicago Mercantile Exchange say the FBI came to their homes and coerced them into giving incriminating statements during a government probe of the futures industry. Sam Cali, Robert Bailin and John Baker, all traders in the Merc's Japanese yen pits, say armed FBI agents came to their homes and threatened to arrest them and take their property if they refused to cooperate. Assistant U.S. Attorneys Mark Pollack and Daniel Gillogly, who were present for part of the interviews with the men, have labeled the charges ``false and outlandish.'' U.S. District Judge William T. Hart was expected to begin taking evidence today to determine which view would prevail. Defense attorneys have asked for the pretrial hearing in an effort to keep prosecutors from presenting the contents of the interviews to a jury when the men go to trial April 23 with 14 other yen traders. The traders' allegations were made in pretrial motions filed by the three men, the Chicago Tribune reported in today's editions. The traders were charged with racketeering Aug. 2 in the government's first round of indictments stemming from the investigation of alleged improper trading practices at the Merc and the Chicago Board of Trade. Four of the yen traders have pleaded guilty and have agreed to testify against others. Cali, Bailin and Baker have pleaded innocent.

DOC.HEAD: Lujan Settles Strip Mining Dispute
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 10 grafs new with agreement signed; picks up at pvs 5th graf, `An initial ...,' and deletes redundant last graf. Also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Interior Secretary Manual Lujan, in a bid to end a decade-old battle with environmental groups, agreed today to create a new computer system to make it easier for the government to suspend coal mining permits issued to past violators of the 1977 strip mining law. Interior Department officials said the agreement signals a new and more cooperative approach to the concerns of environmentalists on the part of President Bush and his administration. In the exchange for the dropping of a law suit, Lujan agreed to a detailed ``work plan'' to improve the computerized Applicant Violator System maintained by the department's Office of Surface Mining. The system has been widely regarded as a failure. ``Our aim is fair, even-handed enforcement of the surface mining law,'' Lujan said in a statement. ``This new agreement underscores our willingness to cooperate with citizen groups and the Congress in seeing that the law is enforced consistently and effectively.'' At the same time, Lujan said, ``this settlement does not go beyond the law's requirements, or compromise coal mine operators' entitlement to due process of the law.'' The agreement, worked out in intense negotiating sessions beginning last September, is aimed at creating a computer system that will accurately match previous violators of the law with applicants for new coal mining permits. Brent Rushforth, an attorney for Save Our Cumberland Mountains, a principal plaintiff in the case, told reporters: ``This agreement goes further than ever before to assure that the information is accurate and that permits issued to violators can be suspended.'' ``It doesn't go beyond the law; it implements the law,'' Rushforth said. Filed in 1980, the suit arose out of the conviction of many residents of the coal mining regions of Appalachia that strip mining laws were going unenforced. An initial settlement was reached in 1981 after a court order directed the Interior Department to install a computer system to match past violators with new coal mining applicants. Critics complained some strip mine operators found to have violated the law simply changed the name of their companies and applied for a new permit at another location. Many such operators were failing to comply with requirements that the land be restored after the mining was completed, the critics said. Installation of the computer system did not end complaints. Environmentalists contended the system proved wholly ineffective in preventing the issuance of new permits to past violators. Early last year, the Save Our Cumberland Mountains organization sought to have a judge hold the Interior Department in contempt of court for allegedly failing to comply with the earlier court order that it strictly enforce the surface mining law.

DOC.HEAD: CNN to Open Bureaus in Manila, Brussels
DOC.TEXT: Cable News Network, which already has 12 bureaus outside the United States, said Wednesday it plans to open two more, in the Philippines capital Manila and in Brussels, Belgium. CNN also named Maria Ressa as its Manila correspondent. She has been the network's stringer there since June. Patricia Kelly, a print and broadcast reporter in Brussels since 1974, will be CNN's Brussels bureau chief.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Lower, Gold Soars
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version for AMs is planned by 5:30 p.m. EST.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar tumbled against all major foreign currencies, except the Canadian dollar, in hectic European trading Wednesday in the wake of lower stock prices. Gold prices jumped about $11 an ounce in active trading after several large purchases triggered a wave of technical buying. Traders said the dollar dropped sharply in reaction to weakness on Wall Street, but recovered some of its early losses as U.S. stock prices recovered. ``The market is overreacting to movement in the equity markets because there is no other news and no clear direction,'' said one corporate dealer in London. Another London trader said: ``The dollar has fallen a long way on very little.'' In London, the British pound rose to $1.6555 from $1.6480 late Tuesday. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Tuesday's rates were: 1.6855 West German marks, down from 1.6965; 1.4975 Swiss francs, down from 1.5070; 5.7305 French francs, down from 5.7625; 1.8975 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9225; 1,255.75 Italian lire, down from 1,262.00; and 1.1852 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1780. In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 145.80 Japanese yen from 146.33 yen at Tuesday's close. Later, in London, it fell to 145.35 yen. Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $421.50 a troy ounce, up from $413 late Tuesday. In Zurich, the metal rose to a closing bid of $420 dollars, up from $408.50 late Tuesday. The Hong Kong gold market was closed for the Lunar New Year holidays. Silver rose in London to a late bid price of $5.34 a troy ounce, up from $5.32 late Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Hughes Posts Quarterly Profits
DOC.TEXT: Baker Hughes Inc., an oil tool maker, posted a 46 percent quarterly profit gain, despite a worldwide decrease in drilling activity, the company announced Wednesday. Earnings for the three months ended Dec. 31, the company's first fiscal quarter, were $25.4 million, or 20 cents a share, on revenue of $579 million, compared with earnings of $17.4 million, or 13 cents per share, on revenue of $566 million a year earlier. ``The increase in revenues in the first quarter of 1990 was achieved despite a 1.6 percent decrease in worldwide drilling activity,'' said J.D. Woods, Baker Hughes' chairman, president and chief executive officer. ``Additionally, the year earlier quarter included revenues of $57.8 million from mining equipment operations which were sold in July 1989. The increase in earnings was a result of the continuing favorable mix in the oilfield operations as well as significant improvement in the quality of revenues in Baker Hughes process equipment.'' Woods said the progress of the previously announced acquisition of Eastman Christensen Co. is on schedule and expected to be completed by March 31. ``The acquisition of Eastman Christensen will allow Baker Hughes to be a prominent participant in the rapidly growing high performance directional drilling markets, which will benefit the company, its stockholders and the community.'' Houston-based Baker Hughes also is noted for keeping a nationwide count of drilling rig activity.

DOC.HEAD: U S West Say Earnings Rose for Quarter, Dropped for Year
DOC.TEXT: U S West Inc. reported an increase in fourth-quarter earnings Wednesday, but said profit for the regional phone company dropped slightly for all of 1989. ``We ended the year on a very positive note financially, and as a whole,'' said Jack MacAllister, chairman and chief executive officer. ``Our business is more exciting than it's ever been _ we're truly becoming a global communications company.'' In the fourth quarter, which ended Dec. 31, U S West reported net income of $344.4 million, or $1.84 a share, compared with the 1988 fourth-quarter net income of $271.7 million, or $1.49 per share. Fourth-quarter revenue totaled $2.5 billion, compared with revenue of $2.3 billion in 1988's fourth quarter. The results for the 1989 quarter were due to increased revenue from local phone operations, long-distance service, cellular and paging operations and the company's directory publishing operation, the company said. It also said it benefitted from a property sale and a change in accounting for income taxes. For the year, the company's net income totaled $1.11 billion, or $6.02 a share, compared with $1.13 billion, or $6.17 per share, in 1988. Revenue for 1989 totaled $9.7 billion, up from $9.2 billion in 1988. The 1988 results include a non-recurring after-tax gain of $88.7 million, or 4tials Unlimited Inc. of Grand Rapids, which claims to be the biggest, and Midwest Research Inc. of Walled Lake, a Detroit suburb. The industry's premise is that we can recognize information presented below our threshold of awareness. Even though the listener hears only soothing music or the sound of ocean waves on an audio cassette or sees images of nature on a video, the subconscious mind can detect the hundreds or thousands of speeded-up, underlying subliminal suggestions, manufacturers say. Mind Communication offers about 300 titles by direct mail, ranging from weight loss and improving sex _ two of the biggest sellers _ to controlling spending habits and becoming a better bowler. There are tapes designed for children to build self-esteem or stop bedwetting. Subliminals have been raising eyebrows since the 1950s, when it was reported that by flashing ``eat popcorn'' during a movie, theatergoers rushed for the concession stand, unaware they had been subliminally persuaded. In recent years, it appears millions of consumers have brushed aside the diabolic connotations associated with mind control and comparisons to Big Brother while they plunk down $10 to $40 for what manufacturers market as a shortcut for solving problems and breaking bad habits. The 60-minute tapes, most of which provide a script of their messages, are prominently displayed near self-help books in national bookstore chains. Such publishing companies as Simon & Schuster, Random House and Bantam Books recently have devised their own versions. Many respected researchers accept the validity of subliminal perception, but claim there is no proof that these self-help tapes work. ``They're a waste of time and money,'' said Howard Shevrin, a University of Michigan psychologist who's been involved in subliminal research for more than 30 years. Shevrin said even if there was a behavioral change in some people it would be impossible to trace it to the tapes. Shevrin suggests the possibility of harmful side effects in some people, a theory with which Tuthill agrees. ``Theoretically, they could be harmful with forced prolonged exposure,'' Tuthill said. ``If the message is noxious or contrary to what you want, people have actually developed some bizarre symptoms.'' Tuthill said he has seen a smoker develop headaches and heart palpitations when exposed to a stop-smoking tape. The symptoms stopped when the person stopped listening to the music. Tuthill even puts warning labels on his weight loss tapes because of reports from pediatricians that children inadvertently exposed to the tapes were losing weight. Barrie Konicov, owner of the 14-year-old Potentials Unlimited, has among his 200 titles Bust Enlargement and Birth Control (``If you create a thought that you will not get pregnant, you will not get pregnant,'' is one message.) A 1981 raid by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration forced Konicov to soften his medical claims. He stands by his tapes, 1 million to 2 million copies of which sell each year worldwide in such bookstore chains as B. Dalton, WaldenBooks and Barnes & Noble. ``Look, it's a $10 tape,'' he said, adding that the company offers a money-back guarantee. ``Nobody questions what we do.'' Though the field is largely unregulated, the Texas Attorney General's office confirmed it is investigating claims made by several such companies. The use of such tapes by retailers to cut shoplifting or by employers to increase production of unsuspecting employees has raised ethical questions. Tuthill's biggest customers are retailers, but he said he has turned down requests from auto dealers and political candidates. While many of the companies cite self-conducted studies, little independent research has been done in the area of self-help subliminals. Most of the companies point to individual testimonials as proof of their effectiveness. Two Canadian psychology professors who have done independent research call the tapes a health fraud. Timothy Moore of York University's Glendon College in Toronto said some of the tapes he has studied apparently contain no hidden message at all. Philip Merikle of the University of Waterloo in Ontario said an analysis of tapes made by several companies found there is no identifiable signal on them that could penetrate the subconscious. He likened the amazing success stories to placebos. ``We've known for hundreds of years that effective treatments are ones that people believe are going to work,'' he said. But subliminal tapes, he concluded, ``are clearly health fraud. ``It's not inconceivable that 20 to 30 percent of these people could report real improvement, but not for the reasons used by the manufacturers,'' he said. ``But if 25 percent of the people who listen to these tapes stop smoking, that's great. That's also the irony of it.''

DOC.HEAD: Corporate America Develops New Product: An Inner-City School
An AP Extra. Also on general news wires.
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Phyllis Pelt's workday is consumed by the grim realities of the ghetto: the evicted family, the girl who goes hungry, the boy whose mother was murdered. It's part of life as a school nurse. Only minutes and miles away, Chuck Ruder's day on the 51st floor of the sleek Sears Tower is devoted to the fast pace and steady pressures of retail and finance. It's part of life in the Fortune 500. Little children and big business, rich and poor, two worlds seemingly destined to remain apart. Instead, they've united in an experiment in which corporate America's money, muscle and management are being used to develop a desperately needed product: academic success in the inner city. The Corporate-Community Schools of America is a tuition-free academy created, guided and financed by United Airlines, Baxter International, Sears, Quaker Oats, McDonald's and other Chicago-area powerhouses that donate dollars and sense to matters ranging from purchasing to personnel. ``We must manage our schools as we manage our major corporations _ with accountability, responsibility, skilled, talented, paid people,'' said school founder Joe Kellman. ``If there was a profit motive ... is there any doubt IBM, General Motors and Sears Roebuck would be in the school business? ``If you try to run major city school systems with volunteers that have no skill, get no money and have no time, then you get what you've got _ bankrupt systems,'' he said. Big city education is a billion-dollar business, Kellman says, so who better to oversee it than experienced executives such as Ruder, from Sears? He's among seven corporate board members; eight others are area residents or educators. Such partnerships aren't new. America's corporations have poured millions into education programs ranging from adopt-a-school systems to guaranteed jobs. Organizers say this is different. ``They're supporting and assisting; we're building,'' said Bud Kraus, assistant to the chairman and chief executive officer at Baxter, a medical and hospital supply company. The 1{-year-old private academy, in predominantly black Lawndale, one of Chicago's poorest neighborhoods, is designed to be a lab to find ways to teach inner-city children, then duplicate the process in urban areas nationwide. ``We're looking to influence change in the system, not educate 300 kids,'' Kraus said. The school's small size and independence set it apart. Unlike urban systems, there are no powerful unions, no tangled bureaucracies, no crumbling buildings. Teachers' salaries are 10 percent to 15 percent higher. As far as duplicating this in Chicago, ``I can't see how you can do it with prevailing resources,'' said Robert Saddler, deputy school superintendent and a board member of the corporate school. Still, he said, ``I don't think you have to replicate it on a mass scale to gain from it.'' Chicago's schools are doing their own experimenting with a reform plan establishing local councils in each of some 600 schools, giving parents major decision-making powers. Kellman thinks success will be limited, considering 68 percent of Chicago's 409,000 public school students live in poverty. ``The underclass will never manage their schools,'' he said. ``They're having trouble managing their lives.'' Kellman concedes he's no educator _ he quit school after eighth grade to join his father's glass business and now runs the $100 million corporation. But the 70-year-old philanthropist knows business, and he's devoted to Lawndale, his childhood home. Today, it's in trouble. More than half Lawndale's residents get public aid. More than a third of the housing is substandard. Recent studies found a murder rate six times the national average, infant mortality almost three times as great. ``If you walk into a typical class and ask a group of children how many know someone who's been shot ... hit by a car ... in jail ... or been killed, virtually all the hands go up,'' said Primus Mootry, the school's project director, who grew up in the area. Despite such brutal surroundings, educators hope to prove these children can learn as well as those raised in affluence. ``(We do) not accept any of the stereotypes that might travel with the neighborhood the school is situated in,'' said teacher Kathy Irwin. ``We do not put numbers on their heads in terms of IQ. (Some say) there are social or biological limits. We reject that.'' ``The example we're setting is that educating children in the inner city ... is not only possible, but the children deserve it,'' said principal Elaine Mosley. To smooth the way, the school has taken special steps. Classes, for example, are held year-round to minimize exposure to street life. The building is open from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m. to accommodate working parents _ pre-school takes children as young as 2 _ and high school equivalency degree programs are offered. Each room has a teacher and an aide. There are no grades, and children up to age 9 are grouped in two-year clusters, an idea that appeals to Elaine Finley, whose two sons and daughter are pupils. ``They're learning at their own speed. ... Public school would have pushed them aside,'' she said. ``They're active participants in learning. In public school they would sit back behind a desk all day.'' Mrs. Pelt cuts red tape, working with dozens of social service agencies. She weighs children, helps them get eyeglasses, makes dental appointments, supplies gloves, accompanies parents to doctor visits and even allows them to do their laundry at the school. ``The role of the school is everything that needs to be done to enhance learning,'' she said. Money helps. More than $2.8 million has been invested, mostly by 55 corporations providing annual contributions ranging up to $150,000. The $5,200 annual per-pupil cost, compared with $4,624 in Chicago, will drop as enrollment increases from the current 200 to the 300 maximum, Kraus said. All pupils are chosen by lottery. Businesses also provide resources. Sears, for example, donated carpeting, air conditioners and cabinets. But just as vital is white-collar wisdom. ``There are parts of the school that are much like a business _ personnel practice and policies, for instance,'' said Ruder, Sears' vice president of corporate public affairs. Still, there are skeptics. Business leaders don't have the ``magic answer'' to education problems, said Don Moore, director of Designs for Change, a group involved in Chicago's school reform. ``I'm just as content to see the manager of a store or a bus driver or a policeman on one of these councils,'' he said. Moore also wonders, ``How long are these corporations willing to put up this much money? ... The history of these kinds of efforts is they fall on hard times after awhile.'' School officials say it's too early to gauge success. But Kellman predicts that at the end of three years, pupils' test scores will be better than their public school counterparts. Mootry said the school already has helped by bringing movers and shakers to Lawndale. ``They see the families,'' he said. ``They realize it's not just a bunch of poor, drug-crazed underclass folks but people struggling to make their lives better. It's drawing attention to the plight of the community. ... It's bringing some hope.''

DOC.TEXT: Sharon Cohen is the AP Midwest Regional Reporter, based in Chicago.

DOC.HEAD: BankAmerica Chief to Retire, Report Says
DOC.TEXT: A. W. Clausen, who returned to BankAmerica Corp. in 1986 to lead it through a remarkable financial comeback, will retire this year, according to a report published Wednesday. The San Francisco Examiner quoted sources close to the bank, who asked not to be named, as saying that the chairman and chief executive officer will retire and his successor will be announced before the bank's annual meeting on May 24. But BankAmerica spokesman Peter Magnani declined comment. ``We have no comment. We just won't speculate,'' he said when asked for reaction to the published report. ``We have made no announcement.'' Clausen, 66, joined BankAmerica in 1949 and climbed the corporate ladder to become chief executive in 1970. He left to head the World Bank in Washington, D.C., in 1981. Once the largest bank in the nation, BankAmerica suffered major losses related to its Third World loans in 1985-87. BankAmerica, parent of Bank of America, lost nearly $1 billion in 1987. Clausen returned as chairman to stabilize the banking institution's image. BankAmerica sold its headquarters building in San Francisco and its Charles Schwab brokerage subsidiary, cut expenses and laid off employees, also taking steps to improve its credit. Last week, BankAmerica reported its 1989 earnings were up an impressive 52 percent and its annual profit soared to $1.1 billion, the highest in its 80-year history. The Examiner article identified the most likely candidate to replace Clausen as BankAmerica Vice Chairman Richard Rosenberg, 59, who heads the company's California banking operations. Also listed as in the running for the top job is BankAmerica Chief Financial Officer Frank Newman, 47.

DOC.HEAD: Stock Market Moves Broadly Lower
DOC.TEXT: The stock market suffered another broad setback today, extending Wall Street's early-1990 slide as worries mounted about rising interest rates and pressure on the Japanese market. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down 194.83 points over the past three weeks, was down another 33.56 to 2,581.76 by 2 p.m. on Wall Street. The widely followed index regained some ground after a more than 60-point plunge at the opening. Losers overwhelmed gainers by about 7 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 204 stocks rising, 1,397 falling and 333 unchanged. Prices skidded after traders learned overnight of a sharp decline in the Tokyo stock market, which has been unsettled lately by rising interest rates in Japan. Analysts said the drop in the Japanese market intensified fears that rates would have to climb further in this country to stay competitive in the international marketplace. A sale by the government Tuesday of 40-year bonds to finance a rescue plan for troubled thrift institutions drew a very chilly reception from investors. As the outlook for interest rates has worsened, investors have begun to face the possibility that the recent slowdown of the economy might deepen in the months ahead. Brokers also said a weak attempt by stocks to rally on Tuesday left many traders unimpressed and disheartened. Today's drop opened up some room for bargain hunters who helped bring prices off their early lows. Losers among the blue chips included Merck, down 1] at 39[; Coca-Cola, down 1| at 69], and IBM, down [ at 96|. Precious metals issues provided one of the market's few pockets of strength. ASA Ltd. gained 1{ to 65; Homestake Mining { to 22~, and Newmont Gold ] to 53{. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks was off 2.40 to 181.20. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down 6.99 at 352.74. Volume on the Big Board came to 152.22 million shares at midafternoon.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Post Modest Decline
DOC.NOTE: EDS: RECASTS throughout to UPDATE with later activity, closing indices; No pickup
DOC.TEXT: London shares were buffeted by continuing erratic swings on world stock markets Wednesday, but recovered to show only a modest decline at the close of trading. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index finished down 12.5 points, or 0.5 percent, at 2,278.6. That was just 0.2 point shy of its 2,278.8 peak for the day and well above its low of 2,250.5, or 40.6 points down. Volume was a moderate 527.9 million shares, down from 544.3 million on Tuesday. Dealers said late afternoon bargain-hunting saved the London market from a rout. The market was extremely jittery, they said. The gyrations also affected the foreign-exchange markets, where worries about stocks accelerated a decline in the dollar in hectic trading. ``We're shellshocked,'' said one London stock dealer. ``It puts everyone off doing anything because you don't know where Tokyo or New York is going to end up. It doesn't make for calm markets.'' London shares initially fell sharply amid nervousness over a tumble in Tokyo earlier Wednesday. The Tokyo market's Nikkei 225-share index shed nearly 600 points after a poor round of U.S. Treasury bond auctions, which widened the already pronounced discrepancy between stock and bond yields. That pointed to further declines in equity values. At the start of London trading, dealers also were expecting a plunge of as much as 100 points in the Dow Jones industrial average at Wall Street's opening. After trading began in New York, the blue-chip average dropped more than 61 points but then rebounded to show a decline of about 44 points when the London market closed. London investors found the rebound encouraging. The Dow Jones barometer has dropped nearly 200 points in the past three weeks. In London, the Financial Times 30-share index was down 11.0 points at 1,828.6 at the close. The Financial Times 500-share index fell 10.31 points to close at 1,243.38.

DOC.HEAD: Company Reimbursed Executives Attending Haig Fund-Raiser, Founder Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf pvs bg'ng, Joseph Guerin ... to CORRECT first name to James; Also moved on general newswires
DOC.TEXT: A defense contractor reimbursed executives who attended a $500-a-plate fund-raiser for Alexander Haig's presidential campaign in 1987, the company's founder said in court documents. Corporations cannot legally contribute directly or indirectly to presidential campaigns. James Guerin, founder of International Signal & Control Corp., made the allegation in a deposition filed Tuesday in an employment dispute with his former chief attorney. The dinner raised some $26,000 for Haig. The deposition said the former chief attorney, William A. Clark, had told Guerin and other top ISC officials he felt the contributions were illegal, the deposition said. Guerin, in his sworn testimony, gave no further details about the alleged reimbursements. There was no indication in the documents that Haig, secretary of state under President Reagan, White House chief of staff under Presidents Nixon and Ford and former NATO supreme commander, was aware of the alleged arrangement between ISC and its executives. ``I can certainly say that we are shocked and surprised and know absolutely nothing about what was alleged,'' Woody Goldberg, a spokesman for Haig, said from Washington today. ``We wouldn't know and certainly have no knowledge about this whatsoever.'' Goldberg said Haig was out of town and could not be reached. News reports at the time of the dinner quoted an ISC spokesman as saying the company had a keen interest in Haig and felt his presidency would benefit the company. A year earlier, Haig had worked as a consultant to ISC and helped negotiate a deal to sell missiles to the Pakistani government of the late Gen. Mohammed Zia ul-Haq, Guerin said. Guerin later sold ISC to the London-based Ferranti International PLC for $670 million in Ferranti stock. In the employment dispute, Clark claimed Guerin paid him only $1 million of a promised $2.75 million settlement ending Clark's five-year association with Guerin. Guerin countered that Clark used coercion and extortion to secure the agreement.

DOC.HEAD: Stock Market Moves Broadly Lower
DOC.TEXT: The stock market suffered another broad setback today, extending Wall Street's early-1990 slide as worries mounted about rising interest rates and pressure on the Japanese market. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down 194.83 points over the past three weeks, was down another 26.81 to 2,588.51 by 3 p.m. on Wall Street. The widely followed index regained ground after a more than 60-point plunge at the opening. Losers overwhelmed gainers by about 6 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 246 stocks rising, 1,374 falling and 330 unchanged. Prices skidded after traders learned overnight of a sharp decline in the Tokyo stock market, which has been unsettled lately by rising interest rates in Japan. Analysts said the drop in the Japanese market intensified fears that rates would have to climb further in this country to stay competitive in the international marketplace. A sale by the government Tuesday of 40-year bonds to finance a rescue plan for troubled thrift institutions drew a very chilly reception from investors. As the outlook for interest rates has worsened, investors have begun to face the possibility that the recent slowdown of the economy might deepen in the months ahead. Brokers also said a weak attempt by stocks to rally on Tuesday left many traders unimpressed and disheartened. Today's drop opened up some room for bargain hunters who helped bring prices off their early lows, but blue chip issues were the main beneficiaries of the buying spurt. Comeback stocks included Merck, up { at 72]; General Electric, up ] at 63[; and AT&T, up \ to 41. Big losers included Dupont, down 1\ to 39\; Coca-Cola, off 1\ at 69}; and ITT, down 1 at 53}. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks was off 1.88 to 181.72. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down 6.76 at 352.97. Volume on the Big Board came to 176.41 million shares with an hour of trading to go.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Workers in Britain Accept 10.2 Percent Wage Increase; Avert Strike
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with final returns; No pickup; Also moved on general newswires
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. Ltd. workers voted by nearly 3-2 to accept a 10.2 percent pay increase, averting a nationwide strike, union leaders said Wednesday. Final returns showed that 59 percent of those voting went against their union leaders' recommendation and accepted the improved offer. They will get a 10.2 percent raise in the first year and a minimum of 8 percent, or a choice of 2.5 percent above inflation, in the second year. The vote took place Tuesday and Wednesday. Most of the 32,000 workers at the U.S. company's 22 British plants earn an average of $374 a week. Union leaders rejected the offer last week and sought agreement from the workers to start striking with the last shift on Friday. The Ford pay negotiations are considered a bellwether for Britain's manufacturing industry. A higher settlement there would have encouraged other pay demands, further undermining Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's battle to cut Britain's high inflation rate of nearly 8 percent. As it is, the Ford deal is likely to mean more double-digit pay demands. The engineering union, the biggest in the country, immediately announced it considered 10.2 percent a ``benchmark'' for raises throughout industry. A spokesman for the Ford unions, who wasn't identified in accordance with British practice, said members accepted the proposal because ``it was quite a good offer.'' ``It was always our aim to get our members a pay settlement in double figures and that we did,'' he added. A Ford spokesman said the acceptance vote ``has saved us the prospect of a potentially damaging strike here and at Ford's continental (European) plants.'' Workers at Ford plants near London and Liverpool, among the largest sites, voted only narrowly to accept the offer; it was rejected at two major engine plants in South Wales. Unofficial strikes at some plants are possible, including at Halewood, near Liverpool in northwestern England, where 550 workers in their second week of an unofficial strike may stay out to protest the settlement.

DOC.HEAD: Nymex, Comex Pursuing Merger; Joint Governing Board Formed
DOC.TEXT: The New York Mercantile Exchange and Commodity Exchange Inc. said Wednesday they were exploring a merger of the two markets, a combination that analysts said could give the Comex the most immediate rewards. The two commodities markets announced they were pursuing merger negotiations and would form a joint board that would govern any consolidated company resulting from a merger. The exchanges, which trade a variety of precious metals and energy futures, said they agreed to form a joint governing board after their executive committees met Tuesday. The markets'e respective boards instructed their executive committees to continue negotiations over the most efficient way to consolidate the administration and operations of the exchanges. Analysts said Nymex and Comex, which have been housed in the same lower Manhattan building since 1933, have discussed merging at various times over the last decade. Sharing resources would mean greater efficiency and cost savings for both exchanges, but particularly for the smaller commodities exchange, they said. ``I see more advantages for Comex,'' said Evan Baron, senior account executive for Elders Futures Inc. ``Its entire trading system needs to be overhauled. Nymex is already more computerized and up to the minute.'' Comex still operates under an antiquated trading system that is more vulnerable to fraud, he said. In addition, ``sharing the Merc fee revenue appeals to them,'' said John Azarow, vice president and senior energy trader for Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. A marriage of varied products and markets _ as the much larger Chicago commodity exchanges have had for years _ also makes sense financially and strategically. ``The concept of having diversified products is attractive because if one market is quiet another one might be cooking,'' said Azarow. While Nymex now is the larger, more active market, that wasn't always true. At various times in the 1970s and 1980s, Comex was the bigger, more active exchange. Comex traded 19 million futures and options contracts last year compared with 38.5 million for Nymex. ``Now is the Merc's time in the sun, but who knows? We could have a change in the economic environment and oils could slump while the metals markets boom,'' said Azarow. But while current Comex volume is down, ``the Merc is slowly reaching maturation,'' said one analyst who did not want to be named. Except for a proposed new natural gas contract, it has traded the same products for years, he said. The joint governing body will include a chairman who is a Nymex member, a vice chairman who is a Comex member, 16 Nymex member directors, eight Comex member directors and six public directors. The exchanges said many of the terms of any consolidation had not yet been determined, including the extent that either exchange's liquid capital reserves woudl be made available to the consolidated market. The two exchanges also said any agreement reached by the executive committees and board is subject to membership and regulatory approval. Nymex, the nation's largest energy exchange, trades crude oil, heating oil, unleaded gasoline, residual fuel oil, propane, platinum and palladium futures. Comex trades gold, silver, copper and aluminum futures. A futures contract is an agreement to buy or sell a fixed amount of a commodity or instrument at a set price on a future date. Both exchanges also trade options in many products. Options are contracts that permit the owner to buy or sell at a fixed price until a specific date.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Close Mostly Lower On Slack Export Sales
DOC.TEXT: Futures prices of grain and soybeans closed mostly lower Wednesday on the Chicago Board of Trade, reflecting slack export demand for the commodities. The markets had opened slightly lower amid worries about the stock market's steep early decline, then turned higher as stocks steadied, only to finish with slight losses. ``When all was said and done, we finished right about where we started,'' said Dale Gustafson, an analyst with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. in Chicago. He said export demand for U.S. wheat, corn and soybeans had been very slow, although traders are expecting the Agriculture Department to announce new wheat subsidies for China and the Soviet Union. At the close of trading, wheat futures were 1\ cents lower to \ cent higher with the contract for delivery in March at $3.91{ a bushel; corn was { cent to 1 cent lower with March at $2.40{ a bushel; oats were unchanged to 1 cent higher with March at $1.39 a bushel; soybeans were 2\ cents lower to { cent higher with March at $5.65{ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Two-Year Yields Rise
DOC.TEXT: Yields on two-year Treasury notes rose in Wednesday's auction to the highest level since last September. The average yield was 8.21 percent, up from 7.71 percent at the last comparable auction on Dec. 19. It was the highest rate since two-year notes averaged 8.39 percent on Sept. 26. The notes will carry a coupon interest rate of 8[ percent with each $10,000 in face value selling for $9,984.60. A total of $10 billion in notes was sold out of bids totaling $26.9 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Incoming NADA President Says Lower Rates, Production Would Help Dealers
DOC.TEXT: Lower interest rates and production schedules could help make half of the nation's financially troubled auto dealers profitable by year's end, according to the incoming president of the nation's largest dealer group. The National Automobile Dealers Association, which represents about 20,000 U.S. car and truck dealers, has said for the past year that about half of its members either were losing money or just breaking even. Dealers have slashed vehicle orders from manufacturers, trimmed advertising spending and shrunk their inventories to cut costs. Now it's time for the government and manufacturers to do their part, NADA President-elect Ray Green said Tuesday. ``I think it is a possibility this year we could look for an upturn if interest rates would drop to 9 percent and if the automakers would cut production to the rate of sales,'' Green said in a telephone interview from NADA headquarters in suburban Washington, D.C. Some economists have urged the Federal Reserve to lower the discount rate, the interest it charges on loans to banks. That in turn could encourage declines in open-market interest rates, possibly leading to a cut in the prime lending rate charged by banks, now 10 percent. Banks use the prime for setting lending rates on some car loans and on a range of other consumer and business lending. ``If the things happen that I'm talking about, it could move easily to 75 percent profitable dealers by the end of the year,'' said Green. ``It doesn't take much per car in expense or profit to change that considerably.'' Outgoing NADA President Ron Tonkin and other organization officials blame the tough times for dealers on high interest rates and ambitious production schedules, which forced manufacturers to stick incentives on their new cars to help clear jammed dealer lots. That limited dealers' ability to get a fair return on their investment, Tonkin has said, and has shriveled their profits. Green said that on average, dealers nationwide are losing money on new car sales, and trying to make it up with profits from used cars, service and parts operations. Green, who begins his one-year term as NADA president next month at the organization's convention in Las Vegas, hsa been a member of the NADA's board of directors for eight years. He got into the automotive industry in 1952 when he joined General Motors Acceptance Corp. as a field representative in Des Moines, Iowa. Two years later he became a salesman at a Chevrolet-Buick-Cadillac dealership in Iowa City. Green later became a general manager of a dealership in Monmouth, Ill., a business he bought in 1958. Green now runs Green Holding Co. Inc. of Jacksonville, Ill., which owns four dealerships in central Illinois holding seven franchises. ``If the automobile manufacturers in North America are not making money and if the auto dealers are not making money selling new cars, there's something not working out there,'' Green said. ``It's going to have to be a different arrangement.''

Prices were mixed on Wall Street today after the stock market, boosted by bargain-hunting and program trading, regained some ground following a steep sell-off at the opening. Shortly before the close, the Dow Jones industrial average was little changed, trading at the 2,615 level.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T Closing Electronics Plant
DOC.TEXT: AT&T's New River Valley electronics plant, with 1,000 employees, will phase out operations over the next year to 15 months, the company announced Wednesday. Jay Walters, the plant's manufacturing director, said the shutdown results from excess capacity throughout AT&T's microelectronics business. Most of the electronic components made at the plant will be transferred to an AT&T plant in Dallas. ``We won't move any products associated with this announcement to other factories for at least 60 days,'' Walters said in a letter to the plant's employees. ``And as we shut down operations, we'll make a range of employee assistance programs available to you.'' AT&T began operations at the southwest Virginia plant in September 1980.

DOC.HEAD: Stock Market Moves Broadly Lower
DOC.TEXT: The stock market suffered another broad setback today, extending Wall Street's early-1990 slide as worries mounted about rising interest rates and pressure on the Japanese market. The Dow Jones industrial average tumbled more than 60 points at the opening after traders learned overnight of a sharp decline in the Tokyo stock market, which has been unsettled lately by rising interest rates in Japan. Bargain-hunting and program trading helped Wall Street regain some ground, but the market remained pessimistic. Analysts said the drop in the Japanese market intensified fears that rates would have to climb further in this country to stay competitive in the international marketplace. The Treasury's sale Tuesday of 40-year bonds to finance a rescue plan for troubled thrift institutions drew a very chilly reception from investors. As the outlook for interest rates has worsened, investors have begun to face the possibility that the recent slowdown of the economy might deepen in the months ahead. Brokers also said a weak attempt by stocks to rally on Tuesday left many traders unimpressed and disheartened.

DOC.HEAD: IBM, Siemens Announce Joint Venture To Develop New Computer Chip
DOC.TEXT: IBM and Siemens AG, the German electronics giant, said Wednesday they would jointly develop a new generation of computer memory chips. Under the agreement, the two companies will work on developing a 64-million-bit dynamic random access memory chip, or DRAM. The largest-capacity chip now on the market holds 4 million bits of information. That chip was first introduced commercially by International Business Machines Corp. last year. IBM and Siemens also have independent efforts under way to develop 16-million-bit chips, which would be the next generation after the 4-million-bit chip. A bit is the smallest unit of information used by a computer. Because of the way chips are constructed, advances in capacity usually take place in intervals of four times greater capacity than the previous generation. Development of the 64-million-bit, or 64 megabit, chip will take place at IBM's East Fishkill, N.Y., semiconductor center, and will use the resources of IBM's Essex Junction, Vt., facility and Siemens' Munich research center, the companies said in a statement. Each company will share equally in development costs, the companies said. Manufacturing would be done individually by Siemens and IBM, said IBM spokesman Paul Bergevin. IBM, the world's largest chip producer, uses all the chips it makes in its own products. It said it has no plans to sell the 64-million-bit chips on the open market. The goal of the joint venture is to have a world-standard 64-million-bit DRAM ready for commercial introduction in the mid-1990s, the companies said. ``The strengths of the two firms complement one another and increase the probability that world leadership in memory chip technology will be maintained,'' the companies said. The companies did not disclose what they expect to invest in the venture, Bergevin said. He said the joint venture was proposed to ``reduce the overall costs each firm would have had to bear individually.'' He said it will be the first time IBM has jointly developed a computer chip, although it has joint ventures in other areas. For example, IBM and Siemens jointly operate the Rolm telephone business. One industry analyst said the announcement is not surprising. ``The cost of development runs into the many millions of dollars. Each generation gets to be that much more expensive,'' said Millard H. Phelps of the San Francisco investment firm Hambrecht & Quist. He said Siemens, which is known for its basic research, is not a direct competitor of IBM. As computer chips become more complex and more circuits are packed onto the silicon wafers, the traditional method of making them _ using photolithography techniques with visible light to etch the electronic circuits _ is no longer practical, Phelps said. ``Probably at the 64 megabit (level) you can't do it that way,'' he said, and instead may require the use of X-rays or electron beams for the etching. ``They're really having to break a lot of physics barriers getting to that level,'' he said. ``That's why they had to get somebody with basic research involved.'' Phelps said other companies known to be working on 64 megabit chips include Texas Instruments Inc. and a number of Japanese companies, including Hitachi, NEC and Matsushita.

DOC.HEAD: Bubble Bursts For World's Largest Ad Agency
LaserPhoto, Graphic
DOC.TEXT: ``Saatchi and Saatchi First Over the Wall'' boasts a large poster recently hung on the eastern side of the Berlin Wall. It typifies the bravura that helped Saatchi & Saatchi Co. PLC burst onto the scene in the 1980s and gobble rivals to become the world's largest advertising company. But that audacity has backfired. A foray into consulting businesses has been disastrous, and costs spiraled out of control. If the London-based agency is to recover, analysts say it should stick to advertising. After nearly two decades of uninterrupted annual profit growth since brothers Maurice and Charles Saatchi founded the company, it recently reported the first loss, about $97 million for the fiscal year ended Sept. 30. Saatchi's stock has fallen sharply on London's exchange, and the company cut its annual dividend 38 percent. Five of the 12 directors have left in the past year and Saatchi recruited a new chief executive, Frenchman Robert Louis-Dreyfus, who turned around IMS International Inc., the New York-based pharmaceutical market research firm. Saatchi already has cut 800 jobs and is trying, with apparent difficulty, to sell its troublesome consulting businesses. Company executives declined to be interviewed, but Deputy Chairman Jeremy Sinclair said in a statement that although ad revenue growth has been slowing industry-wide, Saatchi ``has a solid base from which it can develop.'' Saatchi's strategy is to refocus on its communications business, exploiting advertising operations and strength in public relations, sales promotions and corporate identity and design, the statement said. ``Hopefully, they are going to get their house in order,'' said Richard Dale, a securities analyst with the London investment firm James Capel and Co. The Saatchi brothers, who own less than 5 percent of the stock, already had been drifting away from the day-to-day running of the company, British press reports suggested. Maurice Saatchi, 43, relinquished the chief executive's role but remains chairman. Charles Saatchi, 46, remains as executive director. Charles has been selling works from his private modern art collection, considered one of the finest, and reportedly is depressed over the breakup of his marriage. His brother is said to have lost some interest in the business since he married in 1984. The Saatchis' aversion to publicity has given them a Garbo-like mystique, which critics claim is carefully calculated. Glossy British magazines occasionally publish teasing photos of the dark-haired, intense-looking Saatchis trapped by paparazzi photographers. Charles reportedly has never attended a Saatchi shareholders' meeting. But their impact on advertising has been enormous. They pioneered a global company offering one-stop service to multinational clients. They convinced investors that ad agencies were sound, cash-generating investments despite a volatile image. They incited merger-mania in a creative, egocentric industry once thought invulnerable to corporate empire-building. But Saatchi's own dash for growth became its weakness. Although mega-agency status meant discounts on advertising space, the company inevitably ended up handling rival accounts. It lost hundreds of millions of dollars in business from the consumer products giants Procter & Gamble Co. and Colgate-Palmolive Co. and others, because clients were concerned about confidentiality and conflicts of interest. Born in Baghdad to a prosperous textile merchant, the Saatchis grew up in Hampstead, north London. Maurice was an academic success with a sharp business mind. Charles proved a brilliant copywriter. They set up their business in 1970 in Soho, London's ad agency heartland, and quickly developed a reputation for simple, provocative ads. Their 1971 print ad promoting contraception, for example, showed a pregnant man and asked, ``Would you be more careful if it was you who got pregnant?'' The agency became publicly owned within five years, and the Saatchis chose to relinquish ultimate control in exchange for the investors' money they needed to expand. The agency came to prominence in 1979 with the advertising campaign that helped the Conservatives oust the Labor Party and put Margaret Thatcher in office. ``Labor Isn't Working,'' said one poster, depicting a long line of unemployed people. Ambitious and self-made, the Saatchis embody the Thatcherite ideals of entrepreneurship and meritocracy. The Sunday Times' list of Britain's richest people estimates the Saatchis' personal fortune at 35 million pounds, or $58 million, and ranks them tied for 178th. But the Saatchis remain foreigners to Britain's upper crust, which bristles at their flashy, self-congratulatory style. Putting a billboard on the Berlin Wall was another example of their instinct for the well-timed publicity coup. To create their mega-agency, the Saatchis embarked on a takeover binge that shocked Madison Avenue and generated much hostility against what detractors called ``creeping Saatchiism.'' Their biggest purchases were Ted Bates, for $450 million, Dancer Fitzgerald Sample, for $75 million, and Backer and Spielvogel, for $56 million, all in 1986. That year Saatchi became the world's largest ad holding company. As a result, revenues climbed to nearly $700 million in 1986 and $1.5 billion in Saatchi's latest fiscal year from $62 million in 1982. It now employs 16,600 people in 58 countries, and had client billings of $13.5 billion in 1988, giving it control of 5 percent of the worldwide advertising market, the trade journal Advertising Age said. Saatchi has championed the global, translatable campaign, like its new TV ad for British Airways, appearing on three continents, in which 4,000 people form a smiling, winking face on a vast landscape. To overcome the reluctance of clients to be lumped together with their competitors, Saatchi divided itself into two competing international groups, Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising, and Backer Spielvogel Bates Worldwide. But critics say Saatchi overspent on its buying spree, took too long to combine acquisitions effectively, and suffers a lack of financial controls. The turning point, analysts say, was the 1986 departure of Martin Sorrell, Saatchi's longtime finance director. Sorrell heads the ad agency group WPP Group PLC, which took over Madison Avenue's venerable J. Walter Thomspon agency in 1987 and Ogilvy & Mather last year. Another Saatchi blunder, analysts say, was to diversify into consulting. ``Maybe if they just stayed to what they knew best they would not have gotten themselves into this situation,'' said Mark Shepperd, an analyst with UBS-Phillips and Drew. Starting in 1984, Saatchi bought eight main consulting businesses for $360 million. But valuable managers at the consulting businesses, whose expertise ranged from executive recruitment to jury selection, began to quit, and Saatchi wasn't winning many cross-referrals. Then, in a 1987 move that smacked to some critics of megalomania, Saatchi made unsuccessful takeover overtures at one of Britain's biggest banks, Midland Bank PLC, and the investment firm Hill Samuel Group PLC. This undermined confidence in Saatchi and left shareholders confused. Last spring, Saatchi first warned that profits would suffer and announced plans to sell most of the consulting firms. So far it's only sold four small ones for $38 million.

DOC.HEAD: Bristol-Myers Squibb Posts Loss Due to Charge
DOC.TEXT: Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. on Wednesday reported a quarterly loss of $352.7 million and a 40 percent drop in its 1989 profit due to a charge to defray the costs of merging the former Bristol-Myers Co. and Squibb Corp. Sales grew 10 percent in the three months ended Dec. 31 and were up 7 percent for all of last year. The company said the fourth-quarter loss, which came to 67 cents a share, compared with earnings of $293 million, or 56 cents a share, in 1988's fourth quarter. Sales rose to $2.36 billion from $2.14 billion. In all of 1989, Bristol-Myers Squibb earned $746.8 million, or $1.43 a share, down sharply from $1.25 billion, or $2.39 a share, in 1988. Last year's sales amounted to $9.19 billion vs. $8.56 billion in 1988. The profit deterioration was foreshadowed in a Jan. 9 announcement of $855 million in pre-tax charges taken in the fourth quarter. A $740 million charge was earmarked to cover the costs of closing factories and eliminating and reassigning employees. An additional $115 million charge was taken for professional fees and other expenses related to the merger. Together, the charges totaled $693 million, or $1.32 a share, after taxes, the company said in releasing its results. Richard L. Gelb, chairman of Bristol-Myers Squibb, said exchange-rate fluctuations had a negative impact on sales of 1 percent in the fourth quarter and 2 percent in the year.

DOC.HEAD: American Express Posts Profit For Quarter, Year
DOC.TEXT: American Express Co. reported Wednesday that its profit for the final quarter of last year jumped 17 percent over a year earlier, while earnings for all of 1989 were up 11 percent. The company attributed the improvement to double-digit gains in the divisions that run its credit card, financial services and information services businesses. Last year the three accounted for around 85 percent of the financial giant's income. Meanwhile, Shearson Lehman Hutton Holdings Inc., which is partially owned by American Express, posted a slender quarterly profit, and American Express Bank saw a decline in earnings. Net income from continuing operations totaled $257 million, or 61 cents a share, in the three months ended Dec. 31, compared with a profit of $221 million, or 52 cents a share, in the 1988 quarter. Revenue rose 9 percent, to $6.3 billion from $5.8 billion. For the year, American Express netted a record $1.2 billion, or $2.70 a share, compared with earnings of $988 million, or $2.31 a share, in 1988. Revenue totaled $25 billion, up 20 percent from $20.9 billion in the previous year. In a statement, Chairman James D. Robinson III said the company ``achieved impressive growth in the 1980s during an era of great change for the customers and markets we serve throughout the world.'' At the Travel Related Services division, which runs the credit card and travelers checks business, quarterly earnings climbed 16 percent to $190 million from $164 million. For the year, it earned a record $830 million, up 17 percent from 1988 income of $710 million. Revenue in 1989 rose 22 percent to $8.4 billion. During the year, credit-card charge volume rose 12.5 percent to a record $100 billion as 19 percent more merchants accepted the card. The company also reported a 12 percent gain in travelers check sales. IDS Financial Services posted a 20 percent jump in quarterly earnings to a record $49 million from $41 million, American Express said. For the year, the division netted $175 million, up 19 percent from $148 million earned in 19888. The company said sales of mutual funds, life insurance and investment certificates led the increase. Information Services Co. had fourth-quarter net income of $27 million, up 40 percent from the $19 million earned the previous year. Net income for the year rose 32 percent to $83 million. The results reflected strong growth in the bankcard processing business and entry into the mutual fund transfer agency business. ISC also expanded its payment systems business through aggressive advertising of its MoneyGram consumer money transfer service. Shearson Lehman, in which American Express recently lowered its stake to less than 50 percent, had fourth-quarter earnings of $3.8 million, compared with a $13 million loss a year earlier. Its after-tax income for 1989 rose 14.6 percent to $110 million, or 95 cents a share, from $96 million, or 81 cents. Revenue rose 19 percent to $12.5 billion from $10.5 billion. Higher commissions, net interest income and revenue from market-making and principal transactions contributed to Shearson's overall income growth. At American Express Bank, quarterly earnings fell to $31 million from $47 millionl. Earnings for the year also declined, to $122 million from $149 million in 1988. The weaker results reflected a decline in net interest income due to a drop in cash collections on loans to Brazil and the impact of the bank's continued effort to reduce exposure to Third World debt, American Express said.

DOC.HEAD: Wang Reports $10.5 million Loss; Expects More Before Situation Improves
DOC.TEXT: Wang Laboratories Inc. on Wednesday reported a loss of $10.5 million for its second fiscal quarter, and the troubled computer company said it expects the red ink to continue for at least six months. The company's loss for the quarter ended Dec. 31, 1989, amounted to 6 cents per share. During the same quarter of 1988, the company reported a profit of $1 million, or 1 cent per share. Revenue for the most recent quarter totaled $637.7 million, compared with $722.2 million for the 1988 quarter. Richard W. Miller, Wang's president and chief operating officer, said that despite the losses, ``the results for the second quarter are in line with our expectations.'' The company, whose financial troubles have spawned management shuffles and a restructuring, anticipated further losses before it could start reporting earnings again, said Miller, who last August replaced Frederick Wang, the founder's son, as head of the company. ``We are taking the necessary and difficult actions to successfully turn the business around,'' Miller said. For the six months ended Dec. 31, 1989, the net loss totaled $72.6 million, or 44 cents a share, compared with earnings of $14.1 million, or 9 cents a share, for six months ended Dec. 31, 1988. For the first six months of the current fiscal year, the company reported revenues of $1.24 billion, compared with $1.4 billion in the comparable 1988 period. Miller also said Wang has reduced the amount of money it owes banks to $308 million from $575 million last August, in part by selling assets. Wang briefly halted payments on the debt in August when it faced a cash crunch. Wang expected to gain $250 million to $300 million more from additional asset sales in the next few months that could help address the company's debt load, Miller said.

DOC.HEAD: Whittle Disputes Reports of Magazine Advertising Slump
DOC.TEXT: Whittle Communications maintains that its doctor's office magazines, Special Reports, are healthy even if some major advertisers are reducing their participation. ``We have more demand than we have supply,'' vice chairman Alan Greenberg said. ``We have not lost one penny of revenue.'' Business Week magazine reported this week that Procter & Gamble, Kraft General Foods and Mott's were cutting back on advertising in Special Reports, a series of six magazines distributed quarterly to 18,500 doctors' waiting rooms. Greenberg said Business Week overestimated losses from the advertisers' cutbacks, which reportedly could reach several million dollars, but he would not release exact figures. ``Yeah, it will be down,'' Greenberg said of revenue from the advertisers. ``But we will turn around and sell the space to someone else. That is how everybody in the media business operates.'' He estimated Whittle will have to sell one-third of the Special Reports' ad space for next fall. Thirteen companies have participated in Special Reports since its launch in September 1988. Eleven have renewed their commitments, said Greenberg, calling it ``a fantastic record.''

DOC.HEAD: Markets In An Around-The-World Slump
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: The upward spiral that carried the stock markets of the world to new highs through much of the 1980s now seems to be threatening to transform itself into a vicious cycle in the other direction. And the catchphrase ``global investing'' suddenly no longer conjures up the heady images it once evoked in the minds of Wall Street brokers and their customers. The new sequence that has unsettled so many investors and business planners played out in typical fashion Wednesday: Share prices in the Tokyo stock market, which has been under intermittent pressure because of rising interest rates in Japan, posted a sharp loss, driving the bellwether Nikkei index of 225 issues down 599.04 points to 36,778.98. As the business day shifted to Europe, stocks also dropped in London in selling attributed both to the decline in Japan and fears of a shaky session in New York. Then, trading began on Wall Street with a burst of selling that seemed preordained by what happened earlier in foreign financial centers. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell about 60 points in early trading, on top of a loss of nearly 195 points over the past three weeks, before staging a partial recovery to finish at 2,604.50, down 10.82 on the day. At the same time, interest rates on U.S. government securities continued their recent rise, which was touched off by tightening monetary conditions abroad. No matter what the Federal Reserve's intentions for the domestic economy, many analysts fear, U.S. interest rates will be forced higher just to stay competitive with higher yields on securities available to investors in the Far East and Europe. That worry was reinforced Tuesday when a government sale of 40-year bonds to finance a rescue plan for troubled thrift institutions drew a very chilly reception from investors. At the extreme, some observers worry, the next noteworthy ``export'' to the United States from Japan could be not a car or a stereo system but a recession aggravated by high borrowing costs. However, a sizeable optimistic contingent in the financial world maintains that events aren't likely to reach that stage. World markets toppled in domino fashion during the crash of 1987, these observers recall, but they started coming back strong within a matter of months, paced by an especially brisk recovery in Japan. This time, some suggest, the U.S. bond market could take a leading role in stabilizing the situation. The more anemic the U.S. economy gets, analysts say, the greater the appeal of Treasury bonds might become, if only because they represent a haven from default risk. ``Only a few weeks ago, interest in U.S. bonds was widespread, based on an exclusive focus on the weak U.S. economy,'' observed Robert Barbera, economist at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. ``We do not expect further bond market deterioration.'' Should American bonds need a boost, furthermore, some analysts still believe they could get it from the Federal Reserve, which might feel compelled to ease credit simply to calm the markets. Said Rao Chalasani, an analyst at the Cleveland-based investment firm of Prescott, Ball & Turben Inc., ``Pronounced weakness in U.S. markets will ultimately cause the Fed to react, since the cost of preservation is lower before things get out of hand.''
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Chet Currier has covered the stock market for The Associated Press since 1974.
