DOC.HEAD: John Lyden: Big Board Specialist in Times of Criticism
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: John Lyden pops a Certs amid the constant din of ringing bells, ripping paper and shouting traders on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange. As a specialist at the Big Board, the nation's largest stock exchange, Lyden's job often requires close contact and rapid-fire discourse. Breath mints are mandatory. But some securities professionals are questioning whether the job of specialist _ the middleman who ensures fair and fluid buying and selling of stocks _ will be necessary in a future dominated by computerized trading. ``They're a horse-and-buggy institution in a jet-propelled world,'' said Robert Sobel, a business history professor at Hofstra University. ``Technology has made them obsolete.'' Bunk, say Lyden and other proponents of the specialist system, which has been in place since after the Civil War. Under the system, specialists receive what amount to lucrative franchises in handling particular stocks in exchange for setting opening prices and keeping trading orderly. Specialists sell from their own inventory when other sellers are scarce and buy when buyers can't be found. Last week, a draft report by an independent congressional agency described the specialist system as ``faltering'' and said the human operation was outmoded by the capabilities of new technology to match buyers and sellers. Academics and Wall Street officials advising the Office of Technology Assessment slammed the report, which questioned fundamental practices in the stock and futures markets, including the role of specialists. Lyden, who has worked on the exchange floor for 30 years, following his father's 42 years, undertook his own defense from the NYSE floor. ``The exchange is the only place in the world where common stocks are traded in the sunlight, totally in the sunlight,'' Lyden, 55, a senior partner in the specialist firm Nick, Lyden & Co., said in an interview. ``We feel if you put all the supply and demand together at one particular time in one particular place you get a fair price,'' he said. ``And by a fair price I mean integrity.'' ``No one will make a trade in a phone booth, no one will make a trade in a closet, no one will make a trade under the Brooklyn Bridge,'' said Lyden, whose firm holds franchises in 28 stocks including Humana Inc. and Shawmut National Bank. With the looks and sincere speech of a B-movie leading man, Lyden is a commanding presence on the floor, and a historical one too. His father, Ken, worked on the exchange floor from age 16 until his death at age 58 in 1965, moving up from gopher to telephone clerk to specialist. He even played on the NYSE's baseball team. After graduating Brown University and New York University's business school, John Lyden joined Irving Trust bank on Wall Street. At his father's funeral, he was asked by one of Ken's younger partners, a pallbearer, to come to the exchange. ``My dad died of a heart attack,'' Lyden said, standing in the middle of the exchange's soaring main room near an idle clerk flicking order cards. ``I never had an inclination to be here...I came into the business at the age of 30 not knowing a buy order from a sell order.'' Lyden said specialists have three roles: to ``make markets'' for individual stocks by pairing buyers and sellers, to generate action in less heavily traded stocks and to trade for their own accounts. More than 400 NYSE specialists at 49 firms make money through commissions for handling trades and by trading stocks for themselves. With soaring volume the last decade, specialists now generate about 75 percent of their income from commissions. But specialists are involved in about 12 percent of NYSE trades. Brokers who take orders at banks of yellow telephones on the floor often trade with other brokers at a stock's post; in those cases specialists serve as traffic cops, making sure the trade is properly recorded. If there is no buyer or seller, the specialist records the order in his ``limit order book'' and awaits a corresponding transaction. Or, the specialist will step in and complete the trade to keep the market active. In a purely electronic system, such as the the National Association of Securities Dealers Automated Quotation system, traders set prices and computer programs match up and execute trades. ``We feel that everybody in the marketplace, whether they're a retail customer or an institutional customer, gets a fair price,'' Lyden said. ``You don't necessarily do that if you're dealing with a black box.'' The current fuss over the specialist system stems in part from the October 1987 stock market crash, when an avalanche of sell orders threatened to put the specialists under. That day, specialists made $485 million in net purchases and the market stayed open. Still, some specialists were reluctant to buy stocks because of uncertainty. Others who spent enormous amounts of borrowed money to buy stocks faced credit crises with their banks. A few went out of business. A Securities and Exchange Commission report on the crash praised the system for helping prevent an even worse disaster. The report said traders of over-the-counter stocks simply didn't pick up the phone that day. Some automated execution systems didn't function. ``Market professionals have long agreed that a market cannot work without negotiation,'' NYSE President Richard A. Grasso said in a cover letter to his sharp critique of the congressional agency draft report, which was sent back to the drawing board because of complaints of shoddy research and unfounded conclusions. ``Full automated trading systems have been doomed to failure.'' Said Lyden: ``You might not like what happaned, that the market was down 508 points, but at least you had a place to liquidate if you wanted out.'' To better ensure that specialists can meet extraordinary volume orders, the NYSE increased capital requirements to the equivalent of 15,000 shares of each stock a firm handles overnight, from 5,000 before the crash. ``He provides a number of really sophisticated functions and (the specialist system) works,'' said Eric K. Clemons, an associate professor at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School. ``Stopping a market correction is not one of them,'' he said. ``If the market is overvalued, there is no power on earth that can stop that.''
DOC.NOTE: End advance for Sunday Jan. 28

DOC.HEAD: Dun & Bradstreet Posts 11.7 Percent Increase in 4th-Qtr Profit
DOC.TEXT: Dun & Bradstreet Corp., which offers an array of information services for businesses, said Wednesday its fourth-quarter profit climbed 11.7 percent on a 2.6 percent rise in revenue. For the year, the company that provides the Nielsen television audience ratings, Moody's Investors Service debt ratings and McCormack & Dodge construction reports said earnings rose 17.5 percent on a 1.3 percent revenue increase. The company said its revenue growth was limited by the absence of revenue from its Official Airlines Guide which was sold in 1988 and a decline in sales at its U.S. credit services division, stung by complaints from some customers that they had been overcharged. The company said it has taken steps in recent months to address problems within the credit services unit. Also limiting revenue growth, the company said, were the strong dollar, competition for marketing research products and adverse market conditions in the debt and construction markets, limiting demand for services in those areas. Dun & Bradstreet said it earned $137.4 million, or 74 cents a share, in the three months ended Dec. 31, up from $123.1 million, or 66 cents a share, a year earlier. Fourth-quarter revenue rose to $1.16 billion from $1.13 billion a year earlier. For the year, the company earned $586.4 million, or $3.14 a share, up from $499 million, or $2.67 a share, a year earlier. Full-year revenue rose to $4.32 billion from $4.27 billion a year earlier. Company officials announced in November that they expected earnings per share would decline to the range of $2.80 in 1990, citing the impact of lower sales at its U.S. credit services and the costs of ``repositioning actions'' in that area. Those actions included increasing the size of the sales force, changing pricing and usage policies and steps to improve the depth and timeliness of information in its database.

DOC.HEAD: Orange Juice Futures Collapse
DOC.TEXT: Orange juice futures prices plummeted Wednesday on the New York Cotton Exchange in a selloff that was sparked by the stock market's weakness and snowballed amid profit-taking. On other commodity markets, livestock and meat futures fell; gold advanced while silver retreated; oil futures were mixed; and grains and soybeans were mixed. Most contracts for future deliveries of frozen concentrated orange juice fell the permitted 5-cents-a-pound daily limit. The March contract, on which the price limit has been expanded to 10 cents due to the market's recent volatility, plunged 9.35 cents to $1.9515 a pound. The March settlement price was more than 10 cents below the record high settlement of $2.0535 scored by the same contract only four days earlier. Wednesday's action marked the sharpest downturn in orange juice futures since a Christmas freeze that heavily damaged the Florida orange crop and triggered a 64 percent rise in futures prices. ``We had really not had a good retracement since the 80 cent runup began,'' said analyst Celeste Georkakis of Cargill Investor Services Inc. ``The market appears to be coming back in line with support levels.'' The slide began at the opening bell, which was delayed one hour by computer problems. Ms. Georkakis said Wednesday's stock market decline probably led to profit-taking in the orange juice market as players sought money to meet margin calls elsewhere. The Dow Jones industrial average fell more than 60 points at the opening of trading but recovered to finish with only a 10-point loss. Most livestock and meat futures fell on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange ahead of the Agriculture Department's quarterly cattle-on-feed report and monthly cold-storage report, both of which were released after the close and interpreted by analysts as bearish for the markets. The cattle report showed a 3 percent increase in the number of cattle on feedlots Jan. 1 compared with the same date a year ago in the 13 largest cattle producing states. The number was within expectations, as was a 10 percent increase in feedlot placements during the last quarter of 1989. But a reported 2 percent drop in marketings was below expectations and is likely to result in a weaker opening Thursday in the April live cattle contract, said Charles Levitt, senior livestock analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. ``This report certainly tells us we're going to get some supply relief as we get into the second quarter,'' he said. The cold-storage report showed 85.2 million pounds of pork bellies in the nation's commercial freezers as of Dec. 31 compared with expectations for about 90 million pounds. Live cattle futures settled .25 cent lower to .05 cent higher with February at 78.70 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .43 cent lower to .08 cent higher with January at 84.50 cents a pound; live hogs were .62 cent lower to .30 cent higher with February at 49.15 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.30 cent to 1.95 cent lower with February at 54.87 cents a pound. Stock-market jitters sent gold futures up sharply for the second straight day on New York's Commodity Exchange but silver succumbed to profit-taking after a recent rally. Gold finished $4 to $5 higher with February at $417.70 a troy ounce; silver was 8.2 cents lower across the board with March at $5.258 a troy ounce. Petroleum futures ended mixed on the New York Mercantile Exchange with prices pressured by Tuesday's weekly American Petroleum Institute report of increased U.S. inventories of gasoline and petroleum distillates. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 3 cents to 10 cents lower with February at $18.89 a barrel; heating oil was .17 cent to .29 cent higher with February at 59.57 cents gallon; unleaded gasoline was .30 cent lower to .40 cent higher with February at 59.38 cents a gallon. Grain and soybean futures settled mostly lower on the Chicago Board of Trade, reflecting slack export demand. Wheat futures finished 1 cent lower to \ cent higher with March at $3.91{ a bushel; corn was \ cent to 1 cent lower with March at $2.40} a bushel; oats were unchanged to 1 cent higher with March at $1.39 a bushel; soybeans were unchanged to 2{ cents lower with March at $5.66 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Move Broadly Lower on Interest Rate Worries
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with closing prices and final advance-decline figures. ^By JOYCE M. ROSENBERG
DOC.TEXT: Interest rate worries took a further toll on the stock market Wednesday, sending prices broadly lower in heavy trading despite bargain hunting and program buying. The Dow Jones industrial average plunged more than 60 points at the opening after traders learned overnight of a sharp decline in the Tokyo stock market _ which itself has been unsettled by rising interest rates in Japan. The Dow Jones average recovered ground as the session wore on and bargain hunters and program traders moved into the market. But the index still closed with a deficit of 10.82, ending at 2,604.50 and extending its slide over the last three weeks to more than 205 points. Declining issues swamped advancers in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 384 rising, 1,207 falling and 399 unchanged. In the early going, losers held a 16 to 1 advantage over gainers. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 207.83 million shares, up from 179.30 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 244.43 million shares. Interest rates remained the stock market's nemesis, analysts said. The drop in the Japanese market intensified fears that rates would have to climb further in this country to stay competitive in the international marketplace, the analysts said. Also troubling Wall Street was the disappointing sale by the government Tuesday of 40-year bonds to finance a rescue plan for troubled thrift institutions. The auction sent market interest rates higher and made investors uneasy about the Treasury's quarterly refunding sale scheduled for next month. ``The short-term direction of interest rates is high and no one knows how high they'll go,'' said Michael Metz, an analyst with Oppenheimer & Co. Meanwhile, as the outlook for interest rates worsened, investors were also facing the possibility that the recent slowdown of the economy might deepen in the months ahead, and some analysts expected further selling. ``You have the same doomsday attitude that accompanied major lows'' on Wall Street in the past, Metz said. Other market watchers found some signs of strength. ``The world didn't end this morning and they had a chance to try to do that,'' said Dennis Jarrett of Kidder Peabody & Co. Jarrett said investors were confused about interest rates and foreign markets, but ``we haven't reached the point where the investor has tossed in the towel.'' At the same time, he said, the market still has room for further declines, adding, ``We haven't reached bottom.'' Among the stocks that recovered from their early losses were AT&T, which closed at 41\, up {; General Electric, which rose { to 63\; and Merck, which picked up } to close at 72|. UAL surged 6 to 161{ on the eve of a board meeting to consider a recapitalization of the parent of United Airlines. Exxon slipped [ to 47 after announcing its fourth-quarter profits fell 40 percent because of a charge related to the Alaska oil spill. Dupont also fell _ closing at 39], down 1[ _ after announcing an earnings drop. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $25.357 billion, or 0.79 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell 0.96 to 182.64. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 1.34 to 379.92, and S&P's 500-stock composite index dropped 1.35 to 330.26. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market fell 4.76 to 425.66. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 354.67, down 5.06.

DOC.HEAD: Chevron Takes $1.2 Billion Fourth-Quarter Charge; Shell Profits Rise
With AM-Earns-Exxon
DOC.TEXT: Chevron Corp. said Wednesday it took a $1.2 billion charge against fourth-quarter earnings primarily because of an inactive oil field and environmental cleanup costs that led to an $883 million quarterly loss. Houston-based Shell Oil Co. attributed a 25 percent fourth-quarter rise in profits to higher crude oil prices. The charge by San Francisco-based Chevron depressed 1989 profits to $251 million, or 73 cents a share, from $1.77 billion, or $5.17 a share, in 1988. The quarterly loss amounted to $2.58 a share, compared with profits of $175 million, or 51 cents a share, in the 1988 period. Chevron said the largest charge for the quarter was a $598 million write-down in the value of several producing and non-producing oil and natural gas properties, including $445 million for the idle Point Arguello field off the Southern California coast. In a sharply worded statement, Chevron Chairman Kenneth T. Derr criticized a series of regulatory obstacles he said have blocked the field's operation for more than two years. ``After enduring a series of adverse rulings from what appears to be an irrational public policy process, I think it is prudent to assign a more realistic value to this project,'' he said. ``It is irresponsible to prohibit production from already developed domestic eneergy reserves at a time when our nation is importing, by tankers, nearly half the oil it needs,'' Derr said. Chevron also said it was charging $325 million against fourth-quarter earnings for future environmental cleanup costs at U.S. refining, marketing and chemicals locations. Other charges were $164 million for adjustments to prior years' income taxes, $63 million for a property write-off and other items associated with a previously announced restructuring, and $53 million for reserves for regulatory and other issues. Chevron's fourth-quarter revenue was $8.9 billion, up from $6.9 billion in 1988. For the full year, revenue rose to $32.8 billion from $28.9 billion the previous year. Chevron cited annual losses of $428 million in U.S. exploration, production, refining and marketing which were offset by $708 million in profits from non-U.S. operations. For the three months ended Dec. 31, Shell reported earnings of $264 million on $5.5 billion in revenue, compared with $212 million in profits on the same revenue in the same 1988 quarter. For all of 1989, Shell had earnings of $1.4 billion, up from $1.2 billion the previous year, on revenue of $21.9 billion, compared with $21.4 billion in 1988. Shell does not report per-share figures because it is wholly owned by the Royal Dutch-Shell Group, which is based in London and the Hague, Netherlands. Shell attributed the increases to higher crude prices, which benefited oil and gas exploration and production earnings. Shell's chemical products performed well, but its oil products slumped because prices did not recover the increased cost of oil. Oil and gas exploration and production showed profits of $144 million for the quarter, up from $51 million in the same 1988 period. Full-year earnings were $546 million, up from $326 million.

DOC.HEAD: Clausen Reported Stepping Down From BofA
DOC.TEXT: BankAmerica Corp. Chairman A.W. ``Tom'' Clausen reportedly is stepping down from the nation's fourth-largest banking concern, following a turnaround that moved the company from financial turmoil to record profits. The San Francisco Examiner said the 66-year-old Clausen's retirement and his successor would be announced before the bank's annual meeting on May 24. BankAmerica spokesman Peter Magnani declined comment Wednesday about the report, which was attributed to unidentified bank sources. Under Clausen, BankAmerica rebounded from three years of huge financial losses with a restructuring that saw thousands of employees laid off, its headquarters building and other major assets sold and its business refocused. It also thwarted unwanted takeover overtures from rival First Interstate Bancorp in an often-bitter struggle to remain independent. ``The bank has made a tremendous recovery of health...'' said Dan Williams, a bank analyst with Sutro and Co. of San Francisco. ``It may be that he (Clausen) figures the time to go out ... is when you're on top.'' Clausen, son of a small newspaper publisher from Hamilton, Ill., joined BankAmerica as a $185-a-week clerk counting cash in a vault in 1949 after he was graduated from the University of Minnesota Law School. Clausen worked his way up to chief executive by 1970 and during his tenure BankAmerica quadrupled in size. He left in 1981 to become president of the World Bank in Washington. San Francisco-based BankAmerica, the holding company for Bank of America, suffered three years of huge losses starting in 1985. Much of its problems were blamed on losses from bad loans to developing nations and on real estate and farm loans in the United States. In 1986, it eliminated its common stock dividend for the first time since the Depression. BankAmerica, once the largest banking concern in the country, fell behind other giants such as Citicorp and Chase Manhattan Corp. on the basis of assets. Some banking experts blamed much of BankAmerica's problems on Clausen, contending he contributed to many of its difficulties before leaving in 1981 with such moves as decentralization of its lending operations. But Clausen claimed the bank had lost the confidence of customers, its board, staff and shareholders because of ``over-promising and under-performing'' management, of which he was not a part. Clausen returned as chairman in 1986, replacing ousted ``boy wonder,'' Samuel Armacost, who had earned the nickname ``Clausen's clone.'' Under Armacost, BankAmerica was rocked by almost $6 billion in loan losses and the battle with First Interstate. ``If we are given the time, we will return our bank to its position of preeminence,'' Clausen pledged on his return. ``The restructuring program ... will work. I am absolutely confident about our strategy.'' BankAmerica sold assets, including its world headquarters in San Francisco for $660 million and its Charles Schwab discount brokerage subsidiary. It cut expenses, laid off 9,000 employees and expanded hours while experiencing strong growth in domestic consumer and residential mortgage loans. Last February, Bank of America restored its common stock dividend. Last week, the company reported 1989 earnings were up 52 percent from a year earlier to $1.1 billion, the biggest annual profit in its 86-year-history. It currently ranks fourth among bank holding companies with $82.9 billion in assets. Candidates seen as likely to succeed Clausen include Richard Rosenberg, 59, vice chairman of the board of BankAmerica Corp., or Frank Newman, 47, vice chairman and chief financial officer for BankAmerica. Both worked previously for Wells Fargo & Co. Rosenberg was with Wells for 22 years, leaving a job there as vice chairman. He also worked as vice chairman for Crocker Bank and was chief operating officer of Seafirst Corp. Newman spent 13 years with Wells Fargo, working as executive vice president and chief financial officer before coming to BankAmerica.

DOC.HEAD: Taking A Second Look At The 1980s
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 4-5, `Moreover, he ... a year' with two grafs to DELETE quote and conflicting GNP growth rate of 0.8 percent in '80s; picks up 6th graf, Many people ...
DOC.TEXT: Sometimes you have to take a second look at some deeply embedded impressions. In the 1980s the economy grew for seven straight years, longest peacetime advance ever. But: ``During the 1980s, U.S. real gross national product has grown at an annual rate of 2.6 percent, the slowest rate of growth for any decade since the 1930s,'' according to John Winthrop Wright of Wright Investors Service. Even the oft-maligned 1970s, the decade that gave rise to the term stagflation, managed a better annual real GNP growth rate of 2.8 percent, Wright said in his 19th annual review and forecast to the New York Society of Security Analysts in December. You have to go back to the Depression-era 1930s to find a lower growth rate _ a meager 0.1 percent a year, he said. Many people in the 1980s held strongly to another impression _ that taxes really had been cut, in part because President Reagan stood for lower taxes and, in fact, helped engineer a big tax cut early in his first term. But: ``We are no better off than in 1981, despite strong economic growth and much ballyhooed cuts in income tax rates,'' according to the Tax Foundation. The foundation hasn't yet determined when Tax Freedom Day will occur this year, but because of higher Social Security taxes it probably will be later than in 1989, when it occurred on May 4, and 1988, when it fell on May 3. Tax Freedom Day, it says, is the theoretical date on which Americans finish working to support federal, state and local entities and begin earning money for themselves. Conceivably, it might even be later this year than in 1980. It attributes the standoff to three main factors: 1. The base-broadening provisions in the Tax Reform Act of 1986 and other legislation that subjected a greater percentage of income to taxation. 2. Social Security taxes that increased faster than the overall economy. 3. State and local taxes that continued to rise, partly in reaction to reductions in federal aid programs. Another major misimpression concerns the amounts of money available for spending by choice _ rather than necessity. During the 1980s, discretionary income _ the amount of income left after paying for taxes and normal household expenditures _ rose sharply. Such income totaled nearly $320 billion in a Census Bureau survey in March 1987, or 22 percent more than in the previous report four years earlier. Moreover, an analysis issued by the Commerce Department and the Conference Board in 1989 showed that 30 percent of U.S. households now have income beyond that needed for a comfortable living. But, according to that report, it took a major effort by two breadwinners rather than just one. In their analysis they observed that ``households with two or more people earning a paycheck account for 65 percent of all U.S. discretionary dollars. Most of this income is in families where both husband and wife are working.'' In addition, the discretionary income was shown to be geographically skewed. In announcing its findings, the board, a nonprofit research organization, stated: ``A well-above-average 34 percent of all homes in the New England states have discretionary income. The incidence also runs relatively high in the Pacific and South Atlantic regions. ``In the Mountain, Middle Atlantic and East South Central states, the prevalence of discretionary income homes tends to be below the national average.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PMs Wednesday, Jan. 24.

DOC.HEAD: IBM, Minnesota Supercomputer Center Announce Partnership
DOC.TEXT: The Minnesota Supercomputer Center said Tuesday it will install International Business Machine Corp.'s most powerful computer as part of a $55 million partnership expected to influence design of the next generation of IBM supercomputers. Using an IBM 3090 supercomputer with 12 interconnected processing units and with a memory capacity of more than five billion characters of information, the supercomputer center will explore new ways to connect even more advanced supercomputers, the center and IBM said in a joint statement. IBM is funding about half the cost of the project, according to the statement. ``Our partnership with IBM brings us the new capacity and challenge we need to maintain MSC as a world-class facility,'' said John M. Sell, chief operating officer and president of the Minnesota Supercomputer Center. Under the agreement, the supercomputer center will join IBM as a development partner and will use IBM supercomputing equipment in projects the center manages for its scientific and engineering customers. Sell said engineers at the center will be devising software with applications for all sorts of industries. Also, the center will join the IBM Information Network and will provide AIX services to IBM customers who use the network, according to the statement. AIX is an operating system designed to make supercomputers, advanced workstations and other data processing equipment operate in an environment that can handle numbers of users who want to perform many computing tasks simultaneously. The Minnesota Supercomputer Center is a private corporation owned jointly by the University of Minnesota and the University of Minnesota Foundation.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Futures End Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices ended mixed Wednesday on the New York Mercantile Exchange after falling at the opening in response to an industry report that showed an increase in oil inventories. The March contract for West Texas Intermediate, the main grade of U.S. crude oil, slipped a penny to $21.59 a barrel, after a 17-cent drop on Tuesday. Other contract months also declined. Among refined products traded on the New York Merc, regular unleaded gasoline for February delivery lost 0.24 cent to 59.38 cents a gallon, while other contract months were mixed. February heating oil gained 0.29 cent to close at 59.57 cents a gallon while the contract for March delivery rose 0.29 cent to 57.36 cents a gallon. Contracts for later delivery declined. Analysts said prices moved lower at the opening in response to an industry report that showed a buildup in petroleum supplies in the nation's storage tanks. The report by the American Petroleum Institute, a trade association representing mainly large oil refineries, said that heating oil and gasoline stocks rose last week, while crude oil supplies declined. Prices rebounded in the afternoon as large refiners moved into the market. Larry Lawrence, manager of options and technical analysis for Elders Futures Inc., said refiners who hedged against declining refinery margins by buying crude and selling products did the reverse _ bought products and sold crude. ``That spurred buying in products and firmed us,'' Lawrence said.

DOC.HEAD: Coke, Disney Sign 15-Year Extension of Marketing Contract
DOC.TEXT: Mickey Mouse and his buddies have taken sides in the cola wars, and they'll be sipping Coca-Cola for at least the next 15 years. The Coca-Cola Co. and The Walt Disney Co. on Wednesday signed a 15-year marketing agreement, extending an association that dates to 1942. The deal calls for Coke products to be available exclusively in all Disney theme parks. Coca-Cola also will have the right of first negotiations for joint promotional programs with Disney movies and exclusive rights to use certain Disney characters in advertising and consumer promotions. Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed. ``This new agreement continues the partnership of two of the world's greatest brand names,'' said Coke President Donald R. Keough. ``Coca-Cola and Disney share a passion for serving consumers and always providing a reflection of the bright side of life.'' Disney President Frank G. Wells said his company was ``extremely pleased to renew and enlarge a relationship that has been mutually beneficial over the past half century.'' Coca-Cola and Disney first joined forces when Coke's Sunday afternoon radio show in December 1942 presented a program featuring music from the Disney movie ``Saludos Amigos.'' Coke was a sponsor of Disney's first television show in 1950.

DOC.HEAD: SEC Chief Calls for Removing Some Legal and Regulatory Barriers
DOC.TEXT: The nation's top securities regulator Wednesday called on Congress to remove legal and regulatory barriers so the United States could meet increasing competition in world financial markets. Securities and Exchange Commission Chairman Richard C. Breeden said the strength of Japan as a financial center and the removal of European trade barriers in 1992 would give U.S. capital markets their first real challenge. Breeden, just back from three days of meetings in Japan, said securities professionals there told him the United States is regarded as ``the source of innovation and creativity in financial products.'' ``We have to recognize that here at home and get rid of some of the legal and regulatory barriers,'' Breeden said at a meeting of the Securities Regulation Institute. Breeden said the European Economic Community's single market would mean standardized disclosure and takeover rules for companies and no barriers to banks engaging in the securities business, as in the United States. Among other steps, Breeden called on Congress to remove barriers to stock market trading of ``hybrid'' securities that have elements of futures. A federal court recently banned trading of a stock-index future on the Philadelphia and American stock exchange because of restrictions limiting such products to commodities exchanges. ``If you can find one smidgen of futurity ... then that product becomes unlawful'' on stock exchanges, Breeden said. ``that sets up the prospect that all products will have to go to the courthouse before going to investors.'' Similar securities are available to investors on the London and Toronto stock exchanges, he said. Breeden also said the United States should eliminate barriers under the Glass-Steagall Act to allow banks to enter the securities business, make takeover laws parallel in all states and remove barriers to interstate banking. Breeden also supported lowering barriers to foreign investment to make it harder for other countries to keep out U.S. investors and companies. Along those lines, he said Japanese officials indicated they would allow foreign mutual funds into their country's $500 billion investment trust business, now limited to 14 Japanese companies. ``We believe the U.S. mutual funds are the finest in the world,'' Breeden told reporters. ``We would like to see them in Japanese markets, particularly the retail markets.'' At a separate session, former SEC Chairman David S. Ruder challenged the commission to become more active and far-sighted in pushing for laws reforming the securities industry. Ruder, who presided over the SEC during two tumultuous years that included the October 1987 stock market crash and Wall Street's insider trading scandals, called for a major study of securities industry reforms such as one undertaken in 1962. ``There should be a study not only of volatility, but of little-known problems in the industry ... and we need to assess whether the crazy-quilt regulation we have in the U.S. over the banking and securities industries is the right one,'' Ruder said. But Breeden said there is too little time to undertake such a study, which he said would take years. ``I'd like to see Congress and the administration get on with the task of reforming the securities market,'' he said. Congress this session is considering a series of bills on market reform, including the possibility of placing responsibility for regulating the nation's stock and futures markets under one body. Ruder said he believes Congress would be forced to re-evaluate scrapping the Glass-Steagall Act to allow banks to underwrite securities. ``Our financial institutions are going to be at a severe competitive disadvantage in the world if they cannot engage in banking and securities transactions at the same time,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: GE Aerospace To Cut 14 Percent Of Work Force
DOC.TEXT: GE Aerospace plans to cut nearly 14 percent of its work force, eliminating more than 5,700 jobs over the next two years, as expectations of reduced Pentagon spending continue to grip the defense industry. About 5,600 of the job cuts will be in the eastern part of the country, a spokesman said Wednesday. The reductions are part of a program begun early last year aimed at trimming a total of 10,000 from the payrolls. In 1989 GE Aerospace, a division of General Electric Co., trimmed 4,775 from its work force. About 4,000 positions will be eliminated this year, with the remaining 1,600 jobs to be cut in 1991, spokesman Don Norton said. The company said no specific decisions have been made on where or when the remaining reductions will be made. The decisions will be made as business conditions develop, it said. GE Aerospace, the nation's third-largest defense contractor, is based in King of Prussia, Pa. Norton said the cutbacks will come through layoffs and attrition throughout the division, which has more than a dozen plants, mostly in the Northeast. By January 1992, the aerospace unit will be left with 35,500 employees, down from 47,000 in January 1988. At latest count, the division employed 41,108. On Tuesday, General Electric reported a 16 percent increase in profits in the fourth quarter of 1989. The parent earned $1.17 billion, or $1.30 a share, up from $1.01 billion, or $1.12 a share. The nation's defense spending has been stagnant, in real terms, for the last few years amid public concern over the federal budget deficit, misconduct by defense contractors and the changing political climate in Eastern Europe. In addition to declining U.S. expenditures for defense, the cutbacks are a ``matter of staying competitive'' in a much tougher business climate, Norton said. Earlier this month, Seattle-based Boeing Co. said it expects to cut 5,000 workers this year. The aerospace giant said the move was made partly because of warmer East-West relations that have dimmed the outlook for its defense business. Company officials said further layoffs were possible. Also in January, the Martin-Marietta Astronautics Group announced plans to cut about 200 jobs by the end of next month. The company said some of the jobs would be transferred to other businesses. Last year, GE Aerospace's aircraft-electronics unit based in Utica, N.Y., was hit heavily with cutbacks. Employment held fairly steady at the astro-space operation in East Windsor, N.J., and at the King of Prussia plant, which makes satellites. Jobs at Moorestown, N.J., where the Aegis radar system for the Navy is made, increased slightly. About half of the 4,775 jobs cut by GE Aerospace last year were in units sold by the company, including the 1,000-employee instrument-products operation in Wilmington, Mass., which was sold to Ametek Inc. of Paoli, Pa. GE Aerospace has no plans to sell any other units, Norton said. The aerospace unit also includes plants in King of Prussia and Philadelphia in Pennsylvania; Camden, Moorestown and East Windsor, N.J.; Binghamton and Syracuse, N.Y.; Pittsfield and Burlington, Mass.; Huntsville, Ala.; Largo and Daytona Beach, Fla.; and Burlington, Vt.

DOC.HEAD: Du Pont Probes Explosion at Chambers Works Plant
DOC.TEXT: An explosion at Du Pont's Chambers Works chemical plant sparked a fire at the site Wednesday, but no serious injuries were reported, officials said. The explosion rocked the middle of the plant in Salem County, N.J., around 1:36 p.m. EST, said Kelli Kukura, a plant spokeswoman. Thirteen workers were treated at an on-site medical center and released, she said. The explosion generated a thick cloud of smoke, but the blaze was extinguished around 3 p.m., said Jeanine Mosley, a spokeswoman for the state Department of Environmental Protection. The department dispatched two hazardous response units to the scene as a precautionary measure, Ms. Mosley said. Authorities said they did not know what caused the explosion. Ms. Kukura said Du Pont officials were still assessing damage to the plant. The explosion occurred after the lid of a 11,000-gallon sulfuric acid tank blew off, according to Ms. Mosley. Sulfuric acid is used to manufacture Kevlar, used in bullet proof vests and Nomex, used in protective clothing for firefighters, Ms. Kukura said. Ms. Mosley said the smoke was confined to the local area and there were no evacuations. She said officials in Salem, N.J., told residents to remain indoors when the fire broke out. The plant is located several miles north of the Delaware Memorial Bridge in Deepwater. A spokeswoman for the Delaware River and Bay Authority said bridge traffic was not affected by the explosion. Du Pont took air samples within an 8-mile radius as a precaution, according to Ms. Mosley. She said preliminary results did not detect any release of toxins. The Department of Environmental Protection has not issued any violations against Du Pont, Ms. Mosely said. She said the agency is still investigating the incident. Chambers Works is Du Pont's largest chemical facility. About 3,600 employees work at the plant.

DOC.HEAD: Call for Boost in Utility Conservation Spending
DOC.TEXT: A group that includes four big California utilities unveiled an energy conservation plan Wednesday aimed at saving hundreds of millions of dollars a year by paying people to buy more efficient homes and appliances and allowing stockholders to benefit from energy savings. The plan by a coalition of businesses, consumer advocates and environmentalists is intended to save fuel, clean the air and, ultimately, lower costs for consumers. ``By offering customers more incentives to use energy more efficiently, we can help them reduce their energy costs, and we can avoid or postpone having to build new power plants,'' said Virgil Rose, a vice president of Pacific Gas & Electric Co., one of four major utilities taking part in the plan. ``Utilities would be paying people to use less of their product,'' observed Ralph Cavanagh of the Natural Resources Defense Council. The plan calls for giving money to builders to encourage construction of homes and offices with better insulation and energy-saving heating and cooling systems; giving rebates to customers for buying energy-saving appliances; and financing free or low-cost home improvements for low-income and elderly residents. There was little incentive for utilities to make those investments in the late 1980s. With fuel supplies abundant and oil and gas prices dropping, utility conservation programs dropped sharply. Spending at PG&E dropped from $138 million in 1985 to $81 million in 1988, and at San Diego Gas & Electric Co. from $17.8 million in 1983 to $2.9 million in 1989. The result has been increased home energy use, more pollution and a greater depletion of resources. The new plan, set in motion by the state Public Utilities Commission last July, will be defined more fully in March when the four utilities _ PG&E, SDG&E, Southern California Edison and Southern California Gas _ submit formal proposals to the commission. Although elements of the plan have been used elsewhere in the country, the size of the four utilities give their effort added importance. PG&E and Southern California Edison are the nation's two largest utilities in terms of sales. The four utilities together serve at least three quarters of California's population, Cavanagh said. Others joining in the conservation plan included groups of developers, small power producers, water agencies, the PUC's consumer staff and the consumer group Toward Utility Rate Normalization. The 82-page proposal calls for $263.8 million in conservation spending by the four utilities this year and $300 million in 1991. Those are no higher than mid-1980s spending levels, taking inflation into account, but they are substantial increases over the totals of $153 million in 1988 and $171.3 million in 1989. The report said utilities should have fuel savings worth at least twice the added investment cost. The utilities primarily burn domestically produced oil and gas. In addition, the report said similar programs in other states have estimated the benefits from environmental improvement as being worth 15 percent to 25 percent of the value of fuel savings. Customers, though initially paying higher rates to subsidize the programs, should get most of the savings through lower utility bills in the long run, the report said. The major incentive for utilities, however, is that some of the savings would go to stockholders. Under PG&E's proposal, for example, 30 percent of the estimated fuel savings from most of programs and 5 percent of the costs of low-income assistance would be given to stockholders. ``The possibility of increased earnings can encourage utility management to search actively for new energy-efficiency opportunities and to implement the programs effectively,'' the report said, summarizing the views of those who favor incentives. The report also quoted opponents as saying the incentives were unnecessary, would increase rates and were no substitute for PUC regulation. Half or more of all spending would be on incentives for energy-efficient new buildings. Utilities also are proposing a variety of individual programs. PG&E wants to offer customers rebates of $50 and $100 for buying refrigerators that exceed federal efficiency standards by 10 or 15 percent; Edison is proposing a design competition with $2,500 prizes for energy-efficient buildings. Publicly owned utilities like the Sacramento Municipal Utility District are not covered by the plan, but the state Energy Commission said it would pursue conservation policies with them as well.

DOC.HEAD: Great Northern Income Down 39 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Great Northern Nekoosa Corp., the target of a hostile takeover offer, reported a 39 percent drop in net income in the fourth quarter partly because of the cost of fending off the bid. Net income was $52 million, or 92 cents a share, compared to $85.8 million, or $1.56 a share, in the last quarter of 1988, Great Northern said Tuesday. The Norwalk-based paper company said its earnings per share were reduced by 33 cents because of the $3.8 billion offer made late last year by Georgia-Pacific Corp., a forest products company in Atlanta. Great Northern is fighting Georgia-Pacific using anti-takeover provisions in its bylaws and an antitrust suit in Connecticut. Chairman William R. Laidig also attributed the decline to a general downturn in the paper industry due to overcapacity. ``Business conditions changed around mid-year, when increasing paper capacity began to affect the supply-demand balance in many of our markets,'' he said. ``Generally, prices for most of our products had been relatively stable the first half of the year, but weakened modestly in the third quarter and continued to weaken in the fourth.'' Great Northern said fourth-quarter sales fell 1 percent to $934 million from $944.1 million a year earlier. Shipments of pulp, paper and containerboard from the company's mills fell 27.7 percent in the fourth quarter because of harsh weather at the company's southern mills. Net income for the year fell 6 percent to $321 million, or $5.78 a share, from $341.7 million, or $6.21 a share in 1988. Sales rose 8 percent to $3.9 billion from $3.6 billion in 1988. ``The outlook is a tough call because most of our markets are becoming more competitive,'' Laidig said. ``Our performance in 1990 will depend on the strength of the U.S. economy and the growth in demand for our products.''

DOC.HEAD: Mexico Removed From Priority Watch List
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with Hills removing Mexico from list. Also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Mexico will be removed from a list of countries accused of failing to provide adequate safeguards for intellectual property rights, U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills said Wednesday. The Mexican government has announced it will send its congress a package of proposed changes to improve the protection of patents and copyrights for companies doing business in Mexico. That follows action taken by the government earlier this month to draft new regulations aimed at reforming the country's licensing and patent system. ``The Mexican government has demonstrated its firm belief in the need to protect intellectual property rights,'' Hills said in a statement announcing the action. ``I want to encourage these developments and work toward a partnership across the Rio Grande that will provide a solid foundation for economic growth and expansion.'' Earlier, Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher called Mexico's actions a ``very important step. The last big block to the forward movement of investment in Mexico has been removed.'' In May, Hills put Mexico and seven other nations on a priority watch list, saying the administration believed they were the worst offenders in failing to provide adequate protection of intellectual property rights. Negotiations, under a section of U.S. trade law known as Special 301, have been conducted with all eight nations in an effort to improve patent and copyright protections. The eight countries on the original list were Mexico, Brazil, China, India, Saudi Arabia, South Korea, Taiwan and Thailand. Taiwan, Korea and Saudi Arabia were moved to a secondary watch list in November because of progress in negotiations, but Mexico is the first country to be removed.

DOC.HEAD: UAL Unions Propose Buying 75 Percent Of Stock
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf pvs, `UAL's board,' with 11 grafs to UPDATE with Coniston backing off from recapitalization, comment from analyst; Pickup 4th graf pvs, `In return.'
DOC.TEXT: UAL Corp.'s three employee unions on Wednesday proposed the acquisition of 75 percent of the airline company's stock by all employees, leaving the remaining 25 percent in the public's hands. In a letter to the company's board of directors, United Airline's pilots, flight attendants and Machinists said they were prepared to negotiate as a group for the acquisition of stock through one or more employee stock ownership plans, or ESOPs. The employees offered wage concessions and long-term contracts in return. ``We are unified as never before in our view that majority ownership of the company is the only acceptable means to resolve the issues that plague United,'' the letter concluded. UAL's board of directors is scheduled to meet Thursday and had been planning to consider a recapitalization urged on the Chicago-based company by one of its largest shareholders, the Coniston Partners investment group, holder of an 11.8 percent stake. But Keith Gollust, one of Coniston's principals, said late Wednesday that he and his partners were ``really pleased'' at the new development and were backing away from their insistence on a recapitalization to boost the value of UAL shares. ``We have always favored an employee buyout as an alternative,'' Gollust said in a telephone interview from his New York office. ``We think this is a great step forward.'' Gollust said a recapitalization, which likely would involve new borrowing by UAL to make a payout to shareholders, ``ought to remain as a backup alternative.'' Joe Hopkins, spokesman for UAL, the parent company of United, declined comment on the ESOP proposal. An ESOP typically buys stock with borrowed money and pays it back over a number of years with dividends on the shares. The UAL employees' letter offered no specifics on how they plan to finance their proposed purchase of 17 million of UAL's 22.6 million shares, which would cost about $2.7 billion at Wednesday's closing stock price of $161.50. Officials of the three unions did not return phone calls. Airlines analyst Samuel Buttrick of Kidder Peabody & Co. said the apparent harmony among UAL's unions and their willingness to take paycuts were a positive sign, ``but the notable lack of specifics on structure and financing indicates that only minimal progess has been made on an ultimate resolution.'' In return for a majority stake in the company, the employees said they were prepared to make ``significant investments,'' including an acceptance of lower wages, under 5-year contracts. The investments, including the contributions of non-union employees, would total about $300 million in the first year and $2 billion over the life of the contracts, the union group said. The letter did not describe the proposed investments or specify how the unions proposed to divide the stock among UAL's four employee groups. ``Our objective is to form a unique partnership among the company and all employees that will permit the company to immediately return to the position of the world's best airline _ and to grow and prosper into the future,'' read the letter. The letter was signed by John Peterpaul, vice president of the Machinists union; Frederick C. Dubinsky, chairman of the United chapter of the Air Line Pilots Association; and Diana Robertson, president of the United chapter of the Association of Flight Attendants. UAL's stock climbed $6 to close at $161.50 Wednesday in New York Stock Exchange trading. UAL directors are under pressure from Coniston Partners, a New York-based investment group with 11.8 percent of UAL's stock, to quickly approve a transaction that will boost shareholder value. Coniston urged UAL's directors to explore a recapitalization after management and the pilots failed to pull together a buyout offer by Jan. 8, the date of the last board meeting. At that meeting, the board directed its financial adviser, First Boston Corp., to explore the merits of a recapitalization and come up with a proposal for Thursday's meeting. But the board also said it reamined open to buyout proposals. Both the pilots and the United chapter of the Association of Flight Attendants have expressed strong opposition to any recapitalization that would increase the indebtedness of the nation's second-largest airline and allow for anything less than majority ownership of the company by its workers. The Machinists opposed a previous buyout attempt led by UAL's management and pilots, which caused lenders to balk and the $6.75 billion buyout bid to fail on Oct. 13. The UAL buyout saga began last August when Los Angeles billionaire Marvin Davis made an unsolicited offer of $200 a share, or $4.32 billion, for the company. The failed pilot-management bid was for $300 a share.
